description: THE New Zealand wine industry came out of nowhere in the 1980's, producing a flock of pungent, razor sharp sauvignon blancs that many people found irresistible. But the sauvignon blanc is a grape of vast likability and dubious glamour, and the New Zealanders preferred talking about the great pinot noirs that were coming rather than the fine sauvignon blancs that were already here.

title: National Briefing | South: Georgia: Parole For Mother Who Killed Dying Sons
description: The state Board of Pardons and Paroles has granted parole to a Spalding County woman who shot her two terminally ill sons to death in June 2002. The woman, Carol Carr, 65, pleaded guilty to assisted suicide in the deaths of her sons Michael R. Scott, 42, and Andy B. Scott, 41, who were in the advanced stages of Huntington's disease, and was sentenced to five years in prison. Ms. Carr will be released in March, after serving one month more than the minimum possible. A condition of her parole is that she not live with or become responsible for the care of her surviving son, James Scott, who also has the disease. Ariel Hart (NYT)

title: 7 Skating Again in 'Miracle'
description: The number of college hockey players majoring in theater is not a readily available statistic, but a number of them showed up last October at an open casting call in Vancouver, British Columbia, where work on the movie ''Miracle'' was beginning. ''Miracle,'' which opens Friday, tells the story of the United States team, which was made up mostly of college players, that upset the Soviet Union en route to the Olympic gold medal in 1980.

title: Southern Cal and L.S.U. Still Vying for Top Spot
description: So far, the college football recruiting season has looked a lot like the football season itself. The battle for superiority has come down to Louisiana State and Southern California, with some people not sure which deserves the mythical title for having landed the best high school seniors. At the least, each team can say it has laid the groundwork for successful teams for years to come.

title: Knight Insists He Didn't Start Latest Incident
description: Texas Tech said Tuesday that it had reprimanded Coach Bob Knight in connection with a heated encounter he had Monday with the university's chancellor, David Smith. But calling the incident a misunderstanding, the university said it would not suspend Knight.

title: World Briefing | United Nations: Palestinian Criticizes Israeli Envoy
description: Nasser al-Kidwa, head of the Palestinian observer mission, criticized the Israeli ambassador, Dan Gillerman, for having accused Secretary General Kofi Annan of showing bias against Israel in his response to the suicide bombing in Jerusalem on Thursday that killed 10 and wounded 50. Mr. Gillerman had faulted Mr. Annan for making ''vague references'' to terror and violence instead of singling out the bombing for condemnation. Mr. Kidwa said the comments represented ''Israel's traditionally negative campaign against the U.N. and its typical tactics of intimidation in regards to actions by this world body.'' Mr. Kidwa said the Palestinian leadership had never complained to the secretary general directly about his condemnations of suicide bombings but had conveyed its concerns over the Secretariat's failure to express ''similar outrage to Israeli military assaults against the Palestinian civilian population.'' Warren Hoge (NYT)

description: The Elan Corporation, the drug maker, said that antegren, a treatment for autoimmune disorders that it was developing in partnership with Biogen Idec, would begin trials for rheumatoid arthritis in the first half of this year. The drug, which works by preventing selected immune cells from moving into tissue where they cause inflammation, completed the final stage of human trials for Crohn's disease last week, and is in the final stage of testing for multiple sclerosis. title: National Briefing | Southwest: Texas: Racial Profiling Found
description: Racial profiling of motorists by the police persists across Texas despite laws and regulations intended to discourage it, a report commissioned by human rights and civil liberties groups said. A survey of law enforcement records from a fourth of Texas's 1,500 police agencies found that blacks and Hispanics were significantly more likely to be stopped and searched than whites. The report said the police in Houston and in Dallas were three and a half times more likely to search a black driver than a white one. Steve Barnes (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Good Technology Revamps Messaging Software
description: Good Technology introduced an update to its software yesterday that aims to make cellphones more like laptop computers. Executives at a gathering in San Francisco showed off some of the new features in the company's GoodLink 3.0 messaging software, which include the ability to easily perform more than one task at a time, to view PC files in their native format and to preview incoming e-mail in ways similar to Microsoft's Outlook application. Good also announced that it would add support for Windows Mobile-based devices, including hand-helds based on the Pocket PC operating system. GoodLink already works on RIM devices as well as on palmOne's Treo 600. While the company, based in Sunnyvale, Calif., has been making inroads in the hand-held software and service market, RIM remains the leader, having signed more than one million customers for its wireless messaging service. The GoodLink event drew several top executives, like Palm's co-founder, Jeff Hawkins, and executives from Electronic Arts, Dell and Microsoft.

title: Insanity Issue Lingers as Texas Execution Is Set
description: In one of the more extraordinary cases in the nation's leading death penalty state, a murder defendant with a long history of mental illness who fired his lawyers and argued his own insanity defense in a cowboy outfit is scheduled to be executed on Thursday.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Ciena Posts Higher-Than-Expected Loss
description: The Ciena Corporation, the nation's fourth-largest maker of fiber optic equipment, said yesterday that it had a first-quarter net loss of 17 cents to 18 cents a share, mainly because of the timing of an order. Ciena's loss for the quarter excluding items such as the order was 8 cents to 10 cents a share, in line with its previous estimates, said the company, which is based in Linthicum, Md. ''Although we have delivered the equipment to fulfill this order and the customer is pleased with its performance, it has taken longer than we anticipated to work through the formalities and processes associated with revenue recognition,'' the chief executive officer, Gary B. Smith, said. Revenue was about $66.4 million for the quarter that ended Jan. 31, Ciena said. Shares fell $1, or 14 percent, to $6.29 in after-hours trading. In regular trading, shares fell 5 cents, to $7.29.

title: Red Lobster Ponders Change in Agency
description: Red Lobster, part of Darden Restaurants, is considering changing the agency handling the creative part of its account as part of its efforts to try reversing a sharp decline in sales. Billings are estimated at $80 million to $100 million.

title: Escape From Sing Sing: How Plans Failed
description: It seemed like the perfect breakout plan: armed with fake guard uniforms, two handguns and a dog-eared copy of an acclaimed book about life as a prison guard at Sing Sing, two convicted violent felons would walk out of prison. They had friends on the outside willing to smuggle in supplies, and an ally on the inside, a prison guard, who gave them crucial logistical information about the inner workings of Sing Sing.

title: Keep the Primaries Going
description: Now that John Kerry has scored such a strong showing in yesterday's primaries, party leaders are going to become less than subtle in their hints that everyone else call it a day. But a few more weeks of campaigning for the nomination would give Senator Kerry useful preparation for the rigors of the race against George Bush. And Democrats will be able to watch his progress far more comfortably if they know there are still other options available.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES

More than 30 chocolate desserts and confections, including bananas Foster chocolate pudding, chocolate ganache pyramid, white chocolate mousse cake, peanut crunch-almond dacquoise and the most silken chocolate marshmallows imaginable will be available starting Friday, and continuing every Friday and Saturday from 8 p.m. to midnight throughout the month. The other sees them as an opportunity to test and promote candidates, hone their message and get voters excited about the coming fight.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Man Pleads Guilty To Child Rape
description: A Queens man pleaded guilty yesterday to impregnating a 9-year-old Brooklyn girl, the daughter of his girlfriend at the time, the Queens district attorney, Richard A. Brown, said. The man, Chancellor Drayton, a 43-year-old street vendor from Astoria, was arrested on Nov. 5, 2002, and was initially indicted on a charge of first-degree rape. The police said he had had sexual relations with the girl repeatedly while the mother was running errands. The girl's mother, after reading incriminating notes, contacted the police, and the girl, 15 weeks pregnant, had an abortion. Mr. Drayton pleaded guilty yesterday in State Supreme Court in Queens to first-degree course of sexual conduct against a child. Justice Barry Kron indicated that he would sentence Mr. Drayton to 20 years in jail on Feb. 26. Corey Kilgannon (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: New Chip For Hynix
description: A leading maker of computer memory chips, Hynix Semiconductor, said yesterday that it would start production this month of so-called NAND flash-memory chips, which go into digital cameras and other consumer electronics. The goal is to become the world's third-largest producer of NAND flash memory by next year, Hynix said in a statement. The South Korean company signed an agreement in April with STMicroelectronics, Europe's largest maker of chips, to jointly make the chips. Hynix did not say how many NAND chips it would make this year.

title: Deadly but Seldom Used

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HARRIS, JEFF STEVE

True cause of death was Emphysema. His memory will live on in the hearts of many: his beloved wife of 40 years, Judy, son Barnaby, daughter Hillary, son-in-law Bob Wasson, grandchildren Charlie and Benjamin and inlaws Ruth and Irving Schatz. His compassion, creativity, integrity and profound sense of humor are the lasting qualities that will live within us forever. Burial will be private with a memorial service to be announced. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to The Actors' Fund.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WESSON, HOWARD SHELDON
description: WESSON--Howard Sheldon. Of West Orange, NJ. Died on February 1st in New York City after a six-month battle with pancreatic cancer. Born and raised in the Bronx, he was among the first students to attend the Bronx High School of Science. After graduating high school, he entered the Army and trained operators in the pioneer expansion of coastal radar during the latter half of World War II. Following his discharge, he returned to New York to study Comparative Medieval Literature at New York University, Columbia and, later, at the Universite de Paris. He began his professional career as a medical advertising copywriter. In 1963, he formed his own medical advertising agency, Wesson & Warhaftig, which he directed for two decades. In the early '80s, he sold the agency to William Douglas McAdams and moved to develop a successful new career in the theater. He studied at the T. Schreiber Studio, and became an active member of Equity, SAG and AFTRA, performing in many off-Broadway, regional and stock productions, as well as on television shows such as Law and Order. His portrayal of Willy Loman in the 1992 William Carlos Williams Center production of ''Death of a Salesman'' was highly praised by the New York Times, StarLedger and Bergen Record. A generous and kindhearted raconteur, he will be lovingly remembered by his wife Micki, daughter Rebecca, sons Daniel and Joshua, and by all who knew him as a warm and giving man. A celebration of his life will take place in Manhattan on May 9. In lieu of flowers, contributions in his name can be made directly to the CP Nichols School Library, P.S. 42, 700 Newark Avenue, Jersey City, NJ 07306.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: Chemical Profit Falls
description: Ciba Specialty Chemicals said its profit fell 55 percent, to 43 million Swiss francs ($34 million), in the last quarter of 2003 as a result of price pressure from emerging markets and temporary plant closings. Sales fell 3 percent, to 1.6 billion Swiss francs. Ciba -- which is based in Basel and makes plastics, car paints and textiles -- said profit for the year was down 15 percent, to 344 million Swiss francs, while sales were down 6 percent, to 6.65 billion francs. Analysts said the figures were below expectations, and the share price fell 2 percent. The chief executive, Armin Meyer, said Ciba had done its homework by cutting costs. Those cuts included expenses of a 2 percent reduction of the work force, but Mr. Meyer said the company's results would pick up only when market conditions improved. Despite a tough year, Ciba said it cut its debt 28 percent and had cash reserves of 728 million francs. He said Ciba was considering 10 takeover candidates but declined to identify them. Fiona Fleck (NYT)

title: VARCO TO CUT 200 JOBS BECAUSE OF POOR SALES
description: Varco International, which announced last week that it was quitting the oil-rig fabrication business, said yesterday that it was cutting 200 jobs because of decreasing sales. Varco said it expected the job cuts at its drilling equipment sales group in Orange, Calif., and in Houston to be completed by the end of the second quarter. The company said it would have $5 million in expenses related to the reductions in the first half of 2004 and save $20 million a year. Varco reported that fourth-quarter net income fell 79 percent to $4.6 million, or 5 cents a share, from $21.4 million, or 22 cents a share, a year earlier. Sales fell 14 percent to $349.7 million from $354.5 million a year earlier.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KAYES, CECILY ELMES
description: KAYES--Cecily Elmes, who served on active duty as one of the youngest members of the Women's Air Force Service Pilots during World War II, died in her residence in Manhattan on Monday, February 2nd. She had recently undergone surgery for colon cancer that had spread to other vital organs of her body, according to a family spokesperson. She was 80 years old. Mrs. Kayes was born in Chicago, where her father, Cecil Elmes, an Englishman who had become an American citizen, headed a firm of engineering consultants. When her family moved to New York City, she was enrolled at the Nightingale-Bamford School and subsequently on graduation, Vassar College. Her collegiate studies ended when the Women's Air Force Service Pilots lowered its age limit and she promptly withdrew from Vassar to join the volunteer organization headed by Jacqueline Cochrane. Mrs. Kayes entered the WASP as a licensed aviation pilot. At the age of fifteen she had begun taking flying lessons in Sarasota, where her parents had a winter home, and she joined the WASP as a qualified flight pilot and instructor. In addition to her duties as a flight instructor, she piloted B-26s on target towing missions during gunnery practice for Air Force and Navy student pilots, remaining with the WASP until it was disbanded shortly before the end of the war. In later years Mrs. Kayes, a member of the New York Junior League, served as its vice-president and was actively involved in its volunteer social work programs. In addition to participating in its annual Mardi Gras fundraising events as a Beauty Queen, she focused on the activities of the Women's Prison Association, where she served as a member of its board of directors and as president of the organization. Despite her commitment to volunteer social service work and the rigorous task of raising 3 children as a divorced single mother, Mrs. Kayes had a professional career as Cecily Crawford in residental real estate in New York City. Her specialty was cooperative apartment sales, and she had a long association with the firm of Kenneth Ives, which was subsequently merged into the Douglas Elliman organization. Surviving are 3 children by her marriage to James W. Crawford: James W. Crawford III of New Berlin, WI, Lillian Aronow of Coconut Grove, FL, Elizabeth Crawford of Lambertville, NJ, 7 grandchildren and 2 great-grandchildren. Her husband, Alan Kayes, a longtime resident of Water Mill and Southampton, who now resides at Peconic Landing in Greenport, NY also survives. A memorial service will take place in the chapel of Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street on Thursday, February 5th at 3:30 PM.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: Profit At Biotech Concern
description: A leading global biotechnology company, Serono, said its profit rose 37 percent in the fourth quarter, to $111.6 million, from the period in 2002. Fourth-quarter sales rose 17 percent. The company said sales growth was led by its reproductive health division and totaled $519 million. For the year, Serono said profit rose 22 percent, to $390 million, and sales rose by a greater-than-expected 31 percent, but its share price declined more than 2 percent because of a cautious forecast for 2004. Andrew Fellows, an analyst for Pictet & Cie, said that investors were disappointed because Serono did not appear to be coming up with enough new products and that growth prospects for its rivals in the United States appeared to be better. Fiona Fleck (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Sweden: Disappointing Result At Volvo
description: Europe's largest truck maker, Volvo, said it had not found a buyer for its 45.5 percent stake in a rival, Scania, and that fourth-quarter profit rose less than analysts had forecast. Net income increased 79 percent to 1.14 billion kronor ($155 million), from 638 million kronor, the chief executive, Leif Johansson, said. Analysts had expected net income of 1.26 billion kronor. Volvo has been trying to find a buyer for Scania after its planned $6.9 billion takeover was blocked by the European Commission four years ago. Volvo said it would spin off half the Scania holding to shareholders should it fail to find a buyer by the commission's April 23 deadline.

title: Chief of Macy's East Division, Part of Federated, Plans to Retire
description: Hal Kahn, the chief executive of the biggest division of Federated Department Stores for the last decade, is retiring on Feb. 15, the company said yesterday. Mr. Kahn, 58, is being succeeded as the head of the Macy's East division by Ronald Klein, 55, who has been running a smaller division for nearly three years.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Silverstein Debt Downgraded
description: Larry A. Silverstein's effort to rebuild 7 World Trade Center suffered a setback yesterday when Moody's Investors Service sharply downgraded its assessment of his $383 million in debt on the property. The bond rating agency tied the downgrade to the developer's lack of progress in settling an insurance dispute over the original building after obtaining new financing and a tenant for the 52-story tower he has begun to build, said James Church, a senior analyst at Moody's. The original building was destroyed in the trade center attack. Although Mr. Silverstein has been at odds with Industrial Risk Insurers over the value of the property, he has started building a $700 million skyscraper on the site, at Washington and Vesey Streets. But rents downtown have fallen sharply, and there are few prospective tenants. Charles V. Bagli (NYT)

title: National Briefing: West
description: ALASKA: TEACHERS REJECT EDUCATION LAW Alaska teachers want the state to ignore the requirements of the federal No Child Left Behind law and thus give up millions of dollars in financing. At the annual gathering of the National Education Association's Alaska chapter in Anchorage, educators voted to send their message to the state. The law requires new standardized tests and demands annual student improvement on those exams, as well as tougher teacher qualifications. Many public school districts have found meeting the requirements expensive and time-consuming. The Education Department has not detailed which financing would be jeopardized if a district or state declined to comply with the law. Alaska public schools last year received about $180 million in federal money.    (AP)

title: CHICAGO: POETRY CHIEF
description: The Poetry Foundation, which made headlines 15 months ago when it received an astonishing gift worth more than $100 million, named John W. Barr its president yesterday. Mr. Barr has published poetry but is known mainly as a businessman and investment banker with the firm SG Barr Devlin, which handles mergers and acquisitions that sometimes exceed the billion-dollar level. Before becoming a co-founder of the firm in 1990, he was a managing director at Morgan Stanley. Financial dealing, however, does not take all of Mr. Barr's attention. He is also on the boards of Bennington College and the Yaddo art colony. The Chicago-based Poetry Foundation was for years a respected but decidedly low-budget operation known as the Modern Poetry Association. It announced its huge gift from the pharmaceutical heiress Ruth Lilly in November 2002 and changed its name soon afterward. A large part of Mr. Barr's role will be to decide how to use the money. ''This is a chance for me to combine and create a point of conjunction for what have been the two principal paths of my life, writing poetry and being a businessman,'' Mr. Barr said. ''I dream of seeing the Poetry Foundation built and operated like a well-run company. The business purpose is to make an important home for American poetry, but I also hope to set an example by making this run well from a business point of view.'' STEPHEN KINZER

description: GRANT--George Vincent. A lifelong resident of NYC, August 15, 1921--January 30, 2004. He served as a squad leader in WWII and earned three Bronze Stars during his tour of duty in Sicily and North Africa. In 1953 he joined the NYPD and moved through the ranks from patrolman to detective sergeant of the MOB Squad, retiring after 24 years. Shortly thereafter, Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan nominated George for US Marshall. President Jimmy Carter appointed Mr. Grant to the Southern District of NYC in 1977. George is survived by his wife of 52 years, Lilla; a stepdaughter; a sister, Audrey; five nephews; four nieces; and a host of friends and relatives. title: Technology Briefing | Internet: SoHu Shares Plunge On Revenue Slump
description: Shares of Sohu.com, a Chinese Web site operator, fell about 20 percent yesterday after it reported lower- than-expected fourth-quarter revenue from wireless text messaging and other phone services. Sales of services that include instant messaging and ring tones were $15.1 million, at the low end of the company's forecast for $14.9 million to $16.1 million, said Safa Rashtchy, a Piper Jaffray analyst. Revenue missed his estimate for $16.1 million, he said. Sohu.com fell $7.50, to $30.41. Shares of the Beijing-based company had more than quadrupled in the last year. Other Chinese Internet stocks also slumped. The plunge in share prices shows how investor expectations for Chinese companies had soared as the stocks rallied. Investors speculated that growth in the nation of 1.3 billion people would lead to surging growth in Internet usage.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Ukraine: Parliament Votes To Let People Choose Leader

title: Powell and White House Get Together on Iraq War
description: The White House and Secretary of State Colin L. Powell scrambled on Tuesday to present a united front about the war in Iraq, a day after Mr. Powell said he was not sure if he would have recommended an invasion had he known Saddam Hussein did not have stockpiles of banned weapons.

title: Overachieving Knicks Outplay East's Best
description: Stephon Marbury screamed, Keith Van Horn punched the air, Kurt Thomas high-fived Penny Hardaway, and the rest of the Knicks walked off the court clenching their fists, knowing that they had made every last play to overmatch the best team in the Eastern Conference.

title: The Cod Transformed: First by Salt, Then by Fire
description: SALTED fish is at least as old as the Egyptians: take salt, fish and hot weather, and some clever person is bound to figure out that the first can help the second survive the third.

title: National Briefing | New England: Massachusetts: Lesser Charges In Child's Starvation Death
description: A former member of a religious sect has been acquitted of murder for starving her infant son to death to fulfill a religious prophecy. But the defendant, Karen Robidoux, was convicted of assault and battery in the 1999 death of her son, Samuel, who was deprived of food for 51 days and died shortly before his first birthday. Ms. Robidoux was sentenced to two and a half years in prison, but was immediately released on time served. She belonged to the Body, a religious sect that shunned modern medicine. Ms. Robidoux's husband, Jacques, was convicted of first-degree murder and sentenced to life in prison without parole in 2002. Katie Zezima (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Europe: Germany: Students Arrested In Abuse Video
description: Four 17-year-old students were arrested on charges that they repeatedly brutalized an 18-year-old classmate over a period of 17 weeks at a vocational school in Hildesheim, filmed the beatings while other class members watched, and put the pictures of the ordeal on the Internet. Kirsten Grieshaber (NYT)

title: Inquiry Lists Prison System Errors in Case of Slain Priest
description: The death of John J. Geoghan, the defrocked pedophile priest who was killed in his prison cell last summer, was largely a result of a series of mistakes and failures by the state prison system to treat him fairly and responsibly and to protect him in jail, according to a report issued on Tuesday on a state investigation.

title: New Jersey Raises the Bar In Death Cases
description: The New Jersey Supreme Court ruled Tuesday that prosecutors who planned to seek the death penalty must first present evidence to support a death sentence to a grand jury as part of the indictment process.

title: The Debt No One Wants to Talk About
description: ''We might hope to see the finances of the Union as clear and intelligible as a merchant's books,'' President Thomas Jefferson wrote to his secretary of the Treasury in 1802, ''so that every member of Congress, and every man of any mind in the Union, should be able to comprehend them, to investigate abuses, and consequently to control them.'' Unfortunately, straightforward government financial information seems as elusive in 2004 as it did in Jefferson's day.

description: Dan Marino surprised the Dolphins on Tuesday by resigning as the team's senior vice president for football operations three weeks after accepting the job.

description: By offering incentives worth more than $1,000 and a range of new sport utility models, the Chrysler Group of DaimlerChrysler and several Japanese automakers racked up sales gains in January even as General Motors and the Ford Motor Company posted declines.

title: For Brooklyn Democrats, a Year of Just-in-Case Campaigns

Several of Mr. Owens's fellow Brooklyn Democratic officials, however, are not abiding by that timetable, and are planning to challenge Mr. Owens, a 22-year incumbent.

description: Sales Gain at Chrysler, Nissan and Toyota

title: Oracle Raises Its Takeover Bid for PeopleSoft
description: The Oracle Corporation raised its bid to acquire Peoplesoft by a third today, offering about $9.4 billion in cash, an amount that exceeds PeopleSoft's current stock value. But even at the higher price, the company faces still considerable roadblocks in its eight-month battle to take over its competitor.

title: Sichuan's Signature Fire Is Going Out. Or Is It?
description: FIRE is a not unfamiliar sensation in food. Cuisines all over the world get a zap from chili peppers in dozens of guises. But there's nothing like the numbing sparkle that the food of Sichuan gets from the Sichuan peppercorn -- huajiao, as it is called there.

title: Burnett decides one way to address its troubles is to poach a top executive from a shaky competitor.
description: AN agency seeking to shake up its lagging operations, Leo Burnett, is poaching a top executive from a competitor sharing that wobbly status, Lowe & Partners. Underlining the significance of the surprising change in leadership: the executive, Tom Bernardin, is in line to become the first outsider ever to lead Burnett in its 69-year history.

title: Bring Back Sousa
description: As moments of cultural incoherence go, it was hard to beat the Super Bowl halftime show last Sunday, which culminated -- if that's the right word -- in a brief display of Janet Jackson's bare but armored right breast. Consider, to begin with, the strange tangle of interested parties mixed up in the post-debacle legal scrum. CBS broadcast the game, MTV produced the halftime entertainment, Viacom owns both CBS and MTV, the F.C.C. is investigating the incident, and the N.F.L. is miffed at MTV. At the center of it all are Ms. Jackson and Justin Timberlake, who tore off the critical part of Ms. Jackson's costume to the words ''have you naked by the end of this song,'' which come from Mr. Timberlake's ''Rock Your Body.'' And then, of course, there is the rest of the world.

title: Aventis Said to Be Talking of Asset Sales
description: Aventis, the French pharmaceutical company that is the target of a $60 billion hostile takeover bid by a domestic rival, Sanofi-Synthlabo, has been in talks to sell some assets, according to an executive close to the discussions.

title: Bush Budget Cuts or Cancels School Programs, Drug Centers and Air Traffic Changes
description: The White House on Tuesday released a list of 128 government programs that it plans to cut back or eliminate, including money for drug treatment centers and secondary school counselors and modernization of the air traffic system.

title: When Wednesday Is Just Too Late
description: TEMPERAMENT plays an important role in cooking. If you are the sort of person who, when catching a train, needs to arrive at the station with time to spare, you will cook in a very different way from someone who habitually boards the train while it is inching away.

title: Finding of Deadly Poison in Office Disrupts the Senate
description: The Senate shut down its three office buildings on Tuesday, disrupting the work of lawmakers and thousands of their aides, after a powder identified as the deadly poison ricin was found in the office suite of the Senate majority leader, Bill Frist.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: The Netherlands: Drug Maker's Profit Falls
description: The pharmaceutical and chemicals company Akzo Nobel said its 2003 net profit fell 9 percent, to 811 million euros ($1 billion), excluding one-time restructuring charges. Sales last year were down 7 percent, to 13.1 billion euros. The company attributed the declines to a weak dollar, rising pension fund costs and a surge in generic drugs that compete in the United States with its best-selling antidepressant, Remeron. Akzo anticipates that its net income this year, not including one-time gains, will be below that of 2003. Its fourth-quarter net income was up 52 percent, to 268 million euros, from the period a year earlier, in part because of an 88 million euro payment from Pfizer that was made in connection with a drug development program. Gregory Crouch (NYT)

title: JUDGE AWARDS FLEETBOSTON $63.7 MILLION IN LAWSUIT
description: FleetBoston Financial Corporation will get $63.7 million from the Advanta Corporation to compensate for overpaying for a credit-card unit, a judge decided yesterday. FleetBoston sued in state court in Wilmington, Del., in 1999, claiming Advanta understated liabilities and failed to disclose interest-rate coding problems on accounts. FleetBoston acquired the unit for $532 million in assumed debt in 1998. FleetBoston has agreed to be acquired by the Bank of America Corporation for $47 billion. FleetBoston originally sought $126 million, plus interest. Advanta, in a counterclaim, accused FleetBoston of trying to take some of its customers and asked for $101 million in damages. The final figures represented a split decision.

title: Couple Charged With Cruelty
description: A New Jersey couple was charged with forcing their young foster daughter to wait on an elderly relative as he lay dead in an upstairs bedroom, officials said yesterday.

description: IT has been a tough year for Viacom. It has had to cope with everything from Justin Timberlake's exposing Janet Jackson's breast during the Super Bowl broadcast on CBS to routine problems like the potential spinoff of its Blockbuster chain of video stores.

title: Ricin as a Weapon
description: Ricin is not on any expert's top 10 list of terrorist poisons to worry about, but its mere presence in powdered form in a Senate mailroom was enough to close several Senate buildings yesterday. The incident was a sobering reminder that even after more than two years of relative quiet on the domestic security front, we remain vulnerable to any extremist who chooses to disrupt the nation's daily routine with a toxic powder.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Sprint Profit Falls On Wireless Unit Loss
description: The Sprint Corporation said yesterday that fourth-quarter net income fell 2.6 percent because of a wider loss at its wireless unit. Net income slipped to $38 million, from $39 million a year earlier. Sales rose 2.1 percent, to $6.68 billion, from $6.54 billion, driven by wireless revenue growth, Sprint said. The company, which is based in Overland Park, Kan., reports separate per-share figures for its wireless and wireline groups. Sprint scrapped a billing system it was developing for the PCS mobile-phone group, leading to a pretax cost of $352 million in the quarter and the wider unit loss. Still, an 8.4 percent jump in wireless sales cushioned the effect of a 12th consecutive revenue decline at the long-distance unit. The chief executive, Gary D. Forsee, is paring costs and jobs to cope with the sluggish sales. Shares fell 2 cents, to $9.10.

title: The Supersizing of Warehouses
description: When executives of Unilever's home and personal care products division of North America decided in 2000 to seek cost savings by streamlining the distribution system, the company had 15 warehouses across the country, the result of mergers since the late 1980's with two other manufacturers, Chesebrough-Ponds and Helene Curtis.

title: A Stew Inspires Even Lightweights to Greater Glory
description: YEARS ago I had the good fortune to be in Burgundy at harvest time and was invited to lunch with the pickers. Big bowls of blanquette de veau, a bourgeois veal stew in cream sauce, were laid out on tables and served with a young, unassuming pinot noir.

title: A Box of Luxuries To Sweeten the Day
description: A new line of artfully wrought chocolates, above, is called the G Collection, which stands for none other than Godiva. These intense, top shelf confections were designed by Norman Love, a pastry chef. The chocolates, which have a three-week shelf life, are as delectable as they are elegant and pricey: about $100 a pound. Nine pieces are $25, 15 are $40 and 30 are $70, at the Godiva stores at 793 Madison Avenue (68th Street) and 200 Park Avenue (45th Street). They can also be ordered online from www.godiva.com.

title: Lindros Should Consider Retiring as Richter Did
description: FOURTEEN months ago, Mike Richter was just getting used to the netherworld of concussion victims, trudging his way through the shadowy hours. Then Eric Lindros, his fellow Manhattanite, dropped over.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: PanAmSat To Transmit Fox Programming
description: The PanAmSat Corporation said yesterday that it would transmit programming for the News Corporation's Fox television networks, raising speculation that News Corporation will sell its controlling stake in PanAmSat. The News Corporation bought a controlling 34 percent stake last year in PanAmSat's parent company, Hughes Electronics. Hughes owns 81 percent of PanAmSat, which is based in Wilton, Conn. PanAmSat shares fell 10 cents, to $20.52. The American depository receipts of News Corporation fell 36 cents, to $36.55. Each A.D.R. represents four common shares. Shares of Hughes, based in El Segundo, Calif., fell 7 cents, to $16.83. PanAmSat said that its satellites would carry all of the Fox networks' American programming for the next 15 years and a ''significant portion'' of Fox's international programming for the next decade. PanAmSat provides satellite capacity to TV-programming companies to transmit video feeds to local cable-TV services and broadcast stations.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Car Bomb Kills One
description: A car bombing in the southern city of Vladikavkaz killed at least one person and wounded 10 others in what appeared to be the latest in a string of terrorist bombings in Russia, officials told news agencies. The bomb exploded as a car carrying Russian military cadets was passing, wounding several, but it was not clear that they were the targets. Officials in Vladikavkaz, near Chechnya, did not immediately link the bomb to the war in Chechnya. Steven Lee Myers (NYT)

title: Uneven Justice

The deposed king of the energy industry and the queen of all things house and home had never had much in common, but for a while, they stood together as emblems of everything that was wrong with the business world. They were using their positions, we were told, to get richer at the expense of ordinary investors.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FERGUSON, KEITH ARTHUR
description: FERGUSON--Keith Arthur, age 38, Sergeant, NYPD, member of the elite Hercules Anti-terrorism squad of the Emergency Service Unit, died on Saturday, January 31st after collapsing suddenly in Soho while assisting other officers in apprehending a suspect after a short foot chase. Ferguson was a 17 year veteran of the NYPD, who joined the force in 1987, and became a sergeant in 1997 and worked in various precincts throughout the department over the years. At the time of his death, he was a member of Unit 7 of the Emergency Service Unit based in the 75th Precinct in East New York. Following the Bosnian conflict, Ferguson was part of a team of criminal justice experts sent to Bosnia by the U.S. government to assist the Bosnians in establishing a civilian police force. His love of travel and interest in diverse cultures made him an excellent choice for the Bosnian assignment. Sergeant Ferguson was a true New Yorker. He loved the city and felt very proud of his work as a New York City police officer. He had great energy, and was a true police officer. He loved his family and had many friends whom he managed to incorporate into his life. His aunts, Joy Cunningham, Fern Cunningham and Sheila Hazel who were very close to Sergeant Ferguson said ''Keith was our son too.'' His fellow officers from the Emergency Service Unit, Tim Murphy and Ronald Racioppi said ''Keith was very well liked; the police department and all of us have suffered a great loss. The guys are really going to miss him.'' His father Victor Ferguson, a retired NYPD police officer said, ''I am very proud of my son. He died doing what he loved.'' Sergeant Ferguson is survived also by his mother Sonia Cunningham, his brother Laird Ferguson, his grandmother Kathleen Ferguson, aunts, uncles, cousins, and many many friends. He will be sorely missed. Friends may call at Andrett Funeral Home, 353 Second Ave, NYC, 10010; 212-475-2024 on Wednesday, February 4th from 25 and 7-9pm. Mass of Christian burial at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Andrews, 20 Cardinal Hayes Place. (Duane and Centre Street) on Thursday, February 5th at 10am. In lieu of flowers, contributions in his memory may be made to the University of Texas Brownsville, c/o Barry T. Horn, Director of Development, 80 Fort Brown, Building 23, Brownsville, TX 78520, the Keith A. Ferguson Scholarship Fund for Criminal Justice.

title: Gaza First
description: Of all the sources of tension between Israel and the Palestinians, few are as frustrating as the Jewish settlements in the Gaza Strip. Among one million impoverished Palestinians, many of them refugees from the 1948 Israeli-Arab war, 7,500 Israeli Jews live in 21 communities, dominating vast portions of the land and water on the parched, densely packed seaside strip. To protect them, the Israeli government has crosshatched the area with roads exclusively for the settlers' use and garrisoned whole military units there, hampering and interrupting Palestinians' movement and daily life.

title: An Appraisal; Glamorous Glass Gives 10 Columbus Circle a Look of Crystallized Noir
description: It is good to see Skidmore, Owings & Merrill back in the business of piling up big chunks of quartz. Stone was never this firm's strength. Ten Columbus Circle does ample penance for the opaque minerals Skidmore deployed so extravagantly during its neo-Art Deco phase. There's some flame-pattern gray granite at the building's base, but it's there mainly for contrast with the giant cluster of glass crystals, which appears to have been quarried from the sky.

description: An unidentified powder was discovered late Monday at a mail distribution center here, where anthrax spores were discovered in 2001. A federal law enforcement official said on Tuesday evening that the substance had tested negative for ricin.

He was a former President of the Jewish Labor Committee, which worked with the IRC during World War II to assist refugees fleeing the Nazis. We will miss Jack deeply and extend heartfelt sympathy to the family. Winston Lord James C. Strickler Co-Chairman John C. Whitehead Chairman Emeritus George Rupp President

title: S.E.C. WARNS GENERAL MILLS OF POSSIBLE SUIT
description: General Mills received a notice from the Securities and Exchange Commission yesterday that it might be sued in a civil case related to its sales and accounting practices. The notice also covered the chief executive, Stephen Sanger, and the chief financial officer, James Lawrence, General Mills said. The S.E.C. staff has made a preliminary decision to recommend a civil action, the company said. General Mills, Kraft Foods, H.J. Heinz, Tyson Foods and Sara Lee said last year that they were contacted by the S.E.C. in an accounting investigation of Royal Ahold's distribution business. General Mills said that it thought its sales practices and related accounting complied with regulations and that it was cooperating with the S.E.C. investigation.

In 2002, one summer school student fatally stabbed another outside the school. A few months later, things became so rowdy after a fire drill that the police officers on duty used Mace.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Centers For Suspended Students
description: Five new centers for students who have been suspended from school will open today, the New York City Schools Chancellor, Joel I. Klein, announced yesterday. The community groups that will run the centers with the Department of Education include Phoenix House in Brooklyn, Boys and Girls Harbor in Manhattan and Phipps Community Development Corporation in the Bronx. Officials said the groups would be paid $200,000 per center this semester, a cost that does not include salaries for teachers and other staff members. Each center will have room for as many as 60 students who have been suspended for up to 90 days, and will provide instruction and enrichment programs, officials said. Elissa Gootman (NYT)

description: DILLON--George Burford, of Manchester, died Thursday, January 29, 2004 at New Brunswick, NJ. Born in Chicago, he lived in Teaneck, before moving to Manchester in 1984. He was a decorated Army veteran, serving during World War II. He was an insurance broker with Marsh McLennan, NY, NY for many years before retiring in 1986. Mr. Dillon was a brilliant and irreverent man with a myriad of interests. He could often be found reading poetry, swimming in the ocean or discussing political topics. He was adored by his family and his love for them will endure. Mr. Dillon was a charismatic and charming man who will be greatly missed. Mr. Dillon was predeceased by his wife Ruthie in 1972. He is survived by his daughter and son-inlaw, Lori Dillon and John Ager; granddaughters, Georgiana and Belle; his dear brother and sister-in-law, Gregory and Jenine Dillon and his beloved nieces and nephews. A memorial service will take place on Friday at 2:00PM at Christ Church, 5 Paterson Street, New Brunswick, NJ. title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Man Convicted Of Murder

Prosecutors said that last September, the accused man, Vadim Traut, 54, of Queens, entered an area where homeless people were known to congregate, pulled a 12-gauge shotgun from his trench coat, and shot Kevin Monroe, 46. Prosecutors said that when three homeless men discovered Mr. Traut standing over Mr. Monroe, Mr. Traut ordered one of the men to help dispose of the body, but that he refused. The patent for Avelox is valid in the United States through at least 2014, Bayer said in a statement, adding that it was ''determined to defend its patents.'' Avelox is used by about 25 million patients to treat respiratory tract infections, Bayer said last year.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Finland: Loss For Paper Maker
description: The paper maker Stora Enso posted a fourth-quarter loss, its first in five quarters, blaming lower prices, the dollar's drop and one-time costs. The company, based in Helsinki, said it lost 42.2 million euros ($53 million), or 5 cents a share, in contrast to net income of 477.5 million euros, or 54 cents, a year earlier. Sales fell 5.7 percent, to 3.03 billion euros, the company said. Operating profit excluding one-time items was 80.5 million euros, above the 70 million euros Stora forecast last month. Its share price posted a slight gain.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Serbia: Parliament Picks A Speaker
description: The country's political deadlock appeared closer to being resolved as former foes joined forces to elect a new speaker of the Parliament. A month after elections failed to give any single party a big enough mandate to govern by itself, Dragan Marsican of the pro-reform Democratic Party of Serbia was elected speaker with 128 out of 245 votes cast after his party sought the help of the Socialists, the party of Slobodan Milosevic. There is still no agreement between the parties on the composition of a new government. Nicholas Wood (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WESSON, HOWARD SHELDON
description: WESSON--Howard Sheldon. Of West Orange, NJ. Died on February 1st in New York City after a six-month battle with pancreatic cancer. Born and raised in the Bronx, he was among the first students to attend the Bronx High School of Science. After graduating high school, he entered the Army and trained operators in the pioneer expansion of coastal radar during the latter half of World War II. Following his discharge, he returned to New York to study Comparative Medieval Literature at New York University, Columbia and, later, at the Universite de Paris. He began his professional career as a medical advertising copywriter. In 1963, he formed his own medical advertising agency, Wesson & Warhaftig, which he directed for two decades. In the early '80s, he sold the agency to William Douglas McAdams and moved to develop a successful new career in the theater. He studied at the T. Schreiber Studio, and became an active member of Equity, SAG and AFTRA, performing in many off-Broadway, regional and stock productions, as well as on television shows such as Law and Order. His portrayal of Willy Loman in the 1992 William Carlos Williams Center production of ''Death of a Salesman'' was highly praised by the New York Times, StarLedger and Bergen Record. A generous and kindhearted raconteur, he will be lovingly remembered by his wife Micki, daughter Rebecca, sons Daniel and Joshua, and by all who knew him as a warm and giving man. A celebration of his life will take place in Manhattan on May 9. In lieu of flowers, contributions in his name can be made directly to the CP Nichols School Library, P.S. 42, 700 Newark Avenue, Jersey City, NJ 07306.

title: National Briefing | Northwest: Oregon: Voters Reject Tax Package

title: Color Palette Courtesy of Desert

But her James Hotel in Scottsdale, Ariz., explodes with color. ''When I got out there, to the hot weather, the bright blue skies, the strongness of the light, I thought, 'Let's go for the big bold gesture,' '' she said. The facade is terra cotta, cream and umber, top right. Magenta columns march down the lobby, far right. The bedrooms are more serene. The owners, Stephen Hanson, the restaurateur, and Danny Errico, a founder of Equinox Fitness Clubs, spent $30 million renovating the former Old Town Hotel. Rooms are $95 to $285. The hotel is at 7353 East Indian School Road. (480) 308-1100; Deborah Berke & Partners, (212) 229-9211.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Southampton Village: Man Dies In Custody
description: A man who the police said was emotionally disturbed died yesterday, shortly after struggling with officers, the police said. Relatives called the police about 10:30 a.m., asking for assistance with David. Glowczenski, who they said had been acting irrationally. Mr. Glowczenski ,35, had fled his home, on Layton Avenue, by the time the Southampton Village police arrived, Officer Robert Bowden, a spokesman for the Suffolk County Police, said last night. Southampton Village officers found Mr. Glowczenski on North Main Street and ''attempted to calm him down,'' Officer Bowden said. Mr. Glowczenski resisted and threw a female officer to the ground, the police said. A struggle ensued, in which the officers used sprayand an electric dart gun, Officer Bowden said. Mr. Glowczenski was eventually handcuffed. A short time later, he stopped breathing, and the officers called for an ambulance and attempted to revive him, Officer Bowden said. Mr. Glowczenskiwas pronounced dead at Southampton Hospital at 11:19 a.m. Sabrina Tavernise (NYT)

title: PENTAIR BUYS WATER PUMP MAKER FOR $850 MILLION
description: Pentair, a maker of water pumps and tools, agreed yesterday to buy the Wisconsin Energy Corporation's Wicor water products unit for $850 million. The purchase is Pentair's biggest acquisition, and will broaden its line of water and wastewater pumps. The company, which is based in Golden Valley, Minn., said it would assume $24 million in Wicor debt. Pentair has also hired the Goldman Sachs Group to determine if it should sell its tools group, which had $1.08 billion in sales last year; proceeds of a sale would help pay debt. Wicor, which is based in Milwaukee and employs 3,100 people in 24 locations, had about $750 million in sales last year, Pentair said.

title: RENT-A-CENTER TO PAY $95 MILLION FOR SMALLER RIVAL
description: Rent-A-Center Inc., the largest rent-to-own retailer in the nation, agreed to buy Rainbow Rentals Inc. for about $95 million in cash, saying that it expected to save on costs because of the acquisition. Rent-A-Center, which is based in Plano, Tex., and operates about 2,650 stores in 50 states and Puerto Rico, will pay $16 a share, the companies said. The price in the acquisition is almost double Rainbow Rental's closing share price Tuesday. Rainbow Rentals, based in Canfield, Ohio, operates 124 stores in 15 states. It had 2002 sales of $99 million. Rent-A-Center's 2002 sales were $2 billion.

title: VALERO TO BUY ARUBA REFINERY FROM EL PASO
description: The Valero Energy Corporation, a leading oil refiner, agreed to buy the El Paso Corporation's refinery in Aruba for $365 million. Valero will also pay $100 million for related marine and bunker-fuel operations, and $250 million for working capital, the company said. The refinery can process 315,000 barrels of crude oil a day. Valero, based in San Antonio, has more than doubled the size of its refining network since 2001. The addition of the Aruba refinery might increase net income by about $80 million this year and $175 million in 2005, the chief executive, Bill Greehey, said in a statement.

title: A Rude Awakening
description: Attention Republicans: You may think the results of the Democratic primaries indicate that Americans aren't interested in foreign policy. All they care about are domestic issues, like health care and taxes, and that's what the president should focus on. Maybe. But be careful. You could wake up in November and find that while Mr. Bush focused on the home front, his foreign policy created the ''Islamic Republic of Iraq'' and the ''Islamic Republic of Palestine.'' Imagine defending those on the campaign trail? Have I got your attention? As they say in the phone commercial, ''Can you hear me now?''

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Candy Acquisition Overruled
description: The Brazilian antitrust authority ruled that the acquisition of Chocolates Garoto, a Brazilian candy company, by the Swiss candy maker Nestl was a threat to competition, and ordered Nestl to sell the unit or equivalent assets to a company that controls less than 20 percent of Brazil's $900 million chocolate market. Nestl bought the Brazilian company, at the time one of the largest chocolate makers in the country, for $230 million two years ago. Analysts expected the agency to approve the sale with some conditions, allowing Nestl to overtake Kraft Foods as the market leader in Brazil. ''It wasn't the decision we expected,'' said Ivan Zurita, chairman of the Brazilian operations of Nestl. Kraft and Cadbury Schweppes of Britain, which lost out to Nestl in the original bidding, had lobbied the government agency to block the deal. Kraft cannot buy Garoto because it already has a market share of more than 20 percent, but the ruling could lead to a second chance for Cadbury to enter the Brazilian market. Tony Smith (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Telephone And Data Systems Posts Sales Increase

Net income was 44 cents a share, in contrast to a loss of $29.5 million, or 50 cents, in the year-earlier quarter, when it wrote down the value of investments, said the company, the parent of the U.S. Cellular Corporation. Sales rose to $884.4 million from $815.6 million, led by a 10 percent jump in U.S. Cellular revenue. U.S. Cellular, which accounts for 75 percent of the sales of the Chicago-based Telephone and Data Systems, added 141,000 subscribers in the quarter, or 19,000 fewer than a year earlier, after raising phone prices in an unsuccessful bid to get competitors to do the same.

description: An article on Saturday about the sighting of bald eagles around New York City misstated the relationship of three eagles spotted by park rangers on an ice floe in the Hudson River, near the George Washington Bridge. They were an adult and two juveniles, all of unknown sex, not a mother and two of her young.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: I.B.M. Takes On Some Sprint Customer Service Jobs
description: The Sprint Corporation has entered a five-year multibillion-dollar agreement with I.B.M. to improve its customer service operation. Sprint, based in Overland Park, Kan., said yesterday that it would save $550 million over the next three years as a result of the agreement. Sprint will shed 1,100 customer service jobs in Nashville and 170 in the Kansas City, Mo., area, transferring them to I.B.M. The jobs of another 4,500 employees who now work for Sprint subcontractors will also be turned over to I.B.M. as a result of this agreement. Sprint said that I.B.M. would help it better identify the needs of customers, improve call routing and help the phone company solve customer problems in just one call.

title: One Answer, but Still Many Questions
description: A day after tests on powder in an envelope at a postal center here addressed to the Republican National Committee did not find a problem, employees at the 500,000-square-foot center were skeptical and frustrated.

title: With Health System in Tatters, Zimbabwe Stands Defenseless
description: Three days after getting word that cholera was again killing villagers outside this district capital, Binga's political and medical leaders gathered at the town's disheveled hospital to take stock of their arsenal against a potential epidemic.

title: Senate Plans Reopenings As Search Is Expanded
description: The Senate is seeking to return life to normal on Thursday by starting to reopen office buildings shut down after the discovery of the deadly poison ricin this week. Congressional leaders said Wednesday that extensive searches had so far turned up no new evidence of ricin and that none of the staff members exposed to the poison on Monday had become ill.

title: Edwards Campaigns in the South, but Looks Beyond, Too
description: With little rest and a raspy voice but a bounce in his step from his primary successes, Senator John Edwards on Wednesday rushed on to Tennessee and Virginia, which will hold the next primaries crucial to his candidacy.

description: CBS still faces the most substantial fallout from Janet Jackson's breast-baring episode during its broadcast of the Super Bowl on Sunday night: a Federal Communications Commission investigation, with the possibility of of substantial fines to CBS stations.

title: Got Dirt? Get Curatorial
description: LIKE most Americans, and certainly most men, I have always approached housecleaning in a desultory, if not explicitly amateurish, fashion. If a surface needed dusting, I damped an old cloth and dusted it. If the frame of a painting seemed grimy, I yanked it off the wall and gave it the once-over. If the rungs of a venerable chair were gathering soot, I cleaned them off and perhaps applied a thin coat of Pledge. That's how you cleaned furniture -- you dusted, you vacuumed, you polished. This wasn't rocket science.

description: JERUSALEM, Feb. 5 — The Israeli police questioned Prime Minister Ariel Sharon here today as part of a bribery investigation that could impede his plan for "unilateral disengagement" from the Palestinians and withdrawal from the Gaza Strip.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   TRIMBLE, HENRY WEEKS, JR.
description: TRIMBLE--Henry Weeks, Jr., Esq. Longtime resident of New York City was born June 6, 1920 in Montclair, N.J. and died January 31, 2004 from complications following surgery. Henry graduated from Princeton University, Yale University Law School and Harvard Business School. He served in the U.S. Army as a 2nd Lieutenant. He first practiced law in New York City with the firm of Cravath, Swaine & Moore and then became General Counsel and Secretary of IBM. He later became an investment banker at Hayden Stone. After his retirement, Henry continued practicing estate law. He and his wife Jane often traveled to their various homes in French Provence, the Caribbean Island of Anguilla and their country home in the Hamptons. Henry was a gifted pianist, singer and a devoted sports enthusiast. Mr. Trimble was a governor of the Metropolitan Club of New York City and a member of the Quogue Field Club and the Quogue Beach Club. He is survived by his loving wife of 20 years, Jane Imbs Trimble of New York City and devoted children, Pamela Mariani (John), of Bermuda, Henry Weeks Trimble III (Joan) of Charleston, S.C. and Neill Trimble (Blair) of Locust Valley, N.Y., brother Jim Trimble (Peggy) of Jacksonville, FL; 8 grandchildren and one great grandchild. Henry was dearly loved by all who knew him and he will be greatly missed. Services will be held at the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Ave (81st St), NYC on Thursday, February 5, at 1:30PM.

title: From Japan, Roofs of Grass and Ceilings of Bark
description: Fumihiko Maki (inset), the Pritzker Prize architect, will give the keynote speech at ''Technology and Tradition in Contemporary Japanese Architecture,'' a three-day symposium beginning Feb. 26 at the Japan Society. The symposium will present recent work by many architects, including Terunobu Fujimori, designer of the Camellia Castle (left), a winery with a grass roof; and a tearoom (far left, bottom) with a ceiling made of hanging strips of bark. Also among the 24 architects, critics and curators is Shuhei Endo, whose model for a museum competition (far left, top) has roofs of curved sheet steel. Ken Tadashi Oshima, an architectural historian who will participate, noted that Japanese architects tend to have ''inventive or far-out solutions.''

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Union City: Fire Ravages Row Of Buildings
description: A four-alarm fire tore through a row of stores and other businesses last night, according to the police. No one appeared to have been seriously injured in the fire, which began about 9:30 p.m. at 3617 Park Avenue on the eastern edge of Union City, said Detective Jose Martinez of the Union City Police Department. Thick smoke poured from the row of burning businesses, and firefighters were still battling the flames at 1 a.m. today. The fire partly destroyed buildings that stretched one block along Park Avenue near the border of Weehauken. The stores included a hardware store, a karate school and a bakery. Sabrina Tavernise (NYT)

title: Moyers and Others Want History Channel Inquiry Over Film That Accuses Johnson

In a book published last fall and again in a television documentary, one of President Lyndon B. Johnson's personal lawyers asserts that Vice President Johnson was complicit in the assassination of President John F. Kennedy.

title: The F.D.A. may ask drug advertisers to make information on side effects more prominent.

The proposals encourage the ads to describe significant risks the drugs may pose in language that is clearer and easier for patients to understand.

The disappearance and later charges that playmates had accidentally pushed the toddler into a hole left uncovered by construction workers, has dominated South African headlines. title: SETBACK FOR OPPONENTS OF AXA TAKEOVER OF MONY
description: Mony Group Inc., a life insurer in the process of being bought by AXA of France, said a federal court granted the company a temporary restraining order against two investors opposed to the $1.5 billion takeover. The order from the court, in the Southern District of New York, prevents Highfields Capital Management and Southeastern Asset Management from mailing duplicate proxy cards to shareholders before a Feb. 24 vote on the offer, said Mary Taylor, a Mony spokeswoman. At least three of Mony's four biggest shareholders are sending letters to shareholders urging them to oppose the buyout, which they say benefits Mony's executives more than investors. Southeastern planned to include a copy of a proxy card in its mailing to encourage opponents to vote, Southeastern's general counsel, Andrew McCarroll, said. ''If holders want to change their vote, management just made it harder,'' he said. A hearing on the order is set for tomorrow.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DALSHEIM, EDWIN A.
description: DALSHEIM--Edwin A., 77, leaves behind a family who loved him very much. He was a patriot, historian, and business man who was blessed with a ferocious sense of humor. He lived life exactly as he chose, honestly.

title: ANDRX SHARES FALL 8 PERCENT ON CHANGE OF LEADERSHIP
description: The Andrx Corporation's shares fell 8 percent yesterday after the company fired its chief executive, Richard Lane, and named a director, Thomas Rice, as his successor. The change ''was in no way associated with the company's financing, accounting or business condition,'' Mr. Rice said in a conference call with analysts and investors. ''The board felt we needed a certain different leadership to execute the plans in place.'' As of Tuesday, shares of Andrx, a maker of generic drugs, had fallen 44 percent since the company announced Mr. Lane's appointment as chief executive in May 2002. Legal and regulatory setbacks in the last 18 months have delayed the introduction of products like generic copies of Prilosec ulcer medicine made by AstraZeneca and Wellbutrin, the GlaxoSmithKline antidepressant. Stock in Andrx, based in Davie, Fla., fell $2.10, to $23.91 a share. The company announced the change after markets closed on Tuesday.

title: World Briefing | Asia: India: $5.5 Billion For The Military
description: India announced a $5.5 billion fund to modernize its armed forces. In recent months the government has completed several defense deals, including the $1.5 billion purchase a Russian-made aircraft carrier, the Admiral Gorshkov. India's booming economy is helping it to outspend by far its regional rival, Pakistan, on conventional weapons systems. Hari Kumar (NYT)

title: M. M. Kaye, 95, Novelist Who Evoked Raj

description: For years it was an article of faith for many Christians that the most powerful vehicle for bringing nonbelievers to Jesus was a Billy Graham crusade.

title: German Court Acquits Man Accused of Aiding 9/11 Attack
description: HAMBURG, Germany, Feb 5  A German court today acquitted a Moroccan man who was accused of aiding the Sept. 11 hijackers, saying that while it was not convinced of his innocence, the evidence was not strong enough for a conviction.

title: Sports of The Times; Marion Jones Returns To a Changed Sport
description: MARION JONES stood on a podium at the New York Athletic Club yesterday fielding questions from an audience of reporters and young runners. She talked about her comeback; her new baby, Tim; her excitement at competing in her first Millrose Games. Then the questions turned toward scandals that have engulfed the track world and have marginally involved her. What about her relationship with Charlie Francis? What about Balco and Victor Conte? What about the state of her sport?

title: KERR-McGEE TO CUT BACK ON OIL AND GAS EXPLORATION
description: The Kerr-McGee Corporation, which produces oil and natural gas, will cut spending on exploration by 14 percent in 2004. The company will spend $300 million this year on exploring for oil and gas, down from $350 million last year, David Hager, senior vice president for oil and gas exploration and production, said at an energy conference in Vail, Colo. The company's $7 billion oil and gas business accounts for more than 70 percent of total assets, Mr. Hager said. Kerr-McGee, based in Oklahoma City, has operations in Alaska, Wyoming, Colorado, the Gulf of Mexico, the North Sea, Brazil and China. Production ''growth is primarily focused on deepwater exploration,'' he said.

title: Computer-Related Shares Lead Major Gauges Lower
description: Stocks dropped yesterday, led by computer-related shares, as the Nasdaq composite index had its steepest drop since September.

title: In the Midst of a Kerry Juggernaut, Edwards Can Glimpse Some Daylight
description: Like his earlier successes in Iowa and New Hampshire, Senator John Kerry's victory in five primaries and caucuses from Delaware to Arizona on Tuesday was rooted in broad support among virtually all Democratic demographic groups, and in the strong conviction that he is the candidate best able to beat President Bush.

title: WITH PURCHASE, HARRIS BANK EXPANDS IN CHICAGO
description: Harris Bank of Chicago, a unit of the Bank of Montreal, has agreed to buy New Lenox State Bank of New Lenox, Ill., for $228.5 million as it expands in retail and small-business services in the Chicago area. New Lenox operates eight branches, with assets of $998 million. The Bank of Montreal has made 13 acquisitions in the United States in the last four years. With the New Lenox purchase, Harris will operate a total of 163 branches and 450 automated teller machines. Bernard Simon (NYT)

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: SERBIA: PARLIAMENT PICKS A SPEAKER The country's political deadlock appeared closer to being resolved as former foes joined forces to elect a new speaker of the Parliament. A month after elections failed to give any single party a big enough mandate to govern by itself, Dragan Marsican of the pro-reform Democratic Party of Serbia was elected speaker with 128 out of 245 votes cast after his party sought the help of the Socialists, the party of Slobodan Milosevic. There is still no agreement between the parties on the composition of a new government. Nicholas Wood (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: White Plains: Illegal Dumping Alleged
description: A construction company was accused yesterday of dumping the equivalent of hundreds of truckloads of illegal construction debris on a public golf course in White Plains, the county police commissioner, Thomas Belfiore, said. Riverkeeper, an environmental group, received a tip that demolition debris was being dumped at the Maplemoor Golf Course last fall, Mr. Belfiore said. County investigators discovered that a driver for Joseph Carducci Inc. had dumped about 70 cubic yards of illegal material for 14 months ending last October, Mr. Belfiore said. The driver, Adolfo Garufi, was charged with a misdemeanor. His employer, Joseph Carducci, denied that his driver had broken the law. Mr. Belfiore said that such material can be legally disposed of only in a solid-waste facility. Lydia Polgreen (NYT)

title: Haiti's Descent
description: Jean-Bertrand Aristide was once hailed as Haiti's democratic champion. Now, his second presidency is declining into despotism. Last year's legislative elections, faced with a threatened opposition boycott, never took place. The legislature has been dissolved, leaving Mr. Aristide free to rule by decree. Almost daily, street protesters demand the president's resignation and are met by armed pro-Aristide gangs and a thoroughly politicized police force. Over the past few months, some 50 people have been killed in the resulting street clashes.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: Suspect In Shootings Found Dead
description: A suspect in a shooting spree that wounded nine people at a Brooklyn diner last month was found dead, apparently a suicide, in an Albany apartment Wednesday afternoon after being surrounded by the police, the authorities said yesterday. After the suspect, Ramel Simmons, 23, had been tracked to the apartment, New York City and Albany police officers arrived to arrest him, the police said. After no response to police calls for two hours, tear gas was fired inside, and a fiber-optic camera showed Mr. Simmons dead on the floor with a 9-millimeter handgun, the police said. It is unclear whether Mr. Simmons shot himself before the police arrived or after the tear gas was used, the police said. The police had identified Mr. Simmons as one of two men who opened fire in the Galaxy Diner in East New York on Jan. 17, sending customers diving under tables for cover before taking jewelry and money and fleeing. Another suspect, Mark Blount of East New York, was arrested the following week. The police are seeking a third suspect, possibly a driver, an investigator said. Michael Wilson (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Bronx: Aid For Co-Op City

Bloomberg announced yesterday. The mayor said the city had altered its rules to allow the 15,372-unit complex to qualify for tax benefits in return for making repairs. Even with the tax break, officials said, tenants will still have to pay higher maintenance fees to pay for the repairs. Michael Cooper (NYT)

title: Partial Progress for the 9/11 Inquiry
description: The White House has wisely reversed its opposition to granting an extra two months of investigation time to the independent commission delving into the 9/11 terrorist attacks. Now President Bush should take the next step and order better cooperation with the investigators, who complain of being stymied in gaining full access to vital intelligence information related to the attacks. After opposing the creation of the outside investigation, then meeting its requests with resistance and delay, Mr. Bush was obliged to give the commission more time to do its work. His commendable reversal on this issue means that the new deadline for presenting an unclassified version of the panel's findings to the nation is July 26. This will come during the heat of the presidential campaign. But politics should not be allowed to overwhelm the public's need to finally receive the fullest accounting of the attacks and whether they could reasonably have been prevented.

title: MEDTRONIC SAYS SALES FELL SHORT OF PROJECTIONS
description: Medtronic, the world's largest maker of devices that regulate heartbeats, said quarterly sales rose less than it expected, setting off a 9 percent decline in its share price. Sales in Medtronic's third quarter, which ended Jan. 23, rose 15 percent, to $2.2 billion, the company said late Wednesday. In December, it said revenue might exceed analyst forecasts of $2.15 billion to $2.23 billion. The global market for defibrillators increased 20 percent in the quarter and Medtronic said growth for its unit that makes the products was slower than expected. Stock in Medtronic fell $4.75, to $47.25 a share.

title: National Briefing | West: California: Thousands Of Sardines Killed
description: A rare confluence of stormy weather and a large run of fish is being blamed for the deaths of thousands of sardines at the San Onofre nuclear power plant north of San Diego. About 13,590 pounds of sardines, which were apparently swimming close to shore to avoid rough seas, were killed in San Onofre's 1.7 million-gallon-a-minute ocean water cooling system. The death toll was probably the largest in the plant's history, a spokesman for Southern California Edison said. On a typical day, the cooling system kills about 200 pounds of fish. Chris Dixon (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Wallingford: No Toxins Found In Powder
description: Additional tests on a gray powder found in a Wallingford mail distribution center have turned up no threatening biological agents, the State Department of Public Health said yesterday. The department would not say what the substance was, but law enforcement officials identified it as wood ash. The substance was discovered on Monday when it leaked out of an envelope addressed to the Republican National Committee, the same day a white powder identified as ricin, a deadly poison, was found in a Senate mailroom in Washington. Previous tests on the Wallingford powder determined that it was not ricin. In 2001, a Wallingford mechanical mail sorter was contaminated with anthrax spores, which were found in a letter opened by a 94-year-old woman in Oxford, who later died. Stacey Stowe (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LASH, TRUDE
description: LASH--Trude. The Board of Directors and the Council of the Foundation for Child Development express their sadness at the loss of our distinguished colleague, Trude Lash, who made significant contributions to developing the field of childhood social indicators. She was the principal investigator of State of the Child: New York City I (1976) and II (1980), which presented for the first time comprehensive data about the quality of life for children living in New York City. These reports inspired similar examinations in cities and states throughout the United States, and highlighted the need for responsive public policies for children and their families. We wish to offer sympathy to her family and friends P. Lindsay Chase-Lansdale, Chair, Board of Directors Eleanor T. Elliott Chair of the Council Ruby Takanishi, President

title: Is Frozen Together The Same as Bonding?
description: WHEN a father agrees to take his twin teenage daughters on a ski trip he guarantees a memorable experience by having them stay in the family's unwinterized summer cabin in the Adirondacks. Little heat, no indoor plumbing and temperatures that hovered near minus 20. Memorable indeed. Page 2.

title: ELI LILLY WINS F.D.A. APPROVAL FOR TUMOR MEDICATION
description: Eli Lilly & Company said yesterday that it had won federal approval to sell a medicine that fights tumors linked to asbestos exposure. The Food and Drug Administration cleared Lilly's Alimta medication to treat pleural mesothelioma, a cancer in the lining of the lungs often caused by asbestos fibers. Alimta may eventually win approval for more uses if Lilly is successful in its research. Alimta is the first of four new drugs Lilly expects to have approved by mid-2004.

title: Nursing Home Where Patient Died Says Door to the Roof Should Have Been Locked
description: An elderly woman who died after being found on the roof of a Queens nursing home late Tuesday night got up there because a door either malfunctioned or had been left unlocked, nursing home officials said yesterday.

title: Citing Arms, Tory Leader Says Blair Should Quit
description: The leader of Britain's Conservative Party, Michael Howard, called on Prime Minister Tony Blair on Thursday to resign, charging that Mr. Blair had failed to ask fundamental questions about Saddam Hussein's weapons before taking the country into war.

description: A Brooklyn high school principal was taken to the hospital yesterday after he was knocked down in the hallway by a student trying to flee from the police, the authorities said. title: Schrder to Step Down as Party Chairman in Germany
description: BERLIN, Feb. 6  German Chancellor Gerhard Schroder, facing disaffection within his own party and hampered by persistently low public approval ratings, announced today that he would step down as chairman of the Social Democratic Party, while retaining the chancellorship.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Spain: Guerrilla Group Warning
description: The Basque separatist group E.T.A. has sent letters to foreign tour operators saying it will extend its summer campaign against tourist sites throughout the year, Interior Minister ngel Acebes said. In the letters, the group cited previous attacks on tourist destinations, including bombings last summer in Alicante and Benidorm, which wounded 13 people. Dale Fuchs (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   JOHNSON, JONES, THELMA
description: JOHNSON - JONES -- Thelma. Family, friends, and students mourn the passing of Thelma Johnson-Jones, 39, on Jan. 21, 2004. Ms. Johnson-Jones had worked for more than 13 years as math instructor for the STEP Program at the Columbia University School of Dental and Oral Surgery. She was a math teacher extraordinaire who will be remembered for her love of teaching children.

title: Experts Urge Bird Vaccination Against Flu
description: Three international health organizations yesterday urged countries in Asia where avian influenza is spreading to consider large-scale vaccination programs to protect billions of healthy birds.

title: Ex-Ogilvy Executive Admits to Overbilling
description: A former executive of Ogilvy & Mather Worldwide in New York, part of the WPP Group, has become the first person to plead guilty to charges of conspiring to defraud the government by overbilling the White House Office of National Drug Control Policy for work on its ad account.
