title: No Running Away, Either
description: Paul Fleischman's story THE ANIMAL HEDGE (Candlewick, $16.99; ages 5 to 9) is as simple as a folk song. Its illustrator, the Russian-born Bagram Ibatoulline, has followed the style of American folk painters of the 18th and early 19th centuries, and the result is as haunting as a loved melody. As the book opens, a farmer lives with his three sons in a peaceable kingdom of cows and chickens, pigs and sheep. His heart ''glowed like a hot wood stove'' with the love of animals; he and his boys sang as they worked. This idyll appears in ovals of color, set in sepia frames adorned with folk motifs, like a songbook or the pages of a family album. Then a drought comes. The pictures now glow with terrible heat, the animals' ribs show, and a heartbreaking little pig peers hopelessly at the bottom of a dry and empty wooden basin. The farmer is desolated; by the time rain and new growth return to the land, he has lost almost everything; the animals are gone, and the farmer has no money to buy more. He and his sons live in a tiny cottage, sharpening tools for a living. One day, preparing to trim his rough hedge, the farmer seems to discern the shapes of his vanished animals in his hedge and clips it to bring out their forms. Soon he is surrounded by green leafy cows, goats and sheep. The sweet and solemn story circles around until the farmer has back what was lost, the same but changed. The illustrations, apparently artless, are uncannily beautiful, filled with light and feeling. Beth Gutcheon

But now that the 1968 code is approaching middle age -- though it is still called the ''new'' code -- it is getting a face lift: a redesigned edition numbering almost a thousand pages that goes on sale on Wednesday.

The guys are more generic. Their style is ''laid back'' ''chill mode.'' They all have a picture of what they'll be doing in five years. And maybe because they make mostly A's and B's, angst is not high on their agenda. So who are their favorites? The Neptunes and 50 Cent and Missy Elliott. No surprise there. title: The Streets Where History Lives
description: Acre for acre, Lower Manhattan may be the most historic piece of real estate in America. Here the Sons of Liberty plotted revolution, the Stamp Act Congress met to defy taxation without representation, colonists exchanged fire with British ships in the harbor, and General Washington and his officers celebrated their victory. The first president was inaugurated here, and Congress, meeting at Federal Hall, wrote the Bill of Rights. In one remarkable moment in time, Washington, Jefferson, Madison and Hamilton all lived and worked in these narrow streets. For two centuries, this tiny quadrant was New York -- and the gateway to America for millions of immigrants.

title: Going Home to Discover the Face of Islam

title: Mr. Bush's Version
description: When Americans choose a president, their most profound consideration is whether a candidate can make the wisest possible decisions when it comes to war. In the case of George W. Bush, they will not only judge whether the invasion of Iraq was the right decision, but what our president has brought away from that experience. If there were misjudgments about the nature of Iraq's weapons programs or in the ways the administration presented that intelligence to the public, we need to know whether he recognizes them and has learned from them. Yesterday, in an interview with NBC's Tim Russert, after a week in which it became obvious to most Americans that the justifications for the war were based on flawed intelligence, Mr. Bush offered his reflections, and they were far from reassuring. The only clarity in the president's vision appears to be his own perfect sense of self-justification.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Traffic Agent Facing Charges
description: A New York City traffic enforcement agent was arrested yesterday on charges of slashing the tires of a neighbor's car. The car's owner said she and her boyfriend had seen the agent, Johanne Doliscar, 24, and her sister, Guardaline Doliscar, 26, slashing the tires on her Toyota Camry on Friday in St. Albans, Queens. Both sisters were arrested on charges of criminal mischief, and Johanne Doliscar was suspended from duty, the police said. The car's owner, Yolanda Auguste, 23, said she encountered her boyfriend's former girlfriend on Friday and the police were called to calm a dispute that followed. Later, Ms. Auguste said, she saw two women, both strangers, slashing her tires. She called to her boyfriend, Delepheche Pierre, 25, who recognized the women as cousins of his ex-girlfriend, she said. Shaila K. Dewan (NYT)

title: Soul Gazing
description: During the last presidential campaign, Condoleezza Rice criticized President Bill Clinton for too ''romantic'' a view of Russia's Boris Yeltsin, and at the outset of his administration, President Bush kept a chilly distance from President Vladimir Putin. But romance blossomed after Mr. Bush met Mr. Putin for the first time in June 2001 and proclaimed that he had seen into his soul. Now the ardor seems to be cooling again. On his recent trip to Moscow, Secretary of State Colin Powell lectured the Kremlin on not finding the ''essential balance'' between branches of government (read ''Putin has grabbed all the power'') and said Russia's policy in Chechnya was of concern (read ''the Kremlin ought to stop that bloody war'').

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HARRIS, LEONARD A.
description: HARRIS--Leonard A. 92, died Friday, in Norwalk, CT. Mr. Harris was a retired editor of the Norwalk Hour and served the City of Norwalk as a fire commissioner, a shellfish commissioner and Second Taxing District Commissioner. He also was a member of the Planning Commission and advisory panels for the Coastal Area Management and the Enterprise Zone. Mr. Harris served twice as Commodore and was a life member of The South Norwalk Boat Club. He was predeceased by his first wife, Jeanette Fainer Harris, and his second wife Elizabeth Rairden Harris. Surviving are three stepsons, Richard Ramsey of Norwalk, CT, Donald Ramsey of Newtown, CT, and Douglas Ramsey of Stratford, CT.

title: PEPSICO RAISES PROFIT FORECAST ON LOWER COSTS
description: PepsiCo Inc. raised its profit forecast for 2004 and revised earnings higher for the last two years because it overstated stock option expenses. Profit this year will be as much as $2.29 a share, or 1 cent more than expected, the company said. Earnings were increased 4 cents a share, to $2.05, for 2003 and 2 cents, to $1.68, for 2002, PepsiCo said. The company, which is based in Purchase, N.Y., said it had recalculated costs after correcting a computational error. PepsiCo said in December that it would start treating stock options as an expense.

title: OPEC Stresses Compliance With Quotas
description: Energy ministers gathering here on Monday for a meeting of OPEC members said stricter adherence to their current production quotas was needed to avoid a sharp decline in the price of oil this spring, signaling that formal output cuts could probably wait until next month.

title: National Briefing | Science And Health: No Conclusion On Porpoise Deaths
description: A preliminary federal investigation into the deaths of 11 harbor porpoises that washed ashore on the Puget Sound last May ended with scientists unable to determine whether a Navy sonar exercise played a role. Six of the porpoises were too badly decomposed to determine a cause of death, and three died of infections, the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration said. The other two suffered head injuries, which could have been caused by collisions with a ship. Anahad O'Connor (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Africa: South Africa: Minister Defends Garlic Aids Diet
description: The minister of health, Manto Tshabalala-Msimangagain, insisted that a diet of garlic, olive oil and lemon juice helps fend off the effects of AIDS, repeating a message denounced last year by a leading national medical journal as ''ill-considered advice'' not backed up by scientific data. Ms. Tshabalala-Msimang scolded reporters at a parliamentary briefing for their earlier ridicule of her prescription, saying that the three ingredients are ''absolutely critical'' to boosting the immune system and that as little as a monthly teaspoon of olive oil would reap benefits. Like President Thabo Mbeki, she has cast doubt on what most scientists call an irrefutable link between the HIV virus and AIDS. Estimates vary, but at least one in 10 South Africans is H.I.V.-positive. Michael Wines (NYT)

Mr. Sanford, a Republican, said that if he were called to service abroad, ''that goes with the territory.'' In a statement, he said he was ''a husband and a father first, a governor second and a reservist third.'' He is a logistical officer in the Medical Service Corps. A Greenville man had filed suit, citing a provision in the state's Constitution that prohibits governors from holding any other office or commission, except in the militia. title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Tunnel Operator Needs Funds
description: The operator of the Channel Tunnel, Eurotunnel, warned that it might not survive without another major overhaul of its debt as it cut the value of its assets and posted a net loss of 1.9 billion euros ($2.4 billion) for the full year. In an effort to increase traffic and revenue, Eurotunnel is proposing a cut in the tariffs that it charges rail operators to use the 10-year-old undersea link between France and Britain. But first, Eurotunnel wants its financial and industrial partners, including its banks, to help it shore up its balance sheet, which lists 9 billion euros of debt left over from its construction and delayed opening. Eurotunnel posted a net loss of 1.89 billion euros as a weak economy and a price war with ferry services battered its operating results.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   PARSONS, EVELYN HOLMES
description: PARSONS--Evelyn Holmes. Died peacefully at The Connecticut Hospice in Branford CT on February 2, 2004. She was born on October 7, 1919 in Manchester, NH, the only child of James Robertson and Lena (Eckhardt). She attended Manchester public schools and The University of New Hampshire, before moving to Boston, where she worked as a legal secretary at Hale and Doerr. She cofounded and operated Academic Year Abroad with her first husband, the late Stetson Holmes. She lived variously in New York City, Paris, France, Beirut, Lebanon, and Connecticut, spending the last two decades in Madison, as the loving wife of Howard L. Parsons, who predeceased her. She is survived by her daughter, Shelley Holmes, her son, Brian Holmes (and his wife Eugenie Jenkins), step sons William Parsons (and his wife, Margo), and George Parsons (and his wife, Delores), three grandchildren, and three stepgrandchildren. She will be remembered by those who knew her as a good and cheer ful friend with a gift for words, a wonderful sense of humor, and a love of reading, The New York Times Crossword Puzzle, gardening, gourmet cooking, entertaining, and serving as Treasurer of The Windermere Beautification Committee. A Memorial Service will be held at 3 P.M. on Saturday, February 21, in The Chapel of The First Congregational Church of Madison, which is located at 26 Meeting House Lane, in Madison, CT. Donations in her memory may be made to: The Connecticut Hospice, 100 Double Beach Road, Branford, CT 06405.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on Thursday about the decision by George J. Tenet, director of central intelligence, to publicly defend American intelligence on Iraq referred incorrectly to the reason given by Henry A. Kissinger for his resignation from a commission looking into the Sept. 11 attacks, a move that White House officials said influenced their approach to screening candidates for a commission to investigate intelligence operations under Mr. Tenet. (The error also appeared in a front-page article on Dec. 14, 2002.) Mr. Kissinger said he decided to step down because resolving potential conflicts of interest would have meant liquidating his consulting firm, Kissinger Associates, a step that he said would have unduly delayed the commission's work. He did not say he stepped down to avoid releasing a list of clients of his firm.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HOBERMAN, HENRY D.
description: HOBERMAN--Henry D., 89, biochemist and physician, on January 10, 2004. Dr. Hoberman was professor emeritus of biochemistry at the Albert Einstein College of Medicine. He was noted for his studies of pathways of hydrogen atoms in intermediary metabolism. He received his B.A. and PhD from Columbia University and MD from Harvard Medical School. At Columbia he was a member of the group that pioneered the use of stable isotopes in biochemistry. At Harvard, he conducted war related research. In 1947 he joined the faculty of Yale School of Medicine. In 1953 he became one of the founding members of the Albert Einstein College of Medicine, where he remained until his retirement in 1993. Dr. Hoberman was an attending physician in the Medical Clinic of the Jacobi Hospital, an affiliate of the Einstein. He is survived by his wife, Hilda Carnicero, his children John, David, Ruth and Michael and his grandchildren Steven, Richard, Madeline, Della & Langston.

It's the story of how Herb Brooks's cold-blooded coaching forged the 1980 United States Olympic hockey team that upset the Soviet Union and won the gold medal at Lake Placid during the cold war. title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SCHOLZ, ROBERT
description: SCHOLZ--Robert. The Rev. Dr. Pastor of Holy Trinity Lutheran Church, Manhattan, died on February 7 at age 65 from a brain tumor diagnosed last June. Born in West St. Paul, MN, Scholz received BA & PhD degrees from the University of Minnesota. He married Dorothy Mareck in 1961. Before entering the ministry he taught American History at the University of Washington in Seattle and was also affiliated with the AFSC and the Society of Friends (Quakers). In 1971 he became Director of Pendle Hall, a Quaker study center near Philadelphia. He then returned to his childhood faith and entered the Lutheran Theological Seminary in Philadelphia. Scholz was ordained a pastor of the LCA in 1976 and called to St. Paul's Lutheran Church in Land sdowne, PA. In 1979 he became chaplain and history professor at Wagner College, Staten Island. He was Senior Pastor of St. David's Lutheran Church in Massapequa Park, NY from 1985-96 and was called to Holy Trinity in 1997. He was a distinguished leader in the Metro NY Synod of the Evangelical Lutheran Church in America and author of several Lutheran historical publications. In strumental in the creation of the Commission for Gay & Lesbian Concerns, he was also its first Chairman. Known for healing ministries to individuals and congregations and dedicated to ecumenism, he was the first Lutheran ''Licensed to Officiate'' in the Episcopal Diocese of New York in 2003. He is survived by his loving wife Dorothy, son Charles M. Scholz, daughter Anna S. Godas, two grandchildren and sister Suzanne Walsh of St. Paul, MN. Funeral Service Wednesday February 11, 11am. Holy Trinity Lutheran Church, 65th and Central Park West. Viewing Tuesday February 10, at Nagel Funeral Home, 352 E. 87th St. (1st-2nd Ave), 2-5 & 7-9:00 p.m. Also, viewing in church 9:30-10:30 before the service. Memorials are requested for the Holy Trinity Centennial Fund, 3 West 65th Street, NYC 10023. Inquiries: 212-877-6815

Outside candidates will also be considered and a decision is to be announced before midyear, Foster's said. Mr. Kunkel, 60, transformed the century-old brewer with the purchase of Beringer Blass Wine Estates in 2000, building a business that now accounts for 44 percent of profits.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FEIN, IRENE
description: FEIN--Irene, 81, of Hollywood, FL, formerly of Merrick, NY, passed away February 9th, 2004. Beloved wife of Harold Fein. Cherished grandmother of Shana and Tori Sterken. Chapel services Friday, February 13th, 9:45 AM, at Parkside Memorial Chapel, 98-60 Queens Blvd., Forest Hills, New York, 718-896-9000.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   TABLER, WILLIAM BENJAMIN
description: TABLER--William Benjamin. Age 89 of Upper Brookville, NY retired head of William B. Tabler Architects died Tuesday, February 3, 2004. Graduate of Harvard University, B.S. Cum Laude, 1936, M. Arch. 1939. Survived by his wife of 67 years, Phyllis Baker Tabler, his children, William B. Tabler, Jr. and Judith Tabler Cook, and three grandchildren, W. Benjamin Tabler, III, Rebecca Kelsey Roby, and Parker B. Kelsey. Mr. Tabler was the architect of over 400 hotels worldwide, including the Hiltons in New York and Washington, and more recently the Brooklyn Marriott. During WWII, Mr. Tabler served in the Navy and supervised the construction of the airstrips on Saipan and Tinian used for the B-29 bombers. He was the recipient of the Horatio Alger award, a Fellow of AIA, ASCE, Royal Institute of British Architects. He was a member of the Piping Rock Club and Royal and Ancient Golf Club of St Andrews. Interment private. Memorial service at a later date.

description: The Postal Service's mail-sorting plant here, which was contaminated with anthrax in 2001, is now clear of the poison after being fumigated with chlorine gas last year, the service announced Monday.

title: World Briefing | Africa: South Africa: Election Date Announced
description: President Thabo Mbeki set April 14 for general elections, which are widely expected to give his African National Congress continued control of Parliament and most provincial legislatures. The congress holds about two-thirds of the seats in Parliament; retaining that control in April would all but ensure that the body would re-elect Mr. Mbeki to a second five-year term as president. Michael Wines (NYT)

title: A Mind Emerges Joyfully After Years Lost in a Cloud
description: Late one night in August 1994, I tumbled down the stone steps outside the United Nations headquarters as I was leaving a wedding party in the delegates' dining room. As I rolled down the steps, people seemed to step aside politely, the better to clear a path. The back of my head struck the last step with a resonating crack. I can still hear it almost 10 years later like a malevolent echo.

title: Corrections

title: Bronx Courts to Merge in Pilot Project to Trim Backlogs
description: Chief Judge Judith S. Kaye announced on Monday that she would merge the state criminal courts and supreme courts in the Bronx in a pilot project meant to respond to a steep drop in felonies and a surge in misdemeanors over the past decade.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: 7 Arrested In Drownings
description: The police arrested five men and two women on suspicion of manslaughter in connection with the deaths of 19 people, mostly Chinese immigrants, who drowned in tidal surges last week while digging for shellfish in northwest England. The police have said they believe that some victims were illegal immigrants working for a trafficking gang. A bill was introduced in Parliament that would crack down on work-gang masters. Lizette Alvarez (NYT)

Founder/President of Gardner Corporation, Atlantic City Knitting Company and Colebrook, Inc. Survived by his loving wife of 66 years, Marjorie, his children, Stephen, Daniel and Sally, their spouses Leyla, Donna and Bill, and grandchildren Jacob, Aaron, Noah and Ezra. title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Trenton: Man Accused Of Sex Crime
description: A Florida man has been arrested and accused of traveling to New Jersey to have sex with under-age girls. The man, Dennis P. DelPriore, 41, of Daytona Beach, was arrested on Friday in a Mount Laurel hotel room, where the authorities said they found a stun gun, sex toys and Viagra. They said that Mr. DelPriore had met a 13-year-old girl in an online chat room and had arranged to see her Friday. On Thursday, he traveled to New Jersey and later followed the girl's school bus, officials of the United States Attorney's Office said. During a search of Mr. DelPriore's home in Florida, a list of girls, all of whom appeared to be under age, was discovered, a United States prosecutor said. Mr. DelPriore was charged with crossing state lines to engage in sex with a minor. His lawyer did not return a call for comment. Stacy Albin (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Consumer Spending Rises
description: Retail and wholesale spending rose in December for the first time in 11 months, the National Statistical Office said. The agency reported a rise of 0.6 percent from December 2002, possibly indicating that consumer spending will lift the country's sluggish economy. But economists urged caution in their outlook because the credit card debts of consumers remain high. Sam Len (NYT)

title: National Briefing | New England: Massachusetts: First Woman To Lead Boston Police
description: Kathleen O'Toole, a former state secretary of public safety, has been appointed commissioner of the Boston Police Department. Ms. O'Toole, the first woman to hold the position, will succeed Paul Evans, who left for a job with the British government. Ms. O'Toole, who spent seven years on the Boston police force, runs a consulting firm. She takes the job as the Boston police face scrutiny about rioting after the Super Bowl and about security preparations for the Democratic convention in July. Katie Zezima (NYT)

title: Mexican Honor And Olympics On Line vs. U.S.
description: For Mexico's beleaguered people, Tuesday's soccer match between Mexico and the United States in Guadalajara is about much more than winning a place in the Summer Olympics in Athens.

title: ABBOTT LABS CLEARED TO MAKE DIAGNOSTIC PRODUCTS
description: Abbott Laboratories won federal approval of 11 products used to identify diseases like hepatitis and prostate cancer, overcoming a delay caused by manufacturing violations. The tests should reach markets within six months, a company spokeswoman, Rhonda Luniak, said. Abbott is rolling out new products and returning 60 others to the market after manufacturing at a plant in Illinois was halted by the Food and Drug Administration in 2000 on quality concerns. The agency said the plant met its standards in December, clearing the way for the approvals.

title: In Nassau, the Challenge of a Scandal for a County Executive Who Promised Reform
description: Thomas R. Suozzi wore the mantle of reform when he swept into office in 2002 as Nassau's first Democratic county executive in three decades, promising to solve a fiscal crisis and clean up corruption.

Born of the politics of the cold war, the Berlinale, as it is known, continues to address serious political and social issues.

title: Beyond Brrr: The Elusive Science of Cold
description: For tens of thousands of years, nobody knew how cold it was. They knew about ice and snow and the danger of freezing to death, but no one had thermometers. Instead, they used metaphors, often vulgar, to describe what the cold could do.

description: BOSTON  Travel guides like to compare Boston's Newbury Street to Rodeo Drive in LA or Fifth Avenue in New York, but the locals will tell you Newbury is neither of those places.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: India: Growth Forecast Surges
description: India's gross domestic product is estimated to grow at a rate of 8.1 percent in the fiscal year ending in March 2004, making India's one of the fastest-growing economies in the world. Advance data released by the government's Central Statistical Organization said growth would be helped by the farm sector, which was expected to grow by 9.1 percent, compared with a drop of 5.2 percent a year ago. Manufacturing is expected to grow 7.1 percent compared with 6.2 percent a year ago. India's economic output grew 4 percent in the year that ended in March 2003. Saritha Rai (NYT)

title: Labor Raises Pressure on California Supermarkets
description: Four months into one of the biggest labor disputes in decades, the union representing 70,000 striking or locked-out Southern California supermarket workers is waging an increasingly confrontational -- some say desperate -- campaign to fend off cuts in members' health care benefits.

Barbecue dinners with friends at the Pearl Continental Hotel. Picking up paan, a South Asian blend of mints and spices, made specially for him by a local shopkeeper.

title: Koreans Look to China, Seeing a Market and a Monster
description: After a century of looking east, first to Japan and then to the United States, Korean business leaders are now gazing west, to China. But it is a fascination tinged with fear.

title: E.P.A. Raises Estimate of Babies Affected by Mercury Exposure
description: More than one child in six born in the United States could be at risk for developmental disorders because of mercury exposure in the mother's womb, according to revised estimates released last week by Environmental Protection Agency scientists.

description: For more than a decade, a small group of businessmen contributed tens of thousands of dollars to the campaigns of their county commissioners in Luzerne County, a waning coal center in eastern Pennsylvania. description: Three members of a group that tried to enter Afghanistan to fight against American forces after the attacks of Sept. 11, 2001, were sentenced in federal court in Portland. Judge Robert E. Jones of Federal District Court sentenced Maher Hawash, 39, a former engineer at Intel, to seven years in prison for conspiring to aid the Taliban. Two brothers, Ahmed Bilal, 26, and Muhammad Bilal, 24, were sentenced to 10 years and 8 years, respectively, for conspiracy and other crimes. Three other members of the group have already been sentenced, and a fourth remains a fugitive. Matthew Preusch (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on Thursday about the decision by George J. Tenet, director of central intelligence, to publicly defend American intelligence on Iraq referred incorrectly to the reason given by Henry A. Kissinger for his resignation from a commission looking into the Sept. 11 attacks, a move that White House officials said influenced their approach to screening candidates for a commission to investigate intelligence operations under Mr. Tenet. (The error also appeared in a front-page article on Dec. 14, 2002.) Mr. Kissinger said he decided to step down because resolving potential conflicts of interest would have meant liquidating his consulting firm, Kissinger Associates, a step that he said would have unduly delayed the commission's work. He did not say he stepped down to avoid releasing a list of clients of his firm.

title: The Ethics Panel Stirs
description: The House ethics committee, one of Washington's more rubber-toothed watchdogs, will soon hold its first meeting in four months, with Republicans explaining that there simply hasn't been much to talk about. That's true only if you ignore two major ethics issues that have cropped up in those months. But it's not all that surprising that the committee is reluctant to deal with them because one involves last year's biggest piece of legislation and the other one of the most powerful members of Congress.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: Bill On Health Coverage For Entertainment Workers Vetoed
description: Gov. George E. Pataki vetoed a bill yesterday that would have required the state to subsidize continued health care coverage for out-of-work entertainment industry employees. The bill would have required that $2.5 million in state funds be made available to help employees of theaters, circuses, and the music, film and recording industries, among others, according to a memorandum released by Mr. Pataki's press office. Assemblyman Richard L. Brodsky, a Westchester County Democrat and a co-sponsor of the bill, said last night that it was being amended to address criticisms and that it would be resubmitted today. ''We've got to keep New York livable for people in the entertainment business, and this was crucial,'' he said. Sabrina Tavernise (NYT)

title: Psychiatric Patients And a Maze Of Language
description: ''The Flu Season'' begins in darkness. Light comes up on a white set: floor, back wall, one table, four chairs. The set doesn't take up the whole stage area, though. It looks as if it could be snapped shut and hauled off like a suitcase, leaving us in the dark again. That's what the playwright, Will Eno, wants. The first voice we hear tells us: ''I could leave it all alone. I could let us shudder by ourselves. Leave us uncomforted by the shaky fiction of anything shared, of any common story. I could let us wreck ourselves in the dark, shiver closer to death, slowly, unnoticeably, instead of making such a big production out of it. But I won't.''

title: National Briefing: South
description: NORTH CAROLINA: BOARD DELAYS STATE PRIMARY The State Board of Elections voted to postpone the state's primary to July 20 from May 4, and the Democratic Party said it would instead hold county caucuses on April 17 to vote on presidential candidates. Under the May primary schedule, filing for candidates would have begun Monday, but the state is waiting for federal judges to approve district maps drawn by the Legislature. State courts declared previous maps unconstitutional, and in 2002 the state used maps drawn up by a judge. Ariel Hart (NYT)

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: TURKEY: WOMAN SURVIVES WEEK IN RUBBLE A critically injured 24-year-old woman was pulled out alive after being buried for a week in the rubble of a collapsed apartment building in the central city of Konya where 89 people died. Rescuers worked for four hours to free her, and she was cheered as she was carried to an ambulance. On Sunday, teams found a 16-year-old boy who survived under the rubble. (AP)

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Alcan's Profit Rises
description: The Alcan aluminum and packaging group reported net fourth-quarter earnings of $143 million, up from $26 million a year earlier. Operating earnings grew by 9 percent. title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KEBBON, RICHARD A., JR.

title: Mr. Bush's Revisionism

In a preview of how his campaign will respond to complaints about the huge deficit and overall job losses, Mr. Bush defended his tax cuts as ways to stimulate the economy, blamed Congress for not getting spending under control and made vague promises about avoiding catastrophic red ink in the long run by reforming Medicare and Social Security. None of what we heard made much sense.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   PARSA, MOHAMAD H., M.D.
description: PARSA--Mohamad H., M.D., Professor of Clinical Surgery, Columbia University, College of Physicians and Surgeons and Director of the Trauma Center, Harlem Hospital Center passed away February 9th at the age of 64. An avid teacher and writer, he dedicated the majority of his professional efforts to total parenteral nutrition and is credited with its implementation and usage in New York State in the late 1960s. Personal interests included philosophy, poetry, and religion although his loyalty and dedication rested with his profession. A departmental commendation awarded June 2003 reads, ''Mohamad will forever be remembered as a distinguished surgeon and extraordinary human being who deprived himself of sleep and comfort in order to serve humanity''. He is survived by his wife, Gretchen and his son, Cyrus who reside in Bronxville, NY. Visiting hours will be held at the Whalen & Ball Funeral Home, 168 Park Avenue, Yonkers, NY on Thursday evening, February 12 from 7-9PM.

title: Walking a Beat in Tikrit
description: We had walked just a few blocks into this northern Iraq city when Capt. Jason Deel of the Fourth Infantry Division paused to show me where an improvised explosive device (the military term for a homemade bomb) had blown a large hole in the sidewalk. It was late January, I was back in the country on my third visit with our soldiers, and Captain Deel had invited me on a night patrol with his remarkable platoon: a combined unit of American and Iraqi soldiers.

title: The President's Guard Service
description: If President Bush thought that his release of selected payroll and service records would quell the growing controversy over whether he ducked some of his required service in the Air National Guard three decades ago, he is clearly mistaken. The payroll records released yesterday document that he performed no guard duties at all for more than half a year in 1972 and raise questions about how he could be credited with at least 14 days of duty during subsequent periods when his superior officers in two units said they had not seen him.

title: In a City of Pleasures, Clothes That Curb Them
description: In two weeks, the HBO series ''Sex and the City'' will become part of television's past, and with it will go a certain fantasy of what it means to get dressed in New York. The fantasy had little do with the clothes actually worn in the show, which often must have seemed as ludicrous to viewers on West 94th Street as they did to those in Tallahassee. For every time Carrie Bradshaw hailed a taxi in a perfect Oscar de la Renta cocktail dress, there were occasions on which she left home looking like a World War I nurse or an inverted potted plant or a lamentable collision between Fidel Castro and the Hindu goddess Lakshmi.

description: HOBERMAN -- Henry, D., M.D., Ph.D. Albert Einstein College of Medicine of Yeshiva University records with profound sorrow the passing of our distinguished professor emeritus of biochemistry. A member of our founding faculty, in 1953, Dr. Hoberman, was instrumental in helping the College attain its status early on as one of the leading medical schools in the country. An outstanding scientist with particular expertise in kinetics and physical biochemistry, he was also a dedicated physician who for more than two decades cared for patients at our affiliated hospital, Jacobi Medical Center. His warmth and optimism touched all who knew him. We extend our deepest sympathies to his wife, Hilda, his children John, David, Ruth and Michael and his five grandchildren. Dominick P. Purpura, M.D. The Marilyn and Stanley M. Katz Dean Albert Einstein College of Medicine

title: Recipes From Friends of Bill
description: Bill Clinton, more than any other recent President, was known for his hearty appetite, so as Presidents' Day approaches, a look at ''The Clinton Presidential Center Cookbook'' is called for. Edited by Shannon Butler and Nealon DeVore and costing $24.95, the book raises funds for the William J. Clinton Presidential Foundation, which supports the center and library to be built in Little Rock, Ark. In the book are 250 recipes, heavily weighted toward Southern specialties like grits, jambalaya and pecan pie. They came from friends, celebrities, relatives and officials in the Clinton administration, including James Carville, Mary Steenburgen, Betty Currie, Leon Panetta and Al and Tipper Gore. Some are as simple as Whoopi Goldberg's Malibu Beach Buffet, which consists of buying takeout salads, but others are more elaborate, like Jayni and Chevy Chase's cauliflower soup with croutons. And, of course, there is the recipe for Hillary Rodham Clinton's chocolate chip cookies.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   NEUMARK, MICHAEL
description: NEUMARK--Michael. Who applied his marketing acumen to help bring institutional equity trading into the technological age, died suddenly on February 8 at his home in Pleasantville, NY. He was 60. Mr. Neumark was senior vice president and director of marketing for Investment Technology Group, Inc., the New York-based institutional brokerage and technology developer. He worked for many years at Dean Witter, where he was vice president. Foreseeing that computer technology would reshape the brokerage industry, he then joined Instinet, where he was instrumental in launching The Crossing Network, the nation's first electronic trade crossing system. In 1992 he joined the Investment Technology Group, (ITG), then a start-up subsidiary of Jefferies & Company. ''We were a neophyte company trying to invent a new business category, and he had vast experience in marketing,'' said Raymond L. Killian, retired chairman of ITG. ''By helping us position the company effectively, he made an invaluable contribution to our business.'' ''He was well known and highly respected in the industry,'' said Robert J. Russel, ITG's chief executive officer. ''Everyone knew him as having tremendous integrity and a deep understanding of the nature of equity trading. He did a great deal to shape the evolution of our firm.'' ITG today is listed on the New York Stock Exchange. Mr. Neumark also served on the Board of Directors of the Arbitrage Fund since the company's inception. He was active in various industry and charitable groups, and was most closely involved in the Children's Cancer Fund. Mr. Neumark graduated from Brooklyn College in 1963, earning his B.S. degree in accounting. He served two years of active duty and six years of inactive duty in the U.S. Naval Air Reserve. He is survived by Jody Neumark, his cherished wife of over 29 years, his loving children, Elisa Kirkpatrick and Brett Neumark, and his caring sister, Myra Bloom. Mike was an avid golfer who loved life, his family and friends. Our lives will not be the same without him. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions in his memory may be made to the Children's Cancer Fund, P.O. Box 658, Millwood, NY 10546. Funeral services will be held at Hawthorne Funeral Home, 21 Stevens Ave, Hawthorne, NY Wednesday 11AM. Interment to follow Kensico Cemetery.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Iowa: Judge Strikes Sex Offender Law
description: Iowa's two-year-old law banning sex offenders from living within 2,000 feet of a school or child care center was found unconstitutional by a federal judge. The judge, Robert W. Pratt of Federal District Court, said that the law infringed on offenders' due process rights and that it was unlawfully retroactive. The law, enacted in 2002, was intended to keep offenders away from children, but critics, including the American Civil Liberties Union, said it effectively banished offenders from 30 percent of the towns in the state. title: MERCK TO BUY RIGHTS TO DANISH INSOMNIA DRUG

Merck said it intended to apply for regulatory approval of gaboxadol in late 2006 to mid-2007.

title: An Environmental Deficit

This is good news, assuming that Congress heeds his call for restraint. In most other respects, the environment fared poorly in this budget -- not surprising, given Mr. Bush's failure to mention the issue in his State of the Union address, but disheartening just the same.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Bronx: 3 Shot On Street
description: An argument outside a laundry in the Bronx last night ended in a shooting in which three people, two of whom may have been innocent bystanders, were injured, the police said. None of the victims' wounds was life-threatening. About 11:30 p.m., the police answered reports of shots fired in front of 610 Castle Hill Avenue. Two men had been fighting, and one, who the police said was 23, fired shots from a revolver and from a semiautomatic gun. The shots wounded the man he was fighting with, as well as another man and a woman, the police said. It was not immediately clear if the other man and woman were involved in the fight. Police officers arrested the man they believe was the shooter. Sabrina Tavernise (NYT).

title: Beloved by Czars, Capitalists and One Mother Hen
description: SHE played mother hen for three decades to Malcolm Forbes's felicitous collection of nine Faberg eggs and other bejeweled baubles, snapped up en masse this month by Russia's fourth-richest mogul for around $100 million before Sotheby's even got it to the auction block. So the curator Margaret Kelly Trombly might be allotted a few postpartum pangs. No more imperial eggs, synonymous with the heyday of czarist Russia and the romantic tragedy of Nicholas and Alexandra, to tend? It seems impossible not to think of this as a whole new spin on the empty-nest syndrome; since Ms. Trombly is a careerist and feminist who didn't marry until she was 48, and is childless, this is her only spin on it. She's bearing up well.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   TOLLES, THEODORE L. (TERRY)
description: TOLLES--Theodore L. (Terry), of New Hartford, NY died suddenly on February 7th, 2004 at his home. He was born on March 4, 1938 in Chestertown, MD, the son of Winton and Patricia Doyle Tolles. A graduate of Clinton High School, Williams College 1957 and Harvard Law School 1960, Terry served in the U.S. Army from 1960-1961. He married Jacqueline McCormack on January 2nd, 1963. She predeceased him on November 4th, 1993. Mr. Tolles worked for a New York law firm, before returning to upstate New York in 1963 as a law clerk to Judge John Gualtieri. Over the course of the next several years he pursued an extensive career in business and the law in Utica and New York City. He worked with Mohawk Data Sciences, Cosgrove-Kinney Corp, the Cogar Corp., McCartney and Tolles Inc., the Indium Corp and in 1991 joined the law firm of Kowalczyk Tolles & Deery. He was active in local and state politics as a Democratic committeeman for the town of New Hartford, Oneida Cty and New York State. He served on the Board of Trustees of Utica College and the House of Good Shepherd, and he was the local radio color commentator for Hamilton College basketball games. His survivors include his daughters and their husbands, Tracy Ann and Donald Rueckert, and Terrill Lynn Tolles and Chris Surace of New Hartford; a sister Patricia and her husband David Smalley of Larchmont, a brother Tony and his wife Carmen Tolles of Glen Ridge, NJ, two beloved granddaughters Jacque and Patricia Rueckert, his aunt Mrs. James Doyle of Clinton, an uncle Roy and aunt Martha Tolles of San Marino, CA, Alexander Anisimov of Moscow, Russia, nephews Brian and Gregory Smalley, and Christopher Tolles and several cousins. His funeral mass will be celebrated Thursday, February 12th, at St. John the Evangelist Church of New Hartford. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Jacque and Terry Tolles Scholarship Fund at Utica College, 1600 Burrstone Rd, Utica NY 13502.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Bombardier Gets Orders
description: Bombardier Inc., the world's third-biggest maker of commercial airplanes, received a $293 million order for 12 aircraft from the commuter airline SkyWest Inc. SkyWest will buy 10 50-seat CRJ-200 regional jets and 2 70-seat CRJ-700's. The contract brings SkyWest's firm orders with Bombardier to 110 of the smaller jets and 32 of the larger ones, Bombardier said. Bombardier, based in Montreal, needs orders for its so-called regional jets that carry 50 to 90 passengers to maintain an investment-grade credit rating. SkyWest, based in St. George, Utah, is a commuter carrier for the UAL Corporation's United Airlines and Delta Air Lines Inc. It will add the Bombardier aircraft to its United Express operations.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KANTOR, THOMAS
description: KANTOR--Thomas. The faculty and staff of NYU School of Medicine, Division of Rheumatology, express their deep sadness over the death of Thomas Kantor, M.D., a distinguished member of the faculty for over 50 years. Dr. Kantor achieved international recognition for his contributions to rheumatology, especially for his seminal descriptions of connective tissue diseases and their treatments. Dr. Kantor, who embodied the finest traditions of the medical profession throughout his career, was an inspiring teacher and raconteur. Generations of NYU-trained rheumatologists will always treasure his morning rounds at Bellevue Hospital where with wit and wisdom he taught them that the secret of patient care was to care for the patient. Dr. Kantor will always be remembered with respect and admiration. Our deepest sympathies go to his wife, Deirdre, and the entire Kantor family. Steven Abramson, M.D., Director, Division of Rheumatology Gerald Weissmann, M.D., Director Emeritus, Division of Rheumatology Arthur Fox, M.D., Director Emeritus, Division of Cardiology NYU School of Medicine

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FRANCAIS, JACQUES PIERRE
description: FRANCAIS--Jacques Pierre. Died on February 4, 2004 in New York City at the age of 80 after a long battle with Parkinson's disease. He is survived by his wife Beatrice Mathews Francais, his daughter Isabelle Francais, his granddaughter Daniella Valentine Saarma and two stepdaughters Hilary and Diana Combs. Jacques was born in 1923 in Paris emigrating to the United States in 1948. He became one of the leading dealers of stringed instruments in the United States and a world recognized expert. A funeral service will be held at Frank E. Campbell at 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street on Wednesday, February 11 at 11:30AM. In lieu of flowers please send contributions to Young Concert Artists Inc., 250 West 57 St, Suite 1222, NYC, NY 10107-0103.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CARPENTER, H.
description: CARPENTER -- H. Daniel. Hudson Guild marks with great sadness the passing of Dan Carpenter, age 95. Dan joined the Guild in 1931, serving as executive director from 1943 until 1973. Upon his retirement he served as a trustee for 18 years. His impact on the Guild and on Chelsea was extraordinary; in addition, he was a major leader in the Settlement House movement and a true pioneer for many social issues, most notably affordable housing. Dan was admired for his wit, astuteness, and tenacity and was consulted by many even after his relocation to Arizona last year. Lee Buckley, President Paul F. Balser, Chairman Janice McGuire, Executive Director

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Suspected Skinheads Attack Tajik Family
description: A gang of teenagers in St. Petersburg attacked a family from Tajikistan, stabbing a 9-year-old girl to death and badly injuring her father and her 7-year-old cousin, a police spokesman said. The attackers, reportedly drunken skinheads, escaped. Violence by neo-Nazi and other xenophobic gangs is common in St. Petersburg and other Russian cities, but the brutality of the act prompted unusually strong denunciations by the city's leaders. Steven Lee Myers (NYT)

Beloved and loving wife for 64 years of the late Rabbi Murry S.; devoted daughter of Abraham Max & Fannie Beatrice Stavisky; cherished mother of Andrea & David Rosen, Monty & Yael, Jordan, and Sharon & Joseph Kaplan; adored grandmother of Alexis, Amanda & Steven, Avery, Avi & Rochelle, Talya & David, Yonina & Mark, Ayelet, Ariel & Shifra Chana, Micole, Daniele, Raquel & Jason, and Gabrielle; doting great-grandmother of Kevin, Daniel, Jamie, Ari, Rinat, Leah, Bat-Ami, Nachshon, Elisha, Orli, Ariella, Elisheva, Ilana, Chananel, and Moriah; respected machateynesta of Gertrude & Simon Kaplan and the late Nathalie & Clement Rosen and Leah & Abraham Goodman; client of the caring and dedicated Kim Gordon. description: It is as if someone took a broomstick to a hornet's nest under the eaves, as far as Colorado College Coach Scott Owens is concerned.

description: A compromise was reached on Tuesday to allow 30 college students here to compete for Fulbright scholarships even though their applications were late because of a missed Federal Express pickup.

title: Clintons Business-Aid Plan Expanding Beyond Harlem
description: Former President Bill Clinton's office in Harlem is expanding to Brooklyn and the Bronx, a program that has helped small businesses in the neighborhood.

title: One of the Biggest Is Best in Show
description: A Newfoundland named Josh, a serene, lumbering black working dog, won the Westminster Kennel Club's best in show at Madison Square Garden last night, the second victory ever for the breed.

title: No 'Smoking Guns' in Reports, Head of Sept. 11 Panel Says
description: The chairman of the commission on the Sept. 11 attacks said Tuesday that there were ''no smoking guns'' in classified Oval Office intelligence reports to suggest that President Bush and senior White House aides fumbled intelligence warning of the possibility of a terrorist strike before the attacks.

title: Mets Infielders Speak the Same Language on the Field
description: Al Jackson, an original Met and now a spring training coach, looked on with admiration Tuesday as the team's celebrated middle-infield twosome took ground balls together for the first time. The Mets are hoping they will ultimately develop into the National League's premier double-play combination.

title: A Matronly Aesthetic With a Subversive Twist
description: Halfway through the Marc Jacobs show on Monday night, around 10:30, it probably hit some of the older men in the audience at the New York State Armory on Lexington Avenue that they were witnessing a frightening vision of their mothers. Years of waking up in a cold bath of sweat, of running from the old ball and chain, and here she was, amid the cool kids at Marc Jacobs, a vision in crepey Wheatena lace with a lynx cape thrown over her shoulders and a red velvet ribbon sagging gloriously at her bosom. Well, for those men, there is no other way to look at Mr. Jacobs's collection of matron tweeds and scoop-back dresses in jolly turquoise lace except as a limited-interest category.

title: Ex-Executive For Chrysler Defends Merger
description: A former Chrysler chief financial officer, Gary Valade, testified Tuesday that he had not been ''snookered'' by the 1998 merger of Chrysler with Daimler-Benz.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LEVINE, BURT
description: LEVINE--Burt, 75, died peacefully February 7th. Loving brother, uncle, grand-uncle, cousin, friend. We will miss his kind and gentle personality and his wonderful piano playing.

title: ARTS BRIEFING: HIGHLIGHTS
description: A NEW JOB -- Just weeks after he stepped down as president and chief executive of Arista Records, Antonio Reid, as expected, has landed as chairman of the Island Def Jam Music Group. Mr. Reid, left, succeeds Lyor Cohen, who recently joined Time Warner Music as chief of North American operations. During his four years at Arista, Mr. Reid fostered the careers of artists like Avril Lavigne, Pink and Dido and led the label to 31 Grammy nominations this year. OutKast, a hip-hop duo Mr. Reid discovered nearly a decade ago, won album of the year and rap album Grammys on Sunday evening. Mr. Reid's sudden departure from Arista caught many in the industry by surprise. Huge financial losses were said to have played a part in his decision to resign. Doug Morris, chief executive of the Universal Music Group, described Mr. Reid in a statement as ''a multidimensional music man and entrepreneur, whose hallmarks have been a deep love of music and an incredibly successful track record in building the careers of world-class artists.'' LOLA OGUNNAIKE

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Cognizant Profit Rises 94%
description: The Cognizant Technology Solutions Corporation, which manages computer systems and writes software with a staff predominantly based in India, said yesterday that fourth-quarter profit almost doubled as sales gained 61 percent. Net income rose to $17.7 million, or 25 cents a share, from $9.14 million, or 14 cents, a year earlier. Sales increased to $108.2 million from $67 million. The company's workers in India are paid as little as one-fifth as much as their American counterparts, executives have said. Cognizant, based in Teaneck, N.J., will hire 4,000 people in India this year. The company has been able to raise prices, while many American rivals have cut theirs as competition increases.

title: PeopleSoft Says Justice Dept. Is Urged to Block Oracle Bid
description: Staff lawyers at the Department of Justice are recommending that the agency seek to block the Oracle Corporation's $9.4 billion hostile takeover of PeopleSoft Inc. on the grounds that the deal would be anticompetitive, PeopleSoft said late Tuesday.

title: After a Year, Students Take a Second Look at the Iraq Invasion
description: One year ago, when the nation's schoolhouses echoed with debate about imminent war, two Normal Community High School freshmen shared a moral certainty that it was America's duty to invade Iraq and destroy weapons of mass destruction. Today they could hardly disagree more.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BIMEL, NATALIE
description: BIMEL--Natalie. The Board and staff of the Correctional Association mourn the untimely death of Natalie Bimel, our friend and colleague in advocating on behalf of the vulnerable and powerless people caught up in the criminal justice system. Natalie's tireless commitment to social justice, her personal honesty, her vital spirit, and her unfailing good humor endeared her to us over the years, inspire us now, and will do so into the future.

title: An Odd Combination Finds Synergy
description: The pianist Danilo Perez and soprano saxophonist Steve Lacy started playing duets together in 1998. They seemed an odd combination - a young Panamanian pianist in his early 30's who came through Caribbean and Afro-Cuban roots and the American jazz mainstream, and an American soprano saxophonist in his mid-60's who had perfected his own sometimes delicate and odd version of jazz while living in Europe.

title: Kerry Sweeps to 2 Victories As Clark Drops Out of Race
description: Senator John Kerry of Massachusetts rolled to commanding victories in the Tennessee and Virginia primaries on Tuesday, solidifying his position as the perhaps unstoppable front-runner for the Democratic nomination and dealing a serious blow to his two Southern rivals.

title: Big Swiss Bank Reports Profit Of $1.5 Billion In 4th Quarter
description: Buoyed by the recovery in world stock markets, Switzerland's largest bank, UBS, reported a better-than-expected fourth-quarter profit, despite losses incurred in the unexpected default of the Erb Group, a Swiss conglomerate.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Study Shows One In Four Subway Phones Flawed
description: About one in four pay telephones in the New York City subway and commuter rail system do not work properly, according to a survey released yesterday by the Straphangers Campaign, a passenger advocacy group. Volunteers and staff members of the group spent four months surveying 100 stations picked at random from the 712 stations in the system. About 27 percent of subway pay phones surveyed did not work, compared with 17 percent of Long Island Rail Road and Metro-North Railroad pay phones, the survey said. The most common problems were no dial tone on the phone (38 percent); failure to return a coin (24 percent); coin not registering (13 percent); coin slot blocked (11 percent); inability to connect a call (10 percent); and flawed handset (5 percent). A Verizon spokesman, Daniel Diaz Zapata, said that the problems stemmed from vandalism and the difficulty of tracking the phones' condition. He urged riders to dial *55 from a working phone to report a problem. Michael Luo (NYT)

title: Philippine candidates start presidential race
description: MANILA:  The campaign for national elections on May 10 began on Tuesday, with the presidential candidates, their running mates and senatorial candidates promising an end to the country's problems.

description: The New York police officers' union escalated its criticism of Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly's handling of the police shooting of an unarmed teenager last month by calling yesterday for his resignation.

title: 15 Institutions Stay in Search for Arts Hub at Ground Zero
description: The Museum of the City of New York, the New York City Opera, the New-York Historical Society and the Signature Theater Company are among 15 cultural organizations that are the top contenders to inhabit a performing arts center at ground zero, or help create an interpretive museum there that will describe the attacks on the World Trade Center in 1993 and 2001.

description: The Goldman Sachs Group laid off 50 traders and sales executives in its equities division yesterday, as it continues to concentrate its resources in more profitable areas.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Mexico: Trade Deficit Declines
description: Mexico's trade deficit declined in 2003 to $5.6 billion, 29 percent less than the $7.9 billion deficit in 2002, the finance ministry reported. The ministry said higher prices for Mexico's oil exports accounted for most of the decrease. The higher oil prices made up for stagnant manufacturing exports, which dipped 0.4 percent in 2003. Even though more than 90 percent of Mexico's exports go to the United States, Mexico's recovery has lagged that of the United States. But the figures for December exports suggest that the economy may finally be starting to rebound. Exports rose 11.2 percent, to $14.9 billion, in the last month of 2003. Manufacturing exports increased 10.2 percent. The figures were released on Monday. Elisabeth Malkin (NYT)

title: National Briefing | South: Georgia: Court Rejects Voting Map
description: A three-judge federal panel in Atlanta found the maps for state legislative districts unconstitutional because they violated the principle of one person one vote by an unacceptable margin for no legitimate reason. The suit had been filed by Republicans. The maps, drawn when the Legislature was controlled by Democrats, were used in the 2002 elections. The panel gave the state until March 1 to draw acceptable new maps, or the court may draw them itself. The 2002 elections produced a Republican governor and led to a Republican-controlled Senate, but Democrats still control the House. Ariel Hart (NYT)

title: Haiti Erupts
description: Haiti's long smoldering political crisis has exploded into insurrection, with armed gangs driving the police out of the country's fourth-largest city, Gonaves, and at least 10 other towns. Some are now back in government hands, but more than 40 people have been killed so far, and the violence is far from over. Haiti's democratically elected president, Jean-Bertrand Aristide, helped bring this crisis on himself, with his encouragement of mob violence, politicization of the national police and failure to ensure fair legislative elections. Yet many of the insurrectionists are former Aristide allies with even weaker democratic credentials.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BUDOW, SAUL
description: BUDOW--Saul. On February 9, 2004. Beloved husband of the late Sunny. Devoted father of Fern and Stephen. Cherished grandfather of Scott and Alec. Brother and brother-in-law of Phil and Sandy Bern. Father-in-law of Lesley Budow and Robert Reiss. Brother-in-law of Bee and Murray Miller. We'll all miss your love. title: G.M. SETTLES SUIT ON LENDING DISCRIMINATION
description: The General Motors Corporation has agreed to pay as much as $11.2 million to settle a class-action lawsuit that claimed its finance unit charged higher interest rates for blacks than for whites. The finance unit, the General Motors Acceptance Corporation, will pay as much as $9.6 million in fees and expenses and spend $1.6 million to educate consumers about credit financing, the automaker said. The settlement does not include payments to consumers, G.M. said. The finance unit will also cap how much G.M. dealers can mark up interest rates on vehicle loans and start a marketing effort aimed at generating 1.25 million loan offers over five years to black and Hispanic customers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CHEN, WEI GUN
description: CHEN--Wei gun, on Friday, February 6, 2004, age 75. Beloved Tai Chi Master (Sifu), husband of Chen Ru Qiong, father of Zhi Hong and Ying Jie, father-in-law of Gong Kok Dun and Yue Fangli and grandfather of Stephen, Barry and Siao Ming. Sifu Chen practiced martial arts since early childhood in Canton Province. He came to the U.S. in 1992 and introduced hundreds of students to his fluid, authentic Mainland form of the Tai Chi practice. Sifu Chen's wisdom, patience and humor will be missed by all. On behalf of all of his loyal students, Robert Blanton, Gary Gamboi, Rick Rudeman, Robert Janowsky. Visiting on Saturday, February 14, 3-7 PM, at Wah Wing Sang Funeral Home, 26 Mulberry Street, New York City. Flowers welcome that day.

title: Surprising And Bold, Even if Not In the Club
description: Osmo Vanska, the 50-year-old Finnish conductor, took over the Minnesota Orchestra this fall convinced that it had the makings of a top-flight international ensemble. The blazing, incisive and risk-taking performance of excerpts from Prokofiev's ''Romeo and Juliet'' ballet score that he conducted on Monday night at Carnegie Hall offered clear evidence that he is getting results.

title: Plague Survivors Are Back In Hospital, to Say Thanks
description: The last time they were in New York, their stay turned into a nightmare out of the Dark Ages, but yesterday John Tull and his wife, Lucinda Marker, came back to thank the doctors who had saved their lives.

description: A clue that Botticelli was too daring in his depiction of earthly pleasures comes as the camera pans down the long white torso in his painting ''The Birth of Venus'' and stops at the goddess's loins.

title: Officials Say Mob Stole $200 Million Using Phone Bills
description: Forget gambling, loan-sharking and labor racketeering. New York organized crime figures bilked millions of unsuspecting consumers out of more than $200 million over five years by piggybacking bogus charges on their telephone bills, federal authorities said yesterday.

title: Oh, Those French: A Tasting
description: ON a trip to Burgundy several years ago, a friend and I bought some black truffles in the time-honored fashion -- from a fellow selling them out of the trunk of his Citron. We paid in cash, naturally, and then buried the truffles among a dozen eggs in an airtight plastic container. At least we thought it was airtight. Within several hours, the entire car was suffused with a lavish, earthy scent that I wanted to pull tight around me like a robe.

title: Program Promoting Car Safety for Children Will Focus on the Poor
description: Most parents have gotten the message that children are safer in the back seat of the car, but parents with less income and education disproportionately have not, according to a new survey. In response, safety officials plan to announce on Wednesday a program to distribute safety information with the food vouchers given to mothers of young children under a federal program.

title: Fresh From Maine, Tiny Bites From the Ocean
description: Fresh shrimp from Maine, in season until early March, are delicious cooked ever so briefly in water as salty as the sea, then peeled and eaten for a feast of sweet little mouthfuls. They are also good to smoke lightly. Line a wok and its cover with foil, place two tablespoons each of brown sugar, white rice and black tea leaves in the bottom, cover the wok and place it over high heat. In about five minutes, fragrant smoke should start to rise. Place the raw shrimp in their shells on a rack in the wok, cover again and smoke about 10 minutes, then serve the shrimp alone with a dipping sauce. The shrimp are often sold with their heads on, $5.99 to $7.99 a pound at stores like Wild Edibles, above.

title: Crimes Most Outlandish, but Why in Germany?
description: The worst by far would seem to have been the Internet cannibal, though the beating and murder of a three-year old child whose father intended to crucify her, the videotaped torture of a high school student, the bludgeoning to death of a youth because he was wearing clothes that, his murderers felt, made him look like a Jew -- these incidents too have lately made Germany appear to be a sort of European center for gothic crime, or at least a place of concentrated tabloid sensationalism.

description: A 19-year-old woman whose cellphone dropped onto the tracks in a Queens subway station was killed yesterday when she climbed down from the platform to retrieve the phone and was crushed by an oncoming train.

title: Pataki, in Surprise Trip to Iraq, Applauds War on Terrorism
description: Iraq is an odd place for a photo op. Staggering numbers of citizens are out of work, bandits roam the highways and terrorists continue to blow up buildings and people at a frightening rate.

title: National Briefing | Education: New Chief For Fund-Raising Group
description: The United Negro College Fund has announced that Michael L. Lomax, left, 56, the president of Dillard University in New Orleans, will become chief executive in June. He will succeed William H. Gray, 63, the former Pennsylvania congressman who led the fund for 13 years, raising $2.3 billion for its activities. The fund raises about $150 million a year to support 39 historically black colleges and universities around the nation, with about 60,000 students. It also gives scholarships to another 5,000 students at other colleges or universities. Greg Winter (NYT)

He placed second not only in Michigan but also in Washington (not Wisconsin, which votes next Tuesday).

title: A Showcase for Prizewinning African Choreographers in Brooklyn
description: One mission of the Brooklyn producing organization known as 651 ARTS is to gain a wider audience for arts grounded in the culture of the African diaspora. It has presented important programs of modern dance tinged with traditional African forms, created by influential African and American companies. And so it must have seemed a sure bet to open 651's 15th anniversary season, on Friday night at the BAM Harvey Theater, with a program by three award winners from a competition in Madagascar.

title: For Valentine's Day, A Kiss in a Glass
description: Bartenders' imaginations tend to go into overdrive for Valentine's Day. At City Hall, 131 Duane Street (Church Street), Gordon Levy, the bar manager, and Seth Gurka, the manager, have concocted a tall yellow cocktail called First Kiss. It is made with Laurent-Perrier Champagne, passion fruit pure and vanilla. It will be free for couples celebrating their first Valentine's Day together. After Saturday, it is $10, and so is the restaurant's pale pink refresher, a mojito made with ruby red grapefruit juice.

title: UAL ASKS FOR ANOTHER 4 MONTHS TO FILE RECOVERY PLAN
description: UAL, the parent of United Airlines, asked a judge to give it another four months to prepare a recovery plan. Judge Eugene R. Wedoff of United States Bankruptcy Court might rule on Feb. 20 in Chicago on UAL's request for a third extension. If he agrees, UAL would retain until June 30 the exclusive right to submit a recovery plan and creditors would be precluded from submitting competing proposals. UAL said in court papers that before it filed its plan it wanted to resolve certain issues, such as whether it will receive a $1.6 billion loan guarantee from the Air Transportation Stabilization Board. UAL said it still planned to emerge from bankruptcy by midyear.

title: Ingram Out At St. John's; Keita Expects Expulsion
description: One of the suspended starters on the St. John's men's basketball team has withdrawn from the university and another appears to be on the way out. Both were to face a university hearing yesterday over their roles in a scandal last week.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: Senate Votes To Stiffen a Penalty
description: The State Senate approved a bill yesterday that would raise the classification of endangering the welfare of a child to a felony from a misdemeanor. The State Assembly has yet to introduce the bill. The bill, known as Laura Mae's Law, is named after an infant who died at an overcrowded, unlicensed day-care center in Rensselaer County. The center's operator, Mary Beth Anslow, pleaded guilty to misdemeanor child endangerment, was sentenced to one year in prison, and was released after three months. Her release was overturned this week. Under the bill, the crime would be punishable by up to four years in prison. Stacy Albin (NYT)

title: Stewart Trial Focuses On Message From Broker
description: Martha Stewart sat down at her assistant's computer a month after selling ImClone Systems shares and deleted part of a record of a phone message from her stockbroker, Peter E. Bacanovic, after a telephone conversation with her lawyer, the assistant testified yesterday.

title: Harvard Student's Love Story Endures Beyond Grave (and Archives)
description: Instead of the usual Harvard student's account of the period, with an uninspiring recitation of classes, chapel and walks about Cambridge, the diary contained a lock of chestnut brown hair, a cluster of pressed flowers and a handwritten poem of worshipful love and inconsolable loss.

title: World Briefing | Middle East: United Arab Emirates: 43 Die In Iranian Plane Crash
description: A twin-engine Iranian passenger plane crashed while approaching the airport at Sharjah, killing 43 of the 46 people on board, officials said. Most of the dead were immigrant workers. Three survivors were hospitalized, two in critical condition. There were conflicting reports whether the plane, a Dutch-built Fokker-50 operated by Kish Air, had signaled that it was in trouble, though witnesses said it began wobbling as it descended. Officials ruled out terrorism as a possible cause. Neil MacFarquhar (NYT)

title: Edwards Says His Campaign Will Survive Double Losses
description: Senator John Edwards of North Carolina spoke for just eight minutes Tuesday night, enough for a few bursts of cheers, before dashing off stage for a larger purpose: a round of national network interviews to explain why he should stay in the presidential race despite being soundly defeated in his neighboring states of Tennessee and Virginia.

title: Report Questions the Reliability of an F.B.I. Ballistics Test
description: A study by a group of scientific experts called into question Tuesday the reliability of a process the F.B.I. has used in some 2,500 investigations to trace bullets from crime scenes, and government officials said they would review the findings to determine whether past convictions should be re-examined.

title: Thomas Is Tossed; Knicks Fall Short

title: The Songs Of a Culture Almost Lost
description: Cultures on the verge of disappearing often stage a last stand for their music and language, and Oki, who led his band at Merkin Hall on Sunday afternoon as part of the Music from Japan Festival, is doing just that. He wants to preserve the culture of the Ainu, Japan's indigenous inhabitants, who are now largely found on the northern islands of Hokkaido and Sakhalin. ''We lost our land,'' he sang in Ainu, ''but soul and spirit never fade away.'' The musicians were barefoot, wearing robes with elaborate geometric patterns.

title: Labor Department Now Backs Jobless Pay for Gay Partners

title: National Briefing: Midwest
description: IOWA: JUDGE STRIKES SEX OFFENDER LAW Iowa's two-year-old law banning sex offenders from living within 2,000 feet of a school or child care center was found unconstitutional by a federal judge. The judge, Robert W. Pratt of Federal District Court, said that the law infringed on offenders' due process rights and that it was unlawfully retroactive. The law, enacted in 2002, was intended to keep offenders away from children, but critics, including the American Civil Liberties Union, said it effectively banished offenders from 30 percent of the towns in the state.    Jo Napolitano (NYT)

title: National Briefing | Science And Health: New Mars Distance Record
description: The Mars rover Spirit set a record for driving on Mars, NASA managers announced in Pasadena, Calif. The journey covered 70 feet on Monday, they said; the previous single-day mark was 23 feet, set by the Sojourner rover on NASA's Mars Pathfinder mission in 1997. The Spirit is en route to a depression nicknamed Bonneville Crater, 820 feet to the northeast of its landing site. As flight controllers gain experience with the Spirit and its twin, the Opportunity, on the other side of Mars, they hope that the rovers will be able to travel 130 feet a day or even farther. Kenneth Chang (NYT)

The fine is believed to be the largest ever given for speeding in Finland, where traffic offenders are penalized according to their ability to pay. Mr. Salonoja's 2002 income was $8.9 million, Reuters said. The Finnish Internet millionaire Jaako Rytsola held the previous record for a speeding fine: $101,700. Walter Gibbs (NYT)

title: This Is Your Proselytizer Speaking
description: Flight 34 had just taken off from Los Angeles for New York last Friday morning when the pilot's voice resounded through the cabin. The writer Tom Wolfe traces it to Chuck Yeager, the daring war ace and low-key test pilot with the ''poker-hollow West Virginia drawl'' emulated by successive generations of pilots.

title: A Further Renovation on the Lower East Side
description: WHEN Alias, the offbeat bistro on the Lower East Side, closed its doors in November, it came as a surprise. No words are more dreaded in the restaurant business than the phrase ''closed for renovation.'' It is the soaped-window, papered-over sign of death. But Alias was the rare restaurant that closed with no intention of staying closed. Instead, a new chef and manager were installed, the menu was overhauled and the interior softened and simplified, and when Alias reopened after a mere four days, it was better than ever.

title: Russia's Lopsided Politics
description: The political farce of the brief disappearance of the candidate Ivan Rybkin may well prove to be the only excitement in the greater tragicomedy of the Russian presidential election. One of a handful of utterly hopeless challengers to Vladimir Putin, Mr. Rybkin came home with a bag of fruit last Thursday, draped his jacket over a chair, sent his driver and bodyguard away, turned off his cellphone and vanished. His wife finally called the police over the weekend, setting off wild speculation that he had been assassinated by ''the organs.'' A sheepish Mr. Rybkin reappeared on Tuesday, with the lame explanation that he had taken a few days off in Kiev. Uh-huh, said his wife, Albina, before delivering the coup de grce: ''I feel sorry for Russia if people like this want to govern it.'' Mr. Rybkin never registered more than a blip in the polls. But the effect of his political demise was to underscore the lack of serious opposition to President Putin.

The petite VP-1 Data Projector has a Zuiko digital zoom lens, similar to the one Olympus uses for its camera line. With 1,000 ANSI lumens of brightness and a contrast ratio of 2,000:1 -- the highest of any similarly sized projector -- the VP-1 will make those PowerPoint presentations sharp and clear. It even magnifies the projected picture up to 10 times for those who want to zero in on a specific detail.

title: Cable Giant Bids to Take Over Disney
description: In an audacious bid that could once again reshape the entertainment landscape, the Comcast Corporation, the largest cable operator in the United States, made an unsolicited $54.1 billion takeover offer yesterday for the Walt Disney Company.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sunday about the policies of New York City's Human Resources Administration under Commissioner Verna Eggleston referred imprecisely to the advisory role of Alan B. Siskind, chairman of the Human Services Council of New York City. When he said he advises the agency, he meant as a member of its Citizens Advisory Committee, not in his capacity with the council. Although the council also offers advice, it is a nonprofit association of social service agencies and not primarily an advisory group to the commissioner.

title: Judge Rules in Favor of Opponents of MONY Takeover
description: A federal judge cleared the way yesterday for opponents of the planned takeover of the MONY Group to use a tactic that the company had contended was a violation of federal securities law. At the same time, the opponents drew support from an organization whose recommendations are followed by some institutional investors.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SMITH, LESUEUR (BUD)
description: SMITH--LeSueur (Bud) of Larchmont, NY on February 11, 2004. Beloved husband of Mary Cecile (nee: Graham). Loving father of Cici, Joanne Clark, Carol, Nancy, Barbara, Meg Poor & Girard. Devoted grandfather of eight grandchildren. Visiting Friday 2-4 and 7-9 PM at the John J. Fox Funeral Home, Inc in Larchmont. Mass Saturday 10AM at St. Augustine Church.

title: FitzGerald to Retire as Unilever Chairman
description: LONDON, Feb. 12  Unilever , the Anglo-Dutch conglomerate that makes consumer products ranging from Dove soap to Hellman's mayonnaise, lowered expectations for sales growth as it presented year-end results today and said that its co-chairman Niall FitzGerald would step down in September.

title: Federal Judge Eases Snowmobile Curb
description: A federal district judge in Wyoming late Tuesday allowed the National Park Service to raise the current cap on the number of snowmobiles allowed in Yellowstone National Park.

title: A Chair to Think or Drink In, A Lamp That Glows Without Juice
description: At the Interior Design Show running today through Sunday in Toronto, Brigitte Shim and Howard Sutcliffe, both architects (right), will unveil their HAB line of tables, chairs and lights. Ms. Shim and Mr. Sutcliffe, who work in Toronto, say their molded plywood HAB Chair (top, with maple finish) is a modern interpretation of a rustic cabin classic like the Adirondack chair. ''The wide arms help you deal with a magazine, a gin and tonic or a laptop,'' Ms. Shim said. The chair is priced at $1,950. Painted prototypes of a metal version will be on view at the show, at the National Trade Center at Exhibition Place.

title: Black Ties at a Mall, Glam in Luggageville
description: It used to be said of the actress and gadabout Sylvia Miles (actually, she said it of herself) that if a hostess put a potato chip on a window sill, Ms. Miles would appear. Like a lot of wisecracks, this one contained both cruelty and truth. When it comes to social enterprise, Ms. Miles turns out to be a prototypical New Yorker. Or so events of the last week reveal.

title: Algerian Explosion Stirs Foes of U.S. Gas Projects
description: An explosion that flattened a large part of the Algerian port of Skikda last month, killing 30 people and injuring 70 more, has shaken plans to build dozens of liquefied natural gas terminals in the United States to address a forecast shortage of natural gas.

title: A Strategy of Opening the Door Before Opportunity Has to Knock
description: Brian L. Roberts's bold $50 billion takeover of AT&T's cable business two years ago was seen as his defining moment. But that deal, it turns out, may have been just for starters. Not content running the nation's largest cable company, Comcast, Mr. Roberts set out yesterday to create the world's largest media company.

title: Corrections
description: A listing in the Residential Sales column last Thursday for a limestone house at 295 East Seventh Street in Brooklyn misidentified the neighborhood. It is in Kensington, not Park Slope.

description: To the Editor:

description: When the battleship New Jersey was formally welcomed to its permanent berth along the Delaware River here on a bright October day in 2001, it was billed as a ship-turned-museum that would promote maritime history, excite veterans and military buffs and provide a much-needed boost to downtrodden Camden.
