title: Intel Reports A Research Leap To a Faster Chip
description: Intel scientists will announce on Thursday that they have built a prototype of a silicon chip that can switch light on and off like electricity, blurring the line between computing and communications and bringing sweeping changes to the way digital information and entertainment are delivered.

title: What the Newcomers Brought to the Fair
description: NEW products by young designers often fuel high energy and interest at a design show. More so than in past years, this was the case last week in the Accent on Design section of the New York International Gift Fair. Not coincidentally, the youthful showing was accompanied by an abundance of wares for babies and children.

title: Lottery Numbers
Review of TV Decency Law Looks Beyond Bared Breast
description: The widespread criticism of a Super Bowl halftime show on CBS that featured one singer grabbing his crotch and another baring her breast reached the Capitol on Wednesday as lawmakers gathered support for measures that would strengthen laws against indecency on television.

title: National Briefing | Southwest: Texas: Budget Troubles In Houston
description: The City of Houston faces a $150 million budget shortfall in the fiscal year beginning July 1, said Mayor Bill White, describing the projected deficit as more than double the estimated level. Mr. White, who took office last month, said layoffs and sales of city-owned land were being considered to close the deficit. Steve Barnes (NYT)

title: Investigators Ask if Stock Is Linked to Rowland Friend
description: Federal investigators have requested information about a penny stock called Edulink Inc. that Gov. John G. Rowland reported owning in 2000, on the theory that his friend Robert V. Matthews may be linked to the company, documents show.

title: Excerpts From Comcast Letter Informing Disney of Bid
description: Following are excerpts from the letter to Michael D. Eisner and the Walt Disney Company from the Comcast Corporation about its proposal to buy Disney. The full text is online at nytimes.com/business.

title: Q & A
description: Q. When an Internet intruder attacks my computer, my firewall gives me the offender's I.P. address. I have notified the Federal Trade Commission and my Internet service provider, but nobody seems to care. What should I do with this information? And where can I learn more about computer security issues?

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Travelocity.com To Cut Jobs
description: Travelocity.com, the Internet travel agency that is a unit of the Sabre Holdings Corporation, said yesterday that it would close a customer-service center in Virginia by the end of the year and cut its staff in San Antonio after contracting some of the work to WNS Holdings Ltd. Shares of Sabre, which is based in Southlake, Tex., rose 72 cents, to $21.83.

(The commission has pointed out that the same error occurred last April 2.) The member is Chris Kojm, deputy executive director, not Philip Zelikow, the executive director.

title: Facing a Battle, Disney's Chief Is Known to Fight Back, Hard
description: When under attack, Michael D. Eisner, chief executive of the Walt Disney Company, can be counted on for a tried-and-true response: a tenacious counterattack.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   COLENDA, FRANK G., MD.
description: COLENDA--Frank G., MD. Of NYC died unexpectedly on February 10, 2004. Dr. Colenda was a well-respected internist who practiced in Manhattan for more than 30 years. He was a senior attending physician at Lenox Hill Hospital. Funeral services are tentatively being planned for Friday and/or Saturday at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street. Please call (212) 288-3500 for more details. Donations in his name may be made to the American Heart Association.

title: C.F.L. QUARTERBACK VISITS JETS
description: Ricky Ray, who led the Edmonton Eskimos to the Grey Cup championship in the Canadian Football League, will visit the Jets today and could be considered a backup quarterback candidate, particularly if the Jets cannot find common ground with Vinny Testaverde.

title: Court Is Urged to Change Media Ownership Rules
description: Broadcasters and public interest groups on Wednesday urged the federal appeals court here to order the Federal Communications Commission to rewrite its new rules that govern the size and reach of the nation's largest media conglomerates. Many of the parties joining the fight against the F.C.C., however, are doing so for diametrically opposed reasons.

title: World Briefing | Europe: France: News Director Out Over Erroneous Report
description: The news director of the state-owned television network France 2, Olivier Mazerolle, left, stepped down after a rare vote of no confidence by its journalists. On Feb. 3 the network's evening newscast wrongly announced the departure of former Prime Minister Alain Jupp from politics after his conviction on corruption charges. At the same time, Mr. Jupp was giving an interview on a rival station in which he said he planned to wait for a decision while his conviction was appealed. Ariane Bernard (NYT)

title: U.N. Aide Backs Cleric on Elections; Offers No Timetable
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Feb. 12  An envoy for the United Nations said he supported a powerful Shiite cleric's call for elections to install a new sovereign government after having met with the cleric this morning.

title: Big Media, Please Meet Wide Distribution
description: With the memory of nightmare media mergers like AOL Time Warner and Vivendi Universal still lingering, no wonder Comcast avoided the dreaded S-word -- synergy -- to justify its hostile $54 billion takeover bid for Disney.

title: U.S. Traces Financial Roots Of Terror Network to Brooklyn
description: A prominent Yemeni sheik came to Brooklyn in 1999, raised money at mosques that was ostensibly for charity and then went to Italy, where he met with a top operative of Al Qaeda, according to federal prosecutors in Brooklyn.

title: Tilting Tradition With Punch-Line Proportions
description: DO not adjust your set. It won't do any good.

title: Tax Questions For Military's Contractors
description: More than 27,000 military contractors, or about 1 in 9, are evading taxes and still continuing to win new business, Congressional investigators have found.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BROWN, JOHNNIE
description: BROWN--Johnnie. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Johnnie Brown, associated with The Times from January 1979 until retiring in February 1997

title: No Laws Broken, Artemis Quartet Goes on Tour
description: The Berlin-based Artemis Quartet, one of the most impressive of the new generation of string quartets, arrived on Monday at Logan Airport in Boston, all excited to begin an American tour that includes two concerts this weekend in New York. But for a while that day it looked as if security officials in Boston might prevent the quartet's cellist, Eckart Runge, from entering the country. Could the depressing events of the quartet's aborted 2002 tour be happening again?

title: Sports of The Times; One Coach's Calamity Is Another's Opportunity
description: WHILE you are wondering who in his right mind would take over the ravaged basketball program at St. John's, what coach of substance would come to a university recently associated more with lap dances than with big dances, remember this: Someone took the head coaching job at Baylor.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Sri Lanka: Ministers Dismissed
description: President Chandrika Kumaratunga dismissed 39 junior ministers allied with her rival, Prime Minister Ranil Wickremesinghe. Ms. Kumaratunga dissolved Parliament on Saturday and ordered new elections for April 2. The latest move was seen as an effort to prevent Mr. Wickremesinghe's party from having an advantage in the election because of access to government resources. Hari Kumar (NYT)

title: As Democrats' Field Narrows, Jockeying Begins for No.2 Spot
description: Okay, only 14 states have held Democratic primaries or caucuses , and barely one-quarter of the delegates have been chosen. But with presidential candidates dropping out weekly, it is time to think about the vice presidency, assuming Senator John Kerry of Massachusetts makes it to the end.

title: Birds Outside, Stories Within
description: 'The Parrot'

title: A Police Shooting Revisited
description: As a career police officer, the New York City police commissioner, Raymond Kelly, knows firsthand about the anger and misinformation that can sweep through the streets when a white police officer kills a black resident. Mr. Kelly has therefore made a practice of speaking candidly to the public after each case of deadly force in an effort to defuse tension.

title: Bolts and Bolts of Fabric Finds, Worth a Long Drive or a Short Call
description: If choosing fabric from tens of thousands of deeply discounted bolts and a wide selection of trims is appealing, you can try Mary Jo's Cloth Store in Gastonia, N.C., 20 miles from Charlotte. If visiting is not convenient, the store does business by phone and mail. The staff will search stock based on descriptions, photos or small cloth samples. The choice is varied, including curtain sheers and durable outdoor fabrics. For a charge, swatches can be sent (a sixteenth of a yard is the smallest). The store, open Monday through Friday, is in the Gastonia Mall, 401 Cox Road, Gastonia 28054; www.maryjos.com or (800) 627-9567. MARIANNE ROHRLICH

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an obituary of the writer John Gregory Dunne on Jan. 1 referred incorrectly to the victim in the Black Dahlia murder case in Los Angeles, the basis of his novel ''True Confessions.'' The victim, often described as a would-be actress, was not a prostitute. Also because of an editing error, the obituary misstated the surname of the author of ''Panic in Needle Park,'' a nonfiction book that Mr. Dunne and his wife, Joan Didion, turned into a screenplay. He is James Mills, not Mill. This correction was delayed by an editing lapse.

title: Learning to Prevent Avalanche Deaths
description: It was roughly a year ago that the snowboarder Craig Kelly, a four-time world champion and one of the sport's pioneers, died along with six others, buried beneath an avalanche in British Columbia. Kelly, 36, had left competitive snowboarding to launch a career as a backcountry guide.

title: Israel Wont Participate in Hague Hearing on Security Barrier
description: JERUSALEM, Feb. 12  Israel said today that it would not participate in a hearing this month at the International Court of Justice on the legality of the contentious separation barrier that is under construction in the West Bank.

title: Jockey Mourned 2 Victories Short Of a Milestone
description: The Kentucky morning was cold but clear Wednesday, with the sun breaking through the clouds, as the entire family of the racetrack, as they call it, the jockeys, the trainers, the grooms, the valets, the hot walkers, the agents and the everyday betting folks -- and the widow and three daughters, ages 20, 15 and 8 -- filed into the Homestretch dining room just off the track at Turfway Park.

title: French Question $11 Million Sent to Arafat's Wife
description: French prosecutors are investigating bank transfers of $11.4 million to accounts controlled by Suha al-Taweel Arafat, the wife of the Palestinian leader, French media reported Wednesday.

title: Roses Blue, Violets Red? A Tool to Calibrate Your Monitor Colors
description: How can you be sure that a digital print will look the same as the image you see on your computer screen? Correcting the screen image by eye is tricky, even with software to help. Instruments can do the job more accurately and consistently, but until now they have had high prices.

title: A Festival Of Odd Finds To Cheer Film Buffs
description: February can be a hard month for movie lovers. The studios continue their annual winter clearance sales, dumping dumbed-down damaged goods into the multiplexes to offset their Oscar contenders. A few interesting films usually straggle into view, but it is easy to become dispirited and to succumb to gloomy grumbling about the sad condition of cinema.

title: Iraq Bombings Seem to Aim at Voting Plan
description: Back-to-back suicide bombings on Tuesday and Wednesday that killed more than 100 people came as a United Nations delegation was examining whether early elections could be held in Iraq. The message, Iraqi politicians and others here said Wednesday, is unmistakable.

title: British Airways Cancels 2 Flights, Citing Security Fears
description: British Airways today canceled two flights that were scheduled to fly next week from London to Washington, D.C. and Saudi Arabia, saying it was acting for security reasons based on advice from the British government.

description: Michael Jackson is near insolvency as he continues to pile up debt, sapping his last credit reserves, several close financial advisers say.

title: A New Cellphone Nods to the Needs of the Disabled
description: BONNIE O'DAY, a slight woman with nimble fingers, is standing in the dining room of her home in Alexandria, Va., demonstrating how she uses her cellphone. She presses some buttons and the phone emits a beep. ''I don't know what I just did,'' Dr. O'Day said. ''It beeps and I don't know what's going on.''

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Intel Wins Appeal
description: Intel won an appeals court ruling yesterday that may save it $100 million in its patent dispute with the Intergraph Corporation. The United States Court of Appeals for the Federal Circuit said a federal judge in Texas incorrectly interpreted a patent that Intergraph said covered technology used by Intel's Itanium processors. The appeals court ordered the case returned to the trial judge for reconsideration. Under a settlement, Intel, based in Santa Clara, Calif., paid Intergraph $150 million after the judge ruled the patent was infringed, and agreed to pay another $100 million if it lost the appeal. Shares of Intergraph, which is based in Huntsville, Ala., fell $2.16, to $22.47. Intel shares rose 45 cents, to $30.99.

title: It's Not Only the Giants With Franchises Abroad
description: Cynthia McKay was in business for more than a decade before her food basket company received a dreaded Better Business Bureau complaint in 2003. She assigned the blame, in part, to her sometimes overzealous plan to go global.

title: Corrections
description: Explanatory text yesterday about the method used for exit polls in the Virginia and Tennessee primaries described the one in Tennessee incorrectly. A total of 2,489 voters were interviewed there, 961 of them as they left early-voting locations in 21 counties between Jan. 31 and Feb. 5. There were no telephone interviews.

description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 12  President Bush , campaigning in Pennsylvania, tried to repair damage today from a politically awkward remark recently uttered by one of his advisers about American jobs going overseas.

title: Mr. Greenspan Weighs In
description: Alan Greenspan has cleared up any questions about whether a half-trillion-dollar deficit is a danger to the American economy, and whether the huge Bush tax cuts are part of the problem. Testifying before Congress yesterday in that polite, jargon-riddled way of his, the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board contradicted the Bush administration and its allies, who have been dismissing the significance of deficits. Mr. Greenspan also complained about ''diminished restraint'' on discretionary spending -- perhaps an indication that he has lost some faith in the conservative credo that cutting revenue is the best way to control spending.

title: Coca-Cola Profits Off 0.3%; Revamping Costs Are Cited
description: The Coca-Cola Company said yesterday that its fourth-quarter earnings fell slightly because of restructuring costs associated with streamlining its North American business. The decline had been widely expected by Wall Street analysts. But even without the $197 million restructuring charge, which depressed earnings by 8 cents a share, the company's results were disappointing, analysts said.

description: Less than two months after he stealthily captured New York magazine, Bruce Wasserstein, the Wall Street financier, came up with another surprise yesterday, hiring Adam Moss, an assistant managing editor at The New York Times, to be its new editor.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ADAMS, STIRLING SHATTUCK
description: ADAMS--Stirling Shattuck, of Vero Beach, Florida, died suddenly on February 8, 2004, aged 93. Beloved husband of Rosamond Hodges Adams, his wife of 66 years. Devoted father of Stirling S. Adams, Jr., William Woodward Adams and Rosamond Adams Chadwick. Loving grandfather of Rosamond Macy Chadwick and Thomas Adams Chadwick and two great grandchildren. He was a graduate of Middlesex School and Harvard College, class of 1933. He served as a Lieutenant Commander in Naval Intelligence in World War II. He was a vice-president of Marine Midland Trust Company and retired as vice-president of CIT Financial Corporation, both of New York City. He lived with his family in Millbrook, NY, until 1977 when he and his wife retired to Vero Beach where he served on the boards of the Environmental Learning Center, the Riverside Theater and the John's Island Club. Always a keen sportsman, he was also a past president of Ducks Unlimited. A memorial service will be held on Friday, February 13, at 11AM in the Great Hall of Trinity Episcopal Church, corner of Royal Palm and Pine Aves. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to Environmental Learning Center, 255 Live Oak Drive, Vero Beach, FL 32963 or Middlesex School, Concord, MA 10742.

title: U.S. Infant Mortality Rate Rises Slightly
description: For the first time in more than 40 years, infant mortality rates in the United States increased in 2002. Experts said the use of new technology and drugs improved the chances of high-risk pregnancies but had yet to keep some premature babies alive much longer than their first month.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MESSING, WILLIAM L.
description: MESSING--William L., 90, on February 9, 2004 in Los Gatos, California. Loved and survived by Norma, wife of 63 years; children Joan, Margie and Gary and their spouses; five grandchildren and their partners; and one greatgrandchild. Graduated New York City College, 1933 and Columbia Law School, 1936. Extraordinary 55 year legal career in government and private practice. Esteemed for his integrity, intellect and compassion. Deeply committed to social justice. Gifts may be sent to the ACLU.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: KLM Takeover Cleared
description: The European Commission approved the Air France takeover of the Dutch airline KLM after the companies agreed to give up 94 takeoff and landing slots. With the takeover, which still requires the approval of regulators in the United States, Air France will overtake British Airways as the biggest carrier in the world. Paul Meller (NYT)

It is one of 14 next to the Continuum, a condominium tower at the southern tip of Miami Beach. Each cabana is 270 square feet and has a kitchen, a bathroom and a porch.

title: A Greensward Soft as Linen, No Water or Mowing Required
description: The grass is greener with these pillows, which evoke Palm Beach and are the latest from Variegated, a design studio in a restored mill building in Hudson, N.Y. Jim Deskevich and Corbett Marshall, who met at the design college at North Carolina State University, created the 2 Blade pillow (right foreground), 12 by 16 inches, $80, and the larger Clump (far right) and Clump Repeat pillows (both 18 inches square, $100). They were inspired by their passion for gardens, which they also design. Variegated makes duvet covers, shams and pillowcases, too. The pillows are linen; (518) 671-6667 or www.variegatedinc.com. STEPHEN TREFFINGER

title: Officer Said To Tell Jury He Can't Recall Fatal Shooting
description: The police officer who shot and killed an unarmed 19-year-old last month on the roof of a Brooklyn housing project told a grand jury yesterday that he did not remember raising his weapon and pulling the trigger, according to two people familiar with his testimony, who spoke on the condition of anonymity.

title: A Tale of Nuclear Proliferation: How Pakistani Built His Network
description: The break for American intelligence operatives tracking Abdul Qadeer Khan's nuclear network came in the wet August heat in Malaysia, as five giant cargo containers full of specialized centrifuge parts were loaded into one of the nondescript vessels that ply the Straits of Malacca.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ONYAN, BLAINE WELLINGTON
description: ONYAN--Blaine Wellington, of Fort Lee, died on February 11, 2004, at the age of 92. Blaine, beloved husband of Edith Hufman Onyan, liked to call himself the ''an upstate Apple Knocker.'' He was born in Clinton, NY and raised in Oriskany Falls. He was especially proud of his service in the US Army during World War II, a draftee rising to Captain over his 52 months. For many years he was a sales engineer with the Cyclone Fence Division of US Steel. After retiring he was associated with Royal Guard Fence Company in Westbury and acted as consultant on fencing for New York City Parks Department. Besides his wife, he leaves nieces Susan Skogerson, Patricia Reske; nephews Kenneth and Howard Gould. Visiting will be Friday 3:00-5:00 and 7:009:00 p.m. at the Frank A. Patti and Kenneth Mikatarian Funeral Home, 327 Main Street ''opposite the Fort Lee Library.'' Religious service Saturday at 10:00 a.m. Burial in Pinelawn Cemetery, Farmingdale, NY at 12:30 p.m. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Children's Aid Society of New York or the charity of your choice. For further information: www.pattiandmikatarian .com or 201-944-0100.

title: Politics Could Overshadow Legal Hurdles Of a Merger
description: As it tries to acquire the Walt Disney Company, the Comcast Corporation faces hurdles in Washington that are less legal than political, media analysts said today.

title: Edwards Presses an Argument Of His Strength Against Bush
description: A day after being trounced in two Southern primaries, Senator John Edwards urged Wisconsin voters on Wednesday not to write him off and declared that he would appeal to a broader swath of voters than John Kerry in a general election campaign against President Bush.

title: Oldest Known Insect Identified From 400-Million-Year-Old Jaws
description: Scientists say they have discovered the world's oldest known insect fossil, a 400-million-year-old set of minuscule jaws that have been lying unrecognized for nearly a century in a drawer at the Natural History Museum in London.

title: AHOLD TO SELL 2 SOUTHEASTERN U.S. SUPERMARKET CHAINS
description: The Dutch food retailer Royal Ahold said yesterday that it intended to sell both its BI-LO and Bruno's supermarket chains in the southeastern United States to cut debt and recover from a $1.2 billion accounting scandal. Ahold, which wants to focus on its other chains, like Stop & Shop and Giant-Landover, did not disclose a sale price or any potential buyers. Together, the two chains operate 470 stores stretching from North Carolina to Florida. Gregory Crouch (NYT)

title: CLONING CREATES HUMAN EMBRYOS
description: Scientists in South Korea report that they have created human embryos through cloning and extracted embryonic stem cells, the universal cells that hold great promise for medical research.

title: Bush's Guard Record: A Debate Touches a Nerve
description: To the Editor:

title: National Briefing | South: Alabama: Suit Over Sewage Spill
description: The state attorney general, Bill Pryor, sued the sewer board of Prichard, an industrial suburb of Mobile, over a huge spill in which a ruptured main sent millions of gallons of raw sewage into a creek that empties into Mobile Bay. The suit, in Mobile County Circuit Court, requests that the court appoint a supervisor to take charge of the board's daily operations. Ariel Hart (NYT)

title: F.C.C. Begins Rewriting Rules on Delivery of the Internet
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 12  The Federal Communications Commission began writing new rules today that officials and industry experts said would profoundly alter both the way the Internet is delivered and used in homes and businesses.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CARPENTER, H. DANIEL
description: CARPENTER -- H. Daniel. Hudson Guild marks with great sadness the passing of Dan Carpenter, age 95. Dan joined the Guild in 1931, serving as executive director from 1943 until 1973. Upon his retirement he served as a trustee for 18 years. His impact on the Guild and on Chelsea was extraordinary; in addition, he was a major leader in the Settlement House movement and a true pioneer for many social issues, most notably affordable housing. Dan was admired for his wit, astuteness, and tenacity and was consulted by many even after his relocation to Arizona last year. Lee Buckley, President Paul F. Balser, Chairman Janice McGuire, Executive Director

title: Prosecutor Says No. 1 War Crimes Suspect Is Hiding in Belgrade
description: Correction Appended

title: Sisterhood in a Floating Powder Room; An Oscar-Nominated Documentary Captures Life Aboard the Staten Island Ferry
description: Katja Esson, a German filmmaker who lives in New York, began lurking about the ladies' room on the 8:15 Staten Island ferry to Manhattan in the summer of 2001. Call it location scouting or character casting.

title: Dean Attacks Kerry on Fund-Raising and Acting 'Like a Republican'
description: Just days after he vowed not to run a ''scorched earth'' campaign that could hurt the eventual Democratic nominee, Howard Dean lit into Senator John Kerry of Massachusetts on Wednesday, saying that if Mr. Kerry wins the nomination, ''once again we may have to settle for the lesser of two evils.''

title: Bush's Guard Record: A Debate Touches a Nerve
description: To the Editor:

title: Old Navy Begins Search for an Agency
description: The Old Navy division of Gap Inc. is beginning a search for an outside agency to help its advertising team create campaigns for the general market. Old Navy spends about $150 million a year on such ads.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Garden City: Report Alleges Housing Bias
description: An advocacy group for families with low incomes released a report yesterday detailing what the group called patterns of housing discrimination on Long Island. The state may investigate. The group, the Association of Community Organizations for Reform Now, said that suburban real estate agents were more likely to show apartments to white people than to members of minorities, and were often dismissive of black and Hispanic customers. State Comptroller Alan G. Hevesi, above, endorsed the findings of the report at a news conference yesterday morning. ''There is now evidence that a number of these real estate agencies have behaved in an illegal fashion and an immoral fashion,'' he said. Mr. Hevesi said he would urge the Human Rights Commission to investigate practices at the agencies the report criticized. Patrick Healy (NYT)

title: Student, 19, in Trial of New Antidepressant Commits Suicide
description: A 19-year-old college student who had shown no outward signs of depression killed herself over the weekend at an Eli Lilly & Company laboratory in Indianapolis where she had been participating in a company drug trial for an experimental antidepressant.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Thailand: Another Discount Airline
description: The battle for Southeast Asia's budget air traveler gained a new combatant this week as Nok Air, a new low-cost airline backed by Thai Airways International, announced plans to begin domestic service in Thailand by the second quarter of this year. Thai Airways will hold a 39 percent stake in Nok Air. Nok Air will compete with two other discount airlines. Wayne Arnold (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: The On Education column yesterday, about a mentor program at the Birney Elementary School in Washington, misstated the name of a nearby housing project. It is Barry Farm, not Berry Farm.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Indonesia: Bank Stake Sale Approved
description: Indonesia's Parliament approved government plans to sell a stake worth about $735 million in PT Bank Permata, the country's 13th-largest lender by assets, after a delay of one week. A fifth of the bank would be sold on the stock market first, followed by the sale of 51 percent to a single investor or a group of investors, said Emir Moeis, chairman of Parliament's budget commission.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   MINOLDI, CARMELO
description: MINOLDI--Carmelo Feb. 12, 1927 -June 16, 2003 Happy Birthday. With love, Maria, Joseph and Nanc

title: U.S. Asks China to Trim Threat to Taiwan
description: A senior Pentagon official told Chinese leaders this week that they should withdraw missiles aimed at Taiwan, stressing that the burden of reducing tensions across the Taiwan Strait falls heavily on Beijing.

title: World Briefing: Americas
description: MEXICO: LAWMAKERS WANT REGISTRY FOR TOURISTS Members of Congress are calling for a registry of foreign tourists as a way of combating a perceived growth in the sexual abuse of children in Mexico. "We need to diagnose the problem," said one congressman, Arturo Nahle Garcia. The problems of "sex tourism"  foreigners seeking sex with youths  and sex trafficking in Mexico are thought to be on the increase, although few reliable statistics prove it. The federal authorities say 33 foreigners face trial in Mexico on charges of sexually abusing children. Tim Weiner (NYT)

title: Toll-Free Apology Soothes Savage Beast
description: HERE were my plans for a recent Sunday afternoon: bake cornbread to take to a party, take the dog for a hike and finish reading ''Mystic River'' in an attempt to fill in the jarring plot holes in the movie adaptation of same.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KANTOR, THOMAS G., M.D.
description: KANTOR--Thomas G., M.D. Husband of Deirdre. Memorial service Saturday, February 14, 11 AM, Christ and Holy Trinity, Westport, Connecticut. Memorial contributions to Doctors Without Borders or Arthritis Foundation.

title: Iraq Is Granted Observer Status At the W.T.O.
description: Trade ministers and ambassadors granted Iraq observer status at the World Trade Organization on Wednesday and, in a trade-off to avert a new dispute, gave Iran a glimmer of hope that its membership would be considered in May.

title: Economic Scene; Information technology may have been what cured low service-sector productivity.
description: PRODUCTIVITY growth took a breather last quarter, slowing to 2.7 percent, after the previous quarter's torrid 9.5 percent growth. Still, by historical standards, 2.7 percent is a respectable number.

title: Brodeur Objects to Proposal That Would Rein Him In
description: The National Hockey League is seriously thinking about limiting the space in which Devils goaltender Martin Brodeur can chase a puck. As far as Brodeur is concerned, the league might as well saw his stick in half.

title: Bush's Guard Record: A Debate Touches a Nerve
description: To the Editor:

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: WorldCom Seeks Extension
description: WorldCom said yesterday that it had asked the United States Bankruptcy Court in New York for a 60-day extension of the Feb. 28 deadline for completing its reorganization. WorldCom said that it needed more time to complete filings with the Securities and Exchange Commission that restate its earnings and revenues for 2002 and 2003. The final accounting of the impact of the $11 billion accounting fraud that plunged the company into bankruptcy in 2002 is the last step in the reorganization. WorldCom, based in Ashburn, Va., plans to change its name to MCI when it emerges from bankruptcy. Stock in the new company, which began trading over the counter in November on a when-issued basis at $26.70 a share, fell 25 cents yesterday, to $23.50. Barnaby J. Feder (NYT)

title: F.D.A. PUTS APPROVAL FOR KIDNEY DRUG ON FAST TRACK
description: Neurochem Inc., an unprofitable biotechnology company based in Montreal, said the Food and Drug Administration agreed to put its Fibrillex drug for treatment of a complication linked to chronic infections and rheumatoid arthritis on fast-track status in the approval process. Fibrillex is intended to treat a condition called secondary amyloid A amyloidosis, which can cause the kidneys to fail, the company said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   NICHOLS, RONALD
description: NICHOLS--Ronald. The Berrie Center extends our condolences to the Nichols family on the passing of Ron, beloved husand and father. Our thoughts are with his wife Nancy, cherished member of our Diabetes Advisory Committee, and daughters Stephanie and Kimberly. Robin Goland, M.D. Rudolph Leibel, M.D. Co-Directors, Naomi Berrie Diabetes Cntr at Columbia University Medical Center

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FOX, CONSTANCE M.
description: FOX--Constance M. 1932-2004 Of North Salem NY. Died on February 7. Devoted daughter of the late Frank and Regina Fox, beloved wife of the late Gilbert Anyon. She is survived by brothers Frank and Michael Fox, and their spouses, Evon and Lizann, six nieces, two nephews and ten grand nieces and nephews. We celebrate Connie's life of limitless compassion and courage, commitment to family, friends, the disadvantaged and world peace. She is gone too soon. A master of words--a teller of tales. A weaver of dreams--her spirit prevails. Calling hours February 13, 7-9PM at Clark Assoc Funeral Home, Katonah NY. Funeral Mass February 14, 11AM at St. John's Catholic Chapel, North Salem NY. Contributions in her memory may be made to Doctors Without Borders, USA, PO Box 1856, Merrifield VA 22116-8056 or Marymount College, 100 Marymount Avenue, Tarrytown, New York 10591-3796

title: Merger Is Proposed for Buffalo and County
description: With New York's second-largest city struggling under immense annual deficits, the leader of the county that surrounds it called on Wednesday for consolidating his government with that of the City of Buffalo.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Ad Concern's Revenue Falls
description: The Publicis Groupe, the marketing and advertising company, said fourth-quarter revenue fell 6.9 percent as a better-than-expected increase in ad spending failed to offset a weaker dollar. Revenue fell to 1.08 billion euros ($1.38 billion) from 1.16 billion euros, the chief executive, Maurice Lvy, said. Excluding the impact of currencies, revenue rose 5.2 percent. ''I expect the ad market growth will be solid this year -- but not booming,'' Mr. Lvy said in a conference call. The impact of exchange rates reduced revenue by 123 million euros in the fourth quarter and 494 million euros during the full year, Mr. Lvy said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KLEIN, MEYER
description: KLEIN--Meyer, 90, died February 10. Beloved husband of Frances. Father of Gladys Honigfeld (Robert), and Paul Klein. Grandfather Lori Zucker (Ron), Jill Bloom (Bryan) and great-grandfather to Jason, Jenna, Matt, Allie.

title: National Briefing | Washington: Setback For Hospitals
description: The medical education establishment suffered a setback when a federal judge refused to dismiss a lawsuit contending that medical residents are forced to participate in a system that ensures that they work long hours for low pay. The judge, Paul L. Friedman of United States District Court, rejected pleas by medical schools and teaching hospitals that he dismiss the suit. It argues that a system known as the match, which pairs medical school graduates with hospitals for training, is a violation of antitrust laws.

title: FitzGerald to Retire as Unilever Chairman
description: LONDON, Feb. 12  Unilever , the Anglo-Dutch conglomerate that makes consumer products ranging from Dove soap to Hellman's mayonnaise, lowered expectations for sales growth as it presented year-end results today and said that its co-chairman Niall FitzGerald would step down in September.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   EDGERTON, PROF. WILLIAM B.
description: EDGERTON--Prof. William B., 89, of Bloomington, IN, died Sunday. He was Professor Emeritus of Slavic languages at Indiana University and formerly taught at Columbia University. Memorial services will be at 2:00 pm February 14, at Bloomington Friends Meeting. For information, contact Day Funeral Home in Bloomington, IN.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Mexico: Lawmakers Want Registry For Tourists
description: Members of Congress are calling for a registry of foreign tourists as a way of combating a perceived growth in the sexual abuse of children in Mexico. ''We need to diagnose the problem,'' said one congressman, Arturo Nahle Garca. The problems of ''sex tourism'' -- foreigners seeking sex with youths -- and sex trafficking in Mexico are thought to be on the increase, although few reliable statistics prove it. The federal authorities say 33 foreigners face trial in Mexico on charges of sexually abusing children. Tim Weiner (NYT)

title: Ryszard Kuklinski, 73, Spy in Poland in Cold War, Dies
description: Ryszard Kuklinski, a former Polish Army officer who secretly served as one of the C.I.A.'s most important spies behind the Iron Curtain during the cold war, died Tuesday in his adopted American homeland, United States government officials said Wednesday. He was 73.

title: Corrections
description: A picture credit was omitted in World Business yesterday with an article about Iran's mobile phone industry. The photographer was Newsha Tavakolian for Polaris.

description: To the Editor:

title: Led by Stellar Backcourt, St. Joseph's Hits 21-0
description: Continuing its special season, St. Joseph's enjoyed another special night Wednesday.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Michigan: Manslaughter Conviction
description: Desmon Venn, 27, was sentenced to 29 months to 30 years in prison for involuntary manslaughter in the death of a high school classmate who had been in a coma for 10 years after a fight with Mr. Venn. Mr. Venn pleaded guilty in the death of Zuhair Pattah, who hit his head at West Bloomfield High School in 1994 and died in January 2003. Mr. Venn will serve at least 15 months. Jo Napolitano (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KLEIN, ISADORE
description: KLEIN--Isadore. The firm of Herzfeld & Rubin, PC is deeply saddened to hear of the death of our longtime friend, Isadore Klein. His loss will be felt by all whose lives he touched. Herbert Rubin, Herzfeld & Rubin

title: Vietnam-Era Kerry Saw a Military Led by U.N.
description: The student newspaper at Harvard University has unearthed a 34-year-old interview with Senator John Kerry, in which Mr. Kerry, then fresh out of Vietnam and an underdog candidate for Congress, suggested that he would cede authority over the military to the United Nations and rein in, or perhaps eliminate, the C.I.A.

title: U.S. Charges 4 With Supplying Steroids
description: Four people, including the personal trainer of Barry Bonds, baseball's pre-eminent slugger, were charged today in a federal indictment with running an operation that supplied dozens of professional baseball, football and elite track-and-field athletes with illegal performance-enhancing drugs.

title: Philharmonic Announces Schedule
description: The 163rd season of the New York Philharmonic will begin on Sept. 21 when Lorin Maazel leads the orchestra in Beethoven's Violin Concerto, featuring Maxim Vengerov, and Dvorak's Symphony No. 9, ''From the New World,'' a work given its premiere by the Philharmonic in 1893.

title: Why Clark's Campaign, Once Full of Hopes, Fell So Short
description: Gen. Wesley K. Clark made his way out of a hotel ballroom in Memphis on Tuesday night, minutes after he all but conceded that he was pulling out of the race for the Democratic presidential nomination after losing two primaries, when a supporter stopped him and whispered, ''I wish you'd gone to Iowa.''

title: Benign Viruses Shine on the Silicon Assembly Line
description: LIVING organisms do a fine job of growing crystals, like the ones that make up abalone shells, for example. But there are lots of other inorganic materials, including those that make up semiconductors, that living things haven't gotten around to producing.

title: City Issues New Safety Procedures for S.I. Ferry
description: New guidelines intended to tighten safety procedures for the Staten Island ferry were announced today, about four months after one of the large commuter boats plowed into a pier last year, killing 11 people and wounding dozens.

title: L.I. Bishop Is Accused Of Shielding Sex Abusers
description: Despite his denials, the Roman Catholic bishop of Long Island shielded priests accused of child sex abuse when he served as the second-highest prelate in the Boston diocese, a child-protection advocate against abuse contended on Wednesday.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Friday about criticism of a hunting trip taken by Justice Antonin Scalia with Vice President Dick Cheney misidentified the newspaper that first reported the trip. It was The Daily Review in Morgan City, La., not The Los Angeles Times.

title: Nets Roll as New Coach Ties a Record
description: The play began with Carlos Boozer driving toward the basket. Didn't he see Kenyon Martin?

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: BSKYB To Pay Dividend
description: The pay television network British Sky Broadcasting said that it would pay investors a dividend for the first time in five years. The company, which is 35 percent owned by Rupert Murdoch's News Corporation, angered investors in 2003 when it hired Mr. Murdoch's son James as chief executive. Investors were worried at that time that the strong cash flow from BSkyB would be diverted from their pockets. BSkyB will pay an interim dividend of 2.75 pence a share, the company said. BSkyB also said that net profit for the last six months of 2003 was 130 million ($245 million), up from 12 million a year ago. Heather Timmons (NYT)

title: Financing Plan to Rebuild Far West Side Is Unveiled
description: City officials unveiled a long-awaited plan yesterday to borrow $3.7 billion to transform the far West Side of Manhattan with an extended subway line, parks and a deck over a railyard where office buildings and a cultural institution could be built.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Lycos To Focus On Pay Services
description: Lycos plans to introduce a Web site that will focus on subscription-based services, and cut 12 percent of the work force. The company, a unit of Terra Networks, will cut about 50 jobs, Mark Stoever, a Terra vice president, said yesterday. The focus on subscription services, like dating through the Internet, is intended to generate stable revenue growth and make the company less dependent on advertising.

title: Deadline for Bids Nearing For Hollinger Publications
description: Preliminary offers for Hollinger International's most valuable assets, the publications in the Telegraph Group, are due by Thursday afternoon to the investment bank Lazard Brothers.

description: Olives in Brooklyn

title: Magazine Advertising Falls for an 8th Month
description: Magazine advertising began on a down note in 2004 as ad pages declined in January for an eighth consecutive month, according to information released by the Publishers Information Bureau in New York.

description: Correction Appended

title: He Loves Me Not, Digitally
description: TECHNOLOGY with roots in antiterrorism will soon make the singles scene safer and friendlier, not to mention more efficient, if a software system called the Love Detector lives up to its billing.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   NASS, NANETTE
description: NASS--Nanette. We are saddened by the loss of Nanette Nass who passed away on February 11, 2004. Beloved wife of Harold for 57 years, devoted mother of Lily and Max and grandmother of Eva. Nan's loving ways will be missed.

title: A Show and a Real Trial: A Moral Line
description: On Oct. 17, before any evidence had been presented in the murder trials of Lee Malvo and John Muhammad, an actor playing Mr. Malvo appeared on television. In sequences that looked like documentary clips, he made terrorist demands and loaded the trunk of a car with guns. ''Everything but pulling the trigger,'' says David Erickson, who wrote ''D.C. Sniper: 23 Days of Fear'' for the USA Network. ''It was clear what he was doing.''

title: For Those Who Can't Wait for the Future to Arrive
description: MIKE TRAINOR has the luxury of being a pragmatist who is required to spend a lot time in the world of computing make-believe.

title: Nursing Home Is Penalized Over a Death
description: State investigators have partly suspended Medicaid and Medicare subsidies to a nursing home in Queens where a woman died last week after she was found on the roof of the home, the state Department of Health said yesterday.

title: An Illustration of the Law of Unintended Consequences
description: Democratic lawmakers are chortling over the cover letter that accompanied the new presidential economic report that landed on Capitol Hill with a thud this week because of its positive outlook about moving jobs overseas.

title: On an English Bay, a Rising Turf War Over Lucrative Shellfish
description: The competition for cockles had grown stiff over the last year on Morecambe Bay, where 19 Chinese workers drowned last week after getting trapped by swiftly rising tides.

title: Corrections
description: An entry in the Addenda listing of Business Day on Jan. 30 about the selection of the Draft agency to handle direct marketing for American Century Investments misidentified the agency that previously held that role. It was Digitas, not Bernstein-Rein Advertising.

title: Jim Russo, 81, 'Superscout' Who Helped Build the Orioles
description: Jim Russo, who helped build a host of pennant-winning Baltimore Oriole teams in a scouting career that spanned more than three decades, died in Grover, Mo. He was 81.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Finland: Financial Services Acquisition
description: Sampo, a Finnish financial services company, agreed to buy control of If Skadefoersaekring Holding for 1.37 billion euros ($1.75 billion) to become the largest Nordic property and casualty insurer. Sampo is buying stakes in Stockholm-based If, owned by Skandia A.B., Skandia Liv and Storebrand. The purchase values If at 24 billion kronor ($3.3 billion), Storebrand said. Sampo, whose shares have risen 41 percent in the last year, has a market value of 5 billion euros.

title: U.N. Chief Calls More Talks in Effort to End Division of Cyprus
description: Secretary General Kofi Annan on Wednesday scheduled a third day of critical talks for Thursday with Greek and Turkish Cypriot leaders to overcome objections to his terms for ending the 30-year division of Cyprus.

title: Regime Thought War Unlikely, Iraqis Tell U.S.
description: A complacent Saddam Hussein was so convinced that war would be averted or that America would mount only a limited bombing campaign that he deployed the Iraqi military to crush domestic uprisings rather than defend against a ground invasion, according to a classified log of interrogations of captured Iraqi leaders and former officers.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-22

title: Two in Clinton Impeachment Taking Roles in Rowland Case
description: Two lawyers who represented President Bill Clinton during his impeachment will now play roles in the impeachment inquiry of Gov. John G. Rowland, officials said on Wednesday.

title: Judge Denies N.F.L.'s Bid To Keep Clarett Out of Draft
description: Ohio State running back Maurice Clarett cleared one of the final hurdles in his quest to enter the N.F.L. draft, when a federal judge yesterday declined the league's request for a stay of her decision that Clarett and other underclassmen are eligible for the draft.

description: LOVE MONKEY

title: A Troubled 'Marriage'
description: There is much common ground between many proponents and opponents of gay marriage. What matters, they say, is not whether the government may give gay couples who commit themselves to lasting partnerships the same bundle of benefits and burdens it gives straight couples who marry. What matters is the word used to describe the bundle.

title: Making High-Tech Play Less Work
description: IN the late 1990's, as personal computers were becoming as common in many American households as televisions and cordless phones, the toy industry quickly embraced technologies like microprocessors, optical sensors and audio synthesizers. But some parents complained that child's play was becoming anything but. Toys and games, they said, were becoming too difficult to set up, charge up and play.

title: Mortgage Index Declines Again
description: An index of mortgage applications fell for a third week, reflecting fewer home purchases and less refinancing, an industry group report showed.

title: The Khan Artist
description: I think President Bush has cleared up everything now.

title: 2 Testify on Williams's Reaction to Death
description: The prosecution in the aggravated manslaughter trial of Jayson Williams opened its case Wednesday with testimony and evidence establishing the fatal shooting of a chauffeur, Costas Christofi, in Mr. Williams's master bedroom nearly two years ago.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KURTZ, MORTON, MD.
description: KURTZ--Morton, MD. The Officers, Counselors and Trustees of the Medical Society of the State of New York (MSSNY) record with deep sorrow the passing of their past president, friend and esteemed colleague. ''Morty'' Kurtz practiced medicine in Queens for 50 years and enriched the lives of innumerable patients, friends and fellow physicians. Dr. Kurtz was a caring physician, knowledgeable medical practitioner and a true humanitarian. As President of MSSNY (1992-1993), his leadership and thoughtful deliberation were invaluable in the formation of society policy aimed at bettering healthcare for all New Yorkers. We extend our deepest sympathies to his wife Georgine, his family and his friends. Jeffrey Ribner, MD, Pres.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LOVE, DR. SIDNEY
description: LOVE--Dr. Sidney. Rest in peace. The Stokes family

title: White House Memo; Anxiety Takes Hold of Presidential Aides Caught Up in Inquiry Over Leak
description: It started almost casually last fall, with F.B.I. agents leaving business cards under doors around the White House, politely calling for appointments and even meeting some officials, without any lawyers present, over a few beers at a nearby bar.

title: Julius Schwartz, 88, Editor Who Revived Superhero Genre in Comic Books
description: Julius Schwartz, a comic-book editor who rescued the superhero genre from near extinction in the mid-1950's and helped shape popular characters including Batman, the Flash and Green Lantern, died on Sunday in Mineola, N.Y. He was 88 and lived in Queens Village.

title: In Middle Age, L.I. Suburbs Show Wear
description: Long Island, where post-World War II suburbia was born, is in a midlife crisis and battling some disturbing social and economic trends that provide a window into issues that suburbs around the nation may face, according to a 15-month study sponsored by a nonprofit group.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Morristown: Inquiry Into Death Of Child
description: A child died in a New Jersey hospital on Jan. 31, after a resident connected the child's oxygen tubing and intravenous tubing, lines that should not have been compatible, a hospital spokeswoman said. The spokeswoman added that the child's family did not want details of the death to be made public. The hospital, Morristown Memorial, said in a statement on Monday that it had been conducting an investigation into the death, which it had immediately reported to state authorities. It did not disclose the name of the child or the resident. The death was first reported in The Star-Ledger. Sabrina Tavernise (NYT)

title: Our Children in Iraq
description: To the Editor:

title: Bush Proposes Strict Limits on Black Market Sale of Equipment to Make Nuclear Fuel
description: President Bush on Wednesday proposed a seven-point plan to make it far more difficult to sell nuclear equipment on the black market, declaring that the ease with which North Korea, Iran and Libya received help from a Pakistani scientist showed that the United States must ''prevent governments from developing nuclear weapons under false pretenses.''

title: Revlon Announces Deal to Cut Its Debt Load
description: Ronald O. Perelman, the financier and majority owner of Revlon Inc. , has struck a deal with Fidelity Management and Research, the giant mutual fund company, to help cut the cosmetic giant's $1.9 billion debt load almost in half by swapping bonds for company shares.

title: Chrysler Deal Called a 'Godsend'
description: On the last day of testimony in Kirk Kerkorian's fraud lawsuit against DaimlerChrysler, the company's expert witness described the $36 billion combination that created the company as a ''godsend'' for Chrysler shareholders, including Mr. Kerkorian.

title: The Mouse Besieged
description: The attempt by Comcast, the nation's largest cable company, to take over the fabled entertainment empire built by Walt Disney and Mickey Mouse is far from a completed deal. But it's not too early for federal regulators to stop distracting themselves with small-change debates over the sanctity of the Super Bowl halftime show and focus on remaking the nation's policy on media companies for the 21st century. Comcast should have to work harder to woo federal regulators on this $54.1 billion deal than to persuade Disney shareholders to permit the takeover.

title: Global Job Hopping
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Longing
description: The best possible response to spring couture. Photographs by Jean-Baptiste Mondino.

title: The Biker Governor
description: Becoming governor of California has not stopped Arnold Schwarzenegger from enjoying a Sunday motorcycle ride with friends.

title: Southwest's $29 Fares Jolt US Airways in Philadelphia
description: Beginning a heated competition for passengers in Philadelphia, Southwest Airlines said yesterday that fares would cost as little as $29 for a one-way ticket when it begins service there on May 9.

title: Holiday on Monday
description: Washington's Birthday, actually Feb. 22, will be observed.

title: Why Outsource? Just Do the Math
description: To the Editor:

title: Split on Clones of Embryos: Research vs. Reproduction
description: The news that South Korean researchers have become the first to produce human embryos and stem cells through cloning has revived a complex debate about whether such research should be permitted in the United States.

title: Corrections
description: An article and a picture caption on Feb. 2 about the relocation of Thurgood Marshall Academy to a new building in Harlem referred incorrectly to an apartment in a neighboring building owned by Jeanne Littlejohn, who has filed a lawsuit claiming that it was damaged during construction. It was a rental apartment; she does not live in the building.

title: Questions About the Fitness Of Rowland Security Chief
description: There was great relief here last week when a suspicious powder found in a Wallingford mail distribution center on Feb. 2 turned out to be a harmless substance with no connection to terrorism.

title: Blurring the Line Between the Present and the Future
description: Among portraits of artists' mothers, few are as complicated as ''Materia'' (1912), a very large image of his mother by the Futurist painter-sculptor Umberto Boccioni (1882-1916). She sits in the window of an apartment in Milan, a work-worn woman with enormous gnarled hands that are given frontal prominence, folded in her lap. Her pose is an ironic reflection of the Renaissance Madonna with a background of a tranquil landscape.

title: Bishop Offers Detailed Rebuttal To Charge of Shielding Abusers
description: The Roman Catholic bishop of Long Island issued a detailed denial yesterday of allegations that he shielded priests accused of child sex abuse while he was serving in the Archdiocese of Boston.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: More Charges For Durst
description: Robert A. Durst, the New York real estate heir who was acquitted of murdering his Galveston, Tex., neighbor last November, was indicted on another criminal charge yesterday as he sat in a Texas jail. A grand jury indicted him on a charge of ''tampering with physical evidence,'' a reference to his decision to butcher his 71-year-old neighbor and throw the body parts in Galveston Bay. Bail was set at $1 billion, bringing his total to a record $3 billion. Although he admitted cutting up the neighbor, a jury found Mr. Durst not guilty of murder after he claimed that the two men struggled over a pistol, which went off accidentally in the neighbor's face. But Mr. Durst had remained in the county jail on charges of bail-jumping. ''It's awfully late and awfully retaliatory,'' Dick DeGuerin, one of Mr. Durst's lawyers, said yesterday.

title: 160 Migrants Are Seized At Upscale Arizona Home
description: To people in the placid neighborhood at the golf course's edge, where the median price of a home is $450,000, it seemed there was an awful lot of traffic at a house on East Shea Boulevard in Scottsdale, Ariz., the most exclusive suburb of Phoenix.

title: New Targets: Attackers Shift Their Sights to the Iraqis
description: The fourth deadly suicide bombing in Iraq in less than two weeks suggests that the insurgency that has bedeviled the Americans and Iraqis since the collapse of Saddam Hussein's government is changing in important ways.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about assertions by the chief United Nations prosecutor for war crimes that the leading Bosnian Serb suspect, Dr. Radovan Karadzic, was hiding in Belgrade referred incorrectly to Beta, the news agency that reported the Serbian government's denial. The agency is private, not state-owned.

title: Greek and Turkish Cypriot Leaders Agree on End to Split
description: UNITED NATIONS, Feb. 13 — Greek and Turkish Cypriot leaders today accepted Secretary General Kofi Annan's plan for ending Cyprus's decades of division and pledged to negotiate reunification in time for the island's May 1 entry into the European Union.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Solectron To Sell Unit
description: The Solectron Corporation plans to sell its Smart Modular Technologies memory and communications products unit to Texas Pacific Group, Francisco Partners and Shah Management for $100 million in cash. Solectron, a maker of printers for Hewlett-Packard, is selling Smart Modular for a fraction of the $2 billion in stock that it paid in 1999.

title: For Kerry and Bush, Vietnam Years Loom
description: In loosely organized campaigns that in some ways are mirror images, political partisans are poring over the Vietnam War years of Senator John Kerry and President Bush.

title: Candidates' Schedules
description: HOWARD DEAN -- Eau Claire, Green Bay, Cleveland and Milwaukee, Wis.

title: The Media's Job
description: To the Editor:

title: To Gain an Edge in Fuel Use, Newman Says, Do the Math
description: On his way to winning a series-high eight races on the Nascar Winston Cup circuit last season, Ryan Newman met both praise and skepticism over his seeming ability to run longer on a tank of gas than other drivers.

title: Corrections
description: A chart with the State of the Art column in Circuits yesterday, comparing high-capacity portable music players, truncated the name of the software used with the Nomad Zen Xtra player from Creative Labs. It is Creative MediaSource. The chart also overstated the player's abilities; it cannot record.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   PAPOCK, HERBERT
description: PAPOCK--Herbert. On February 9, 2004. Loving husband of the late Hurley. Beloved father of Alexander and Tatiana. Dear brother to Sylvan. Private services were held on on February 11, 2004.

title: Lamb Tagine With Honey, Almonds and Apricots (Mrouzia)
description: Equal parts sweet and savory, this dish is a long-cooking stew where lamb shares the stage with a host of spices. Lamb shoulder is the ideal stewing meat; it's plentiful connective tissue will melt down during the braising process to thicken the sauce. Beef or rabbit can also be used, though the cooking time may be shorter.

title: ImClone Cancer Drug Behind Martha Stewart Trial Is Approved by F.D.A.
description: ImClone Systems' cancer drug, Erbitux, won approval from the Food and Drug Administration yesterday, more than two years after an initial rejection set off the stock-trading scandal that sent the company's former chief executive, Samuel D. Waksal, to prison and put his friend, Martha Stewart, on trial.

title: Lottery Numbers
World Business Briefing | Europe: Inquiry Into Music Merger
description: The European Commission has opened an investigation into the merger planned by the record companies Sony of Japan and BMG, a unit of the German publisher Bertelsmann. The commission said the deal might ''create or strengthen a collective dominant position of the major record companies in the markets for recorded music.'' It said Sony BMG would have a market share of about 25 percent, and with its biggest rival, Universal, would control about half of the recorded music market. Paul Meller (NYT)

title: INSIDE ART
description: National Gallery Adds to Collection

title: Medical and Ethical Issues Cloud Cloning for Therapy
description: In cloning human embryos and extracting universal stem cells, scientists in South Korea have taken a big step toward a tantalizing goal: growing tailor-made replacement tissues for people who are sick or injured. Imagine new cardiac muscles to restore a heart after a heart attack, insulin-producing cells for diabetics or neurons to stave off Parkinson's disease.

title: Republicans Attack Kerry in Video and E-Mail
description: Republicans attacked Senator John Kerry of Massachusetts on an array of fronts Thursday, the beginning of what party officials said would be an attempt to undercut Mr. Kerry's reputation at a time when he is riding high from repeated victories in primaries and caucuses.

title: Why Outsource? Just Do the Math
description: To the Editor:

title: Johnson Out to Make Most Of Second Chance by Knicks
description: DerMarr Johnson had traveled across the country and was now crisscrossing Westchester County, the best day of his life winding slowly into the longest night of his career.

title: Ashcroft Defends Subpoenas
description: Attorney General John Ashcroft rebuffed calls from Congressional Democrats and abortion rights groups on Thursday to drop the Justice Department's demands for abortion records from a half-dozen hospitals.

title: Tightening of Media Knots
description: The knots that bind the biggest media companies were poised to pull tighter yesterday with Comcast's $54 billion bid for the Walt Disney Company. As rivals scramble to react, they could get tighter still.

title: Changes Urged In Operations Of S.I. Ferry
description: Correction Appended

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-14

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GOLDSTEIN, ELIZABETH L. (NEE KAMINSKY)
description: GOLDSTEIN -- Elizabeth L. (nee Kaminsky). On February 12, 2004, at age 96, in Norfolk, VA. Beloved wife of the late Samuel K. Goldstein of Brooklyn, New York. Adored mother of Marilyn G. Schwartz and proud motherin-law of Joseph B. Schwartz of New York City. Devoted sister, sister-in-law, aunt, great aunt, cousin and teacher. Services Sunday, 11:15AM at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 W. 76 St, NYC. Memorial donations may be made to the Schwartz-Goldstein Lecture Fund, Stephen Wise Free Synagogue, 30 W. 68 St., N.Y., N.Y. 10023.

title: Determined Women, Finding Their Voice
description: On the way to a women's suffrage meeting in 1912, the radical agitator Alice Paul (Hilary Swank) freezes in her tracks at the sight of a pink cloche in a shop window. She and her friend Lucy Burns (Frances O'Connor) banter winningly over who saw the hat first, then flip a coin to settle who should have it.

title: National Briefing | South: Arkansas: Guarantee Of Education Money
description: Gov. Mike Huckabee signed a bill to guarantee financing for public schools. The legislation provides that money be diverted to education from other state accounts if tax collections cannot fully finance schools. The new law was one of several enacted in response to a State Supreme Court finding that public schools in Arkansas were unconstitutionally underfinanced. Steve Barnes (NYT)

title: A Star With an Image Problem, In Search of the Perfect Date
description: Win a Date With Tad Hamilton!

title: Soulful Androids Who Endure Those Cold Humans
description: Opening today in Manhattan, the writer-director Greg Pak's ''Robot Stories'' -- a fantasy anthology that details the ways robots have complicated human lives -- has a dexterous sense of wonder that nonetheless leaves the film feeling a bit detached. Perhaps it's because the film's four stories, well told, have the gentle lull of whimsy. But Mr. Pak's fascination with the material goes a long way; many of the loveliest moments seem to owe to touches from Isaac Asimov's sweeping ''Robot Chronicles.''

title: Newark Holds Rally to Back New Arena for Devils
description: Newark's cheerleader-in-chief, Mayor Sharpe James, donned skates and took to the ice at a recreation center here Thursday to rally support for the city's plan to build an arena for the New Jersey Devils.

title: Legendary Silk Weavers of Queens Plan to Pack Up Their Needles and Go
description: Franco Scalamandr opened his fabric mill in 1929 in Long Island City, Queens, and one of the first orders was a silk brocatelle for the estate of William Randolph Hearst.

title: Weekender | Cold Spring, N.Y.
description: ITS breathtaking setting on the banks of the Hudson River has long drawn both day-trippers and potential homeowners to Cold Spring, and the area is an outdoor enthusiast's dream, with the Appalachian Trail just seven miles away.

title: Richard Diamond, 71, Newspaper Publisher
description: Richard Edward Diamond, publisher of The Staten Island Advance, part of the Newhouse publishing empire, died yesterday at his home in the Todt Hill section of Staten Island. A lifelong resident of Staten Island, he was 71.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Fatal Fall After Police Raid
description: A man fell to his death on Wednesday afternoon while trying to evade the police by hanging off an East Harlem roof, a police spokesman said yesterday. Narcotics agents were executing a search warrant at 1799 Lexington Avenue when the man, Simon Ambrose, 31, of the Bronx, fled to the roof and tried to hang over the wall, but lost his grip and fell seven floors, the police said. The officers found marijuana and arrested three men, Lawrence Shields, 29, and Jason Romero, 22, of the Bronx, and Jimmy Rooks, 22, of West 109th Street in Manhattan. Shaila K. Dewan (NYT)
