description: Two New York City police detectives and a sergeant have been placed on desk duty and a second sergeant has been transferred in connection with an investigation into corruption accusations in a Queens police precinct, several police officials, who spoke on the condition of anonymity, said last night.

title: A Murder in Brazil
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   NOVINA, PHILIP
description: NOVINA--Philip. We mourn the passing on February 3, of a beloved father, husband, and physician. Philip was a successful OB/GYN for 21 years, but his greatest legacy is his children, Carl and Julia. He is also survived by first wife, Ulla, and second wife, Dale. Memorial: February 15, 2PM, The Hermitage, Ho-HoKus, NJ. Donations can be made to the Valley Hospital, Ridgewood, NJ.

title: Former Chechen Leader Killed in Car Explosion in Qatar
description: The former president of Chechnya was killed in an explosion of his car in the Gulf Arab state of Qatar today, according to a report by Al Jazeera, the Arab television network that is based there.

title: ART GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times: New or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York museums and art galleries this weekend. At many museums, children under 12 and members are admitted free. Addresses, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan. Most galleries are closed on Sundays and Mondays, but hours vary and should be checked by telephone. Gallery admission is free unless noted. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: CABARET GUIDE
description: A selective listing of new or noteworthy cabaret shows in Manhattan this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: On an Island: A Chance To Chill Out
description: AFTER 50 minutes, the afternoon ferry from Point Judith, R.I., pulled into Block Island's Old Harbor at 5 o'clock, just as the setting sun forced a blush from the enormous, thin-blue sky. A string of pretty little shops with ''closed'' signs hanging in their doors faced the ferry dock. At the end of the street stood the grand Victorian pile of the National Hotel, its porch roof supported by two-by-fours while the lower portion was being rebuilt.

title: National Briefing: Southwest
description: TEXAS: INQUIRY ON TUITION INCREASES Legislators concerned about increases in tuition have ordered a performance audit of the state's two major university systems. The University of Texas will increase tuition and fees 26 percent this year, and Texas A&M has proposed a 21 percent rise. Steve Barnes (NYT)

title: National Briefing | Washington: Science Foundation Leader To Leave
description: Rita R. Colwell, director of the National Science Foundation, is retiring as of Feb. 21, the agency announced, and Arden Bement Jr., a former professor at Purdue, will become acting director. Dr. Colwell, a microbiologist, will become chairwoman of Canon U.S. Life Sciences, a unit of Canon U.S.A. Jo Napolitano (NYT)

title: U.N. Envoy, Visiting Iraq, Backs Cleric On Elections
description: A senior United Nations envoy said Thursday that he supported a powerful Shiite cleric's call for elections to install a new sovereign government, but did not offer a specific timetable.

title: A Party With One Too Many Sponsors
description: There were teapots on the tables set alongside the catwalk at Cynthia Rowley's show last night, so why not a tempest? Backstage at the conclusion of Ms. Rowley's show, titled ''Midnight Tea,'' a guard wrestled away a camera she was carrying as she headed onto the runway to take the traditional bow. ''He grabbed it right off me,'' a shaken Ms. Rowley said, proferring a scratched hand.

title: Chicken Tagine With Lemon and Olives (Djej MChermel)
description: Aclassic that is truly ubiquitous in Morocco, this dish combines the tang of preserved lemons (lemons that have been soaked in a brine for up to six months) with the salinity of olives (be stingy with any added salt). If you can't find preserved lemons (see note), you can substitute lemon zest, ideally zest that has been blanched two or three times to remove its bitterness.

title: Dean Explains Support for Civil Union but Not Gay Marriage
description: Since the beginning of his presidential campaign, Howard Dean has had to defend his signing of the first bill in the nation creating civil unions for gay couples while also being challenged about why he does not back gay marriage.

title: Soldier Is Facing Charges Of Trying to Aid Al Qaeda
description: A member of the Washington State National Guard was taken into custody on Thursday to face possible charges that he tried to pass information to Al Qaeda terrorist network.

title: Bond Swap By Fidelity Helps Revlon Cut Its Debt
description: Ronald O. Perelman, the financier and majority owner of Revlon Inc., has struck a deal with Fidelity Management and Research, a large mutual fund company, to help cut his company's $1.9 billion debt almost in half by swapping bonds for company shares.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BERNSTEIN, SELMA D.
description: BERNSTEIN--Selma D. Died February 2, 2004 at age 90. Wife of Lester. Mother of Robert and Joel. Grandmother of Benjamin, Ariel, Simon, Emily, Jacob and Haylee. Teacher, past President of Hadassah (New Rochelle) and of her condominium. She will be praised at the Gates by her very own deeds. Contributions in her memory should be made to Hadassah (New Rochelle).

title: Why Outsource? Just Do the Math
description: To the Editor:

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Appeals Court Revives Gemstar Suit
description: A federal appeals court yesterday revived Gemstar-TV Guide International's patent lawsuit against EchoStar Communications and makers of television set-top boxes. The United States Court of Appeals for the Federal Circuit in Washington ruled that a federal judge in North Carolina incorrectly interpreted patents related to on-screen TV program guides. The judge had ruled that EchoStar, Hughes Electronics' DirecTV unit and Thomson's consumer electronics division did not infringe the patents. Gemstar settled a patent suit with Thomson last year and reached an agreement to license the program technology for Thomson's RCA and General Electric televisions. It also settled a dispute with TiVo Inc. The appeals court ordered the EchoStar case returned to the trial judge for reconsideration. The ruling came on the same day that Gemstar said it settled consolidated shareholder lawsuits for $67.5 million: $42.5 million in cash and the issuance of 4.1 million shares at $6.09 each.

title: Procreation, Passion and Partnership: A Tour of Africa by Twos
description: ''Make love, not war'' is one amendment I wouldn't mind seeing written into the United States Constitution, and into every other civic document across the world. The idea has a long history in art (as, of course, does its bellicose opposite). And it reigns supreme in the pulsing little valentine of an exhibition titled ''Echoing Images: Couples in African Sculpture'' at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WEISS, HAROLD
description: WEISS--Harold. Farewell dear friend. It's been too short but we'll treasure every memory. Judy and Jack

title: A Little Marital Stress? He's a Cop Who Buys the Drugs She Demands
description: ''After the Life'' is the last film in Lucas Belvaux's ''Trilogy'' to be released, a decision by the film's American distributors that may well be arbitrary, since the three episodes were made simultaneously and can be watched in any order. But the choice nonetheless feels apt: this installment, a sorrowful, sunlit melodrama about addiction and marital malaise, is the one that most convincingly carries both the ambitions and the cumulative richness of Mr. Belvaux's project.

title: Studiously Unraveling the Intricate Web of Chaplin as Filmmaker and Performer
description: In ''The Dreamers,'' Bernardo Bertolucci's celebration of youthful cinephilia, two youthful cinephiles argue about the relative merits of Buster Keaton and Charlie Chaplin. Keaton seems to be prevailing until the Chaplin fan plays his trump card -- the famous scene from ''City Lights'' in which the blind flower seller, her sight restored thanks to an operation paid for by the Little Tramp, recognizes her benefactor by touching his face. That moment, which Mr. Bertolucci inserts into ''The Dreamers,'' provides the final image in Richard Schickel's ''Charlie: The Life and Art of Charles Chaplin,'' a new documentary that opens today in Manhattan.

title: Reunion Tour On the Street; One for Money And Prestige
description: With its rich mix of prestige and lucre, the proposed Comcast-Disney deal has attracted an all-star lineup of Wall Street's most famous dealmakers.

title: In the Snow: Speed, Schnapps And Bloodshed
description: A SPECTATOR nearly died from hypothermia one year. Another year, a snowmobile racer was rushed to a hospital when his corneas froze. And then there was the year the temperature dropped to 31 degrees below zero, and the portable toilets filled with ice. But none of that kept Kim Taylor from standing outside for eight hours last weekend to witness 33 souped-up sleds compete in the International 500 Snowmobile Race here -- an indigenous sport that is equal parts Nascar, gladiator games and Arctic ''Survivor.''

title: U.N. Aides Slaying in Congo Brings Back Eerie Memories
description: BUNIA, Democratic Republic of Congo, Feb. 13  The death of an unarmed United Nations military observer in the ambush of his convoy on Thursday was an eerie replay of the troubles that beset the United Nations peacekeeping mission here just under a year ago.

title: Just Fly the Plane!
description: To the Editor:

title: Steroids and Sports Take On Political Dimension
description: President Bush drew a lot of snickers when he spoke out about steroid use by athletes in his State of the Union speech. The knock was that such a frivolous subject trivialized the national address and showed the former part-owner of the Texas Rangers was more caught up in sports than other critical policy debates.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: Adecco Investigation
description: The Zurich stock exchange said it had opened a formal investigation into Adecco, the large employment services company, to establish whether the Swiss group failed to provide investors with timely market-sensitive information. Adecco, which is listed in Zurich and on the New York Stock Exchange, said it was cooperating with the inquiry but declined to comment. The Zurich stock exchange, which opened a preliminary inquiry last month, said its action was prompted by Adecco's disclosure on Jan. 12 that it had found accounting problems in its North American unit, Adecco Staffing, and that as a result, 2003 results would be delayed. Fiona Fleck (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HEALY, BEA
description: HEALY--Bea. February 11, 2004. Beloved mother of Margaret Healy Bay and Jacqueline Fitzgerald. Cherished grandmother of Marianne Belica and her husband Michael and great-grandmother of Michael, Alexandra and Jessica. She will be deeply missed by all who knew and loved her. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave and 81st St., Monday, Februay 16, 2-5 and 7-9 PM. Mass of Christian Burial, Tuesday, February 17, 10 AM at St. John the Evangelist Church, First Ave at 55th St., NYC. Contributions in her memory may be made to the Cabrini Hospice, 227 E. 19th St., NY, NY 10003.

title: Budget Office Suggests Tax On Lattes and Liposuction
description: It has been almost 40 years since a Beatles song suggested imposing a tax -- or as certain New York politicians prefer to say, ''user fee'' -- on part of the human anatomy: ''If you take a walk, I'll tax your feet.''

title: CHICAGO EQUITY COMPANY TO BUY PRESTIGE BRANDS
description: GTCR Golder Rauner, a Chicago-based private equity company, agreed to buy Prestige Brands, a maker of household cleaning and personal care products, from MidOcean Partners for an undisclosed amount. The acquisition comes two days after GTCR said it agreed to buy Medtech Holdings, the maker of Compound W wart remover and Denorex shampoo, for an undisclosed amount.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: PC Sales To Rise In First Quarter
description: Sales of personal computers will rise 13 percent in the first quarter on higher demand by consumers for portable devices, the market researcher Gartner Inc. said yesterday. Shipments will increase by 14 percent in 2004, with gains of at least 10 percent every quarter as businesses replace PC's bought in 2000, especially in the United States, Gartner said. Shipments grew 11 percent in 2003, up from a 2.7 percent increase in 2002 and a 4.6 percent decline in 2001, according to Gartner. PC shipments will top 187 million this year, Gartner predicted.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   FELD, ISABEL
description: FELD--Isabel. In memory of Isabel Feld, a lady of beauty, grace, and generosity, who enriched the life of her husband, Harold Feld, and her family.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Feb. 8 about Oswald Villard Jr., an electrical engineer who did early work on over-the-horizon radar, misstated the surname of an electronics pioneer with whom he worked as a student at Stanford. It was William Hewlett, not Hewett.

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times: New or noteworthy pop and jazz concerts in the New York metropolitan region this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended concert.

title: Israel Will Not Join In Hearing in Hague
description: Israel said Thursday that it would not take part in a hearing this month at the International Court of Justice on the legality of the contentious separation barrier that is under construction in the West Bank.

title: Profit Increases 24% In Quarter at Dell
description: Dell, the personal computer maker, said yesterday that fourth-quarter profit increased 24 percent as it cut expenses while demand for its products rose.

title: Couscous
description: Commonly mislabeled a grain, couscous is actually a semolina pasta, rolled into small pellets. It is the universal accompaniment to all tagines in north Africa, though rice will work fine in its absence.

title: Altering Your Engine With New Chips
description: WHEN Scott Farrell, a Coast Guard instructor in Newport News, Va., wanted a big power boost for his 1998 Volkswagen Jetta TDI, he didn't lower the suspension, install a hot camshaft or add a free-flow exhaust. Instead, he had a business-card size electronic part installed -- a so-called ''performance chip'' designed to reprogram the car's engine control module to provide more horsepower. ''It was a night-and-day difference,'' he said.

title: Dean Woos Fans of Clark, Who Is Said to Support Kerry
description: Just two days after abandoning his bid for the Democratic presidential nomination, Gen. Wesley K. Clark plans to endorse Senator John Kerry of Massachusetts on Friday, aides to the senator said.

title: Paula Hayes -- 'Forest'
description: Salon 94

title: A Four-Cornered Asylum With Solos Inside
description: Deborah Hay has been through many choreographic transformations, beginning with relatively traditional work and then moving into the experimentalism of the 1960's and on to ''protofolk'' pieces, as the dance writer Don McDonagh put it. But one continuing theme has been the individual natures of her performers. And that is the central theme of ''The Match,'' a new work Ms. Hay presented on Saturday night at the Danspace Project.

title: What's Under the Ink? White House Comes Clean
description: ''Have you ever been arrested, indicted or convicted for any violation of civil or military law?'' a form in President Bush's National Guard file asks. But the answer in the publicly released form, published on Thursday in USA Today, is blacked out, suggesting the worst.

title: A Mystical View of God's Feminine Side
description: Elisa Monte established herself as a choreographer with a belief in the equality of the sexes from her first piece, which was a sensual 1979 duet called ''Treading'' that is now a modern-dance classic.

title: Party Houses: Room for Guests, Room for Dancing
description: WHO -- Jean Carper, 72, USA Weekend columnist and author of ''Stop Aging Now!''

title: Greece Struggles to Reach Olympics' Finish Line
description: Greek organizers of the 2004 Olympics like to bill it as the competition's heady return to its birthplace, and their favorite, most frequently trumpeted illustration of that modernity-meets-antiquity theme is the planned marathon route.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FRAME, EDITH
description: FRAME--Edith, of Lauderhill, FL, died peacefully at home on February 11, 2004, at the age of 93. Beloved wife of the late Maurice Frame. Devoted mother of Susan Frame of Manhattan. Rest in peace, with eternal love.

title: F.D.A. Delays Decision on Wider Access for Contraceptive
description: The Food and Drug Administration has told Barr Laboratories, the marketer of a so-called morning-after pill, that it is delaying its decision on whether to allow the drug to be sold over the counter.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BERG, SYLVIA
description: BERG--Sylvia. Formerly of Jackson Heights, NY, died peacefully at Connecticut Hospice on February 12, 2004. She is survived by her children Dr. Gerald and Barbara Berg of Woodbridge, CT and Stanley Berg of Garnerville, NY. She was the wife of the late Alban (Abe) Berg. Our dear Grandma Sylvia will be greatly missed by grandchildren Adam of Hyde Park, VT, Jason and Laura Berg of North Hampton, MA, and Melissa and Dr. Andrew Lawson of Woodbridge, CT. She was the darling great-grandmother of Matt, Alex, Emily and Samantha. Beloved sister of Mildred and Sidney Spector and Lorraine and Harold Mechlin. Loving aunt and friend to many nieces and nephews and caring companion to Nathan Katz. Her enduring legacy is her family and friends who love her deeply. Services at Schwartz Bros.-Jeffer Memorial Chapels, 114-03 Queens Blvd, Forest Hills, NY at 12 Noon. Contributions may be made to the Jewish Center of Jackson Heights.

title: A View From Syria
description: To the Editor:

title: Officials Discuss Details of Bush's Immigrant Worker Plan
description: Government officials outlined details of the Bush administration's sweeping plan to overhaul the nation's immigration laws on Thursday, saying that the proposed guest worker program would grant legal status to illegal immigrants who were living in the United States on Jan. 7.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: India: Industrial Output Rises
description: India's industrial output rose at an annualized rate of 6.2 percent in December, fueled by demand from the farm sector, which profited from a strong growing season. The government report supported estimates that the gross domestic product could grow more than 8 percent in the fiscal year ending in March. For the first nine months, industrial output rose 6.3 percent. Saritha Rai (NYT)

title: It Isn't Easy Being Queen (Murders and Power Grabs!)

Orchids and other flowers were imported from Thailand, and a 110-member orchestra was flown in from Britain, a Sahara statement said. Chinese acrobats and dancers entertained. Thousands of chefs cooked for the guests, who included Prime Minister Atal Bihari Vajpayee, at center in dark suit. As newspapers speculated about the cost of the six-day extravaganza  The Guardian put it at $94 million  the father of the grooms and Sahara's chief executive, Subroto Roy, to the left of Mr. Vajpayee, announced that free meals would be distributed to more than 140,000 poor people. title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Glaxo's Profit Falls
description: The pharmaceuticals company GlaxoSmithKline said that legal costs and a decline in sales of the antidepressant Paxil helped reduce fourth-quarter net income by 15.5 percent. Net income for the three months ended Dec. 31 was 790 million ($1.41 billion), down from 935 million in the 2002 quarter. Fourth-quarter sales fell 5 percent, to 5.38 billion ($9.30 billion). The company said Paxil sales fell 40 percent in the period as a result of generic competition. The generic drug was released in the United States in September, and by January generic drugs had taken 52 percent of the market, GlaxoSmithKline said.

After years of subordinating his health to his sense of mission, he is finally heeding his doctors' call to take a well-earned retirement. He will be missed.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Illinois: Ex-Patient Wins Suit
description: A woman who said doctors at a Skokie hospital led her to believe she had multiple personality disorder has settled a malpractice suit for $7.5 million. The woman, Elizabeth Gale, 52, was treated for mild depression at Rush North Shore Medical Center for 11 years, ending in 1997. She said three doctors used repressed memory therapy and erroneously led her to believe she had been molested as a child and was a cult member. The hospital said the doctors no longer worked there. The two have been battling for eight months for control of the company. Brascan has the backing of the company's founder and a major shareholder, Paul Reichmann. Heather Timmons (NYT)

title: 36 Hours | Steamboat Springs, Colo.
description: SITUATED in the Yampa River Valley in Colorado's northwestern corner, Steamboat Springs (population 10,115) exudes a subtle beauty. Fresh snow blankets the meadows and aspens and Douglas firs look as if they've been dipped in frost. Storms from the Pacific charge unimpeded into Steamboat releasing froths of ''champagne'' powder onto its peaks. (There has been nearly 15 feet of snowfall this season.) At 6,695 feet, Steamboat Springs is a true mountain town; in addition to skiers, you'll run across whitewater paddlers, mountain bikers and trail runners. One tip for visitors: if the combination of the high altitude and the high-quality beers sold at many of the town's restaurants and bars proves to be a debilitating combination, take advantage of the town's free bus shuttle that operates every 20 minutes from 7 a.m. to 2 a.m. each day. WENDY KNIGHT

title: Tribute to a Composer Shows How He Heard and Thought
description: Alan Feinberg's explorations in the piano repertory are always refreshing, and usually surprising. Having built his reputation playing contemporary music, with a subspecialty in the music of Ives, he devoted a concert this season to Haydn sonatas, played beside music of two contemporary composers, Mauricio Kagel and Judith Weir. When the Abby Whiteside Foundation presented him in another recital on Wednesday evening at Weill Recital Hall, he offered a program that at a glance seemed equally eclectic.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CHEN, WEI GUN
description: CHEN--Wei gun, on Friday, February 6, 2004, age 75. Beloved Tai Chi Master (Sifu), husband of Chen Ru Qiong, father of Zhi Hong and Ying Jie, father-in-law of Gong Kok Dun and Yue Fangli and grandfather of Stephen, Barry and Siao Ming. Sifu Chen practiced martial arts since early childhood in Canton Province. He came to the U.S. in 1992 and introduced hundreds of students to his fluid, authentic Mainland form of the Tai Chi practice. Sifu Chen's wisdom, patience and humor will be missed by all. On behalf of all of his loyal students, Robert Blanton, Gary Gamboi, Rick Rudeman, Robert Janowsky. Visiting on Saturday, February 14, 3-7 PM, at Wah Wing Sang Funeral Home, 26 Mulberry Street, New York City. Flowers welcome that day.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Arrest In Shooting Of Officer
description: The police arrested a Queens man yesterday in the killing of an off-duty Rikers Island correction officer in a shooting at a birthday party in Queens last week, the authorities said. The man who was arrested, Derrick Coleman, 27, of 139-06 219 Street in Jamaica was charged with second-degree murder and weapons possession. Three other people were injured in the shooting, which occurred at 3 a.m. Feb. 7 at the Lebanon Lodge, a Masonic hall at 107-51 Guy R. Brewer Boulevard in Jamaica. The correction officer, Gregory G. Goff, 24, above, died at Mary Immaculate Hospital after the shooting, the police said. The shooting stemmed from a fight over a woman and two other men fired shots in the incident, the police said, and their investigation was continuing.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   COLENDA, FRANK G., MD.

He was a senior attending physician at Lenox Hill Hospital. Funeral services are tentatively being planned for Friday and/or Saturday at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street. Please call (212) 288-3500 for more details. Donations in his name may be made to the American Heart Association.

And given that Impressionism, the world's most popular art movement, is arguably foremost an art of the city, the country and the riverbank, this show hails from an unexpected realm, that of Neptune.

title: The Cloning Success in Korea
description: The day scientists might be able to create a human baby through cloning moved closer this week, when South Korean scientists revealed that they had cloned some 30 human embryos, grown them for a week in a laboratory and extracted stem cells for more research. Although the experiments were not intended to produce a baby, and none of the embryos were implanted in a woman, the techniques described by the Koreans will probably make it easier for some scientist somewhere to clone a human. Clearly it is time for the United States and other nations to ban cloning for human reproduction. For now, the only legitimate use of cloning should be for research and medical therapies.

Donald J. Trump, who now controls 47 percent of the company, will remain chairman and a ''significant equity holder,'' the company said. The investment will come from Credit Suisse's DLJ Merchant Banking Partners III. Trump Hotels, based in Atlantic City, said Credit Suisse's stake was contingent upon restructuring approximately $1.8 billion in debt at a discount to face value. State Comptroller Alan G. Hevesi last month rejected a $1.2 million no-bid consulting contract awarded to the Wall Street firm by the commission because of a potential conflict of interest. Sheldon Silver, the speaker of the State Assembly, said the firm was already being paid millions of dollars by the state for other work. The commission, which was appointed by Gov. George E. The company, which is being investigated by the Securities and Exchange Commission, said it was also considering selling assets to increase liquidity. Footstar said it had received a waiver from its lenders, giving it until Feb. 27 to provide a financial statement. The company, based in West Nyack, N.Y., operates Footaction and Just For Feet stores.

title: World Briefing: Americas
description: BRAZIL: SLAVE WORKERS FOUND ON SENATOR'S RANCH Dozens of workers were found in slavelike conditions on a senator's ranch, the Labor Ministry said, as Congress debated a bill to confiscate the land of such employers. The discovery of the 32 workers on the ranch of Senator Joao Ribeiro of the right-wing Liberal Front Party came two weeks after four ministry officials investigating slavery elsewhere were found shot to death. The killings prompted efforts to speed up passage of the legislation. The workers on the senator's ranch, in northern Para, were not allowed to leave, worked seven days a week and received no pay, the ministry said. (Reuters)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   IIJIMA, GRACE K.
description: IIJIMA--Grace K. Died January 26, 2004 in Manhattan. She was 93. She had been a Principal Librarian with the NY Public Library and a Director of Information for the US Information Agency in Japan. After retirement, she became an advocate for women and the elderly, serving as a member of the executive board of the Global Alliance for Women's Health. For over two decades she represented GAWH, the PanPacific and Southeast Asia Women's Association and the International Federation on Ageing at the United Nations. Quick to pick up a pen and try to correct injustices, she sought for 25 years greater equality and better health for women and the ageing and inspired all who came to know her. Her relatives, friends and associates deeply mourn her passing. Survivors include Etsuko Morris and family of Palm Beach, FL. Memorial services at 3:30 P.M. on March 4, 2004 in the chapel of the Church Centre for the United Nations, 777 United Nations Plaza; at 2 P.M. on March 14, 2004 at the Japanese American United Church, 255 7th Avenue, NY; and early next summer at the Mountain Grove Memorial Church, Huletts Landing, Lake George, NY.

title: AETNA REPORTS A SHARP RISE IN 4TH-QUARTER EARNINGS

Net income rose to $249.5 million, or $1.56 a share, in the fourth quarter, from $98.2 million, or 63 cents a share, a year earlier, the company said. Revenue declined 3 percent, to $4.57 billion from $4.72 billion. Medical costs consumed 78 cents of every premium dollar for Aetna's employer-sponsored health plans, down from 81.6 cents in the fourth quarter of 2002, the company said.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Antiwar Protesters Sue City
description: Dozens of people who say they were wrongly arrested at an antiwar protest last spring filed a lawsuit in Federal District Court in Manhattan late Wednesday against New York City and the Police Department, seeking redress for bogus arrests, false imprisonment, assault, and malicious prosecution, among other things. At a news conference yesterday, the plaintiffs claimed that they were within the law on April 7, 2003, when they stood on the north side of 56th Street in Midtown and looked on as others lay on the sidewalk on the south side to block the entrance of a building, which the plaintiffs claim housed a business that stood to profit from the war in Iraq. There were 94 arrests in all, for civil disobedience and obstructing government administration, the police said at the time, adding that protesters were blocking pedestrian traffic. Out of the 52 plaintiffs, according to the group, two people were tried and acquitted. Of the rest, only one is still facing charges, according to members of the group. A spokeswoman for the city's legal department said that the suit had not yet been received. , but that it would be evaluated thoroughly. Susan Saulny (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HADLEY, BIBERMAN, SU SAN J., M.D.
description: HADLEY - BIBERMAN -- Su san J., M.D., for many years the highest ranking woman physician at Cornell Medical Center, died on December 27, 2003. She graduated from Cornell University Medical College in 1944. For the next forty years she served on the medical staff of New YorkCornell, rising to the position of Professor of Medicine and serving as Vice Chairman of the Department of Medicine. An esteemed physician, researcher and educator, she was at the forefront of advancements in therapy for pulmonary tuberculosis and in the development of Streptomycin and Isoniazid, treatments still widely used today. At the time of her passing, Dr. Hadley was a Professor Emeritus of Medicine and an Honorary Attending Physician. The Department of Medicine will remember the outstanding legacy of Dr. Hadley and acknowledges her passing with sadness. Ralph L. Nachman, M.D. Chairman, Dept. of Medicine Weill Medical College of Cornell University Physician-in-Chief New York-Presbyterian Hospital

title: From Young Designers, Sense and Sensuality
description: If you still believed in the tyranny of the male gaze in the late 1990's, well past the point at which academia had moved on, you might have turned to the work of a designer named Tom Ford as proof that fashion viewed women through the narrow prism of what a man with a healthy ego and a well-stocked humidor might be looking for when he went out looking. The Gucci woman always seemed a construct of male fantasy, even if Mr. Ford envisioned her in command of her own erotic destiny. But who could believe him when he served up women in studded thigh-high boots, metal-heel stilettos, gold lam and skirts that made sitting down as hard as a full lotus? If the Gucci woman of Mr. Ford's imagining was so convinced of her own desirability, why had she never thought of going out for a quart of milk in a flannel shirt?

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Path Station Numbers
description: With more than 30,000 commuters passing through its turnstiles daily -- about 12,000 more than expected -- the newly reopened World Trade Center PATH station has already regained its position as the busiest station in the system on weekdays, the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey said yesterday. Passengers began using the spartan, temporary, open-air station on Nov. 23, after more than two years of having to find other ways to get between New Jersey and Lower Manhattan. Ridership quickly exceeded the Port Authority's forecasts, with more than 20,000 passengers coming through the station only two days after it opened. The weekday average since Jan. 15 has been more than 30,000 riders, placing the trade center station ahead of the 33rd Street station in Midtown. The authority had not expected that to happen until 2006. (Some 26,500 riders use the 33rd Street station.) Overall daily PATH ridership has increased to 180,000 from 160,000 last November, said Greg Trevor, a spokesman for the authority. Yet there are still fewer than half the number of riders who came through the World Trade Center station on Sept. 10, 2001.

description: Canada's trade surplus widened to 5.4 billion Canadian dollars ($4.1 billion) in December from 4.5 billion Canadian dollars in November, Statistics Canada reported. The improvement was ascribed chiefly to a 3.6 percent rise in exports, with half of that gain coming from higher shipments of motor vehicles to the United States. Bernard Simon (NYT)

title: Cyprus Greeks and Turks Agree On Plan to End 40-Year Conflict
description: Greek and Turkish Cypriot leaders on Friday accepted Secretary General Kofi Annan's plan for ending the decades-long division of Cyprus and pledged to negotiate reunification in time for the island's May 1 entry into the European Union.

title: Manhattan Rides a Fast Start to a Rout of Iona
description: Manhattan College keeps a low profile with high expectations. It has been that way for nearly three years, even though the Jaspers have been the area's most consistent team with a 61-21 record over that span.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on Thursday about the World Pond Hockey Championships misspelled the surname of a player and misstated his occupation. He is Gary Yovanovich, not Yavanovich. He is a civilian graphic designer. (His teammate Mike Veneri is an Air Force major.)

title: Lottery Numbers
At Core of Drug Scandal, Names Are Missing
description: As four men pleaded not guilty yesterday in San Francisco to federal charges of supplying performance-enhancing drugs, one vital question remained unanswered: Exactly who are the dozens of football, baseball and track and field athletes who are accused of taking these illicit substances?

title: About New York; The Commoner Of Queens: Average Bob
description: MEET your average single guy in Queens. Average in looks, average in interests and average in age, although the persistent gray hairs at the temples betray that he remembers a groovier time. He is average, too, in his sharing of the common human desire for companionship.

title: Knicks Track Baker's Status On Waivers
description: Led by their team president, Isiah Thomas, the Knicks have made little secret of their desire to improve the roster for what they believe could be a playoff run. With that in mind, the Knicks are watching the Vin Baker story with interest.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, the Antiques column in Weekend yesterday, about marine paintings, misstated the affiliation of a commentator, Norman Keyes. He is a spokesman for the Philadelphia Museum of Art, where ''Manet and the Sea'' opens tomorrow, not for the Peabody Essex Museum in Salem, Mass., which has an extensive marine collection.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Request For Pharmacy Vigilance
description: Citing ''numerous problems'' involving prescription drugs imported from Canada, the United States Food and Drug Administration has asked the Canadian government to take a more active role in inspecting mail-order and Internet pharmacies in Canada. A report by Minnesota's Board of Pharmacy said that it had found 32 violations of safe pharmacy practice during visits to eight Internet drugstores in Canada. A spokesman for the pharmacies, David MacKay, said the shortcomings had been ''blown out of proportion'' and that they were being rectified. Bernard Simon (NYT)

title: CBS Pulls Advertisement on Medicare Prepared by Administration
description: CBS said on Friday that it had stopped running a television advertisement for the new Medicare prescription drug law while Congress investigates its accuracy.

title: Bush and Kerry: The War Years
description: To the Editor:

title: Nader Searches for His Roots
description: WHILE Ralph Nader says that he will decide within the next week or two whether there is enough grass-roots support for him to run for president, so far it is not easy to discern a groundswell.

title: National Briefing | Washington: E.P.A. And North Dakota Ease Air Rules
description: North Dakota and the Environmental Protection Agency have agreed to adopt new ways to measure air pollution that would ease the way to build coal-burning power plants near Theodore Roosevelt National Park and other areas. E.P.A. scientists had opposed the changes since 1999, saying existing coal-burning plants were already contributing to violations of the Clean Air Act in wilderness areas.

title: National Briefing | West: California: Time Frame For Singer's Trial
description: In a hearing in the sexual molesting case of Michael Jackson, Judge Rodney S. Melville of Superior Court in Santa Barbara asked lawyers to prepare for a preliminary hearing on April 2 and said he would like the trial to start by December. Chris Dixon (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KELLEN, STEPHEN M.
description: KELLEN--Stephen M. The Board of Trustees, Scientific Advisory Council and Staff of the Cancer Research Institute wish to express our grief over the passing of one of the Institute's most beloved friends and generous benefactors. Mr. Kellen, along with his wife Anna - Maria, disti guished himself early on as an ardent supporter of cancer immunology and the Institute's mission to explore and develop this field of research. Over more than four decades of dedication, Mr. Kellen earned our most profound gratitude, respect and admiration. A champion of ours and so many other good causes, his boundless generosity raised the bar for philanthropic giving, inspiring others not only to give, but also to give more. The legacy of his many good works, which touched the lives of so many people, will live on long into the future. Our love and condolences go to his wife AnnaMaria, his children Marina and Michael, and his other bereaved family members. Ann W. Jackson, Chairman, Board of Trustees Lloyd J. Old, M.D., Dir., Scientific Advisory Council Jill O'Donnell-Tormey, Ph.D., Executive Director

description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

title: Amazon Glitch Unmasks War Of Reviewers
description: Close observers of Amazon.com noticed something peculiar this week: the company's Canadian site had suddenly revealed the identities of thousands of people who had anonymously posted book reviews on the United States site under signatures like ''a reader from New York.''

title: Snowmobiles Unbound
description: Friends of Yellowstone National Park were thrilled when a federal district judge in Washington ruled last December in favor of a Clinton administration plan that would have gradually eliminated snowmobiles from the park and against a Bush proposal that would have kept them there. Now another federal judge, in a separate case in Wyoming, has muddied the judicial waters by declaring the Clinton plan illegal and, in effect, ordering the National Park Service managers in Yellowstone to end the phaseout. The number of machines entering the park, which had been declining, promptly jumped to more than 700 a day from 490.

title: Corrections
description: A jazz review in Weekend yesterday about the pianists Randy Weston and Rodney Kendrick, who played at Merkin Hall on Monday, misstated the duration of the ''Monday Nites: No Minimum'' series. It continues through June, not through next month.

title: Sharon's Gesture Could Backfire
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about an effort by the Internal Revenue Service to obtain the names of buyers of tax shelters referred incorrectly to a judge's ruling and an I.R.S. summons concerning an investment program offered by xlan, the Economic Association of Health Professionals Inc. While both the ruling and the summons questioned the tax benefits of the program, neither called it fraudulent or illegal.

title: Killing of a U.N. Observer in Congo Heightens a Mission's Fears
description: The death of an unarmed United Nations military observer in an ambush on his convoy on Thursday was an eerie replay of the troubles that beset the United Nations peacekeeping mission here just under a year ago.

title: An Enclave's Favorite Officer, Now Under Scrutiny
description: In the heavily Guyanese enclave in Richmond Hill, Queens, the police detective known simply as Rudy was ubiquitous in his blue community affairs windbreaker. The detective, Rudranauth Toolasprashad, 38, could chat in Hindi with local immigrants about news from Guyana, and he often introduced them to his fellow officers and superiors.

title: Ex-Doctor Receives Sentence Of 21 Years in Child Sex Case
description: A former pediatrician from Sunset Park, Brooklyn, who was convicted last year on charges that he traveled abroad to have sex with minors at what the government called a pedophiles' resort was sentenced yesterday to more than 21 years in prison, the maximum punishment allowed by federal guidelines.

title: Corrections
description: A news analysis article on Thursday about the battle over the use of the word ''marriage'' to describe same-sex partnerships misstated the authorship of the majority opinion in a ruling on gay marriage by the Massachusetts Supreme Judicial Court on Feb. 3. Chief Justice Margaret H. Marshall was one of the four justices who signed the ruling -- not its sole author.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about a report recommending changes in the Staten Island Ferry system gave an incorrect spelling at one pont for the surname of the former captain of the ferry involved in a fatal crash in October. He is Michael J. Gansas, not Ganzas.

title: Valentine Thoughts
description: To the Editor:

title: Ice Hockey Memories: On Frozen Pond

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about plans by members of the House Intelligence Committee to visit Libya misidentified the member of Congress who headed a delegation to that country last month. He was Curt Weldon, Republican of Pennsylvania, not Tom Lantos, Democrat of California.

title: What Runs In the Family Isn't Success
description: Start with Hollywood -- say, the producers Bob and Harvey Weinstein, the filmmakers Joel and Ethan Coen or Peter and Bobby Farrelly, or the actors Ben and Casey Affleck. Move on to the gossip columns, where Paris and Nicky Hilton and Janet and Michael Jackson are recurring fixations. And then consider politics, a field whose most prominent names include George W. and Jeb Bush; John, Robert and Edward Kennedy; and Jerry and Kathleen Brown.

title: Japanese Architect Wins U.N. Competition
description: Correction Appended

title: National Briefing | Northwest: Washington: 2-Year Term In Taliban Case
description: James Ujaama, a former Seattle community activist, was sentenced in federal court to two years in prison for conspiring to aid the Taliban in Afghanistan. The authorities had originally charged Mr. Ujaama, 38, above in a 1991 photo, with trying to set up a terrorist training camp in Oregon. He pleaded guilty to a lesser charge in the spring in exchange for his helping in other terror inquiries. Matthew Preusch (NYT)

title: South Dakota Is Dealt a Setback After Hanging Hopes on a Science Project
description: The hard-luck towns in the desolate reaches of western South Dakota have been banking on plans to build a physics laboratory in an abandoned, flooded gold mine called Homestake as their path to economic rebirth.

title: Rowland Owes Firm $100,000, A Judge Says
description: An interim judge awaiting final confirmation to the bench told the state's Judiciary Committee on Friday that Gov. John G. Rowland, who nominated him for the post, owed his firm $100,000 in legal fees.

title: HOME DEPOT WILL CUT 100 JOBS IN ATLANTA BY APRIL
description: Home Depot will eliminate as many as 100 jobs in financial operations in Atlanta, its second round of cuts announced in three months, as the retailer increases spending on computers to become more efficient. The jobs will be eliminated by April, the company said. In November, the company shed 100 positions as it closed a store-support center in Seattle. Home Depot employs more than 300,000 people. The company, which has more than 1,700 stores, plans to open about 175 stores this year, employing about 35,000 people.

title: When Bidding Was Flexible But Without Today's Precision
description: Half a century ago nearly all the top American players used virtually identical bidding methods.

title: Family-Dominated Comcast Good at Pleasing Investors
description: While the Walt Disney Company has been a lightning rod for corporate governance critics, the Comcast Corporation's governance has rarely generated investor anger -- even though some activists say that Comcast flunks their tests.

title: BPB, A GYPSUM MAKER, IS PLANNING A PLANT IN U.S.
description: BPB, the world's biggest producer of gypsum used in building, plans to build a $100 million plant in the United States to expand wallboard production. The decision to build the plant, to be commissioned in 2007, follows an accord with Progress Energy for the supply of desulphogypsum, a byproduct of coal-fired power generation that is used in wallboard, BPB said. The 700 million square feet plant will be in Roxboro, N.C., alongside Progress Energy's generator. The United States plant ''will significantly strengthen our market representation on the eastern seaboard,'' the chief executive, Richard Cousins, said in a statement. BPB is based in Slough, England.

title: Speaker's Aide Will Leave Job
description: The City Council speaker's chief of staff, Forrest R. Taylor, said yesterday that he would leave the position next month.

title: Gladly Taking The Blame For Health In the City
description: Correction Appended

title: U.N. Warns Against a Hasty Vote, but Iraqis Address the Issue
description: The United Nations special envoy to Iraq departed Friday, warning that the country faced a significant chance of civil strife, and leaving unresolved the contentious question of holding elections before the June 30 transfer of sovereignty to Iraqis.

title: Health Aides Who Get Sick Days?; Ownership Is Good for Co-op Workers, but Union Complicates Mix
description: Using a wheelchair since a gunshot wound 34 years ago, Wilfredo Graulau admits that most mornings he sinks into a funk and would undoubtedly remain there if not for Margarita's arrival.

title: Chaos and War Leave Iraq's Hospitals in Ruins
description: At Baghdad's Central Teaching Hospital for Children, gallons of raw sewage wash across the floors. The drinking water is contaminated. According to doctors, 80 percent of patients leave with infections they did not have when they arrived.

title: EUROPE MOVES DEADLINE FOR RULING ON ORACLE'S TAKEOVER
description: The European Commission set a new deadline yesterday of May 11 to announce its decision on the Oracle Corporation's hostile takeover of PeopleSoft . Originally, the regulators were supposed to complete their review by March 30. The commission, which is investigating the case for its impact on competition in the European software market, suspended its review in January when Oracle missed a crucial deadline for submitting requested documents. The United States Justice Department told PeopleSoft last week that it would announce by March 2 its decision on whether it will approve the deal.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   RUTHEISER, GOLDIE
description: RUTHEISER--Goldie. Happy Birthday. Thank you for everything. I will never forget. I love you, Meri

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GUTERMAN, ABRAHAM S.
description: GUTERMAN -- Abraham S. The Board of Trustees of the Benjamin N. Cardozo School of Law and the entire Cardozo community is deeply saddened by the death of one of its founding members. Abraham Guterman served on the Cardozo Board from the founding of the Law School in 1976 through 2000, when he continued as an honorary member of the Board. From the beginning, he was a visionary for and active supporter of the Law School. Each of us has dreams for what he can do for the good and advancement of others, but not all of us can make these dreams a reality. Mr. Guterman's ability to effect change, to influence generations of students in their development and learning, and to inspire in others the desire to do the same was his special gift; one that is deeply appreciated and celebrated by the Cardozo community. He will be sorely missed. We send our condolences to the entire Guterman family. Earle I. Mack, Chairman, Benjamin N. Cardozo School of Law David Rudenstine, Dean

title: 5 Are Accused Of Trade Fraud
description: Five executives and traders at a defunct Chicago securities company were indicted on charges they defrauded investors of at least $7.3 million.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ALTMAN, BESSIE (MARCUS)
description: ALTMAN--Bessie (Marcus) of Swampscott formerly of Brookline, MA. Entered Into Rest February 12, 2004 at 97. Wife of the late Leonard Marcus and the late Joseph Altman. Companion of the late Charles Altman. Mother of Warren and Florence Marcus, Phyllis and Myer Kravetz and Barbara and Eugene Levinson. Grandmother of Paula Marcus, Cynthia Reilly, David Marcus, Gary Kravetz, Richard Kravetz, Susan Syversen, Lisa Mahaffey, Howard Levinson, David Levinson and ten great-grandchildren. Services and memorial observance in MA. Expressions of Sympathy may be donated to the Alexander Graham Bell Associates for the Deaf and Hard of Hearing, 3417 Volta Place NW, Washington DC 20007 Attn: Lisa Ruffin Schauf.

title: One Bid Is In; Cell Company Awaits Others
description: Cingular Wireless submitted a $35 billion bid yesterday for AT&T Wireless, according to people close to the auction, while Vodafone was putting the final touches on its offer and Nextel was said to be considering one.

title: National Briefing | South: Florida: Rights In Feeding-Tube Case
description: A state court has sided with the parents of a severely brain-damaged woman in part of a battle that pits them against the woman's husband, who wants her to be allowed to die. The Second District Court of Appeals ruled that a lower court should not have automatically denied the parents the right to intervene in a case on the constitutionality of a law passed in the fall to keep alive their daughter, Terri Schiavo. Mrs. Schiavo, 40, has depended on a feeding tube since 1990.

title: Former Senator Torricelli Wields Clout as Party Fund-Raiser
description: Robert G. Torricelli, the former United States senator from New Jersey, is once again emerging as a principal fund-raiser for Democratic candidates and, as overseer of $2.3 million left from his own campaign fund, as a donor as well.

title: For Disney, the Best Defense Could Be a Good Offense
description: The last time Walt Disney came under attack from an unwanted suitor -- a 1984 takeover attempt by the corporate raider Saul Steinberg -- the company fought back with an acquisition of its own. By paying $200 million for the Florida real estate developer Arvida, Disney fattened itself and made it harder for Mr. Steinberg to swallow.

title: Sports of The Times; It's Not an All-Star Game Without These Two
description: THE moment someone mentioned LeBron James's name yesterday afternoon, Rick Carlisle, the coach of the Eastern Conference All-Stars, distanced himself from the decision that left the N.B.A.'s greatest young stars out of the All-Star Game.

title: Stuck in the Woods on the Way to Divorce
description: The song could belong to Shawn Colvin, Beth Orton, Carly Simon. It is sweet and whiny. Plaintive (for what other word exactly applies?), the Lilith Fair-like lament comes about two-thirds of the way through ''It Must Be Love,'' a movie having its premiere tonight on CBS.

title: Corrections
description: A Critic's Notebook article in Arts & Ideas last Saturday about one film on decay and another on architecture misstated the name of the university in Columbus, Ohio, where Jeffrey Kipnis, scriptwriter for the architecture film, is a professor. It is Ohio State University; there is no University of Ohio.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   GROSSMAN, LOUIS
description: GROSSMAN--Louis. February 14, 1998. Time doesn't heal. Your loving family.

title: Philip A. Straus, 88, Financier And Patron of Art and Education
description: Correction Appended

title: Robert A. Bruce Is Dead at 87; Pioneer of Cardiac Stress Test
description: Dr. Robert A. Bruce, who advanced the ability to diagnose heart disease by devising the treadmill stress test, now almost universally used, died on Thursday at his home in Seattle. He was 87.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about an effort by the Internal Revenue Service to obtain the names of buyers of tax shelters referred incorrectly to a judge's ruling and an I.R.S. summons concerning an investment program offered by xlan, the Economic Association of Health Professionals Inc. While both the ruling and the summons questioned the tax benefits of the program, neither called it fraudulent or illegal.

title: Halliburton Likely to Be A Campaign Issue This Fall
description: As the accusations and investigations of the Halliburton Company's federal contracts in Iraq expand in size and number, Democrats say they will use the company's ties to the Bush administration as a campaign issue, and Halliburton is responding with television advertisements implying that it is being unfairly singled out.

title: INSIDE
description: Range of Intelligence Data Given Bush Is Under Review

title: Karan Out of a Furnace, Lauren Out of the West
description: Awaiting the legions of fashion professionals filing into the Donna Karan show yesterday were copies of a magazine called Woman to Woman, one in which Ms. Karan wielded a heavy editorial hand. In it, she wrote about her summer vacation in the Maldives, where she learned to scuba dive, and in Corsica. (''The colors!'') Earlier, the reader learned, she ventured out to Sun Valley, where she was introduced to the work of a glass blower named William Morris. ''Glass blowing is extremely visceral and dangerous,'' Ms. Karan wrote. ''I got burned twice when I tried it myself!''

title: Clark Comes Aboard Kerry Campaign
description: Senator John Kerry picked up the endorsement of Gen. Wesley K. Clark on Friday at a rally where the two men highlighted their military service and national security credentials and struck hard at the White House.

title: Bush and Kerry: The War Years
description: To the Editor:

title: Black Files Libel Lawsuit Against Hollinger Committee
description: Conrad M. Black filed a $644 million libel suit on Friday against members of a special committee set up by Hollinger International, contending that they had set out to transform him from ''a respected owner of a successful media chain into a loathsome laughingstock.''

title: National Briefing | Northwest: Oregon: Agents Seize 5 Stowaways
description: Border patrol agents searching a grain ship anchored near Portland found five stowaways from China. The authorities charged two crew members with human trafficking, a spokesman for the Coast Guard said. Officials said the captain of the 620-foot Liberian-flag vessel, the Pacific Dolphin, had called the Coast Guard to say he might have stowaways aboard. The stowaways, all men, boarded on Jan. 13 in Dailan, China, officials said.

title: South Korea Sending 3,000 Troops to Iraq
description: South Korea on Friday approved a plan to send 3,000 troops to Iraq, ending months of debate over the country's role there.

title: University's Patent for Celebrex Is Invalid
description: An appeals court yesterday upheld the dismissal of a multibillion-dollar lawsuit that contended that Pfizer impermissibly used a university's patent for the painkiller Celebrex.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the historic preservation review process at the World Trade Center site misstated the public availability of a preliminary finding by the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation. It is on the corporation's Web site at www.renewnyc.com/content/pdfs/effects.pdf. It was not withheld from the public.

description: To the Editor:

title: Sorrow and Anger Linger as Brooklyn Buries Two Boys Killed by Truck
description: Theirs were names to grow into, big-man names, Victor Flores and Juan Angel Estrada. When they were buried yesterday, mourners filled a Brooklyn church, large families and small ones, entire classrooms of children from a nearby school. Their coffins were six feet long, polished white boxes with golden trim and ornate carvings, each one pushed, not carried, by six men.

title: Boulez and the Cleveland, Old Friends Reunited Lucidly
description: The composer Pierre Boulez made his American professional debut as an orchestra conductor with the Cleveland Orchestra in 1965. He has been a regular guest with the acclaimed orchestra ever since, always drawing the best from the players, even as the personnel went through enormous changes under the tenures of four quite different music directors from then to now.

title: Knicks Track Bakers Status
description: The Knicks, with hopes of improving their roster to make a playoff run, are watching the Vin Baker story with interest.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Loss At Chemical Maker
description: Rhodia, a chemical maker, said it lost 1.35 billion euros ($1.72 billion) last year and forecast two more unprofitable years as it struggled to cut debt. The loss came after raw material costs rose, the dollar dropped against the euro and the company took a charge of 875 million euros to write down assets. Rhodia, which is based in Paris, agreed to demands from creditors including Soros Fund Management to repay $290 million and is in talks to sell a food additives unit, the chief executive, Jean-Pierre Clamadieu, said in a conference call. Rhodia plans to sell more than 700 million euros of assets this year to reduce debt.

title: Ice Hockey Memories: On Frozen Pond (2 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Devils' Captain Still Waiting For His Return
description: His doctor tells him he can take longer walks in the woods, and he says he feels less fatigued, but Devils defenseman Scott Stevens does not know when he will be able to resume his hockey career. Still.

title: Kith & Kin Inc.
description: One of the growing subspecies in Washington's ever-flourishing influence industry consists of the relatives of members of Congress. They register as lobbyists free to work the Hill -- if not necessarily from within the family hearth, then near enough to count. A tally by The Los Angeles Times finds at least 17 senators and 11 House members with relatives who are paid lobbyists or consultants in government relations.

title: As Fortune Changes, So Has Dean's Campaign
description: Marveling at the $28 million Superior Middle School, complete with wind tunnel and rock-climbing wall, Howard Dean told his tour guide that his own children attended seventh grade in a building from around 1900 ''named after the last guy to run for president from Vermont.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DIAMOND, RICHARD E.
description: DIAMOND--Richard E., of Staten Island, NY, publisher of the ''Staten Island Advance,'' on February 12, 2004. Husband of Alice B. (nee Blach). Father of Caroline D. Harrison, Alison D. Levasseur and Richard E. Diamond, Jr. Father-in-law of Timothy C. Harrison, Laurent C. Levasseur and Francesca P. Diamond. Brother of Elaine D. Berman. Grandfather of Timothy C. Harrison, Jr., Alice D. Harrison, Lucie C. Levasseur and Richard E. Diamond III. Funeral service will be on Sunday 10:30AM, Temple Israel Reform Congregation, S.I., NY. Interment Baron Hirsch Cemetery. Friends will be received Friday 7-9PM, Saturday 2-4 and 7-9PM, Meislohn Silvie Funeral Home, 1289 Forest Ave., S.I., NY. In lieu of flowers contributions to Staten Island. Academy (SINY), would be appreciated.

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: TURKEY: BLIZZARDS LASH AND SINK SHIPS Blizzards cut off villages, blocked roads and kept air and sea routes closed while rescuers battled high seas in a search for 20 crewmen lost when their freighter sank off Istanbul. Since the storms began Thursday, two ships have sunk and two have run aground near Istanbul. The Bosphorus and the Dardanelles, the only outlet to oceans for Black Sea states, were closed with 42 tankers at the entrances. In Istanbul, above, life ground to a halt under 14 inches of snow and winds of 56 miles an hour, and thousands of passengers were stranded at the airport. Neighboring Greece and Bulgaria were also battered, with Athens at a standstill in up to 20 inches of snow, one of its worst snowstorms in decades.    (Reuters)

title: Iraq and Economy Are Costing President, Opinion Polls Show
description: The public's confidence in George W. Bush is continuing to erode amid doubts about the Iraq war and sustained economic worries, according to opinion polls made public this week.

title: Independent Producers Wary of Proposed Deal
description: As the possible takeover of the Walt Disney Company by the Comcast Corporation dominates the headlines, Hollywood producers and consumer advocates are again sounding the alarm that media consolidation will narrow the creative outlets for independent producers and upstart cable channels and ultimately reduce choice for the viewing public.

title: CKE TO CLOSE 28 HARDEE'S RESTAURANTS IN FIRST QUARTER
description: CKE Restaurants, the hamburger-chain owner, plans to close 28 Hardee's restaurants and write down the value of its La Salsa restaurants. CKE, which also owns the Carl's Jr. chain, incurred expenses of $14 million to $16 million for the closures in its fourth quarter, which ended Jan. 26. Writing down La Salsa's value resulted in a charge of $30 million to $34 million. CKE's Hardee's introduced a new menu and eliminated some items last year. The company said some weaker performing restaurants, older ones or those in poor locations would require significant capital spending to upgrade. CKE will close the 28 Hardee's in its first quarter. CKE wrote down the value of La Salsa restaurants, which it acquired in March 2002, to reflect reduced growth and performance expectations.

title: World Briefing: Asia
description: AFGHANISTAN: U.S. SOLDIER KILLED An American soldier and 2 Afghans were killed and 15 others were wounded in separate incidents. The American Central Command said the soldier was killed and nine other soldiers were wounded by a mine near Ghazni. No further details were provided. In southeastern Khost, at least two Afghans were killed and six wounded in an explosion at a government military post. The blast came hours after more than 20 rockets landed near Khost's airport, where United States-led forces are based. It was the biggest single rocket attack since the fall of the Taliban. The military reported no casualties.    (Reuters)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SILVERSTEIN, DON
description: SILVERSTEIN--Don, 71, of New York City, formerly of Detroit, MI. Died January 30th, 2004. Mr. Silverstein is survived by his wife Sakiko Silverstein, his sister Roberta Cohen, and his nephews Dale and Warren Cohen. Mr. Silverstein was a contemporary painter and illustrator of children's books. He began his career in commercial illustration at the Society of Arts and Crafts in Detroit. After two years of service in the U.S. Army, he settled in London and did freelance work. When he finally began to concentrate on fine arts, he had his works displayed at the Detroit Institute of Arts, among other venues. A collection of Mr. Silverstein's art work can be found on the web at www.donsilverstein.com.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Back From Iraq, Pataki Says Trip Confirmed View of War
description: Judging by his comments, Gov. George E. Pataki returned from his two-day tour of Iraq more convinced than ever that the United States' invasion there is an extension of the fight against terrorists that began when Islamic extremists slammed hijacked airplanes into the World Trade Center and the Pentagon 2 1/2 years ago.

title: Sharon's Gesture Could Backfire
description: To the Editor:

title: MOODY'S LOWERS AMERADA HESS'S UNSECURED DEBT RATING
description: The Amerada Hess Corporation's senior unsecured debt rating was cut below investment grade by Moody's Investors Service, which cited concern over costs and the oil company's ability to meet production goals. About $4 billion in securities were affected by the downgrade. Amerada Hess, based in New York, has been selling assets to reduce debt from the acquisition of Triton Energy in 2001. Moody's said it gave Hess a stable rating outlook.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BERNSTEIN, SELMA D.
description: BERNSTEIN--Selma D. Died February 2, 2004 at age 90. Wife of Lester. Mother of Robert and Joel. Grandmother of Benjamin, Ariel, Simon, Emily, Jacob and Haylee. Teacher, past President of Hadassah (New Rochelle) and of her condominium. She will be praised at the Gates by her very own deeds. Contributions in her memory should be made to Hadassah (New Rochelle).

title: World Business
description: ASIA

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Monday about the issue of gay marriage referred imprecisely to reports of a discussion on an airplane trip between President Bush and Representative Jim DeMint, Republican of South Carolina. (The error was repeated in a front-page cross-reference on Monday about an interview the president gave to ''Meet the Press'' on NBC about issues in the presidential campaign.) While Mr. DeMint did say that he and Mr. Bush talked about having contracts and agreements in relationships, the congressman said that Mr. Bush did not refer specifically to gay partnerships; Mr. DeMint said the discussion centered on marriage in general.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MORAN, LAURA REGINA DE BONNEVILLE
description: MORAN--Laura Regina de Bonneville. Of NYC and Palm Beach, FL died Tuesday, February 10, 2004, at Good Samaritan Hospital. Laura, the daughter of the late George F. Moran and Gertrude E. Corbett Moran of Manhattan, NY, is survived by numerous loving cousins, nieces, nephews and friends who cherish the memory of her sterling wit and joy for life. She was a graduate of Manhattanville College of the Sacred Heart, class of 1953, and was a member of the New York Junior League. title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LOVE, DR. SIDNEY IRWIN
description: LOVE--Dr. Sidney Irwin, 82. Psychoanalyst, psychologist, educator and renowned family therapist. Dr. Love, author of numerous papers on psychoanalysis and family treatment, died on February 11 in New York City. He was born February 12, 1922, in the Bronx. He received a Purple Heart serving in WWII. He then received a Master's Degree in social work from Columbia University, a certification as a psychologist and psychoanalyst, and received a doctorate in psychoanalysis. He was also co-founder of the Riverdale Seminars in Modern Analytic Psychotherapy. His contributions to the theory and understanding of modern analytic family therapy are immense. He will be missed by all who knew him. He is survived by his beloved wife Shirley, his beloved daughters, Carolyn Bersak and Jeanine Dropkin, four grandchildren and two sonsin-law. Services Sunday, February 15, 11:30 AM, at the Riverside, 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   POLLACK, JULIA MOSELLE
description: POLLACK--Julia Moselle. February 13th, 2004. Born in Fayetteville, Arkansas to Flora and Harry Baum. Married Isadore Erlich 1934 (died 1968). Survived by her adoring husband of 32 years, the Honorable Milton Pollack, United States District Judge of the Southern District of New York. Moselle, her first name Julia, walked with dignity and grace. She was a woman of great elegance and taste. She was a woman of unconceivable vision, incisiveness and purpose. Utterly selfless and self-effacing--a southern beauty with comprehensive understanding and devotion to family. She glorified in its achievements. A true lady, she was known for her style, charm, intelligence and wit and her presence always illuminated a room. Her charisma and graciousness were an inspiration. Moselle was a devoted matriarch of an extended family and a pioneer businesswoman in Houston, Texas, where she began her illustrious career at Neiman Marcus. She opened the children's clothing department at The Fashion in Houston. With her first husband, Isadore Erlich, she founded a chain of department stores that included the Palais Royal Stores in Texas and neighboring states. After the death of her husband, Moselle remained the active chairman until the company was sold in 1988. Throughout her life, Moselle was always revered as an extraordinary, sweet, genuine and accomplished woman who exercised philanthropic efforts in a private and anonymous manner. Her amazing life full of love, joy and kindness will be celebrated by her family in Houston, Texas. She will always be cherished by her daughters, Joan and husband Marvin Kaplan, Judy and husband Rodney Margolis, Phyllis and husband George Asch, Stephanie and husband William Miller, and sister, Elka Warren, and her grandchildren, Karen and Roy Brooks, Susan and Forrest Bruch, Deborah and Richard Kaplan, Nancy and Robert Risman, Melanie and Lawrence Margolis, Jill and Jeff Levenson, Elizabeth and Daniel Treinish, Drs. Debra Singer and Hal Stein and Marcy Singer Gabella and William Gabella plus 18 greatgrandchildren. Predeceased by sister, Claire Meyers. We will always love you Mimi and you will always be alive in our memory and our hearts.

title: DELACO HAS FILED FOR BANKRUPTCY PROTECTION
description: The Delaco Company, the successor to the company that created the appetite suppressant Dexatrim, filed for bankruptcy protection in New York to deal with hundreds of personal-injury and wrongful-death suits. The suits claim phenylpropanolamine, an ingredient that was used in appetite-suppressant products including Dexatrim, is linked to hemorrhagic strokes. Thompson Medical Company, which created Dexatrim and later merged with Delaco, sold the brand in 1998 to Chattem. Neither Delaco nor Thompson has made products containing phenylpropanolamine since 1998, the company said in papers filed Thursday in Federal Bankruptcy Court in New York. Delaco, based in New York, said it had spent $19 million in defense from the claims and cited mounting legal costs for its bankruptcy filing.

But really, Laura was such a good girl, this only child of theirs, an angel, a love. She had never given them a moment's trouble. She was steady and smart and quiet, and her friends were the Brownies she knew from grade school. She always laughed at her father's jokes; he was a cutup, easy and friendly and open. She always sat by her mother, though. On visits to her grandmother some hours away, Laura and her mother would take turns reading in the car out loud to each other, the huge sky of West Texas arching out before them, vast and familiar, Manifest Destiny beckoning in the shimmering of the nighttime stars.

title: The Very, Very Personal Is the Political
description: Suppose, for the sake of argument, that you are called into the boss's office and asked to help sell the citizens of the United States on one of two presidential candidates in the 2004 campaign. Hard work, but what makes it especially tough is that you've been directed to try something experimental, something that's never been done before in a national election. Instead of creating a traditional political narrative for your candidate -- one that highlights charisma or character, for instance, or one that hews to a message on taxes or Social Security -- you've been told to focus on nothing but the people who might be persuaded to vote. In other words, forget about your candidate's nuanced ideas for space exploration or ending the conflict in Iraq. Forget about TV commercials, forget about radio, forget about debates, forget about the ups and downs of the news cycle. Think voters -- just voters. And don't think only in terms of big demographic groups like senior citizens, middle-class white men or young single women; don't think about them only in terms of geographical areas like districts or precincts or even neighborhoods. Think about what they like, what they do, what they consume. Think about them one by one. Name by name, address by address, phone by phone.

description: The situation in Iraq is fast approaching the tipping point. The terrorists know that if they can wreak enough havoc, kill enough Iraqis waiting in line to join their own police force, they can prevent the U.N. from coming up with a plan for elections and a stable transfer of U.S. authority to an Iraqi government. Once authority is in Iraqi hands, the Baathists and Islamists have a real problem: They can't even pretend to be fighting the U.S. anymore. It will be clear to all Arabs and Muslims that they are fighting against the freedom and independence of Iraq and for their own lunatic ideologies. Which is why they are desperate to prevent us from reaching that tipping point. Their strategy is to sow chaos, defeat President Bush and hope that his Democratic successor will pull out. Which is also why at this moment the most important statement on Iraq that can be made -- one that could even save lives -- is nothing President Bush could say. No, the most important statement on Iraq right now could only come from the likely Democratic presidential nominee, John Kerry.

title: The Man Who Could Carve Tears
description: In 1784, when Thomas Jefferson arrived in Paris to help represent the fledgling American republic, one of his missions was to locate a sculptor to create a statue of George Washington. Jefferson recommended Jean-Antoine Houdon: ''I find that a Monsieur Houdon of this place possesses the reputation of being the first statuary in the world.'' Houdon (1741-1828) was already widely recognized as the greatest European sculptor of his age. His remarkable career, which spanned the Enlightenment, both the American and the French revolutions, and the Directory and the Napoleonic era in France, is the subject of the essays by Anne L. Poulet, an emeritus curator at the Museum of Fine Arts in Boston, and others in JEAN-ANTOINE HOUDON: Sculptor of the Enlightenment (University of Chicago, $85). They detail Houdon's artistic development and provide insights into his working methods and his relationships with his subjects, a group that included Molire, Diderot, Voltaire, Franklin and Napoleon. Houdon was obsessive in his attention to muscle and bone structure, using calipers to measure his sitters' features. He could do teeth, the pupils of the eyes, soft dimples, even tears; details that, two centuries later, still catch the breath. In 1783, a critic said of Houdon's portrait busts of contemporary celebrities: ''M. Houdon lacks only the means to make his portraits speak, since, as for likeness, he lacks nothing.'' Katherine Zoepf

title: The Yom Kippur War

Barbed-wire fencing had sunken almost entirely into the sand, trenches were collapsing, gun positions had insufficient sandbags, and the ammunition supply was short. When the officer he was relieving asked him to sign the standard form acknowledging receipt of the outpost in good condition, Ashkenazi declined. Without this formality, the unit being relieved could not depart. When Ashkenazi refused an order from his battalion commander to sign, the exasperated commander signed the form himself.

title: Uglydolls

A couple of years ago, he was living in Los Angeles, and his girlfriend, Sun-Min Kim, had moved back to Korea to be with her family. Horvath, an illustrator, wrote her long, pining letters, and at the end he would draw one of a number of cartoon characters he had made up -- a blocky, orange guy named Wage, with startled round eyes and an apron. At Christmas, Kim surprised him by sending back a plush-toy version of Wage, about a foot high, that she had sewn herself. Horvath was so excited that he showed it off to Eric Nakamura, the owner of a store in Los Angeles called Giant Robot, which sold art books and magazines as well as toys and T-shirts made by artists.
