description: To the Editor:

title: Israelis Approve $22 Million For Settlements on West Bank
description: Israeli lawmakers approved more than $20 million on Monday night for new spending on Jewish settlements, two weeks after Prime Minister Ariel Sharon suggested he might remove most of the settlers in the Gaza Strip.

title: Priest Admits That He Stole $50,000 From Collections
description: A Roman Catholic priest accused of illegal gun possession and making harassing phone calls admitted on Tuesday that he stole $50,000 from collection plates of a Bethpage church over five years to finance his retirement, prosecutors said.

title: After Losing the Bidding for AT&T Wireless, Vodafone Studies Its Next Move
description: Now that it has lost the battle for AT&T Wireless, what does Vodafone do next?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KING, DONALD A.
description: KING--Donald A. At his home in Avon, CT on February 16, 2004. Funeral services will be Thursday at 10:00 A.M. in St. Thomas the Apostle Church, West Hartford, CT. Calling hours are Wednesday from 47 P.M. at the Molloy Funeral Home, 906 Farmington Ave., West Hartford, Connecticut

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Ex-Police Officer Sentenced For Sex Crime
description: A former police officer at the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey who admitted trying to videotape an 11-year-old girl as she took a shower in her home was sentenced yesterday in Queens Criminal Court to three years' probation, the Queens district attorney's office said. The officer, Russell Bass, 42, of Hempstead, pleaded guilty last month to attempted unlawful surveillance. Mr. Bass was arrested after the girl told the police that she had noticed a hand holding a video camera outside a partly opened bathroom window in her home in Jamaica. Mr. Bass, who had worked for the Port Authority police for 15 years, has since resigned. Judge Douglas S. Wong ordered Mr. Bass to undergo two years of sex offender therapy as part of his probation. Stacy Albin (NYT)

title: Same-Old Same-Old? Listen Carefully
description: On paper the programs that the Royal Concertgebouw Orchestra of Amsterdam brought to Carnegie Hall on Saturday evening and Sunday afternoon seemed unpromising: four symphonies, one each by Mozart, Beethoven, Brahms and Tchaikovsky, with no new or recent works, no rarities, not even a concerto. The orchestra's music director, Riccardo Chailly, now in his final season, would not be on hand; nor would his successor, Mariss Jansons. Instead the orchestra was to be led by Herbert Blomstedt, the music director of the Gewandhaus Orchestra of Leipzig, the orchestra that Mr. Chailly takes over next season.

title: Ohio Charities to Promote Economic Growth
description: A group of 28 foundations said Tuesday that it would work to promote economic development in nine counties of northeastern Ohio, a region hit hard by the loss of manufacturing jobs to foreign countries.

title: Two Cranes Collapse at the Sikorsky Bridge, Killing a Construction Worker
description: Two construction cranes collapsed yesterday at the Sikorsky Bridge in Stratford, Conn., fatally injuring one worker whose crane plummeted into the icy waters of the Housatonic River.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ROSENBERG, CHARLES, M.D.
description: ROSENBERG--Charles, M.D. 84, died on Tuesday. Loved by his wife, Florence, and adored by his children, Ken and Ina. He lived his life with a joy and generosity that affected everyone around him. He will be deeply missed. Funeral to be held at Temple Beth El, Stamford, CT on Thursday, February 19, at 1.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-9

title: Shiite Vote Plan Would Exclude 'Sunni Triangle'
description: Shiite leaders are pushing a new plan for the transfer of power in Iraq that calls for partial elections, with balloting in the relatively secure Shiite and Kurdish areas but not in the more turbulent ''Sunni triangle.''

title: 2 Bush Officials Cautious On Job-Growth Forecast
description: Treasury Secretary John W. Snow distanced himself on Tuesday from the Bush administration's official prediction that the nation would add 2.6 million jobs by the end of this year.

title: After War's Ravages, A New Life in America
description: If you ask him to describe his native Sudan, which has been in a state of civil war for 20 years, Santino Chuor has a hard time finding the words.

title: A Trade Battle Is Brewing Over U.S. Antidumping Fees
description: The European Union took its objections about the way the United States calculates antidumping duties to the World Trade Organization on Tuesday.

title: Los Angeles Archdiocese Names Those Accused of Abuse Since 1930
description: The Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Los Angeles, the nation's largest, released a report yesterday identifying 244 priests, brothers, deacons and seminarians who have been accused of sexually abusing a total of 656 minors since 1930.

title: Rustic Styles, Coast to Coast
description: POT-AU-FEU has been a fixture for years at George Lang's Caf des Artistes, the ideal cold-weather, late-night supper after a concert or an opera at Lincoln Center. The cafe's new chef, Bill Peet, simmers a veal knuckle bone and a calf's foot overnight to make an unusually rich, golden stock; in that, he cooks leeks, carrots, cabbage, turnips, fennel and potatoes.

title: The 27th Annual American Crossword Puzzle Tournament
description: The following note is a special invitation from The New York Times's crossword editor, Will Shortz.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Trenton: Ex-Mayor Is Sentenced For Corruption
description: The former mayor of New Hanover Township was sentenced yesterday to six months in federal prison for witness tampering in the investigation of an $11,500 sidewalk repair contract. The former mayor, Patrick G. Malloy, 69, who walks with a cane, was also sentenced to six months of house arrest by Judge Garrett E. Brown Jr. of Federal District Court, who cited Mr. Malloy's health issues. Mr. Malloy admitted last year that he had told a witness to lie to a grand jury investigating a contract given to his brother in 1999. Along with James J. Nash, the former treasurer of the town and the school board, Mr. Malloy was found to have lied about bids to steer at least 30 township contracts to his friends and relatives over a 17-year period. Matthew C. McCue (NYT)

title: A Pleasure Palace Without the Guilt
description: NEW YORKERS can adjust to anything except a wide supermarket aisle. Allow more than five inches of clearance on either side of two passing carts, and the freedom is too much to bear. With no battle for space, New York shoppers go slack. They begin to wander aimlessly and gape. They are lost.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Monday about Conrad M. Black's relationship with the board of Hollinger International referred incorrectly to the outcome of a deal in which the company sold two newspapers in Washington State -- The Skagit Valley Argus and The Journal of the Island of San Juan -- for 50 cents each to Horizon Publications, a separate company in which Lord Black held a large stake. Horizon said it lost $12,000 after it later sold both papers, not $12,000 on the sale of The Journal alone.

title: Court Upholds Telemarketing Restrictions
description: A federal appeals court on Tuesday upheld the government's right to help people shield themselves from unwanted telemarketing calls.

title: Sather Promises He Will Soldier On
description: The Rangers are 11 points behind the Islanders and Montreal, who are tied for the last two playoff spots in the Eastern Conference, with 23 games remaining in the regular season. If the Islanders, who have one fewer victory than the Canadiens, play .500 hockey, the Rangers would have to win 18 games to qualify for the playoffs.

title: Phoenix Jury Finds Bishop Guilty in Fatal Hit-and-Run
description: Bishop Thomas J. O'Brien, who was arrested last year for his role in a hit-and-run that killed a carpenter, was found guilty on Tuesday of leaving the scene of a fatal accident.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   RUSSELL, MAUREEN
description: RUSSELL -- Maureen. The Board of Governors, Members and staff of Hampshire Country Club are deeply saddened by the passing of Maureen Russell, wife of our General Manager, Wayne J. Russell. Our heartfelt sympathy is extended to the entire Russell family. Stan Brettschneider, Pres.

title: Mayor Says Out With Lights (Not to Mention the Sirens)
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said yesterday that he would ask several people in his administration to relinquish the lights and sirens installed in their city-issued cars, after a news report that one of his deputy mayors frequently used hers for trips that were decidedly not emergencies.

title: The Middle Ages as Beautiful Abstraction
description: Our image of the Middle Ages is dominated by objects thrust into a context for which they were never made. Think of the sculpture fragments in the glass cases of the Metropolitan Museum. Or think of the Masses and chants written in the 13th and 14th centuries. On Feb. 12, the Trio Mediaeval, a Norwegian group making its New York debut, wrested a few of these into a setting just as unfamiliar and just as lovely: presented in the decrepit old synagogue of the Angel Orensanz Foundation, sung by women's voices, juxtaposed with contemporary compositions that echo the spirit of what this music has become for us today, a beautiful wild abstraction.

title: A Minimalist Study of Change
description: Michael Gordon, a founder of Bang on a Can, is an eclectic composer whose music draws its energy from rock, Baroque concertos and Minimalism. Although he has said that Romantic symphony music doesn't interest him, there are moments in his works when a listener might have trouble believing that.

title: $41 Billion Deal, But What's in It For Consumers?
description: The blockbuster merger of Cingular Wireless and AT&T Wireless -- and the consolidation of the wireless industry to five major competitors from six -- may not lead to higher consumer prices for mobile phone service anytime soon, according to industry analysts. And the merger could spur better quality of service, they said.

title: Corrections
description: A listing of credits on Monday with a television review of ''She's Too Young'' included an incorrect surname from the Lifetime channel for the actor who plays Bill Vogel. He is Gary Hudson, not Hudon.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Sri Lanka: Premier Reacts
description: In his first public address since President Chandrika Kumaratunga dissolved Parliament, Prime Minister Ranil Wickremesinghe accused the president of stifling an economic recovery and jeopardizing a cease-fire with Tamil rebels. His speech was carried on several private television channels, but not by the state-run media, which are controlled by the president. P. J. Anthony (NYT)

title: OFF THE MENU
description: Gradually, the restaurants in the Time Warner Center at Columbus Circle are starting to open. The first of the chefs who is ready is THOMAS KELLER , left, an owner of PER SE . Bookings at Per Se are going fast, though lunch reservations are a last-minute possibility. Per Se has a $125 five-course menu, a $135 nine-course vegetable menu and a $150 nine-course tasting menu. Having closed the FRENCH LAUNDRY in Yountville, Calif., for renovations, Mr. Keller expects to be in his restaurant full time until May.

title: Edwards Proves His Point With a Strong Late Surge
description: He did not say, ''I told you so,'' but he might as well have.

title: Setback Seen for Broker In Stewart Judge Ruling
description: The federal judge overseeing the Martha Stewart trial said late yesterday that jurors would be permitted to hear evidence that appears to support the testimony of Douglas Faneuil, the government's chief witness.

title: AXA SAYS IT WILL NOT INCREASE OFFER FOR MONY
description: AXA, the large European insurer, said yesterday that it would not raise its $1.5 billion offer for the MONY Group of New York amid opposition from some of MONY's largest shareholders. The offer is ''full and fair,'' Christopher Condron, who heads AXA Financial, the company's United States business, said in a statement. ''We will not increase it.'' Shares of MONY fell below AXA's $31-a-share offer for the first time since the takeover was announced in September, declining 23 cents, to $30.85, in New York Stock Exchange composite trading. Last week, Institutional Shareholder Services, the largest adviser in the United States on proxy issues, recommended to MONY shareholders that they reject the AXA offer. Glass, Lewis & Company, another proxy adviser, made the same recommendation yesterday.

title: Founder's Children Arrested in Parmalat Inquiry
description: In another attempt to uncover the secrets behind the collapse of Parmalat, the Italian food conglomerate, the financial police on Tuesday arrested Francesca Tanzi and Stefano Tanzi, the daughter and son of Parmalat's imprisoned founder, Calisto Tanzi.

title: Lottery Numbers
Mayor Says '05 Race Is the Last, But What of '06, '07 and '08?
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg has said several times, even as recently as last week, that his bid for re-election in 2005 will be his last campaign for any public office.

title: Market Makers And Big Board Reach a Deal
description: The top market makers at the New York Stock Exchange have tentatively agreed with regulators to pay about $240 million in penalties and fines because of trading abuses, capping a yearlong investigation at the Big Board, people involved in the settlement said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   COVICH, SIDNEY
description: COVICH--Sidney. The Board of Governors and members of The Falls Country Club, Lake Worth, Florida acknowledge with deep sorrow the passing of our esteemed member, Sidney Covich. We extend our deepest sympathy to his beloved wife, Marion, and their family. Dr. Elliott Solomon, Pres.

title: Sports of The Times; Jeter Shows His Cool, This Time in the Preseason
description: IF Derek Jeter was feeling the heat from the newest star in the Yankees' expanding galaxy, he didn't show it. If he was feeling defensive about remaining the shortstop of the team he captains, he didn't sound it.

title: Nobel Laureate In Iran Joins Boycott Of Elections
description: Shirin Ebadi, the Nobel Peace laureate, joined protesters on Tuesday in announcing that she would not vote in parliamentary elections on Friday in which more than 2,000 candidates were disqualified by the government.

title: Avoiding a 'Florida' in 2004 Vote
description: To the Editor:

title: More Jobs to the Gallon
description: WASHINGTON  The Bush administration has issued a proposal that would weaken one of the nation's most successful environmental laws. The administration's plan would change current automotive fuel economy standards and allow a loophole that would hurt the environment, auto workers and the economy.

title: Yankees Welcome Rodriguez, An M.V.P. Who Wants to Blend In
description: He wore a white tie with thin navy blue stripes, evoking his new allegiance. A giant Yankees logo hovered behind him, and more than 300 members of the news media -- about the total for a playoff game -- stared back at him.

title: Advice to Kerry On Exiting Iraq
description: To the Editor:

title: War Shows Its True Colors As Both Friend and Foe
description: Brecht called ''Mother Courage and Her Children'' a chronicle of the Thirty Years' War in Europe. Today encyclopedias divide that bloody 17th-century marathon into periods like the Bohemian Period or the Swedish Period. It is so neat it could be art history. Protestant and Roman Catholic armies battled, dynasties fell, territories changed hands, refugees scattered. When it ended in 1648 more than half the German population was dead.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Nepal: Strike On Rebels
description: Security forces said they killed as many as 60 Maoist rebels in an offensive against a guerrilla camp in the Kalikot district, west of Katmandu, the capital. The strike comes amid increasing violence in the conflict between the constitutional monarchy and the rebels. Amy Waldman (NYT)

title: National Briefing | South: Georgia: Senate Votes To Ban Same-Sex Marriage
description: An amendment to the State Constitution banning same-sex marriage passed in the Republican-controlled Senate with two more votes than the two-thirds that it needed. If the measure passes the House of Representatives, which has a strong Democratic majority, it will then need a simple majority of votes in a November referendum. Ariel Hart (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: An article on Feb. 10 about efforts by Democrats to win Tennessee in the November election after it supported President Bush in 2000 misspelled the surname of a political scientist at Vanderbilt University who commented that ''Tennessee is basically a Republican state.'' He is John Geer, not Gear.

title: The Day That Lutce Closed Its Doors . . .
description: To the Editor:

title: Share Prices Advance as Investors Respond to Mergers
description: Stocks advanced yesterday on optimism that an increase in mergers was a sign that shares are inexpensive even after an 11-month rally and that corporate profits would keep rising.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: World Briefing | Europe: Ireland: Sister Lived With Body
description: A 65-year-old woman in County Mayo continued sharing a bed with her sister's body for up to a year after the sister died, according to a court inquest into why the death was not reported. The woman, Mary Ellen Lyons, said she could not remember when Agnes, 70, died. Her decomposed body was found in August by a doctor making a house call. The sisters had become so reclusive that they communicated with their brother, Michael, 74, who lives in the same house, by passing notes under the bedroom door. ''There is no way that Michael would open the door of a woman's room,'' a neighbor told the inquest. ''They were from a different era.'' Brian Lavery (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KELLEN, STEPHEN M.
description: KELLEN--Stephen M. The Alliance for the Arts mourns the passing of our great friend and benefactor, Stephen M. Kellen. His generosity was equalled by his modesty and by the love he shared with his wife Anna-Maria and his family. He was loyal to what he called his ''two hometowns'', Berlin, where he was born, and New York, which welcomed him and where he prospered. Stephen was a great New Yorker and an elegant, humane citizen of the world. Paul Beirne, Chairman Randall Bourscheidt, Pres. Alliance for the Arts

title: Coping in a Land That's Not Quite Heaven
description: When one of the hopeful teenagers of ''Lost Boys of Sudan,'' speaking about his coming trip to America, says that ''the journey is like you are going to heaven,'' your heart sinks. But in this tidy and fascinating documentary, making its New York premiere today at Film Forum, the accretions of small defeats recorded by the intelligent filmmakers Megan Mylan and Jon Shenk don't sap the will of the young African refugees transplanted to the United States to make a better life.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 543 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the death of the following Americans yesterday:

title: Tattoos Affirmed As Evidence
description: The State Court of Appeals ruled on Tuesday that a defendant's own body -- specifically, his tattoos exalting swastikas and skinheads -- could be used as evidence that he committed a crime fueled by hatred.

title: Offenses Wake Up for Defensive Teams
description: A game between two teams that swear by yawn-inducing, defense-first systems unexpectedly dissolved into a thriller. The Devils took the lead three times Tuesday, and the Minnesota Wild tied the score three times.

title: Squeezing the Poor for Votes
description: Destructive fine print is showing through the budgetary bandwagon President Bush has designed for his re-election drive. It turns out that hundreds of thousands of poor and low-income families will lose child care and housing assistance if the administration's ballyhooed spending cuts take effect. In trying to campaign as a late-blooming fiscal disciplinarian, the president is making a show of marking 128 programs -- count 'em, G.O.P. budget hawks, 128 -- for elimination or cutbacks in many vital social service areas. As if they are at the heart of the administration's rolling deficits, which threaten the nation's economic future.

title: Corrections
description: A headline yesterday on a front-page article about fund-raising for President Bush's re-election referred imprecisely to donors described in the article. Not all are Arab-Americans; they include Pakistani and Iranian-born donors.

title: Remember Afghanistan?
description: To the Editor:

title: When Cultures' Sounds Don't Match, but Echo
description: How do you tune a balafon? At an engrossing concert at St. Ann's Warehouse in Brooklyn on Friday night, the trombonist Roswell Rudd gave the answer: you don't.

title: Mets Sign a Left-Hander
description: While the newest Yankee was being introduced yesterday, the Mets agreed to a minor league contract with the left-hander Randy Keisler, a former Yankees draft pick (second round, 1998), who was 0-1 with a 12.00 earned run average in two starts for the San Diego Padres last season and 7-7 with a 4.13 E.R.A. in Class AAA.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: AUTO RACING

title: Bay Area Judges Stop Short Of Banning Gay Weddings
description: In a setback for opponents of gay marriage, city officials here said Tuesday that they would continue issuing marriage licenses to same-sex couples after two judges stopped short of halting them.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: India: Profit In Consumer Goods
description: India's largest consumer products company, Hindustan Lever Ltd., said its profit rose 3 percent, to 5 billion rupees ($110 million), in the fourth quarter. The company, which makes Surf detergent and Pepsodent toothpaste among other products, said overall sales were slightly lower but rose 2.2 percent when discontinued brands were excluded. The results fell short of expectations, and shares in Hindustan Lever fell 7 percent. The chairman, M.S. Banga, said that he expected sales to increase this year. Saritha Rai (NYT)

description: Correction Appended

title: Corrections
description: An article last Wednesday about the closing of Lutce referred incorrectly to the first restaurant review in which it received four stars in The New York Times. Before Mimi Sheraton's rating in 1980, it had received four stars from Raymond Sokolov, in 1972.

description: Comcast Is Giving No Sign That It Will Raise Disney Bid

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MILLER, SOL
description: MILLER--Sol, On February 17, 2004. Beloved husband of Gloria. Devoted father of Lynn & Caryn. Loving fatherin-law of Roy. Dear brother of Morris. Adored Poppa of Michelle and Andrew. Cherished by family and friends. Services are today, 11 A.M., at ''Sinai Chapels'', 162-05 Horace Harding Expressway, Fresh Meadows, New York.

title: Kermit and Miss Piggy Join Stable of Walt Disney Stars
description: The Walt Disney Company said yesterday that it had acquired two of the Jim Henson Company's best-known properties -- the Muppets and the Bear in the Big Blue House, for an undisclosed sum.

title: Annan to Back Indirect Elections in Iraq, Diplomats Say
description: UNITED NATIONS, Feb. 18  Secretary General Kofi Annan has decided to endorse the view that the interim government to take office in Iraq this summer cannot be chosen by direct elections, but he will delay for at least a week his recommendation on how best to chart the country's political future, senior United Nations diplomats said today.

title: BOLDFACE NAMES
description: Correction Appended

title: The Improbable World of Lawrence Frank
description: Rumors abound. The weave of fact is sometimes stitched over with fiction. A dollop of fancy may be thought to have spiced the narrative. One such example is that the Nets' improbable, implausible, imperturbable head coach, Lawrence Frank, was never a head coach before Jan. 26, when the Nets astonished the basketball world by announcing that he would be taking over.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Chinatown Buses Impounded
description: Officers impounded 16 buses in Chinatown yesterday after conducting surprise inspections on 19, the police said. More than 130 summonses were issued, for violations including parking and safety infractions, a police spokesman said. A law enforcement official described yesterday's checks as ''safety stops'' but noted that they coincided with a continuing investigation into violence and intimidation among more than half a dozen companies that run discount bus trips from Chinatown to cities like Boston, Washington, Philadelphia and Atlantic City. The police did not identify the companies that owned the impounded buses. Violent incidents have been linked to the business over the years, and last week, a driver for one of the bus companies and another man were stabbed on East Broadway, police officials said. Michael Luo (NYT)

title: Remember Afghanistan? (2 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Sotheby's Sells Real Estate Firm to Cendant for $100 Million
description: Sotheby's Holdings, the owner of the auction house, has agreed to sell its 15-office real estate brokerage firm in the United States and the brand's licensing rights to the Cendant Corporation, owner of the Century 21 and Coldwell Banker real estate names.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Feb. 8 about the impact of Al Gore's endorsement of Howard Dean on the campaign for the Democratic presidential nomination referred incorrectly to the position of Moveon.org, a liberal political group. It supports the broad goal of defeating President Bush in November; it does not prefer Dr. Dean or any other candidate.

title: Scientists Accuse White House of Distorting Facts
description: The Bush administration has deliberately and systematically distorted scientific fact in the service of policy goals on the environment, health, biomedical research and nuclear weaponry at home and abroad, a group of about 60 influential scientists, including 20 Nobel laureates, said in a statement issued today.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   SHEERIN, RAYMOND T.
description: SHEERIN--Raymond T. Raymond Thomas Sheerin 2/18/34--8/13/01 We remember.

title: Man Sentenced to 40 to Life for Rape and Murder of Teenager
description: An East Harlem man convicted of raping a teenage girl and throwing her battered body from the roof of a 14-story apartment building was sentenced yesterday in State Supreme Court in Manhattan to 40 years to life in prison.

title: Kerry Holds Off Push by Edwards in Primary Vote in Wisconsin
description: MILWAUKEE, Feb. 17  The Democratic presidential nomination battle turned into a two-man contest on Tuesday as Senator John Kerry narrowly defeated Senator John Edwards in the Wisconsin primary. Howard Dean suffered a dismal third-place showing that Democrats said would effectively end his campaign.

title: Jury Awards Ranchers $1.28 Billion From Tyson
description: A federal jury in Alabama yesterday awarded a group of ranchers $1.28 billion in damages after it found that Tyson Fresh Meats, the country's largest beef packer, used illegal cattle contracts to artificially hold down the prices it paid them.

title: Jervis Langdon Jr., 99, Dies; Rail Executive Led Penn Central
description: Jervis Langdon Jr., a top railroad executive during an era in which the industry was reshaped, died on Monday at his home in Elmira, N.Y. He was 99.

title: Investigations Are Opened Into 2 Deaths From Leaks
description: The owners of a Murray Hill apartment building where two people died and two others were seriously injured on Sunday from carbon monoxide poisoning came under growing scrutiny yesterday, as District Attorney Robert M. Morgenthau and the city's Department of Housing Preservation and Development pursued investigations.

title: Schools Seek Private Firms To Teach Foreign Tongues
description: At the Atlantis Preparatory School in Manasquan, N.J., it's just after 11 a.m. on a Tuesday. For nine third graders, that means Spanish class. Carolyn Bermeo, their teacher, introduces a song popular in Latin America. When she invites the class to join her in acting it out, her charges need little prodding.

title: The Day That Lutce Closed Its Doors . . .
description: To the Editor:

title: Students and Records Overlooked In Special Education Overhaul
description: LAST summer, as part of his overhaul of the New York City schools, Chancellor Joel I. Klein reorganized the special education system, which assesses and educates 150,000 children with handicaps ranging from minor learning disabilities to severe retardation. The restructuring, he promised, would remove bureaucratic deadwood and shift teachers and resources to classrooms, where they are most needed.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Canada: Legislator Quits As Party Slides
description: A Liberal member of Parliament, John Bryden, quit the party, adding to the swelling effects of a scandal over government misspending of public money. ''I've lost confidence in the prime minister and I've lost confidence in the Liberal Party,'' he said. The announcement came as a poll indicated that public support for the party had fallen to 35 percent, from 48 percent a month ago. Colin Campbell (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   REGENSTREIF, LEFFLER, JEANNETTE
description: REGENSTREIF - LEFFLER -Jeannette. Missed every day. Beloved mother. My mentor, confidant and friend. Dear Mom, you've always been there for me. Herbert

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Singapore: Exports Rise
description: Reflecting strong growth in global electronics demand, Singapore's nonoil domestic exports rose 2.7 percent in January compared with January 2003. Leading the growth were shipments of telecommunications equipment and semiconductors to Australia. Economists said the figures were all the more impressive because the long Chinese New Year holiday fell in January this year, reducing the number of business days. Demand for exports was so strong that many factories kept non-Chinese employees working to fill orders, they said. Wayne Arnold (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Yahoo To Use Inktomi Software
description: More than a year after buying Inktomi, a company that makes software for searching the Internet, Yahoo will start using a modified version of that software for its Web searches, starting today. Until now, Yahoo's Web searches were provided by a rival, Google. Yahoo said its Web searching would be fresher and more relevant than Google's. Google said that it had added nearly one billion pages to its Web index for a total of 4.28 billion pages. Yahoo declined to say how many pages are in its index. Yahoo's move is the first shot in what it hopes will be an assault on Google in several search-related areas. Saul Hansell (NYT)

title: Hearty Soup, Short Wait
description: TOO few soups are both hearty and quick to make, but West Lake soup is a stunning exception. Named after its area of origin, in Hangzhou, China, it is sometimes called a variation on egg drop soup. This is a bit like calling a cream-enriched lobster bisque a variation on creamy potato soup.

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: RUSSIA: PUTIN WATCHES AS MISSILE TEST FAILS President Vladimir V. Putin took to sea aboard a nuclear submarine in a carefully orchestrated visit on the eve of presidential elections to observe one of the country's largest military exercises in years. Russian news agencies, including the official Itar-Tass, reported that two ballistic missiles aboard another submarine misfired because of a glitch in satellite communications. The Navy's commander, Adm. Vladimir I. Kuroyedov, later denied that there were any malfunctions. The exercise, under way since last month, involves Russia's strategic nuclear forces and includes test flights of ballistic missiles and strategic bombers, military commanders have said. Steven Lee Myers (NYT)

title: A Little Fish, Much Maligned

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Network Appliance Says Earnings Rose
description: Network Appliance said yesterday that third-quarter earnings more than doubled as the company added products and sold more software. Net income in the period ended Jan. 30 increased to $40.2 million, or 11 cents a share, from $19.7 million, or 6 cents, a year earlier, the company said. Sales rose 30 percent, to $297.3 million from $228.5 million. Sales will probably rise 32 percent to 34 percent in the fourth quarter, the chief financial officer, Steve Gomo, said. Profit including some costs will probably be 11 cents to 12 cents a share, compared with a forecast of 11 cents by Thomson First Call. Sales have risen in nine consecutive quarters. Third-quarter operating expenses rose 13 percent.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Trenton: Homeowners Lose Free-Speech Suit
description: In a widely watched challenge to the power of homeowner associations over issues of speech, a State Superior Court judge ruled yesterday that such associations may restrict political signs and enforce other rules that would be unconstitutional if adopted by a town or other local government. Prof. Frank Askin of the Rutgers Law School in Newark, who represented a group of East Windsor residents challenging their homeowners association, said they would appeal the decision. The ruling, by Judge Neil H. Shuster, dismissed most of the claims against the governing association in Twin Rivers, a development of 10,000 people. The lawsuit claimed that the association's board had banned signs on front lawns to squelch political opposition. But Judge Shuster ruled that the residents were bound by the contracts they signed when they moved in and that the association was not subject to constitutional restraints.

title: Armagnac, Cognac's Country Cousin
description: IT is Armagnac's fate, and maybe its fortune, always to be overshadowed by Cognac. While Armagnac producers have plodded away in rustic Gascony south of Bordeaux -- the sticks, really -- Cognac has won renown as the epitome of elegance, its virtues trumpeted on billboards around the world. By contrast, Armagnac is the hick cousin, recognized but ultimately accorded secondary status.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Putin Watches As Missile Test Fails
description: President Vladimir V. Putin took to sea aboard a nuclear submarine in a carefully orchestrated visit on the eve of presidential elections to observe one of the country's largest military exercises in years. Russian news agencies, including the official Itar-Tass, reported that two ballistic missiles aboard another submarine misfired because of a glitch in satellite communications. The Navy's commander, Adm. Vladimir I. Kuroyedov, later denied that there were any malfunctions. The exercise, under way since last month, involves Russia's strategic nuclear forces and includes test flights of ballistic missiles and strategic bombers, military commanders have said. Steven Lee Myers (NYT)

title: A Texan's Accent for French Fables
description: The 17th-century fabulist Jean de la Fontaine may have borrowed the plots of many of his animal allegories from Aesop and early Persian storytellers, yet the resulting ''Fables'' could not be more French. They were wildly popular in la Fontaine's lifetime as commentaries on human nature, and they have been taught in primary schools here ever since. To this day there is hardly a Frenchman or woman who cannot recite several of the tales.

title: To Eat an Oyster and Grow One, Too
description: Oysters were once abundant in the Raritan and Hudson River estuaries, stretching from Sandy Hook, N.J. to Ossining, N.Y. An environmental group, the New York-New Jersey Baykeeper, hopes to restore oyster beds to some of this habitat. To help, Bahrs Landing, a restaurant in Highlands, N.J., is canning an oyster stew for sale in New York and New Jersey, with 10 percent of the sales going to Baykeeper, whose executive director, Andrew Willner, is at right. (The oysters in Bahr's stew are not local, because there are none.) Mixed with a can of milk and heated to a simmer, it is a fine winter warmer. I melted a pat of butter and added a dash of paprika to each portion. Bahr's stew is sold at the restaurant and in Foodtown and A.&P. supermarkets, at $2.99 for a 16-ounce can.

title: National Briefing | South: North Carolina: Suit Filed In Shooting Of Soldiers
description: A soldier and the estate of another soldier are suing the sheriff's deputy who shot the soldiers two years ago when he mistook Green Beret training exercises for criminal activity. The suit also names the sheriff's office. Sheriff Lane Carter said that the deputy, Randall Butler, killed First Lt. Tallas Tomeny and wounded Sgt. Stephen Phelps in February 2002 near Fort Bragg after Deputy Butler stopped their pickup truck and found a bag with a disassembled machine gun in it. The sheriff said the deputy fired to protect himself when the soldiers came at him and went for the gun. A lawyer for the soldiers said there had been no provocation for deadly force. The State Bureau of Investigation examined the matter, and no charges were filed. Ariel Hart (NYT)

title: SUN BANCORP AGREES TO ACQUIRE COMMUNITY BANCORP
description: Sun Bancorp agreed yesterday to buy Community Bancorp of New Jersey for about $83.2 million in stock to add eight branches in New York suburbs. Sun will pay 0.83 share for each Community share, or about $22.35 a share, 9.3 percent more than Community's closing price Friday. Community, based in Freehold, N.J., may also pay its shareholders a one-time cash dividend of 75 cents a share. Sun is buying Community to expand in Monmouth County, an affluent and growing suburban area in central New Jersey.

title: In a Midwinter Wedding of Sweet and Salty, The Ham Needn't Be the Better Half
description: Prosciutto and melon may be a classic pairing, but at this time of year, fresh melon does not live up to its half of the bargain. Instead, consider narrow wedges of French glac melon, which resembles dried fruit but is fragrant, lush and moist, with a rich concentration of melon flavor. It is a sublime foil not only for prosciutto but also for other cured hams like serrano and spicy coppa. The melon is also excellent with cheese or in a fruit salad. It is $6.99 a pound at Fairway markets, where it is called dried melon.

description: Back when he was a rising phenomenon in Iowa and New Hampshire, Howard Dean used to revel in reeling off the names of the various politicians to whom journalists had taken to comparing him: Jimmy Carter, Bill Clinton, George McGovern, even Barry Goldwater. (I myself, writing in The New York Times Magazine , drew a parallel between Dr. Dean and Jerry Brown.) But as Dr. Dean's once-soaring campaign lost altitude over the dairy farms of Wisconsin during the last month, Dr. Dean took to invoking a more distant historical figure: Robert LaFollette , Wisconsin's iconic early 20th century governor and senator, whose name is synonymous with progressivism.

title: City Agency Seeks Public Advocate's Data on Special Ed
description: The city's Department of Education has served the public advocate with a Freedom of Information request, seeking information about problems in the special-education system cited last week by the advocate, Betsy Gotbaum.

title: Knicks Are Still Pursuing Wallace and Dampier
description: Isiah Thomas made one deal for the Knicks this week, and he is pushing to make a second one by tomorrow's 3 p.m. trading deadline. He still hopes to obtain one of two post players who have been high on his wish list: Atlanta's Rasheed Wallace or Golden State's Erick Dampier.

title: Taliban Using Violence to Deter Potential Afghan Voters
description: KABUL, Afghanistan, Feb. 18  After a relatively dormant winter, the Taliban insurgency is waging a violent campaign in the countryside to frighten people from cooperating with the American-backed government and from taking part in elections scheduled for the summer.

title: KERRY HOLDS OFF PUSH BY EDWARDS IN WISCONSIN VOTE
description: The Democratic presidential nomination battle turned into a two-man contest on Tuesday as Senator John Kerry narrowly defeated Senator John Edwards in the Wisconsin primary. Howard Dean suffered a dismal third-place showing that Democrats said would effectively end his campaign.

title: Russia Levels New Charge of Theft Against Yukos Oil Stockholder
description: Russian prosecutors expanded charges on Tuesday against a major shareholder in the Yukos oil company, one day after a group of shareholders made an offer they hoped would free him and two other imprisoned Yukos figures.

title: Hip New Churches Sway to a Different Drummer
description: It was ''alt.worship'' night at Bluer on a recent Saturday, and as a crowd of about 50 people, mostly in their 20's and 30's, milled around an open loft space filled with couches and candles, John Musick, the pastor, sat behind a drum set, accompanied by three other members of the musical ''ministry team.'' Light fixtures dangled from exposed pipes; slides and videos of old stone crosses or statues flashed on two screens.

description: Jos Lpez Portillo, who as president of Mexico from 1976 to 1982 brought his nation to the brink of economic collapse, died yesterday. He was 83 years old.

title: U.S. Economic Recovery Begins to Trickle Into Mexico
description: The recent news that the American auto parts maker Tower Automotive would shut a plant in Milwaukee and move production, and 600 jobs, to a joint venture partner in northern Mexico was greeted here as a sign that after three years in the doldrums, Mexico was finally feeling the effects of the recovery in the United States.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   D'ARCANGELO, A. RICK
description: D'ARCANGELO--A. Rick, a man who was respected and loved by everyone who knew him, died on Valentine's Day, February 14th, 2004. He was 85. In 1942, Rick graduated cum laude from New York University. After graduation, he distinguished himself as a 2nd Lieutenant, for the 8th Air Force, at headquarters in England. His commanding officer reported ''Mr. D'Arcangelo succeeded in establishing and maintaining the most remarkable and accurate reporting systems ever devised in accounting for Ordnance. This data was of utmost importance to the troops in determining priorities to several active theaters of war.'' In 1950, he founded D'Arcangelo and Co., LLP. He built the organization, specializing in accountancy and consulting, to have offices in Purchase, Poughkeepsie, Millbrook, Rome and Utica, NY. Throughout his distinguished career, to the present, he maintained close personal contact and served his clients with scrupulous honesty, integrity and commitment. He was elected President of the New York State Society of CPAs, Chairman of the State Board for Public Accountancy, and recipient of New York University's Meritorious Service Award as well as many additional professional honors. Rick served on the American Institute of Certified Public Accountants Council and the National Association of State Boards of Accountancy. A. Rick D'Arcangelo was born on July 19, 1918 in Iselin, PA, the son of Dominick and Ines (Cerasoli). His survivors include his beloved wife of 58 years, Marjorie (Foster), his devoted children, James (wife Mary Ellen), Inez (husband Alfred Thoben), Martha and John (wife Kathleen), nine grandchildren and one great-grandchild. Also survived by cherished siblings, Albert (wife Josephine), Stella Coccagnia, Helen Aquillo, Josephine Alberico (husband Richard) and Elizabeth Gratch (husband Leonard). Visitation Monday and Tuesday, February 16-17, 2-4 and 7-9 PM, Coxe & Graziano Funeral Home, 767 East Boston Post Road, Mamaroneck, NY. Funeral Mass Wednesday, February 18, at 11 AM, at St. Gregory the Great Church in Harrison, NY, followed by an interment at Greenwood Union Cemetery in Rye, NY. Contributions in his memory can be made to the New York University Scholarship Fund, c/o NYU Alumni Federation, 25 W. 4th Street, NY, NY 10012.

Because of an editing error, the obituary referred incorrectly to his opponent in his first race for mayor. Yvelyne de Marcellus Marix is a woman.

description: President Bush's plan for clarifying the causes and effects of climate change has been improved over the past year, but can succeed only if the research is shielded from political pressures and if more money is spent on it, an independent panel of experts said today.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Rambus Wins Ruling On Chip Patents
description: A designer of high-speed memory chips, Rambus Inc., won a ruling yesterday by a Federal Trade Commission judge that might help it reap as much as $3 billion a year from semiconductor makers. An administrative law judge rejected government claims that Rambus violated antitrust laws by attending meetings to set industry standards for memory chips as it pursued patents for those chips. The judge said the trade commission ''failed to sustain its burden'' of proving Rambus committed fraud. Judge Stephen McGuire's decision, which will be reviewed by commissioners, bolsters efforts by Rambus to collect patent royalties from semiconductor makers.

title: A Two-Seater Just Right For Getting Away From It All
description: The prototype for a jet plane (above) by the Australian designer Marc Newson (right) made Paris feel like a cutting-edge design center during the Maison et Objet show last month. ''Kelvin 40,'' as the project is called, was shown at the Fondation Cartier Pour l'Art Contemporain, which commissioned it. Mr. Newson has had a lifelong fascination with jets. ''To me they were glamorous, beautiful streamlined objects that gave me the nearest thing to an out-of-this-world experience,'' he said. ''If I hadn't quit college, I would have become an aeronautics engineer.''

description: The debt rating of the Schering-Plough Corporation, the drug maker, was lowered by Standard & Poor's Ratings Services, which said Schering's financial outlook would probably deteriorate in several years. The rating for senior unsecured debt was lowered to A- from A and its short-term credit and commercial paper rating was cut to A-2 from A-1, Standard & Poor's said. Standard & Poor's said Schering-Plough's earnings prospects were ''highly uncertain.'' Schering-Plough is based in Kenilworth, N.J.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MCMAHON, THOMAS VAUGHAN
description: McMAHON--Thomas Vaughan, of Westhampton Beach, NY, died on February 17, 2004, surrounded by his family. Tom is survived by Barbara, his devoted wife of 50 years, as well as four children and their spouses, Don and Kate Galletly of Houston, TX, Molly and Frank Maguire of Darien, CT, Tom and Hilary McMahon of Hillsborough, CA, and Mimi and Frank Melo of Walpole, MA. Known to his grandchildren and their friends as ''Dear'', Tom's seven grandchildren are Barbara and Patrice Galletly, Julie and Frank Maguire, and Tommy, Michael and Erin McMahon. Also surviving Tom are a brother, James, and a sister, Joan. Tom was predeceased by his brother, Edward. Born to Edward W. and Gertrude V. McMahon on October 19, 1924, Tom was reared in Brooklyn and schooled at Poly Prep, Class of '42. He earned his college degree from Princeton University, Class of '46. Tom served his country in the U.S. Army during World War II. Upon completing his legal studies at St. John's Law School, Tom joined and later became a partner of Conboy, Hewitt, O'Brien & Boardman. He practiced law for more than 55 years, principally as a trial lawyer in the New York region. Of that career, he was most proud of the last 14 years which were spent as a partner of the New York area firm of Ahmuty, Demers & McManus, where he helped build the firm's practice on the east end of Long Island. He was a member of the New York State Bar Association, the National Association of Rail Road Trial Counsel, the Knights of Malta, the Princeton Club and the Westhampton Country Club. Visitation will take place at Follett & Werner Funeral Home (60 Mill Road, Westhampton Beach, NY 11978) from 2 p.m. to 4 p.m. and 7 p.m. to 9 p.m. on February 20, 2004. A funeral Mass will be held at Immaculate Conception Church (580 Main Street, Westhampton Beach) at 9:30 a.m. on February 21, 2004. In lieu of flowers, donations to East End Hospice (PO Box 1048, Westhampton Beach, NY 11978) are appreciated.

title: When Imperfection Is Flawless
description: Emery et Cie., a rarefied French version of the home improvement store, has moved to new two-level quarters in Paris. The boutique offers intensely colored paints, handmade Moroccan tiles, fabrics, ironwork and ceramics. ''I prefer to work with craftsmen who give a place for human imperfection and accident, and finally identity,'' said Agns Emery (above right), the owner and designer. Casein paints (top left), in 83 colors, are about $117 for a bit over a gallon. The large paint swatches are $3 each. Mirrored tiles (bottom right), about four inches square in eight colors, are about $4 each, less in quantity. Fabrics (the organdy, lower left, is $19 for almost 40 inches in 51 colors) can be screen-printed from a large selection of patterns. Printing is $70 to $210 an image. All items can be shipped; you will be stopped if you try to take the paint on the plane with you. Emery et Cie., 18, passage de la Main d'Or, near rue du Faubourg St.-Antoine. 011-33-1-44-87-02-02 or brussel@emeryetcie.com.

description: THE cast-iron radiator that sat disconnected in my kitchen last year during a renovation was different from the others in the house in one respect. The others were all covered in cracking white paint. This one, for whatever reason, was covered in cracking black paint.

title: ONESOURCE TO BE ACQUIRED BY PRIVATE INVESTMENT GROUP
description: OneSource Information Services Inc., which sells financial data, agreed to be acquired for about $65.1 million by an investment firm, ValueAct Capital Partners, and its affiliates, which want to take OneSource private. The price, $8.40 a share, represents an 11 percent premium to OneSource's closing price of $7.60 on Tuesday, OneSource said. ValueAct, a closely held investment partnership based in San Francisco, and affiliates already own 32 percent of OneSource, which is based in Concord, Mass.

title: Bridge Out of Nowhere Leads a Town to Its Future
description: EMILIE READY, a 74-year-old mortgage escrow officer and a member of a local women's club, vividly recalls the day seven years ago when Santiago Calatrava, the renowned Spanish architect and engineer, unveiled his design for a glass and steel footbridge across the Sacramento River to members of the Rotary, Kiwanis and Lions Clubs assembled for lunch at the Doubletree Inn.

Martin (Lisa), brothers-in-law Edward S. Solovei (Liisa) and Gerald A. Solovei. A dedicated obstetrician/gynecologist for over forty years. His kind and gentle ways and keen insight will be missed by all. Services Thursday, February 19th, 10AM at the ''RiversideNassau North Chapels'' 55 North Station Plaza, (opposite the LIRR), Great Neck NY.

title: Toyota becomes the first exclusive auto sponsor on EBay.
description: IN its latest effort to tap the advertising potential of the Internet, the Toyota Motor Corporation has agreed to become the first exclusive automotive sponsor on eBay, the online auction site, in a deal that promotes Toyota cars and trucks on special eBay pages and in online charity auctions.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Lucent Shareholders Approve 1-Year Board Terms
description: Shareholders for Lucent Technologies approved proposals to have directors stand for election annually and to allow the board to enact a reverse stock split. At the company's annual meeting yesterday in Wilmington, Del., shareholders voted to have each director face re-election annually, beginning in 2005. One-year terms give shareholders more authority by letting them evaluate directors each year, the chief executive, Patricia F. Russo, said. Lucent's 11 directors had served three-year terms that were staggered so that three or four director posts were up for election each year. Shareholders also gave the board the authority to conduct a reverse stock split at a ratio of 1-for-5 to as much as 1-for-30. Directors may consider the reverse split as a way to reduce administrative costs relating to the company's 4.2 billion common shares and to raise the share price, which could make the shares more attractive to institutional investors, Ms. Russo said. The board won the right for a reverse split of shares at last year's meeting, but did not carry it out. At the time, the company wanted to make sure shares remained above $1, after they dipped as low as 55 cents in October 2002. Shares of Lucent fell 8 cents, or 2 percent, to $4.20. They had more than doubled in the last year.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about a column on the Op-Ed page of The New York Times by the United Auto Workers and the Sierra Club, opposing a plan by the Bush administration to overhaul fuel economy rules, omitted comment from the government. Rae Tyson, a spokesman for the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration, said that the proposals were at an early stage and that suggestions are being sought from all parties, including the union and environmental groups.

title: Russia Told It Understates Dependence On Oil Sales
description: Russia's economy is more deeply dependent on oil and gas than previously thought, with energy making up an estimated 25 percent of output instead of the 9 percent attributed to it in Russia's own accounts, the World Bank said on Wednesday in an economic report.

title: A Hit Record By Norah Jones Buoys Industry
description: Norah Jones has given the ailing music industry a boost as her new album sold more copies during its debut week than any other release has managed to do in more than two and half years.

title: Economic Scene; Far from a 'curse,' natural resources can form the basis for economic growth.
description: A POPULAR notion in economics today is that an abundance of natural resources is a ''curse'' for developing nations. Such an endowment, it is argued, encourages corruption, undermines institutional development, pushes the value of a currency uncompetitively high and cannot support long-term growth because the reserves eventually run out. Small wonder, then, that oil-rich nations like Iraq and Venezuela are poor or in decline.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Applied Materials Posts Income Of $82.4 Million
description: Applied Materials, the world's biggest maker of computer-chip production equipment, said yesterday that first-quarter net income was $82.4 million, as chip makers ordered more machines to meet rising demand. Excluding some costs, profit was 12 cents a share, beating analysts' predictions of 8 cents, based on the average of 27 estimates taken by Thomson Financial. Sales increased 48 percent, to $1.56 billion, the company, based in Santa Clara, Calif., said. Orders rose 32 percent from the fourth quarter, to $1.68 billion, beating the company's forecast for a 20 percent gain. Rising demand for parts for electronics ranging from mainframe computers to cellphones will probably end three years of declining sales at Applied Materials. Shares of Applied Materials rose to $23.52 in extended trading. The stock rose 37 cents, to $22.31, in regular trading.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BESSUNGER, HANS, JOACHIM (JOHN)
description: BESSUNGER -- Hans -Joachim (John). The Board of Directors and employees of Haram - Christensen Corpora tion, Carlstadt, N.J., acknowledge with deep sorrow the passing of its Chairman. Mr. Bessunger was a brilliant man with expert knowledge in the specialty food business. Mr. Bessunger leaves behind his loving wife, Kelen, and his sister, Ann. Services will take place Sunday, February 22, 24 and 7-9PM at O'Shea Funeral Home, Hampton Bays, L.I.

title: Ways to Avoid Games That Slow a Family PC
description: Q. There are several PC games that I would like to install on our family computer. My dad uses the computer for his business and his checking; he thinks that games would open up a lot of background programs that would slow the PC even when a game isn't on. Would my game or its background programs affect his programs?

title: Corrections
description: An article on Feb. 5 about William I. Koch, the investor and art collector, misstated the inheritance he and his three brothers received when their father, Fred Koch, died in 1967. It was stakes in the family oil business, which was worth $25 million to $30 million at the time. While the company, now known as Koch Industries, has since grown into one of the country's largest privately held concerns, with annual sales around $40 billion, the brothers did not inherit hundreds of millions of dollars each.

description: A leading Republican senator charged Wednesday that the Federal Bureau of Investigation may have long tolerated egregious, even criminal conduct by some of its agents, including rape, embezzlement and extortion.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Spain: E.T.A. Calls a Cease-Fire For Catalonia
description: In a video broadcast on television, two members of the armed Basque separatist group E.T.A. announced that it was unilaterally declaring a cease-fire for the northern region of Catalonia ''with the aim of uniting ties between the Basque and Catalan peoples.'' The move follows a meeting last month between E.T.A. leaders and a top minister in the Socialist-led Catalan government. The minister, who claimed his objective was to negotiate a truce with the radical group, was forced to resign when the meeting became known. Political parties across Spain refuse to negotiate with the guerrilla group and criticized the limited cease-fire. Dale Fuchs (NYT)

title: A New Direction For Fast-Food Rivals
description: Two of the three principal competitors in the hamburger segment of the fast-food market are introducing major campaigns, each coincidentally focused on humorous characters.

description: A lingering dispute over the director's credit on the Brazilian film ''City of God'' has found new life in Hollywood as voting for the Oscars intensifies before the awards ceremony on Feb. 29.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GREGG, DAVID III
description: GREGG--David III, 71, senior advisor to and a founder of the Pierce Financial Corporation, a firm handling venture financing for broadcasting companies and other businesses, died February 15 of a cardiac arrest in Richmond, VA, while racing in a regional Masters swim competition. Mr. Gregg also was a founder and chair of the board of Gator Broadcasting Corporation and a director of the Monument Group of Mutual Funds. His Business experience was extensive. After holding earlier leadership positions in Eastman Dillon, Union Securities & Co, and Blyth & Co, Inc, he was appointed in 1973 executive vice president of the newly formed Overseas Private Investment Corporation, an agency of the US government facilitating US investment in developing nations to enhance global economic and social progress toward democratic market - based economies. His interest in overseas development continued in the 1980s when as executive vice president and director of the Pierce International Corporation, he was engaged in financing housing projects in Venezuela and other development efforts in Latin America. Born in NYC and raised in Darien, CT, Mr. Gregg graduated from Deerfield Academy in Massachusetts, from Yale University with a BA in 1955, and from Columbia University Graduate School of Business with a MBA in 1959. He served in the US Army after college. Mr. Gregg was a member of the Mid-Atlantic Venture Capital Association and a former member of the NY Society of Security Analysts. In addition he was a member and former director of the Ontcora Club, a member of the NY Amateur Ski Club, and a member of the Chesapeake Bay Yacht Club. An avid amateur athlete, Mr. Gregg enjoyed skiing and tennis and was an active member of the Fairfax County Masters Swim Team, through which he was nationally ranked in top 10 for Masters breaststroke. Mr. Gregg's first marriage to May Foster Bowers ended in divorce. Mr. Gregg lived in Arlington, VA with his wife, Sarah Massengale Gregg, a vice president for Baxter Healthcare Corporation. He is also survived by two children from his first marriage, Tina Gregg Barkstrom, of Richmond, VA, and Dr. David Gregg IV of San Francisco, his brother Arthur of Chapel Hill, NC and two grandchildren. A memorial service will be held at 11:00 am on February 21st at St. Mary's Episcopal Church Arlington, VA. Interment will be in the family plot in Easton, MD. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions in honor of David Gregg may be sent to Deerfield Academy, Alumni Office, Deerfield, MA 01342 or to Yale University, Office of Development, PO Box 805, New Haven, CT 06503-0805 or to Dr. Jim Miller, President, US Masters Swimming Endowment Fund, PO Box 10, Noblesville, IN 46061.

title: Dean Stops by Campaign Headquarters
description: BURLINGTON, Vt., Feb. 19  Howard Dean was never a sartorial star, wearing the same cheap suits  and ties  for days on end, often having holes in the heels of his socks. When he decided at the end of the Iowa campaign last month that a sweater was more appropriate for a weekend bus tour, he had to borrow one from a staff member. He wore that two days in a row, too.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HOVIS, EUGENE LEONARD (GENE)
description: HOVIS -- Eugene Leonard (Gene). Died on Tuesday, February 17 peacefully in his sleep in his home after a long illness. Cooking was Gene Hovis' destiny. Born in Salisbury, NC, Gene came from a family of fabulous cooks. Hovis left Salisbury for New York in 1952. As an actor and model he always cooked. He took cooking lessons from Dione Lucas, then one of the leading teachers in Manhattan. Several years later he honed his skills with the The New York Times late food Editor Craig Claiborne. Hovis has been involved in the food business as a caterer, restaurant consultant, professional chef and food stylist. He was food editor for HG Magazine and was co-host with Melba Tolliver on Channel 12 Long Island People. Gene Hovis was Vice President and Creative Director, marketplace and restaurants, Macy's East until his retirement in 1997. His book ''Gene Hovis' Uptown Down Home Cookbook'' is filled with the most scrumptious recipes around. Hovis attended Talladega College, New York University, and Ecole Gastronomique in Lausanne, Switzerland. He was associated with the James Beard Foundation, City Meals-on-Wheels and God's Love We Deliver. He is survived by his longtime companion of 42 years Hans J. Teetz. He will always be loved and never forgotten. Funeral arrangements are incomplete at present.

title: Russia's Old Television News
description: By all accounts, the Kremlin does not literally take a black marker to scripts or vet the coverage in advance at the nation's three national networks. Such Soviet-style methods are no longer necessary. Russia's two state-owned television networks and one state-controlled network mostly do the censoring themselves. That means Russia's television news increasingly aims to please an audience of one: President Vladimir Putin. For a nation trying to shed its totalitarian past, this is a treacherous slide in the wrong direction.

title: Shaken Trust: The Netherlands Rethinks an Offshore Industry
description: A black eye over the Parmalat collapse was the last thing the Dutch trust business needed.

description: Howard Dean's decision to abandon his campaign was met with relief by some Congressional Democrats who feared that the former Vermont governor could have been a drag on the party's House and Senate candidates.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Volkswagen Cuts Dividend
description: Volkswagen will cut its dividend for the first time in 11 years after reporting that profit last year fell 57 percent, to 1.12 billion euros ($1.44 billion) from 2.6 billion euros, on flat sales. The euro's gain of 20 percent against the dollar last year led to a loss in the United States, where the company gets 13 percent of its sales. Lower-than-expected sales of the Phaeton, which has a starting price of 57,300 euros, led to a write-down of 711 million euros. The company proposed a dividend cut of 19 percent, to 1.05 euros a share, from 1.30 euros because of the decline in earnings.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Report Says Housing Aid May Wane
description: By 2015, the rents for at least 40,000 of the 120,000 city apartments covered under the state's Mitchell-Lama housing program might no longer be subsidized if dozens of contracts for buildings are not renewed and owners are allowed to rent the apartments at market rates, according to a report released yesterday by Comptroller William C. Thompson Jr. For the nearly 50 years the program has been in place, the report said, about 21,000 of the original 140,000 apartments in dozens of buildings have been removed from the Mitchell-Lama program, which subsidizes rents for low- and middle-income tenants. Eleven more buildings, with a total of 4,800 units, have submitted formal notices to opt out, and 59 buildings with an additional 40,000 units -- mostly in Manhattan and Brooklyn -- could leave by 2015, according to the report. David W. Chen (NYT)

description: IN an ideal motoring world, Amnon Shashua acknowledges, there would be no need for the EyeQ chip, a processor that analyzes signals from automobile-mounted cameras to warn drivers of potential collisions or other dangerous situations.

A naturally occurring byproduct of combustion, it is so ubiquitous it is often found right where people live, eat and sleep.

title: Bush Climate Plan Rated Somewhat Improved
description: President Bush's plan for clarifying the causes and effects of climate change has been improved over the past year but can succeed only if the research is shielded from political pressures and if more money is spent on it, an independent panel of experts said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   D'ARCANGELO, MARK J.
description: D'ARCANGELO--Mark J., 78, died on February 12, 2004. He was born in Buffalo, NY, on September 3, 1925 and served in the Pacific in the liberation of the Philippine Islands during WWII. Mark retired from General Electric in 1988 as a Vice President. He graduated from the Indiana Institute of Technology and studied for an MBA at Case Western Reserve University. Mark was appointed by the first President Bush in 1991 to the Federal Prisons Industries as Chairman of the Board for three years. He was predeceased by his son Timothy Mark D'Arcangelo in 1981 and his wife Marnie D'Arcangelo in 2001. He is survived by his son Andrew Charles D'Arcangelo of Arizona, his daughter Anne Cote D'Arcangelo of Milford CT and his granddaughter Kelsea Cote Leroy of Milford CT. Memorial services will be held at 11AM on Saturday, March 6 at Calvary Evangelical Free Church, 498 White Plains Road, Trumbull CT 06611 and also at 10:30 AM on Friday March 12 at Moorings Presbyterian Church, 791 Harbour Drive, Naples FL 34103. In lieu of flowers memorials may be made to either the Salvation Army or the Christian Heritage School, 575 White Plains Road, Trumbull, CT 06611.

title: For a Soldier's Fretting Family, A Digital Map of Baghdad
description: While Baghdad is not likely to be the next big tourist destination, a Massachusetts company that makes nautical charts and other navigation tools is betting that a CD offering maps of the Iraqi capital's streets will find an audience in the United States.

title: Administration Backs Off Specific Forecast on Jobs
description: The Bush administration backed away on Wednesday from a forecast it made public only last week predicting average job gains of more than 300,000 a month for 2004 but said it remained confident of robust though unspecified job growth for the year.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Intuit Posts 16% Profit Increase
description: Intuit, the world's biggest maker of tax-preparation software, said yesterday that second-quarter earnings rose 16 percent on demand for its TurboTax program, used by consumers, and for small-business products. Net income in the quarter that ended Jan. 31 rose to $149.1 million, or 73 cents a share, from $128.4 million, or 60 cents a share, a year earlier, the company said. Sales at Intuit, which is based in Mountain View, Calif., rose 14 percent, to $636.3 million from $558.1 million. Wider use of personal computers to prepare tax returns before the April 15 deadline is increasing sales of Intuit's software. The company, which vies with H&R Block, is also selling more business-related programs to companies with fewer than 100 workers. TurboTax sales rose 36 percent, to $130 million, from a year earlier, the company said.

description: HIGHLIGHTS

title: Now Preening On the Coffee Table
description: TO most home viewers, remote controls may seem like ancillary sidekicks to the main attraction that is the television, DVD player or digital video recorder. Yet in some ways the remote has become the centerpiece of home entertainment: so many functions have been relegated to this slip of an object that if it is lost, you may find yourself unable to do so much as call up a menu for watching the movie you popped into the DVD player.

title: JETS COMPLETE COACHING STAFF
description: The rebuilding of the Jets' coaching staff was completed yesterday when they named Bob Casullo as tight ends coach. Casullo, who spent four seasons as the Oakland Raiders' special teams coach, replaces Dick Curl, who was the tight ends coach last season and will become the senior offensive assistant/special projects. Jim Hostler, who coached quarterbacks last season, will become wide receivers coach. Judy Battista

title: McEnroe and Garrison to Coach Tennis
description: The United States Tennis Association yesterday named Patrick McEnroe and Zina Garrison as the coaches of the men's and women's teams for the Summer Olympics in Athens. McEnroe, 37, has been the captain of the United States Davis Cup team since 2001, when he succeeded his older brother, John. Garrison, 40, succeeded Billie Jean King two months ago as the captain of the United States Fed Cup team.

title: St. Joseph's Reaches 23-0 And Answers Its Critics
description: For a while, Fordham stayed with unbeaten St. Joseph's last night. There was Mark Jarrell-Wright driving for a dunk that tied the score at 17-17, and the slam by Michael Haynes a couple of minutes later that cut the Hawks' lead to 2 and had Rams fans believing that nothing was impossible at Rose Hill Gym.

title: A Contrived Sense of Urgency
description: ncounters" served as the overall title for the program of six short dances Cherylyn Lavagnino offered on Feb. 13 at St. Mark's Church, an attraction in the City/Dans series of the church's Danspace Project.

title: Washington Guardsman Charged With Trying to Spy for Al Qaeda
description: The Army has charged a member of the Washington State National Guard with attempting to supply intelligence of Army organizations and weapons systems to the Qaeda terrorist network, Army officials said on Wednesday. The intelligence included details about military personnel, troop movement, tactics and ''vulnerabilities,'' the charges said.

title: World Briefing | Middle East: Red Cross Condemns West Bank Barrier
description: The International Red Cross strongly criticized Israel's separation barrier in the West Bank, saying that sections of it usurped land envisioned for a Palestinian state and deprived thousands of Palestinians of access to water, health care and education. ''The construction of the West Bank barrier continues to give rise to widespread appropriation of Palestinian property and extensive damage to or destruction of buildings and farmland,'' the Red Cross said in a statement, adding that Israel had gone ''far beyond what is permissible for an occupying power under international humanitarian law.'' Israel says the barrier is intended as a security measure against suicide bombers and other Palestinian attacks. Fiona Fleck (NYT)

title: A Way Out for Haiti
description: Ever since President Woodrow Wilson sent in the Marines in 1915, the United States has made intermittent -- and sometimes inconsistent -- efforts to bring about stability, democracy and prosperity in Haiti. The last decade, especially, has seen striking examples of contradictory American policy, and the cumulative result has been economic stagnation and turmoil in Haiti, where more than 40 people have died during an uprising this month.

title: American Express Unit Starts a Campaign
description: A small business related to reality television is again the subject of a national campaign for the Open Small Business Network division of the American Express Company.

title: ARTS BRIEFING
description: HIGHLIGHTS

title: Charlie Fox, 82, Former Giants Manager, Dies
description: Charlie Fox, who was the 1971 manager of the year with the San Francisco Giants and spent a half-century in baseball as an executive, manager, coach and scout, died Monday at Stanford Hospital in Stanford, Calif. He was 82.

title: Judge's Order Leads MONY To Delay Vote On Takeover
description: The MONY Group, a leading American life insurer, has delayed next week's shareholder vote on a planned $1.5 billion takeover by AXA Financial. The decision came yesterday, after a court had ordered the company on Tuesday to disclose details of $90 million in executive payouts.

title: Instead of Dr. Ruth, a Nurse Called Sue
description: With typical bluntness Sue Johanson tells older men and women to get over body image: the ''turkey neck,'' the ''wear and tear,'' the hormonal deficiencies. But in her cheerful, no-nonsense style she adds that there are creams, patches and pills to help them, and if all else fails, that they can always kiss and cuddle.

title: Painting Rooms With Lights
description: A NEW generation of light fixtures provides little illumination, but lots of atmosphere -- from mood indigo to pretty in pink. Many of the fixtures change color, washing over rooms with their hues. Other low-level lights can replace drippy wax candles on a table. Some have L.E.D. bulbs, which are rechargeable and never burn out. But if you are looking for a good reading light, these won't fit the bill.

title: In Wake of Worst Season, Paterno Shuffles His Staff
description: With Penn State having declined from a national power to a Big Ten also-ran, Coach Joe Paterno's goal of one more undefeated season and a third national championship seems more pipe dream than possibility.

title: How the Home Front Can Help
description: On the bleak, frozen plains of southeastern Afghanistan, the United States Army's 10th Mountain Division has established a heavily fortified compound of tents, cement buildings, howitzer platforms, artillery storage areas and helicopter landing pads. With its concertina wire and security maze entrance, the compound is conspicuous amid the mud huts of the barren valley.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Gamestop Sales Rise 17%
description: The GameStop Corporation, the country's largest chain of video game stores, recorded sales of about $1.58 billion in the fiscal year that ended Jan. 31, up 17 percent from the previous year. Sales at stores open at least a year, or same-store sales, rose 0.8 percent, GameStop said yesterday. In the fourth quarter, total sales rose 20 percent, to $625.4 million from $520.4 million. Same-store sales increased 3.9 percent during the quarter. Gamestop, based in Grapevine, Tex., opened 300 stores in the fiscal year, and expects to open another 300 to 330 stores this year. Based on strong January sales and tight expense controls, the company expects to report fourth-quarter earnings of 67 cents a share, exceeding the forecast it gave last month of 65 cents to 66 cents a share. The company will report its fiscal 2003 earnings on March 17. GameStop shares fell 26 cents, to $18.05.

title: Pressed at Trial, Ex-Tyco Figure Can't Document Story on Bonuses
description: Under cross-examination at his trial on criminal fraud charges, Mark H. Swartz, the former chief financial officer of Tyco International, acknowledged yesterday that no documents existed to support the version of events he offered last week about millions of dollars in bonuses he received in 1999 and 2000.

title: Four-Alarm Fire in Brooklyn
description: For more than 12 hours yesterday, firefighters battled a four-alarm blaze in a vacant warehouse on Water Street in the Vinegar Hill section of Brooklyn. The fire started at 3:30 a.m. and quickly spread throughout the sprawling building, fire officials said. It was under control shortly after 4:30 p.m.

title: It's Not Enough to Be Just a Phone Company
description: If there is one thing Cingular Wireless's acquisition of AT&T Wireless shows, it is that being either a traditional phone company or a mobile phone carrier may not be quite enough anymore.

title: Playwrights Still in Dewy Youth View Humanity With Dry Eyes
description: Stephen Sondheim was in the opening-night audience at the Young Playwrights Festival at the tiny Cherry Lane Studio. This year the festival, which Mr. Sondheim founded in 1982, offers three intriguing, highly enjoyable plays about taboos. The subjects are a high school boy's suicide, a cannibal with a basket full of goodies and a teenage girl who isn't sorry that she had an affair with her English teacher.

title: National Briefing | South: Georgia: Federal Charges In Murder-For-Hire
description: Two men who were acquitted in a state trial in the shooting death of Derwin Brown, a sheriff-elect for DeKalb County, have been arrested on federal charges in the same case. An indictment charged the men, Melvin Walker and David Ramsey, with conspiring in the murder-for-hire of Mr. Brown. Jurors at their 2002 trial said they did not believe prosecution witnesses, who admitted conspiring to kill Mr. Brown but received immunity from murder charges for their testimony against Mr. Walker, Mr. Ramsey and former Sheriff Sidney Dorsey. Mr. Dorsey, whom Mr. Brown had defeated in a bitter election, was convicted of ordering the four other men to commit the murder and is serving a life sentence. Ariel Hart (NYT)

title: Now in Previews, Political Theater in the Street
description: Karl Rove, the political adviser to President Bush, made a brief visit to a Manhattan nightclub yesterday and netted the Bush-Cheney re-election effort about $400,000. But Mr. Rove also caught a glimpse of what might greet Republicans when they come to New York for their national nominating convention this summer.

description: DOLLAR GAINS. The dollar rose on speculation that Japan's central bank would again intervene to sell yen, seeking to protect Japanese exports. In New York, the dollar settled at 106.72 yen, up from 105.66 on Tuesday.

description: Officials at Molson Inc., the venerable Canadian brewer, will be keeping a close eye on what Brazilian revelers choose to drink during the Carnival street party beginning Friday.
