title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SHINE, WARREN S.
description: SHINE--Warren S., of Putnam Valley, NY, died peacefully on February 18, 2004. Survived by his daughter, Elizabeth Shine McDevitt; grandson, Liam Warren McDevitt; companion, Connie Gruber; sister, Roberta Kunin, of Madison, WI, and nieces and nephews. Services private. In lieu of flowers, donations to Memorial SloanKettering would be appreciated. He served as a lieutenant in the U.S. Navy during the Korean War aboard USS Des Moines; he retired as a senior tax partner from Ernst & Young in the late 1980's. He was a board member of many charitable organizations and foundations, including President of Stanley M. Isaacs Neighborhood Center. He was a kind and loving man of many interests.

title: Coach Accused of Hitting Student Resumes Teaching Before Criminal Charges Are Resolved
description: When a 13-year-old boy came home from football practice in September claiming that a coach hit him twice across the face and bloodied his nose, his mother called the school, then went to the police. The coach proclaimed his innocence, but he was charged with assault and pulled from his position as a gym teacher for the North Shore schools.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Move For Life Terms For Terrorists
description: Parliament's lower house voted unanimously to increase the punishment for terrorism to life in prison. The maximum term has been 20 years. The vote followed a bombing in the Moscow subway this month that killed 41 people. The measure must still go through two more hearings. Sophia Kishkovsky (NYT)

title: Bush Appears on New Middle East Network
description: President Bush, helping to inaugurate a new American television network in the Middle East, said in an interview broadcast Wednesday that the United States would continue to press its plan for a Palestinian state and for democracy in Saudi Arabia, Jordan and other Arab countries.

title: Presto! A Rough Sketch Snaps Elegantly Into Place
description: Graphic design and deadlines often seem to go hand in hand, so most designers welcome software that helps them do their work faster. CorelDraw 12, part of the new CorelDraw Graphics Suite 12 software package, recognizes rough shapes and drawings sketched onscreen with a mouse or a graphics pen, instantly turns them into smooth curves and lines, and properly positions them in a document.

title: Subterranean Pleasures, Nights Steamy and Starry
description: A hidden pleasure, the steam room, lies beneath the Asian-inspired Htel Plaza Paris Vendme. The room (above) has a vaulted slate ceiling scattered with fiber-optic lights. The hotel's interior is by Pierre-Yves Rochon, who is also responsible for the George V in Paris and Le Meridien in Beverly Hills, Calif. The Vendme, a four-star hotel, also has an indoor pool with a teak deck. Upstairs, the lobby is large and skylighted, and there is a library with a fireplace. The Vendme has 97 understated rooms; rates are about $485 to $1,125. The Plaza Paris Vendme, 4, rue du Mont Thabor; 011-33-1-40-20-20-00 for reservations; www.plazaparisvendome.com.

title: Little-Known Legislator to Face Schumer, G.O.P. Leaders Say
description: State Republican leaders announced yesterday that they would back a little-known assemblyman, Howard Mills, with six years experience in the State Legislature, as their candidate to challenge Senator Charles E. Schumer in the fall.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Illinois: Budget Would Raise Business Tax
description: Gov. Rod R. Blagojevich presented a $43.5 billion budget to the General Assembly, calling for higher taxes for big business and $400 million in new education spending. The governor, a Democrat, plans to cut 2,000 vacant jobs and offer retirement incentives to 2,000 more employees. Jo Napolitano (NYT)

In the other, the campaign is scraping for every dollar it can get, and somewhere in that America tonight, its candidate could go to bed hungry.

title: The Presidential Primaries; Goodbye, Candidate Dean
description: Howard Dean dared to bell the cat; he stepped forward from nowhere, far in advance of the Democratic Party establishment, to lambaste President Bush's war policy, even as better-known rivals carefully equivocated. This sense of unvarnished daring ignited his campaign and, even more, laid bare the rank and file's deep passion for a White House victory this fall. Rarely has a party's path been so clearly altered by a politician who then, of course, proceeded to lose every race before him.

description: KURTZ--Morton M., M.D. The membership of the Medical Society of the County of Queens expresses their profound sadness on the loss of their beloved colleague and friend, Morton M. Kurtz, M.D. A distinguished and dedicated physician, he served the society well for over 50 years as its president, secretary, treasurer and delegate to MSSNY House of Delegates. He also served as president of the Medical Society of the State of New York (from 1992 through 1993). His loss will be deeply felt. Our deepest sympathies to his wife, Georgine, and his sons, Steven, Stuart and Robert. Robert Aquino, M.D., President Fred S. Fensterer, M.D., Chairman, Board of Trustees

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Mayor Names Adviser
description: Shea Fink, deputy chief of staff to Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, has been named a senior adviser to the mayor. She replaces Vincent A. LaPadula, who left last month to become a vice president for J.P. Morgan Chase. Ms. Fink has been deputy chief since 2002, responsible for Mr. Bloomberg's schedule and his advance team. In her new role, she will continue to oversee scheduling and advance work, but will also advise Mr. Bloomberg on community outreach strategies and other initiatives, according to a news release. Mr. LaPadula, one of the few Republicans in senior positions in the Bloomberg administration, often served as the liaison between the mayor and more conservative corners of the city. Jennifer Steinhauer (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SCHWEITZER, PAUL
description: SCHWEITZER--Paul, 96, beloved and wise New York City teacher and Fordham professor, died peacefully Wednesday at his home in Pelham, N.Y. His wife Eloise, seven children and 13 grandchildren rejoice in his superbly-lived life, and give thanks for his wisdom, love and generosity of spirit. Visitation Pelham Funeral Home, Thursday and Friday 2-4 and 7-9. Funeral Mass Saturday, February 21 at 10AM at Our Lady of Perpetual Help Church, Pelham. N.Y.

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: SPAIN: E.T.A. CALLS A CEASE-FIRE FOR CATALONIA In a video broadcast on television, two members of the armed Basque separatist group E.T.A. announced that it was unilaterally declaring a cease-fire for the northern region of Catalonia "with the aim of uniting ties between the Basque and Catalan peoples." The move follows a meeting last month between E.T.A. leaders and a top minister in the Socialist-led Catalan government. The minister, who claimed his objective was to negotiate a truce with the radical group, was forced to resign when the meeting became known. Political parties across Spain refuse to negotiate with the guerrilla group and criticized the limited cease-fire. Dale Fuchs (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about the selection of an architect for an addition to the United Nations complex misstated the expected cost of an esplanade that the organization plans to finance in return for taking over the Robert Moses Playground. The United Nations has committed millions of dollars, not $100,000. (The esplanade is to be 100,000 square feet.)

title: Stewart Trial Examines Securities Fraud Issues
description: Newspaper accounts of Martha Stewart's ImClone Systems trade were read aloud in court yesterday as prosecutors tried to show that statements by Ms. Stewart at the time were attempts to prop up the price of shares in her own company.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Ireland: Drug Application
description: The Elan Corporation, the drug maker, said it would submit an application to the United States Food and Drug Administration by the middle of the year, a year ahead of schedule, for approval of Antegren, a drug for immune system disorders that it is developing with Biogen IDEC, as a treatment for multiple sclerosis. Antegren is also in trials as a treatment for Crohn's disease and rheumatoid arthritis. Elan reported a loss of $328 million in the fourth quarter, as it reduced expenses by about 40 percent, cut jobs and sold noncore assets. The full-year loss was $529 million. The chief executive, G. Kelly Martin, said Elan would lose $150 million to $170 million this year.

title: MFS Is Facing Another S.E.C. Inquiry
description: The Massachusetts Financial Services Company, a mutual fund unit of Sun Life Financial Inc. of Canada, is facing a second inquiry by the Securities and Exchange Commission over its links with Morgan Stanley and other brokers.

title: MAKER OF MOBILE PLATFORMS TO RESTATE EARNINGS
description: JLG Industries Inc., which makes mobile platforms to elevate workers and tools, said it would restate its earnings for fiscal 2003 after $8.7 million in revenue from a transaction was recognized prematurely. JLG, based in McConnellsburg, Pa., might also restate results for the first quarter of fiscal 2004, ended Oct. 31, the company said. The company said $1.8 million in net income and 4 cents a share were recognized too early in the fourth quarter. A sale of equipment was erroneously recorded in July 2003 before the deal was completed, JLG said, adding that it would delay its second-quarter earnings announcement until an internal review was completed.

description: The leaders of Germany, France and Britain, meeting here on Wednesday to discuss the European economy, dismissed criticism from other European countries that they were making an effort to dictate terms to the rest of the European Union.

description: A New Jersey gas station owner was convicted yesterday of making false statements to federal agents when he denied helping a Yemeni cleric who prosecutors said made a trip to Brooklyn in 1999 to raise money for international terrorism.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Longer Presidential Term Rejected
description: The lower house of Parliament overwhelmingly rejected a constitutional amendment to extend the president's term of office to seven years, from four years. The Parliament, dominated by the party loyal to President Vladimir V. Putin, took up the proposal earlier this month even though Mr. Putin had publicly opposed making any changes in the Constitution. Some described the vote as a trial balloon or a pre-election political ploy that would allow Mr. Putin to reassure those who fear any increase in his presidential powers. He is universally expected to win a second term in the presidential election on March 14. Steven Lee Myers (NYT)

title: Florida Senators Urge Action on Haiti, Fearing Tide of Refugees
description: Florida's two Democratic senators said Wednesday that the Bush administration was resisting their appeals to take stronger action to avert an exodus of refugees from Haiti, who they fear could end up on the shores of their state.

title: Sheffield Is 'Surprised' To Be Named in Inquiry
description: Yankees outfielder Gary Sheffield said he was unaware that his name had been revealed as part of a federal investigation of steroid distribution to professional athletes until he arrived Wednesday morning at the team's minor league facility.

title: Ford Said to Be Planning Assembly Plant in China
description: The Ford Motor Company is strongly leaning toward the selection of Nanjing to be the site for a large new assembly plant in China, as the cornerstone of a plan to invest more than $1 billion in the world's fastest-growing auto market, people close to the company said this week.

title: Savoring Jazzs Old-Fashioned Glamour
description: Agood jazz singer in the twilight of her career has the prerogative to become sepulchral and shadowy and cultish. Billie Holiday claimed that right late in life, and, like most things she did, it was a meaningful precedent. Shirley Horn has had those tendencies since she restarted her career in the mid-1980's, but in the last year or so she has gone further, pushing the old-fashioned glamour of jazz singing into a realm suffused with mortality.

description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 18  In the Bush administration, it is considered heresy to suggest postponing the planned return of sovereignty to Iraq. Turning over control by June 30, administration officials say, is crucial to assuaging Iraqi distress over living under American occupation.

description: It is reasonably well established that eBay sellers who post pictures of their wares online attract more bidders than those who just describe without showing. Logic suggests that if a picture helps, a moving picture will help even more.

title: Annan Is Said To Have Doubt On Iraq Voting
description: Secretary General Kofi Annan will endorse the view that the interim Iraqi government to take office this summer cannot be chosen by direct elections, but he will not make his recommendation on Iraq's political future for at least a week, senior United Nations diplomats said Wednesday.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Newark: Groups Criticize Cleanup Accord
description: Two environmental groups said yesterday that a settlement between the federal government and a corporation responsible for pollution in Newark Bay was intended to head off a lawsuit the groups had planned to file against the corporation. The Environmental Protection Agency, which announced the settlement on Friday, denied that claim. Bonnie Bellow, a spokeswoman for the agency, said yesterday that the settlement was a better way to bring about a cleanup than extensive litigation. Under the settlement, the Occidental Chemical Corporation and its affiliates agreed to pay for a study of industrial contaminants, including cancer-causing dioxins, in Newark Bay at an estimated cost of $7 million to $10 million. The settlement came just three days before the two environmental groups, New York/New Jersey Baykeeper and the Hackensack Riverkeeper, said they planned to sue. Yaniv Gafner (NYT)

title: Taliban Try To Frighten Afghan Voters In Rural Areas
description: After a relatively dormant winter, Taliban insurgents are waging a violent campaign in the countryside to frighten people from cooperating with the American-backed government and from taking part in elections scheduled for the summer.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MULLER, ANDRE
description: MULLER--Andre. 93, former Director of Latin American affairs for Nestle, devoted husband of the late Helen Maguire Muller and brother of Micheline Lucas, Christiane Tyson, and Elyette Taylor passed away on February 18, 2004 in Lausanne, Switzerland. He was the dedicated and kind-hearted father of Lucienne, Edouard, and Jacqueline and the dearly beloved grandfather of Dalia, Djamila, Marie-Jeanne, and Rosalie. We mourn his absence with great sorrow. We loved him living and we love him still.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Cadbury Forecasts Profit
description: Cadbury Schweppes, the candy maker, said it expected a higher profit in 2004, after being flat in 2003. Profit before tax, good will and exceptional items fell 1 percent, to 922 million ($1.7 billion) in 2003, in part because a hot summer hurt sales in Europe. Separately, Berkshire Hathaway, the investment company run by Warren E. Buffett, said in a regulatory filing that it had bought 10 million shares in Cadbury. Heather Timmons (NYT)

title: India and Pakistan Set a 6-Month Timetable for Peace Talks
description: India and Pakistan have agreed on what officials call a ''road map for peace,'' Pakistan's foreign secretary said Wednesday, setting a six-month schedule for discussions on a range of issues, including their longstanding dispute over Kashmir.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Russia: Gas Spigot Shut
description: Russia halted shipments of natural gas to Belarus in a dispute over prices. Belarus has refused to pay market-rate tariffs, and in an escalation of a fight over subsidies, Gazprom, the Russian natural gas monopoly, said it would temporarily halt deliveries. Gazprom executives told news agencies that they were taking a hard line during negotiations in an effort to force Belarus to agree to accept market prices. Erin E. Arvedlund (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HEVESI, ELEANOR
description: HEVESI--Eleanor, 86, beloved wife of the late Joseph Hevesi, died peacefully at her home in Harrison NY, January 30. She had worked both at Memorial Sloan-Kettering of Westchester and at SUNY in Purchase NY, where she won the Chancellor's Award for Excellence in Professional Service in 1979. She is survived by her loving daughters, Joelle Sander of NYC and Carla Tartaglia of Redding CT, their husbands Dr. Fred Sander and Peter Tartaglia, her beloved grandchildren Stephen Sander of NYC and Weston CT, Jason Sander and Matthew Tartaglia of NYC and Nicole Tartaglia of Danbury, CT and her cherished great-granddaughter Elizabeth Chrissa Sander. We will miss her elegance, her wit, her keen intelligence and her abiding passion for her family. A memorial gathering will be planned for the spring. Donations in her memory may be made to Hospice and Palliative Care of Westchester, 95 South Broadway, White Plains, NY 10601.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Holiday Display Policy Upheld
description: A federal judge yesterday upheld the City Department of Education's policy on holiday displays in the schools, ruling that it does not discriminate against Roman Catholics and other Christians. Judge Charles P. Sifton of Federal District Court ruled in a lawsuit filed by a Queens family, backed by the Catholic League for Religious and Civil Rights, who said their children's public schools allowed a menorah and an Islamic star and crescent to be displayed, but not a crche, depicting the birth of Jesus. A Christmas tree was on display, but the family argued that the tree was not a religious symbol. The lawsuit argued that the menorah and the Islamic star and crescent were religious symbols, but Judge Sifton said they had ''significant secular connotations.'' He also said the department's policy was not an attempt to impose a particular religion on students. Daniel J. Wakin (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BENEDEK, ARMAND
description: BENEDEK--Armand. On February 9, 2004, Armand Benedek of Pound Ridge, N.Y., was declared missing and presumed dead after a tragic scuba diving accident while vacationing on Grand Cayman Island, BWI. Born on February 15, 1931, in the Bronx, N.Y., Armand graduated from the high school of Arts & Sciences. He attended Cornell University and received a degree in Landscape Architecture from the University of Georgia School of Environmental Design. After college, he enlisted in the U.S. Air Force Reserves and retired at the rank of Lt. Colonel. He married Phyllis Roby in 1957 and they have lived in Pound Ridge for over 35 years. In 1961, Armand founded his own practice, currently the firm of Armand Benedek and Glenn Ticehurst, Ltd. where he was still working full time. He was a Fellow Member in the American Society of Landscape Architects. In addition to his wife, Armand leaves behind a brother, Richard (Elissa) of Ann Arbor, MI, and several nieces and nephews. He has two daughters, Lia Kaufman (Frank) of Carmel, N.Y. and Amanda Soulias (Charles) of South Salem, N.Y. and two stepdaughters, Carol Bates and Martha Briante, both of Stamford, CT. Seven grandchildren and five greatgrandchildren will miss their ''Pom Pom'' dearly. As per Armand's wishes, there will be no service. Because he loved Grand Cayman so much and had been visiting there for over 40 years, charitable donations can be made in his memory to the National Trust for Cayman Islands, P.O. Box 31116SMB, Grand Caymen Islands, BWI. (www.nationaltrust.org.ky) or to the Riverkeeper at P.O. Box 130, Garrison, N.Y. 10524 (www.riverkeeper.com)

title: INTERNATIONAL STEEL TO BUY WEIRTON STEEL

The acquisition will increase the steel-making capacity of International Steel by 3 million tons a year, to about 21 million tons. The purchase requires approval from a bankruptcy court and will probably close in the second quarter, the companies said. Weirton, based in Weirton, W.Va., is Mr. Ross's fourth acquisition of a bankrupt steel maker that has been relieved of its pension liabilities by the federal government. The purchase would bring Mr. Ross's steel investments to more than $2 billion since he created International Steel in 2002 from assets of bankrupt steel makers.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Recording Industry Countersued
description: A New Jersey woman, Michele Scimeca, one of the hundreds of people accused of copyright infringement by the Recording Industry Association of America, has countersued the big record labels, accusing them of extortion and violations of the federal antiracketeering act. The suit is one of just a handful of countersuits. Even critics of the recording industry view the suit as a long shot but one worth trying, and as a sign that lawyers are working on arguments against the recording association. Through her lawyers, Ms. Scimeca contends that by suing file swappers for copyright infringement, then offering to settle instead of pursuing a case in which liability could reach into hundreds of thousands of dollars, the association is violating the laws that are more typically applied to gangsters and organized crime. According to the association, which filed its latest round of lawsuits against 531 as-yet-anonymous individuals on Tuesday, it has settled with 381 people, including some who had not yet actually had suits filed against them. A total of nearly 1,500 people have been sued so far. ''If someone prefers not to settle, they of course have the opportunity to raise their objections in court,'' an R.I.A.A. representative said yesterday. ''We stand by our claims.''

title: ART: 212 TO BERLIN
description: On loan from the Museum of Modern Art in New York, 212 masterworks -- a number reflecting Manhattan's most widely recognized area code -- go on view tomorrow in Berlin. Running through Sept. 19 at Mies van der Rohe's framed glass and steel New National Gallery, the exhibition, ''MoMA in Berlin,'' includes ''Starry Night'' by van Gogh, ''The Dance'' by Matisse and ''Drowning Girl'' by Roy Lichtenstein. Among other artists represented in the event, whose honorary patrons are Secretary of State Colin L. Powell and the German foreign minister, Joschka Fischer, are Picasso, Hopper, Mir, Dal, O'Keeffe and Pollock. ''This exhibition shows what Berlin might have become without Adolf Hitler, without the banning of so-called degenerate art, without the East German ghetto,'' Peter-Klaus Schuster, the director of the New National Gallery, said at a news conference yesterday. German and American organizers depicted the display of painting and sculpture not only as the year's cultural highlight in Germany but also as a special gesture of trans-Atlantic friendship between their countries after tensions over the war in Iraq and as a symbol of Berlin's swift return to European cultural prominence. In return for the loan from the Museum of Modern Art, which is undergoing renovation, the New National Gallery will send some of its most famous Expressionist works to New York for an exhibition at the Neue Galerie from March 12 through June 7. KIRSTEN GRIESHABER

title: Look Who's Talking

It's still mostly in private, but more is now erupting in public. For this conversation to be translated into broad political change requires a decent political outcome in Iraq. The man, Awlia Yaya, who was born in Afghanistan and has permanent resident status in the United States, remained on the phone long enough for the Police Department to trace the call to his address on White Plains Road. Mr. Yaya, 38, was arrested at an address on White Plains Road and charged with criminal possession of a weapon, a .38-caliber revolver, and aggravated harassment, the authorities said. Investigators have not uncovered any connections between Mr. Yaya, who has been in this country since 1987, and any terrorist organization, though law enforcement officials said they were continuing to investigate. The police said there was evidence that Mr. Yaya had been drinking. Sabrina Tavernise (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WURTELE, MORTON GAITHER
description: WURTELE--Morton Gaither, died February 14, 2004. Born in Harrodsburg, Kentucky, in 1919. He was at home in Chicago, Cambridge, Los Angeles, Jerusalem and, finally, Berkeley. A Professor of Atmospheric Sciences at UCLA until his retirement, he had wide-ranging interests and an unusual combination of scientific and linguistic skills. His kindness, tolerance, wit, and appreciation of so much and so many were a constant source of inspiration for his family and friends. He was a generous loving husband, father, grandfather, and father-in-law whose words of encouragement and expressions of enjoyment were a gift to us all. He is survived by his wife Zivia Syrkin Wurtele, his children Jonathan and Eve Syrkin Wurtele, his grandchildren Dimitri, Mashette and Judy Syrkin-Nikolau, and Abby and David Wurtele, daughter-in-law Lisa Karp Wurtele and son-in-law Basil Nikolau. The man who made the ''Three Colors'' trilogy and the incomparable ''Decalogue'' will not produce any more masterpieces. But a screenplay he wrote in the 1970's has recently been uncovered, and now it has been adapted, by Jerzy Stuhr, into a small and marvelous film called ''The Big Animal.'' Mr. Stuhr, an actor who worked frequently with Kieslowski and who plays the main character in this film, honors his old friend's memory, producing a minor but nonetheless charming footnote to his oeuvre.

''We don't want their asphalt, and we don't want their help,'' he told the BBC. Carlotta Gall (NYT)

Ms. Ebersole, the singer and actress, who is appearing at Feinstein's at the Regency with her musical sidekick Billy Stritch (her fellow cast member from the Broadway revival of ''42nd Street,'' for which she won a Tony Award), flashes the same dangerously transgressive glint as Bette Midler, another performer who promises the slinging of a certain amount of mud.

title: NORTHWEST AIRLINES WILL CLOSE 25 TICKET OFFICES
description: The Northwest Airlines Corporation said yesterday that it would close 25 ticket offices in the United States by late March to reduce costs, as ticket sales over the Internet increase. The ticket offices are in Detroit, Minneapolis, New York, Atlanta and 12 other cities, Northwest said. The 76 employees at the offices will be eligible to transfer to one of the company's five reservations centers, the airline said. Northwest, based in St. Paul, has been trying to reduce costs to better compete with expanding lower-cost carriers and it recently told employees it wants to reduce expenses by $1 billion this year. The airline is in talks with its pilots' union to lower costs.

title: 36 Hours | St. Petersburg, Fla.
description: WITH a vibrant downtown of graceful Art Deco buildings and broad sun-dappled boulevards lined with palms and willowy bottle brush trees, St. Petersburg stands out in Florida's seemingly homogenous sprawl of malls, megastores and clogged interstates. Yet for all its wealth of charm and sunshine, Tampa's twin city suffers a periodic identity crisis. Named in 1892 after the hometown of a Russian railroad magnate who helped develop it, St. Petersburg was long known for its Old World character as well as for the white-haired legions who occupied green benches along the streets and boulevards. In an image upgrade, the green benches were removed, and a local landmark, the ramshackle Million Dollar Pier, was torn down in 1967 and replaced in 1973 by a charmless steel and glass structure known simply as the Pier. Nearby St. Petersburg Beach took the image remaking a step farther in 1994 and officially changed its name to the more zingy St. Pete Beach. Despite these efforts to reverse the aging process, remnants of old St. Petersburg remain, including the Sunken Gardens flora sanctuary and a sleepy complex that must make the image boosters cringe: the St. Petersburg Shuffleboard Club. STEVE DOUGHERTY

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GREGG, DAVID III
description: GREGG--David III, 71, senior advisor to and a founder of the Pierce Financial Corporation, a firm handling venture financing for broadcasting companies and other businesses, died February 15 of a cardiac arrest in Richmond, VA, while racing in a regional Masters swim competition. Mr. Gregg also was a founder and chair of the board of Gator Broadcasting Corporation and a director of the Monument Group of Mutual Funds. His Business experience was extensive. After holding earlier leadership positions in Eastman Dillon, Union Securities & Co, and Blyth & Co, Inc, he was appointed in 1973 executive vice president of the newly formed Overseas Private Investment Corporation, an agency of the US government facilitating US investment in developing nations to enhance global economic and social progress toward democratic market - based economies. His interest in overseas development continued in the 1980s when as executive vice president and director of the Pierce International Corporation, he was engaged in financing housing projects in Venezuela and other development efforts in Latin America. Born in NYC and raised in Darien, CT, Mr. Gregg graduated from Deerfield Academy in Massachusetts, from Yale University with a BA in 1955, and from Columbia University Graduate School of Business with a MBA in 1959. He served in the US Army after college. Mr. Gregg was a member of the Mid-Atlantic Venture Capital Association and a former member of the NY Society of Security Analysts. In addition he was a member and former director of the Ontcora Club, a member of the NY Amateur Ski Club, and a member of the Chesapeake Bay Yacht Club. An avid amateur athlete, Mr. Gregg enjoyed skiing and tennis and was an active member of the Fairfax County Masters Swim Team, through which he was nationally ranked in top 10 for Masters breaststroke. Mr. Gregg's first marriage to May Foster Bowers ended in divorce. Mr. Gregg lived in Arlington, VA with his wife, Sarah Massengale Gregg, a vice president for Baxter Healthcare Corporation. He is also survived by two children from his first marriage, Tina Gregg Barkstrom, of Richmond, VA, and Dr. David Gregg IV of San Francisco, his brother Arthur of Chapel Hill, NC and two grandchildren. A memorial service will be held at 11:00 am on February 21st at St. Mary's Episcopal Church Arlington, VA. Interment will be in the family plot in Easton, MD. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions in honor of David Gregg may be sent to Deerfield Academy, Alumni Office, Deerfield, MA 01342 or to Yale University, Office of Development, PO Box 805, New Haven, CT 06503-0805 or to Dr. Jim Miller, President, US Masters Swimming Endowment Fund, PO Box 10, Noblesville, IN 46061.

Lower spoilers were not mandated for races at Daytona International Speedway, but at the tracks for most other Nascar races. Higher spoilers are required for races at Daytona.

title: BRITISH COMPANY TO BUY PLANT FROM JOHNSON & JOHNSON
description: Tate & Lyle, a British maker of cereal sweeteners and starches, will buy a plant from Johnson & Johnson for $134 million to increase sales of ingredients to food and drink companies. Tate & Lyle, based in London, said the deal involved a plant in McIntosh, Ala., that makes Splenda sweetener. The McNeil Nutritionals unit of Johnson & Johnson will keep control of the brand. The companies collaborated on the development of the sweetener for more than 20 years. They have agreed to split sales, with the British company focusing on the food and beverages industry and McNeil selling to retail and food services clients. Johnson & Johnson is based in New Brunswick, N.J.

title: Differing Reasons For Sudden Nets Surge
description: The Nets head into Toronto on Friday night with an 11-game winning streak, matching the longest streak in team history. When the Nets did this last, in the 1982-83 season, the streak was followed by chaos, with the departure of Coach Larry Brown late in the season and a first-round playoff loss.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Big Polio Immunization Campaign
description: Hundreds of thousands of volunteers will begin going from house to house next week to give polio immunizations to 63 million children in 10 countries in the World Health Organization's latest effort to eliminate the disease. The program is to begin Monday in Nigeria and Niger, where polio is endemic. Immunizations will also be conducted next week in seven countries that had eliminated the disease before cases were recently spread from Nigeria and Niger: Benin, Burkina Faso, Cameroon, Central African Republic, Ghana, Ivory Coast and Togo. Chad will begin its program next month. Polio has mostly spread from the Kano region in northern Nigeria, where Islamic leaders have stopped immunizations because they say the vaccine sterilizes girls. The W.H.O. has conducted independent tests to refute the charges and is optimistic that Kano will participate, a spokesman for the agency said. Lawrence K. Altman (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Africa: Zimbabwe: Europe Renews Sanctions
description: The European Union voted to renew broad economic sanctions against Zimbabwe and 95 of its top officials, including President Robert G. Mugabe, citing the continued deterioration of human rights since sanctions were first imposed two years ago. Michael Wines (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BENEDEK, ARMAND
description: BENEDEK--Armand. On February 9, 2004, Armand Benedek of Pound Ridge, N.Y., was declared missing and presumed dead after a tragic scuba diving accident while vacationing on Grand Cayman Island, BWI. Born on February 15, 1931, in the Bronx, N.Y., Armand graduated from the high school of Arts & Sciences. He attended Cornell University and received a degree in Landscape Architecture from the University of Georgia School of Environmental Design. After college, he enlisted in the U.S. Air Force Reserves and retired at the rank of Lt. Colonel. He married Phyllis Roby in 1957 and they have lived in Pound Ridge for over 35 years. In 1961, Armand founded his own practice, currently the firm of Armand Benedek and Glenn Ticehurst, Ltd. where he was still working full time. He was a Fellow Member in the American Society of Landscape Architects. In addition to his wife, Armand leaves behind a brother, Richard (Elissa) of Ann Arbor, MI, and several nieces and nephews. He has two daughters, Lia Kaufman (Frank) of Carmel, N.Y. and Amanda Soulias (Charles) of South Salem, N.Y. and two stepdaughters, Carol Bates and Martha Briante, both of Stamford, CT. Seven grandchildren and five greatgrandchildren will miss their ''Pom Pom'' dearly. As per Armand's wishes, there will be no service. Because he loved Grand Cayman so much and had been visiting there for over 40 years, charitable donations can be made in his memory to the National Trust for Cayman Islands, P.O. Box 31116SMB, Grand Caymen Islands, BWI. (www.nationaltrust.org.ky) or to the Riverkeeper at P.O. Box 130, Garrison, N.Y. 10524 (www.riverkeeper.com)

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Monday about Susan Schechter, an expert on domestic violence, misstated the title she used. She was Ms. Schechter, not Mrs. (Her husband's name was Allen Steinberg.)

title: S.E.C. Investigating Shell's Restatement of Oil and Gas Reserves
description: The Royal Dutch/Shell Group said on Thursday that the Securities and Exchange Commission had begun a formal investigation into the company's surprise restatement of its oil and natural gas reserves last month.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WALKER, GERALD
description: WALKER--Gerald. Fox Residential Group mourns the loss of Gerry Walker, beloved husband of our dear colleague, Joanna Simon. Gerry was our good friend and will be sorely missed. Our love and thoughts are with Joanna and the family.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HARCOURT, RENEE

Farewell Mutz, we love you.

title: Technology Briefing | People: PeopleSoft Chief Gets Fewer Stock Options
description: PeopleSoft gave its chief executive, Craig A. Conway, 64 percent fewer stock options last year while increasing his bonus by 21 percent. He was awarded 1.5 million stock options, down from 4.13 million options and $14.6 million in restricted stock in 2002, PeopleSoft said in a Securities and Exchange Commission filing. He received a $2.33 million bonus for 2003, compared with $1.92 million for 2002. His salary has been $1 million for at least the last three years.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SAMUELS, REUBEN
description: SAMUELS -- Reuben. Died peacefully at home on February 17, 2004. A beloved husband and loving father, he is survived by his wife, Diane, son Adam, daughter Julie, son-in-law Barry and granddaughters Alyssa and Monica. The funeral service will be held on Friday, February 20 at 11:30AM at Louis Suburban Chapel, 13-01 Broadway, Fair Lawn, New Jersey. title: CHIEF OF KING PHARMACEUTICALS TO RETIRE
description: King Pharmaceuticals, the heart drug maker being investigated by two federal agencies, said Jefferson J. Gregory would retire as chief executive. The company also said yesterday that it would owe additional money for failing to pay rebates to Medicaid. Mr. Gregory, 48, is quitting as chief executive, but he will remain chairman, King said. King's shares, which have lost more than half their value since Mr. Gregory took the job two years ago, advanced 14 percent. King, based in Bristol, Tenn., faces investigations by the Securities and Exchange Commission and the Department of Health and Human Services after saying in July that it owed Medicaid and other government health programs about $46.5 million in unpaid drug rebates. An internal audit found another $18.9 million is due, the company said yesterday.

title: Editorial Observer; Who Is to Blame for the Creation of Palestinian Refugees?
description: Of all the issues separating Israelis and Palestinians, nothing is more contentious than the Palestinian ''right of return.'' Palestinian refugees say they must be permitted to go back to the lands they lost during the 1947-48 war inside what is today Israel. Even pragmatic Arabs who do not expect that Israel will ever permit large numbers of refugees to return believe that many Palestinians were pushed out of their homes through intimidation and force in a planned expulsion, and they believe that the right of return must be acknowledged, if not actually put into practice.

description: Jean Rouch, a French explorer, ethnologist and film director who played a significant role in forging the cinma-vrit style, died on Wednesday night in a car crash in the west central African nation of Niger, the French Embassy there said. He was 86.

title: Teenage Rate Of Pregnancy Drops in U.S.
description: A new state-by-state breakdown of teenage pregnancy and abortion rates in 2000 shows declines among all racial and ethnic groups and in every state, continuing a decade-long trend that researchers attribute to better contraception and less, or more cautious, sexual activity.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Knighthood For Nazi Hunter
description: Simon Wiesenthal, who spent much of his life in pursuit of Nazi war criminals, will be awarded an honorary knighthood at a ceremony in Vienna in the near future, according to Jack Straw, the British foreign minister. Patrick E. Tyler (NYT)

title: National Briefing | South: Louisiana: Ex-Governor Claims Trial Was Unfair
description: Lawyers for former Gov. Edwin W. Edwards have asked that the verdict that sent him to federal prison for 10 years be vacated because his trial was unfair. Mr. Edwards, 76, was convicted in 2000 of extorting payoffs for casino riverboat licenses. His lawyers say that prosecutors failed to disclose a key witness's financial incentive to testify and that one juror thought Mr. Edwards had not used his influence to help investigate her daughter's death. Ariel Hart (NYT)

title: XO COMMUNICATIONS TO BUY MOST OF ALLEGIANCE TELECOM
description: XO Communications, the telephone and Internet access company controlled by the financier Carl C. Icahn, won bankruptcy court approval to purchase most of Allegiance Telecom's assets for $631 million. XO, based in Reston, Va., will pay about $311 million in cash and 45.4 million of its shares, which were worth $320 million when trading began yesterday. The Allegiance purchase will almost double XO's business-phone customers to 330,000 and give it three new markets, XO said last week. Allegiance, based in Dallas, filed for Chapter 11 protection in May 2003. XO exited bankruptcy last year after shedding $4.6 billion in debt and selling control to Mr. Icahn.

title: To get their messages across, more and more nonprofit organizations are going commercial.
description: WITH an ad in Parade magazine on Sunday, the American Heart Association will begin its first-ever paid advertising campaign, a $36 million, three-year effort to raise awareness of heart disease and stroke. The group hopes that writing checks will help deliver its message more effectively compared with donated advertising, which often translates into ''far from prime time.''

title: Rebel Soldiers Take Control of Haitis Central Plateau
description: HINCHE, Haiti, Feb. 20  Hailed as liberators by thousands of residents, four truckloads of rebel soldiers made a triumphal entry into this dusty town today, ending a week that has seen them wrest control of Haiti's central plateau from the embattled government of President Jean-Bertrand Aristide.

title: After Being Linked to Balco, Sheffield Denies Steroid Use
description: Gary Sheffield of the Yankees vehemently denied on Thursday that he had ever used steroids, but he acknowledged ordering vitamins from a California nutritional supplements company whose founder has been charged with distributing steroids and other performance-enhancing drugs to professional athletes.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Brewer Forecasts Gain
description: The Kirin Brewery Company, the country's biggest beverage maker, said it expected cost cuts to help increase profit by almost a third this year, to the highest since 1994, after a liquor tax increase and a mild summer cut its earnings in 2003. The company forecast a 33 percent increase in net income, to 43 billion yen ($403 million). Profit for the year ended Dec. 31 fell to 32.4 billion yen, from 32.5 billion yen the year before. Sales last year rose 0.9 percent, to 1.6 trillion yen, and Kirin forecast a further gain to 1.7 trillion for this year.

title: National Briefing | Washington: Recall Of Gas Grill
description: More than 160,000 gas grills have been recalled because glass covers on the temperature gauges have shattered, federal officials said. The manufacturer, the Grand Hall Enterprise Company, of Taiwan, announced the recall along with the Consumer Product Safety Commission. Some of the glass covers have broken when moisture got inside the gauges. The grills were sold nationwide from April 2001 to December 2002 under the brand names Bakers & Chefs, Members Mark and Kenmore. The company urged consumers to call (888) 735-5709, toll free, for a free replacement temperature gauge or a repair kit. John Files (NYT)

description: Senator John Kerry won the endorsement of the A.F.L.-C.I.O. on Thursday as Senator John Edwards called trade and job losses a ''moral issue'' and repeatedly pressed for debates with Mr. Kerry.

title: A Subway Map Remade, in Hopes of Matching Routes and Riders
description: When the first train rumbles across the Manhattan Bridge on Sunday morning, the confusion will begin for hundreds of thousands of New Yorkers adjusting to the most significant redrawing of the subway map in decades. The changes come with the nearly two-decade rehabilitation of the bridge finally coming to an end, and four subway tracks, instead of two, will be in use over the nearly century-old bridge for the first extended period since construction began in 1986.

title: Mexican Conceptualists, None Especially Mexican
description: ''Made in Mexico,'' an exhibition at the Institute of Contemporary Art here, asks, ''What is Mexican about contemporary Mexican art?'' It gives no clear answer, and its contents, though entertainingly varied, are mostly underwhelming. But it does offer something valuable to think about and debate.

description: No one can doubt that something new happened during the 2004 Democratic primaries: a candidate who lost may have as great an impact on the party's political future as whichever candidate wins. That candidate, of course, is Wesley Clark.

description: This time, John Daly wants the good times to last. He does not want to wait another eight years for his next victory. He does not want to make headlines for the wrong reasons. title: World Briefing | Europe: Austria: 16 Cleared In Ski Train Fire
description: A judge in Salzburg acquitted 16 defendants accused of criminal responsibility for the deaths of 155 people in a fire at a ski resort in 2000. The defendants included technicians, government inspectors and representatives of companies who installed or operated equipment on a funicular rail car that burst into fire in a tunnel at Kaprun ski resort, south of Salzburg. According to testimony, the fire was caused by a malfunctioning heater. Family members protested the ruling, and the prosecutor said she would appeal, but the judge, who allowed that he did not have ''an easy time reaching this decision,'' said the train ''conformed to the latest technical standards and all requirements were fulfilled.'' Richard Bernstein (NYT)

title: One Woman, Cooking Up the Melting Pot
description: American theater has always tried to inform or misinform audiences about the immigrants arriving on their shores or the outsiders already in their midst. Vaudeville took the lead. Teams like Harrigan and Hart (who were Irish), Weber and Fields (Jewish) and Williams and Walker (black) humanized and parodied themselves for mass audiences. What they didn't know about other groups they usually made up. But the humor and compassion that come from paying real attention to people who are not like you have been pitifully rare in mainstream theater.

title: Iraqis Must Find Own Way to Sovereignty, Annan Says
description: UNITED NATIONS, Feb. 20  Secretary General Kofi Annan has combined his finding that hasty elections in Iraq are not feasible before the June 30, the end of American governance, with a determination to leave to Iraqis themselves the decision on the best alternative way of restoring sovereignty, United Nations officials said today.

title: Corrections

It is the Center on International Cooperation. (He formerly directed the Center for Preventive Action, part of the Council on Foreign Relations.)

title: Cologne Journal; Germany's 'Fun City' Wants Its Share, Taxing Even Sex
description: Fun is not a word that regularly comes to mind in this country, particularly in the leaden grip of a German winter. But Cologne, with its art galleries, theaters, nightclubs and television studios, can reasonably lay claim to the title of Germany's fun city.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about B. S. A. Tahir, a businessman based in Malaysia who has been a subject of investigations related to the trade in nuclear weapons technology, misspelled the surname of his wife and linked her erroneously with another businessman in Malaysia. She is Nazimah Binti Syed Majid, not Jajid. She is not a cousin or other relative of Shah Hakim Zain, an owner of Kaspadu, an investment holding company that is the major owner of Scomi Group Berhad, which has a subsidiary that made nuclear centrifuge parts.

title: CIRCUIT CITY DIRECTORS DROP PLAN FOR POISON PILL
description: Circuit City Stores, the electronics chain, bowed to the wishes of shareholders by abandoning one means of fending off unwanted takeovers. Directors voted to drop a plan, known as a poison pill, in May 2005 rather than its scheduled expiration in April 2008, the company said. The plan, adopted in 1998, gives existing shareholders the rights to purchase more shares -- making a takeover more difficult -- in the event a suitor acquires a big stake or makes a tender offer. A resolution calling on Circuit City to end the plan was approved by nearly three-fourths of shareholders the last two years. Poison pills can entrench management and hurt share prices, the resolution said. Circuit City, based in Richmond, Va., said its board adopted the plan to encourage negotiation and to ensure that shareholders are treated fairly.

title: Impeachment Panel in Rowland Case Starts Strategy Talks
description: Legislators on a committee considering whether to pursue an impeachment of Gov. John G. Rowland discussed strategy for the first time on Thursday, naming subjects for investigation and making plans to start issuing subpoenas next week.

description: A bad day is when (1) you get arrested (2) by the people who once worked for you and (3) they tell you exactly what they think of you.

Why, the production's sulky hero, Constantine (also known as C-Trip and played by the handsome Anthony Mackie), is a walking, flaking, suicidal collage of tattered quotations and references.

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: CYPRUS: REUNIFICATION TALKS BEGIN Greek and Turkish Cypriot leaders met at an abandoned airport in the buffer zone that has divided the island since 1974 and opened United Nations-brokered talks on reunification. The plan calls for them to agree by March 22 on reunification language that can be put to island-wide referendums in April, and both the Greek Cypriot president, Tassos Papadopoulos, above right, and his Turkish Cypriot counterpart, Rauf Denktash, center foreground, indicated that they had staked out tough positions. "It is too early to talk of satisfaction," Mr. Papadopoulos said. The United Nations envoy, Alvaro de Soto, above left, called the session constructive and said the leaders would meet again today. (AP)

description: It's midseason in cheer nation. This winter, thousands of girls will travel on college all-star teams to take part in competitions across the country. Practicing more than 20 hours a week, they will refine a routine of back flips, handsprings, round-offs and splits -- all perfectly synchronized and timed to an Olympic second. Their goal: first place. Their game: competitive cheerleading, one of the fastest-growing sports for women in America.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: 2 Dioceses Spent $3.6 Million On Abuse Cases
description: The Roman Catholic Dioceses of Metuchen and Paterson said this week that they had spent some $3.6 million in legal fees, settlements and other costs over allegations that their priests abused children. The Paterson Diocese said Wednesday in its weekly newspaper that 71 abuse allegations had been made against 39 priests among the 737 priests who served the diocese from 1950 to 2002, The Associated Press reported. The report said, however, that 56 of those claims had been deemed credible and that the diocese had spent about $2.8 million since 1950 on fees and settlements related to the claims. The Metuchen Diocese said in a report published in its newspaper yesterday that it had spent $795,000 in legal and medical fees and settlements on 18 priests and one deacon out of its 990 clergymen who had been credibly accused of sexual abuse involving minors. Matthew C. McCue (NYT)

title: Where Quiet Contemplation Beats the Rewards of Shock
description: The Art Show is going it alone this year. The annual fair of the Art Dealers Association of America usually happens at the same time as the Armory Show, the gathering of contemporary-art dealers held on Piers 90 and 91. That arrangement has enabled visitors to shuttle between the quiet traditionalism of the Art Show at the Seventh Regiment Armory and the cutting-edge theater of its bigger and noisier younger sibling. Scheduling problems at the piers, however, have forced the Armory Show to wait until March 11 for its moment.

Clearly a precocious child, he found in the overwrought 1936 biography the reassurance he needed that dancers might not be the off-puttingly exotic creatures he had envisioned as he gazed down from theater galleries the few times a year ballet came to his hometown, Milwaukee.

title: Fearlessly Going Where The Punches Are Flying
description: ''Against the Ropes,'' a corny new feminist-uplift boxing picture starring Meg Ryan and Omar Epps, was, according to the press notes, inspired by the true story of Jackie Kallen, one of the few women ever to succeed as a manager of professional fighters. What this inspiration means is that the movie, directed by Charles S. Dutton from a script by Cheryl Edwards, is not a biography of Ms. Kallen, but rather an entirely fictional piece about a female boxing manager (Ms. Ryan) who happens to have the same name.

title: Love Notes And Ghosts on A Lonely Road
description: PRECARIOUSLY straddling a ridgeline atop the nation's tallest sand dune, Rick Seth takes a moment to explain his addiction to dune buggies. ''I like to call it anger management,'' he says. ''It's like a roller coaster that never quits.'' With that, he guns his muscular Volkswagen-powered sand rail buggy, and we fall 600 feet down the gritty, black-diamond slope of Nevada's Sand Mountain at 70 miles per hour. Then we turn around, and do it again -- only faster.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Nextel Profit Falls
description: Nextel Communications said yesterday that quarterly profit fell from a year earlier, when it had a gain from the sale of an international unit, but revenue rose 29 percent. Nextel, the wireless telephone company, reported fourth-quarter net profit of $637 million, or 56 cents a share, compared with $1.46 billion, or $1.38 a share, a year earlier. Excluding special items, it posted a profit of 48 cents a share.

title: National Briefing: Southwest
description: NEW MEXICO: SALES TAX ON FOOD IS REPEALED Working through the night to meet a deadline for mandatory adjournment, the Legislature handed Gov. Bill Richardson a major victory by repealing the state sales tax on food and certain medical services. Mr. Richardson, a Democrat, had vowed to call the lawmakers back into special session if they did not approve the tax cut, which will be offset by a higher sales tax on other items. Steve Barnes (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Nissequogue: Missing Patient Found Dead
description: The body of a 52-year-old man who disappeared nearly a month ago washed up onto a beach in Nissequogue yesterday morning, the Suffolk County police said. The man, Isaiah Williams, was an outpatient at Pilgrim State Psychiatric Hospital and lived at a group home in Central Islip. The police said he often wandered away, but usually returned home on his own. The police would not say exactly where Mr. Williams lived, nor whether anyone had seen him after he was reported missing on Jan. 26. An autopsy had not been conducted as of last evening, but the police said there were no signs of foul play. Patrick Healy (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: The Netherlands: Insurer's Profit Slips
description: The insurance and banking concern ING said that its income fell 10 percent last year, to 4 billion euros ($5 billion). The decline resulted mostly from an accounting change and on an operating basis income was up 18 percent. ING said it could not provide a specific forecast for the current year, disappointing some investors, and its shares fell 1 percent. Better results from its banking division contributed to ING's improved performance. One bright spot was ING Direct, its Internet banking division, which has operations in several countries including the United States. ING Direct booked a 2003 pretax operating profit of 151 million euros in contrast to a loss of 48 million euros in 2002. Gregory Crouch (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KONSKER, MORTON
description: KONSKER--Morton. Of Boca Raton, FL passed away at the age of 73, after a long 16.5 month battle with pancreatic cancer. He is survived by his adored wife of 44 years, Sandi, she was the epicenter of his every day thoughts and actions. He was a devoted father of his three sons, Mitchell, Steven and Kenneth. Beloved father-in-law of Lisa, Jackie and Lori. Proud grandfather of Ian, Carly, Samuel, Gabriel, Daniel, Briella, Eliana and Harrison. Dear brother of Norma and Leonard Weiner. He is also survived by many nieces and nephews whom he loved very much. Morty was a true gentleman, always charismatic and humorous. He was a man of great integrity and morals who had the innate ability to make others around him happy. As he grew older, he had an incessant drive to be learned and to live life to the fullest, which never diminished. He will be missed by all the lives he touched. His funeral will be held at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 W 76 St, NY, NY on February 22 at 10:00 AM. The family requests any donations be made to the ''Dr. Bruckner Research Fund'' 150 55 St, Brooklyn, NY 11220-2574

description: Carlsberg, the brewing company, has agreed to buy the 40 percent of its main business owned by Orkla, a Norwegian consumer goods company, for 14.8 billion Danish kroner ($2.5 billion). Carlsberg will pay 11 billion kroner in cash now for the stake in Carlsberg Breweries and the rest in two years, the chairman, Povl Krogsgaard-Larsen, said. The company, which is based in Valby, Denmark, will also assume 5 billion kroner in debt and will sell shares to pay for the purchase.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Engineering Group Posts Loss
description: The Swiss-Swedish engineering group ABB reported a fourth-quarter loss of $387 million, an improvement on its loss of $828 million in the period a year earlier. For the year, ABB lost $767 million, its third consecutive annual loss, but a slight improvement from its loss of $783 million a year earlier. The company attributed the improvement to strong performance in its core divisions of power and automation technologies, as well as to cost-cutting and layoffs. ABB said asset sales helped reduce its debt to $7.9 billion at the end of 2003 from $8.3 billion a year earlier. The chief executive, Jrgen Dormann, above, who provided the fourth-quarter figures during a conference call, said he expected ABB to be profitable in 2004 and 2005. Fiona Fleck (NYT)

The trails didn't seem to be part of the sprawling Killington Resort, where Mr. Evanko rented a ski house each winter, and the lone chairlift was empty. When Mr. Evanko asked his snowmobile guide about it, he got a curious answer. ''He told me that it was some rich guy's private ski hill,'' Mr. Evanko recalled.

Net income rose to 705.4 billion won ($605 million) last year from 641.4 billion won in 2002, Kia said. Sales rose 5.6 percent to 12.8 trillion won. title: World Briefing | Americas: Mexico: Deal To Tighten Border
description: The United States and Mexico have signed an agreement intended to increase security on the border and transport illegal Mexican migrants home rather than simply sending them to the border's edge. In recent years, the trek across the border by hundreds of thousands of migrants has led to roughly one death a day. The agreement, the details of which remain unfinished, is part of the larger discussion between the two nations about President Bush's proposal to grant temporary legal status to some migrants. That proposal, said Asa Hutchinson, under secretary for border and transportation security, would face ''rough sailing unless members of Congress and the American public understand that we have the capability of securing our border.'' Tim Weiner (NYT)

description: Shane D. Mickelson, a 31-year-old helicopter pilot, wrapped up the details of the night shift as the sun rose over a patch of Colorado scrubland intended by the Army to mimic the deserts of Iraq. Beside him, Carl Tafoya, 56, the day-side pilot, worked his own list, making sure Black Hawk No. 308 was good to go for another day of air ambulance rescue training.

title: BYPASSING SENATE FOR SECOND TIME, BUSH SEATS JUDGE
description: President Bush on Friday used a weeklong Congressional recess to install William H. Pryor Jr., the Alabama attorney general, in a federal appeals court seat to get around a Democratic filibuster that had blocked the nomination.

title: Who Is the World's Best Player? That's a Whole Conversation
description: Bridge is so much a matter of partnership that identifying the world's best player with any certainty is not possible. The four Italians, Norberto Bocchi, Giorgio Duboin, Lorenzo Laurie and Alfredo Versace, who have for many years been dominant in European and world play, would each be a strong contender.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: L'Oral's Profit Rises
description: The French cosmetics giant L'Oral posted double-digit growth for the 19th year in a row, reporting its net income rose 16.7 percent in 2003 to 1.5 billion euros ($1.2 billion). Sales figures reflected the drop of the euro against the dollar and slipped 1.8 percent, to 14 billion euros ($11 billion), last year, but the company said excluding currency exchange factors, sales grew 7 percent. The company's net operating profit excluding good will and exceptional items rose to 1.7 billion euros ($1.3 billion), up 13.5 percent from 2002. The 2003 results highlight the performance of the L'Oral brands and its progress, the chief executive, Lindsay Owen-Jones, said. Ariane Bernard (NYT)

title: National Briefing | Southwest: Texas: Cocaine Seized In Cabbage Truck
description: A half-ton of cocaine valued at $32 million was found when Customs agents and a drug-sniffing dog inspected a truckload of cabbage at the Falfurrias checkpoint, 60 miles north of the Mexican border, the authorities said. Officers became suspicious when they noticed that the trailer doors were secured with an ordinary padlock, not a shipper's seal. The driver was arrested. Steve Barnes (NYT)

title: PFIZER SUES TO BLOCK GENERIC DRUG SALE
description: Pfizer Inc., the world's biggest drug maker, has filed a lawsuit to block Dr. Reddy's Laboratories Ltd. from selling a generic version of Norvasc, the hypertension drug that has $3.8 billion a year in sales. Pfizer already is in a protracted legal battle with Dr. Reddy's over a chemical variation of amlodipine, the crucial ingredient in Norvasc. The Food and Drug Administration is reviewing its approval of the variation and a federal appeals court is considering whether federal drug law will permit it.

title: CERTEGY TO BUY VIAD UNIT FOR $43 MILLION
description: Certegy Inc., which processes credit card transactions, agreed to buy the Viad Corporation's Game Financial unit for $43 million to offer cash advances and other services in more casinos. Game Financial provides cash advances on debit and credit cards and check-cashing services at 60 casinos in the United States. The purchase is expected to add $50 million to Certegy's revenue, which was $1 billion last year, Certegy said. The acquisition helps the company, which is based in Alpharetta, Ga., expand beyond its payroll check-cashing services at casinos and retail stores.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about the retirement plans of Douglas N. Daft, chairman and chief executive of Coca-Cola, misspelled the surname of a new director in some copies and misstated his age. He is Donald R. Keough, not Keogh; he is 77, not 76.

title: A Leftist Stalwart, Still Fighting the Fight
description: ''Radical journals are like love affairs,'' says the historian John Patrick Diggins, ''easier to start than sustain.''

title: Beijing Says Only 'Patriots' Are Fit to Rule Hong Kong
description: Chinese leaders, concerned that Hong Kong is becoming difficult to control, are making clear that they will decide who is sufficiently patriotic to govern Hong Kong and how soon democracy can be introduced there.

description: ''Raising Waylon,'' which has its premiere Sunday, might inspire Hollywood writers who cherish the old fantasy: a one-line pitch -- ''Unlikely godparents end up with custody of a child,'' for example -- can get a movie made.

title: Iraqi Kurdish Leaders Resist as the U.S. Presses Them to Moderate Their Demands
description: The alliance between the United States government and Kurdish political parties in Iraq has come under intense strain in recent days, with Kurdish leaders accusing the Americans of trying to block their long stifled hopes for autonomy in the new Iraqi state.

title: San Francisco Judge Rules Gay Marriages Can Continue
description: Opponents of gay marriage suffered another setback here on Friday when a judge refused to block the issuance of same-sex marriage licenses, saying the opponents had not shown that the weddings were causing immediate harm.

title: Odysseus Goes Home. Slowly.
description: If nothing else, Theodora Skipitares's ''Odyssey: The Homecoming'' explains why it took poor Odysseus so darned long to get home from the Trojan War. He and everyone else in ancient Greece apparently moved in ultraslow motion. Snails and turtles would have had to stop and wait for these guys to catch up.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the World Briefing column yesterday about reunification talks in Cyprus misidentified one of four participants pictured. The one at the right was Mehmet Ali Talat, leader of the Republican Turkish Party of Cyprus, not Tassos Papadopoulos, the Greek Cypriot president.

title: Judicial Activism
description: Senate Democrats who worry that President Bush is stacking the courts with right-wing judges of dubious judicial qualifications may have to think twice before taking another holiday. Yesterday, Mr. Bush took advantage of Congress's absence by making his second recess appointment since the first of the year. This time he named Alabama's attorney general, William Pryor Jr., to the 11th Circuit Court of Appeals. Last month, Mr. Bush used the same mechanism to promote a federal judge, Charles Pickering Sr. of Mississippi, to the 5th Circuit.

title: New Jersey Forges Ahead On Stem Cells
description: Gov. James E. McGreevey will use his budget message next Tuesday to announce a plan to make New Jersey the first state to finance research on human embryonic stem cells, officials in the governor's office said Friday.

title: For Musicians, Solid Walls Make Good Neighbors
description: Correction Appended

description: SINGER--Marshall R. On Wednesday, February 18, 2004 of Washington, DC. Beloved father of Paul B. (Molly) Singer, Shepherd L. (Orna) Singer and Juma (Saleha) Attid; loving brother of Lenore Zimmerman; grandfather of five. Also survived by nieces and nephews. A Memorial Service will be held on Sunday, February 22, 11 am at Danzansky Goldberg Memorial Chapels, Inc, 1170 Rockville Pike, Rockville, MD, 800-281-1471. Interment private. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made to Metro Teenaids www.metroteenaids.org

title: New Data on 2 Doomsday Ideas, Big Rip vs. Big Crunch
description: A dark unseen energy is steadily pushing the universe apart, just as Einstein predicted, suggesting the universe may have a more peaceful end than recent theories envision, according to striking new measurements of distant exploding stars by the orbiting Hubble Space Telescope.

title: World Briefing: Asia
description: CAMBODIA: KING FAVORS GAY MARRIAGES After watching television images of same-sex couples receiving marriage licenses in San Francisco, King Norodom Sihanouk said gay couples should be allowed to marry in Cambodia. Since the government chose in 1993 to be a "liberal democracy," it should allow "marriage between man and man or between woman and woman," the king said in a statement posted on his Web site. Gay couples are not allowed to marry in Cambodia. King Sihanouk, 81, a constitutional monarch, is mostly a figurehead with little real power, but he is highly regarded in his country. (AP)

title: Filipino Twins Another Step Closer to Separation
description: Carl and Clarence Aguirre, the Filipino twins joined at the head, successfully emerged from a third operation yesterday, sharing significantly fewer blood vessels.

title: The Public Faces Life Without Its Dynamo
description: Every year or so the word would start to circulate. Something exciting, something new, possibly even something dangerous was happening downtown on Lafayette Street. Such gossip is lifeblood in the back-fence world of the New York theater, where success is measured as much in buzz as in awards and box-office receipts.

title: BOSTON SCIENTIFIC AND GUIDANT SETTLE STENT SUITS
description: The Boston Scientific Corporation, a leading maker of medical stents, and the Guidant Corporation, a rival in the business, agreed yesterday to settle all pending lawsuits over the devices, which are used to prop open heart arteries. Financial terms were not disclosed. The companies agreed to license each other's patented technology. The suits involve stents, tiny mesh tubes inserted in arteries after angioplasty; stent delivery systems; and catheters. Boston Scientific and Guidant have more than a half-dozen federal lawsuits pending between them in San Francisco and Wilmington, Del. Boston Scientific is based in Natick, Mass., and Guidant is based in Indianapolis.

title: National Briefing: South
description: FLORIDA: MECHANIC INDICTED FOR GIRL'S DEATH An auto mechanic accused of killing an 11-year-old Sarasota girl whose abduction was captured on a car wash surveillance camera was indicted on a first-degree murder charge. Prosecutors said for the first time that they believed that the mechanic, Joseph P. Smith, 37, raped the girl, Carlie Brucia, and that she was strangled with a cord or rope. Dennis Nales, an assistant state attorney, declined to say if prosecutors would seek the death penalty. Mr. Smith's lawyer said his client would plead not guilty at his arraignment, set for March 12. (AP)

title: Europe's Farm Minister Says Onus Is on U.S. in Subsidy Fight
description: Franz Fischler, the departing agriculture minister for the European Union, said on Friday that American policy makers can no longer use Europe as their scapegoat in the global battle over farm subsidies.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about a secretive European network used by the Pakistani scientist Abdul Qadeer Khan for the sale of nuclear technology misstated the location of Delft Technological University, where he once studied. It is in Delft, the Netherlands, not Leuven, Belgium. The article also misspelled the surname of a former Belgian member of the European Parliament who lobbied unsuccessfully for tighter export controls on nuclear technology. He is Paul Staes, not Stais.

title: JOHNSON OUTDOORS GETS $68.4 MILLION OFFER
description: Johnson Outdoors Inc., which makes Eureka tents and Old Town canoes, has received an offer from its largest shareholder and his daughter, the company's chief executive, to buy the rest of Johnson Outdoors for $68.4 million. Samuel Johnson, a fourth-generation heir to the Johnson Wax fortune, and the chief executive, Helen Johnson-Leipold, will pay $18 a share for the 3.8 million shares that the Johnson family and its affiliates do not already own. Mr. Johnson and his family control 56 percent of Johnson Outdoors, according to a spokeswoman, Cynthia Georgeson.

title: Report Finds Atlanta Police Cut Figures On Crimes
description: An audit of the Atlanta Police Department concluded that the department consistently underreported crimes for years. The audit, which was released yesterday, found evidence of both negligence and deliberate efforts to improve the city's image for tourism, possibly including the Summer Olympics in 1996.

title: Americans Favor Democrats in New Polls
description: After weeks of increased news media coverage of the Democratic' primary campaign, Americans are paying closer attention to the race and now hold a more favorable view of the Democratic party than of the Republican party and a more favorable view of the two leading Democratic presidential candidates than of President Bush, according to polls out in recent days.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: MASTERCARD INTERNATIONAL INC., Purchase, N.Y., the card company, bought the TowerGroup, Needham, Mass., a financial services research operation, from the Reuters Group, London, for an undisclosed sum to win clients for its MasterCard Advisers unit.

title: Piazza Works At First Base, Wows at Plate
description: Far from Tampa and the breathless anticipation of Alex Rodriguez's arrival, on a side field usually reserved for minor leaguers, a few hundred Mets fans saw one reason they may still want to watch baseball this season.

title: Damning Words in Stewart Case, or Maybe Not
description: In a day of courtroom histrionics, a central witness for the prosecution in the Martha Stewart trial yesterday apparently reversed her earlier testimony about Ms. Stewart, and then made a partial reversal of that. By the day's end, weary prosecutors rested their case and defense lawyers began presenting witnesses of their own.

title: Moody's to Review Tobacco Bonds
description: Moody's Investors Service said yesterday that it would review municipal bonds that are worth $19 billion and are backed by the 1998 tobacco settlement for a possible downgrade because of a recent federal appeals court decision.

title: U.N. Names Canadian Judge and Ex-Prosecutor to Rights Post
description: Louise Arbour, a Canadian Supreme Court justice who as a war crimes prosecutor indicted the former Yugoslav president Slobodan Milosevic, was named Friday by Secretary General Kofi Annan as United Nations high commissioner for human rights.

title: Religion Journal; Frodo's Quest Inspires a Search for Allegory
description: ''The Lord of the Rings'' movie trilogy has created a real-life fantasy world for movie buffs and epic-adventure fans, complete with sold-out midnight releases and coveted action figures.

title: Edwards Calls for 4 Debates, But Kerry Is Cool to the Idea
description: Senator John Edwards returned to New York on Friday for the second of five straight days of campaigning in the state, and pressed the themes of job loss and economic despair while stepping up his push for a fresh series of debates before the Super Tuesday primaries, on March 2.

title: U.S. Expected to Ask United Nations to Keep Trying for an Agreement
description: The Bush administration, seeing little hope for an early accord on Iraq's future government, is likely to ask for more help from a special United Nations envoy to solidify a consensus on how Iraq will be run after June 30, administration and United Nations officials said Friday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KONSKER, MORTON
description: KONSKER--Morton. Of Boca Raton, FL passed away at the age of 73, after a long 16.5 month battle with pancreatic cancer. He is survived by his adored wife of 44 years, Sandi, she was the epicenter of his every day thoughts and actions. He was a devoted father of his three sons, Mitchell, Steven and Kenneth. Beloved father-in-law of Lisa, Jackie and Lori. Proud grandfather of Ian, Carly, Samuel, Gabriel, Daniel, Briella, Eliana and Harrison. Dear brother of Norma and Leonard Weiner. He is also survived by many nieces and nephews whom he loved very much. Morty was a true gentleman, always charismatic and humorous. He was a man of great integrity and morals who had the innate ability to make others around him happy. As he grew older, he had an incessant drive to be learned and to live life to the fullest, which never diminished. He will be missed by all the lives he touched. His funeral will be held at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 W 76 St, NY, NY on February 22 at 10:00 AM. The family requests any donations be made to the ''Dr. Bruckner Research Fund'' 150 55 St, Brooklyn, NY 11220-2574

title: Worker Is Crushed to Death At Troubled Foundry Upstate
description: A maintenance worker was crushed to death Thursday night at a foundry in Elmira, N.Y., the 10th fatality since 1995 at plants owned by McWane Inc., an Alabama-based maker of cast-iron pipe with one of the nation's most extensive records of workplace safety violations.

title: Major City Union May Offer To Give Ground on Pensions
description: Contract talks between the Bloomberg administration and District Council 37, New York City's largest municipal union, accelerated this week after the union's leaders said they might agree to a less generous pension plan for future city workers, union officials said.

title: Yankees Hope Lieber Can Be All That He Was
description: Jon Lieber spotted Tommy John at the Yankees' spring training camp the other day, and he had to talk with him. Lieber has John's name figuratively tattooed across his right elbow.

title: Nets Extend Run to a Dozen, Setting Record
description: In his short reign as coach, Lawrence Frank has pounded some themes into the Nets. He would have insisted that the 11 games that preceded Friday night's were wiped out of their minds; that the 48 minutes of play that had just ended had been their only focus, and even then, those thoughts should have faded as soon as the game was over.

description: JOHN EDWARDS -- Hempstead, N.Y.; St. Paul; and Cleveland

title: City Ballet's 'Sleeping Beauty' Leaves No Time to Sleepwalk
description: George Balanchine built his new American ballet on the firm grounds of the Russian classicism in which he was trained as a child. Peter Martins, in his 1991 production of ''The Sleeping Beauty,'' achieved an approximate symbiosis of past and present. Revived for the New York City Ballet's current celebration of Balanchine's centennial and life's work, the production, last performed in 2000, returned to the repertory on Wednesday night at the New York State Theater.

title: Hunt for Chief Raises Questions for Coke
description: A day after Douglas N. Daft, the Coca-Cola Company's chairman and chief executive, announced he would retire at the end of the year, analysts questioned the timing of the resignation and debated the effect it could have on Steven J. Heyer, Coke's president and chief operating officer, who has long been considered the heir apparent to Mr. Daft.

title: A Woman as Coach at Boys and Girls
description: In September 1994, Ruth Lovelace walked into the office of Frank Mickens, the principal of Boys and Girls High School in Brooklyn. Mickens was juggling a variety of tasks at his desk, the phone cradled to his ear as he pointed to a stack of rsums.

title: Corrections
description: A commentary article in Science Times on Jan. 20 about relationships between medical schools and drug companies misstated the distance between Canadian universities that participated in a study of contacts between interns and pharmaceutical representatives. McMaster is in Hamilton, Ontario, not across town from the University of Toronto. A reader reported the error late last month, and this correction was delayed by an editing oversight.

title: Gerald Walker -- Novelist, 75
description: Gerald Walker, an author and editor who wrote the novel ''Cruising,'' died on Thursday at New York Presbyterian Hospital in Manhattan. He was 75.
