title: Budget Relies On Bad Drivers To Balance Trenton Books
description: Traffic violations like making an illegal left turn could cost New Jersey drivers an extra $75 under provisions for surcharges on traffic offenses in Gov. James E. McGreevey's proposed budget. A serious offense like leaving the scene of an accident in which someone was injured could add $450 to an already stiff fine and court costs.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WEISSMAN, SAMUEL
description: WEISSMAN -- Samuel. Died peacefully in his 94th year on February 7, 2004. He will be greatly missed by Miriam, his wife and friend of 58 years, son Paul, daughter-in-law Lourdes, and grandchildren Gabriel and Julian. He is also survived by his brother Ben and sister Gertrude and by many nieces and nephews.

title: Broncos, Instead of the Jets, Near a Deal to Acquire Bailey
description: The Jets made several trade offers last week to the Washington Redskins for the Pro Bowl cornerback Champ Bailey, but the Redskins appear close to sending Bailey to the Denver Broncos for the Pro Bowl running back Clinton Portis.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Europewide Ban On U.S. Poultry
description: The European Union imposed a ban until March 23 on importing live poultry and eggs from the United States, citing an outbreak of avian influenza in Texas. Last year the union imported nine million eggs worth $25 million, a quarter of all eggs imported into the European bloc. Mexico also imposed a ban on poultry imports from the United States. Mexico bought nearly $100 million worth of American poultry in 2003. Elizabeth Becker (NYT)

title: Israel and Jordan Cooperate in Desert Project
description: Israel and Jordan have agreed to build an environmental studies center on their shared desert border, a rare instance of cooperation on a major project between the Middle East neighbors, officials said Tuesday.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: Airline Narrows Loss
description: Swiss International Airlines said in a preliminary report that it cut its loss last year to 687 million Swiss francs ($547 million) from 980 million francs a year earlier. The airline said it reduced expenses by cutting staff, fleet size and the number of routes it flies. Revenue declined to 4.1 billion Swiss francs from 4.4 billion. Fiona Fleck (NYT)

title: Number of Asylum Seekers Drops To a Six-Year Low, the U.N. Says
description: Increasing intolerance and tough anti-asylum measures, particularly in Europe, helped to reduce the number of asylum seekers to the lowest level in six years, according to a report published Tuesday by the United Nations refugee agency.

title: Sex Attacks in U.S. Military Increasing, Senators Are Told
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 25  The United States military is facing the gravest accusations of sexual misconduct in a decade, with dozens of servicewomen in the Persian Gulf area saying they were sexually assaulted or raped by fellow troops and then denied adequate medical care and counseling, lawmakers and victims advocates said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   RIKER, WALTER
description: RIKER--Walter. The Faculty of the Department of Pharmacology, Weill Medical College of Cornell University mourns the death of Dr. Walter Riker, Jr., our esteemed former chairman. Dr. Riker led this department with great distinction from 1956-1983. He manifested the highest standards of academic and scientific excellence and absoulute loyalty to his faculty and this medical school. He was also a great humanitarian who touched all of our lives deeply. We will always remember him with affection and respect. Our deepest sympathy to his wife, Virginia, and to all of the Riker children, grandchildren and great grandchildren. Dr. Lorraine Gudas, Chairman, Department of Pharmacology

title: Upbeat McGreevey Relies On Borrowing for Budget
description: Gov. James E. McGreevey mixed economic boosterism and a moral call to arms in announcing a new $26.26 billion state budget containing added spending for programs ranging from preschools to stem cell research.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Wisconsin: Official Is Charged
description: The state attorney general, Peg Lautenschlager, 48, was charged with driving under the influence after her car went into a ditch on Monday night as she was headed home to Fond du Lac. Ms. Lautenschlager, who said she fell asleep and drove off the road, said in a statement on Tuesday, ''I have disappointed many people who have put their faith in me.'' A breath test showed her blood alcohol level to be 0.12 percent, above the state's limit of 0.08 percent, said her lawyer, Stephen J. Meyer. Jo Napolitano (NYT)

title: Keeping Faith With His Base
description: It is a cardinal rule of politics, all the more so for a president who saw his father defeated largely because he failed to heed it fully: Pay attention to the party's base.

title: Pupils Seem to Disappear In Shambles of Special Ed
description: MARIA MORALES'S son, Angel, has learning disabilities and speech problems or, as his mother says, ''Angel's slow.'' At both Public School 3 and Intermediate School 217 in the Bronx, the boy was in ''self-contained'' classes of 6 to 12 special education students.

title: Court Voids Fees From Dairy Farmers
description: A federal appeals court ruled yesterday that the fees collected from dairy farmers to finance the ''Got Milk'' ads were unconstitutional.

title: National Briefing | South: Florida: Smuggling Charged
description: Thirteen people, including 10 American Airlines employees at Miami International Airport, were indicted in federal court on charges of smuggling cocaine and heroin through the airport. A four-year international investigation found that the defendants had agreed with undercover federal agents to help ship drugs that were planted on planes in Costa Rica, Panama and Venezuela and later to transport the drugs to undercover agents in Baltimore, Dallas, Nashville and San Juan, P.R. Terry Aguayo (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CARROLL, MILDRED ANNE
description: CARROLL -- Mildred Anne. On February 23, 2004. Beloved wife of the late H. Brooks Carroll. Cherished mother of David, Mark, and Patti. Adoring grandmother of Julia. Dear sister of Diane Novak. Devoted friend to many. A memorial is being planned for March.

title: POWER COMPANY CANCELS $2.3 BILLION DEBT SALE
description: The Calpine Corporation, which produces power in 21 states, yesterday canceled sales of about $2.3 billion in notes and term loans intended to refinance debt. The company's shares fell 7.3 percent. The company said it would find other ways to refinance the debt, which is scheduled to mature in November. Standard & Poor's rated the note offer at below investment grade, and demand for such securities has weakened in recent weeks. ''This leaves a cloud that will concern investors until the refinancing gets done,'' said Gordon Howald, an analyst at Crdit Lyonnais Securities. A Calpine spokesman, Rick Barraza, said that reduced demand helped cancel the sale and that Calpine would probably offer a new package of debt by July.

title: High Court, Citing Flaw in Law, Again Dismisses a Death Penalty
description: New York State's highest court yesterday overturned the death sentence of a Rochester killer who had told police he could not ''do a hundred years in jail'' and wanted to be executed.

title: World Briefing | Middle East: Israel: Restrictions For Nuclear Whistle-Blower
description: Mordechai Vanunu, who worked at the country's main nuclear reactor and was sentenced to 18 years in prison for divulging details of the plant to a British newspaper in 1986, will be placed under government supervision when he completes his sentence in April, the prime minister's office said. A statement by Prime Minister Ariel Sharon's office did not specify the restrictions but said the intention would be to prevent Mr. Vanunu ''from committing additional security crimes.'' Israel has always refused to discuss its nuclear program. Greg Myre (NYT)

title: Candidates' Schedules
description: JOHN EDWARDS -- Claremont, Fresno, and Sacramento, Calif.

title: S.E.C. Chief Proposes Choices for Stock Trading
description: The nation's top securities regulator proposed a rule change yesterday that could shift trades away from the New York Stock Exchange and toward its electronic rivals by allowing investors to choose speed over best price.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Europe May Ask Microsoft For 2 Versions of Windows

title: I.B.M. to Alter How It Pays Stock Options To Executives
description: I.B.M. waded into the debate over stock options yesterday by announcing that it was overhauling the way it pays its senior executives so their stock awards only become valuable if the company's shares rise by 10 percent or more.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Tire Maker's Profit Falls
description: Europe's largest tire maker, Michelin, posted a 45 percent decline in its 2003 net income, citing a rise in the price of rubber, a one-time acquisition charge and the strength of the euro against the dollar. Michelin said its net income fell to 317.5 million euros ($399 million) in 2003, from 580.8 million euros in 2002. Revenue fell 1.8 percent, but the company said that volume was up 3.7 percent. The company said results were affected by a charge of 306 million euros related to its acquisition of Viborg and 192 million euros in restructuring costs. Michelin did not issue specific target numbers for 2004, but the chief executive, Edouard Michelin, above, said he expected the global market to grow by only 1 to 2 percent and costs to remain high. Ariane Bernard (NYT)

title: C.I.A. Chief Defends Handling of Hijacker Data
description: The director of central intelligence on Tuesday defended his agency's handling of information it received about one of the Sept. 11 hijackers some two and a half years before the attacks, saying, ''We didn't sit on our hands.''

title: Putting Bias in the Constitution
description: With his re-election campaign barely started and his conservative base already demanding tribute, President Bush proposes to radically rewrite the Constitution. The amendment he announced support for yesterday could not only keep gay couples from marrying, as he maintains, but could also threaten the basic legal protections gay Americans have won in recent years. It would inject meanspiritedness and exclusion into the document embodying our highest principles and aspirations.

title: Martha Stewart Won't Testify; Defense Is Near End of Its Case
description: Lawyers for Martha Stewart said yesterday that they would wrap up their defense in her trial this morning, without testimony from Ms. Stewart. Closing arguments in the case could begin as early as tomorrow.

description: To the Editor:

title: Lee Agrees To Contract And Seeks A Role
description: The Yankees have agreed to terms with first baseman Travis Lee on a one-year, $2 million contract with a club option for 2005. Lee was here for a physical on Tuesday.

title: CITIGROUP APPOINTS LEADERS OF NEW DIVISIONS
description: Citigroup said yesterday that it had named Tom Maheras and Michael Klein to head new banking and capital markets units. The appointments are among the first organizational changes since the chief executive, Charles Prince, took over the company from Sanford I. Weill on Oct. 1. They give the new global investment banking chief, Robert Druskin, two new deputies. Commercial lending and investment banking accounted for about 30 percent of the company's total profit last year. Mr. Maheras, formerly head of fixed income, will become head of capital markets. Mr. Klein, formerly head of Citigroup's Europe, Middle East and Africa region, will run the new banking unit. Both units report to Mr. Druskin.

title: Italy's hat makers see headier times
description: MILAN  Italy's hat makers may never rediscover the halcyon days when no one ventured far from the front door without reaching for something to put on their head. But, after decades of decline, the industry is looking to reintroduce the hat as an essential fashion accessory and an example of modern Italian craftsmanship.

title: National Briefing: South
description: GEORGIA: 6 PLEAD GUILTY Six men from Trenton, Ga., have pleaded guilty to civil rights conspiracy charges for burning a cross at the driveway of a white woman who was dating a biracial man, the United States attorney's office said. The men, ages 25 to 41, are to be sentenced May 7.    Ariel Hart (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Bronx: Woman Dies In Ritual
description: A woman died last night in the University Heights neighborhood, apparently in an attempt to extinguish flames on her body that were ignited in a religious or healing ritual, the police said. Two police officers in the area heard a woman wailing and crying about 7 p.m. and followed the sound to a second-floor apartment at 51 North Street. The woman had burns on her torso and a wound on her forehead, the police said. She apparently hit her head while trying to put out the flames and died from the injury. Another woman in the apartment had burns on her hand and was taken to St. Barnabas Hospital in stable condition, the police said. The dead woman, who was 41, appeared to have been taking part in a ritual using tarot cards and candles, law enforcement officials said. Sabrina Tavernise (NYT)

description: The Islanders and the Boston Bruins went to overtime Tuesday night at Nassau Coliseum. That was nothing unusual. The teams played an extra period in all four of their encounters this season.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GOLDBERG, BERNARD
description: GOLDBERG--Bernard. The Board of Directors, residents and staff of The Hebrew Home for the Aged at Riverdale mourn with profound sadness the loss of our beloved Chairman and friend. For over twenty years, Bernie provided vision and leadership to the Hebrew Home. His support of the new initiatives of the Home, and his unwavering dedication to the residents and staff were a source of inspiration. More than a Board member, Bernie was an integral part of the Hebrew Home family. We extend our heartfelt condolences to Bernie's beloved wife Carole, loving sons Avery (Leila), Stewart (Gladys), sister Dotty Raines, and grandson Jonathan (Debbie). May Bernie's soul be bound among the mourners of Zion. Milton Gilbert, President Daniel Reingold, Executive Vice President

title: Peru's African Heritage, Celebrated With Gusto
description: After only a few minutes of Per Negro's performance at Town Hall on Saturday night, you understood why one of the principal Afro-Peruvian musical and dance forms is called the festejo. That word, a program note explained, is derived from festejar, meaning ''to celebrate or have a good time.'' This was more than two hours of celebration, and those two hours added up to be a very good time.

title: Senate Democrats Block Caps for Malpractice
description: For the second time in less than a year, Senate Democrats on Tuesday blocked a White House-backed effort to impose strict caps on jury awards in medical malpractice cases. But Republicans vowed to bring the issue up again later in the year.

title: Jeter Says Rodriguez Has the Tools to Stand Out at Third
description: An oversized team logo billowed behind them. An empty soda cup tipped over and rolled across the table. The wind raged and the rain intensified on the roof of the tent. Derek Jeter had taken a seat beside Alex Rodriguez at a news conference on Tuesday after the Yankees' first full-squad workout.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Phony Doctor Inquiry
description: The New York Police Department will send two detectives to Costa Rica today to meet with Costa Rican authorities and United States officials there about the case of Maria Cruz, a 35-year-old investment banker who disappeared last April, Paul J. Browne, the chief spokesman for the New York Police Department said. The police suspect that a sham New York doctor, Dean Faiello, may have been responsible for the death of Ms. Cruz. Mr. Faiello is believed by investigators to be in Costa Rica, and is suspected to have treated Ms. Cruz on the day she disappeared, the police have said. Sabrina Tavernise (NYT)

title: CHIEF EXECUTIVE OF BLOOD REPLACEMENT COMPANY RESIGNS
description: The Biopure Corporation, which is developing a form of artificial blood, said yesterday that its chief executive, Thomas A. Moore, had resigned, less than two months after regulators delayed approval of its product. Mr. Moore, who joined the company in July 2002, will be succeeded temporarily by Francis H. Murphy, the company's senior vice president for engineering and process technology and a former chief financial officer, the company said. Biopure said on Jan. 8 that the Food and Drug Administration had asked to see the results of three studies conducted on animals before it could approve the company's product. Stock in the company, which is based in Cambridge, Mass., fell 26 cents, or 16 percent, to $1.36 a share.

title: Investigator Quits Rowland Inquiry, Citing Possible Conflict
description: An investigator hired last week by the House committee that will decide whether to recommend the impeachment of Gov. John G. Rowland has resigned, citing a possible conflict of interest.

title: Justices Say Airline Is Liable For a Fatal Reaction to Smoking
description: The Supreme Court ruled Tuesday that an airline was liable for the death of a 52-year-old passenger who had an asthmatic reaction to cigarette smoke, because the flight attendant repeatedly refused to move him farther from the smoking section.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an obituary on Saturday about Sister Doris Smith, former president of the College of Mount St. Vincent in the Bronx, misstated the date of her death. It was Jan. 19, not Feb. 19.

title: CANADIAN COMPANY AGREES TO BUY PIPELINE IN U.S.
description: The TransCanada Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to buy a 1,350-mile gas pipeline in the United States from a unit of the PG&E Corporation for $1.2 billion. The deal would help TransCanada complete its network from Western Canada to California. TransCanada will also assume $500 million in debt. The transaction is expected to close in about 75 days, said Hejdi Feick, a spokeswoman for TransCanada, which is based in Calgary, Alberta. TransCanada carries most of the gas produced in Canada.

description: To the Editor:

title: World Briefing | Europe: France: U.S. Halts Import Of French Meats
description: The United States suspended the import of all French meat and poultry, saying France had failed an audit of inspection facilities. A spokeswoman for Agriculture Secretary Ann M. Veneman said that the ban, which includes fois gras and pt, was effective immediately. Three of the 11 French meat or poultry establishments audited by the United States in the last two months failed. The top French meat exports are cold cuts, including hams and sausages. Elizabeth Becker (NYT)

title: The Gun Lobby's Bull's-Eye
description: The Senate is on the verge of approving a new sop to the gun industry that is the latest sad example of what has become of the gun control debate. Many Americans have labored under the mistaken impression that this was a debate about the Constitution and public safety, about the balance between saving lives and assuring law-abiding gun owners and cultural conservatives that the Second Amendment is being protected. In fact, as the legislation before the Senate demonstrates, the Bush administration and its allies in Congress have long been focused simply on making it easier for gun manufacturers and gun dealers to turn a profit.

description: In a span of four days last week, St. John's won one Big East Conference game and lost another by a point, signs of life for a team whose attempt to end the season on an upward note seemed hopeless. Then Connecticut came to town.

title: C.I.A. Says Iran Elections Portend New Era of Repression
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 25  With the victory of religious hardliners in last week's parliamentary elections in Iran, the Central Intelligence Agency is warning of a new era of repression and inflexibility by the country's clerical regime.

title: CLINICAL DATA IS NEW BIDDER FOR MOORE MEDICAL
description: Clinical Data, a supplier of medical instruments to hospitals, said yesterday that it had offered to buy the Moore Medical Corporation for about $39 million in stock to expand its Internet distribution, countering a bid from the McKesson Corporation. Clinical Data, based in Newton, Mass., bid 0.698 share for each share of Moore, worth about $12.22 a share as of the closing price yesterday. McKesson, one of the nation's largest drug distributors, offered $12 a share for Moore on Jan. 20. A third bidder, SJ Strategic Investments, withdrew its bid for Moore Medical on Feb 13. SJ Strategic is one of the largest shareholders in Moore Medical, which is based in New Britain, Conn. McKesson is based in San Francisco.

title: More Stores, Smaller Ones, Planned by Georg Jensen
description: Georg Jensen, the renowned Danish silversmith, has come up with a new design, this one for smaller stores that will be a defining quality of the company's expansion in this country. The first of the new 1,100-square-foot to 2,500-square-foot stores, with a tighter focus on goods manufactured by Jensen, are to open later this year in SoHo in Manhattan and in Greenwich, Conn. Moves from existing stores to smaller spaces nearby are planned for Short Hills, N.J., and the flagship store on Madison Avenue.

title: With a Recovering Economy, The Day of the Big Deal Is Back
description: By his own admission, William B. Harrison would have been vilified for negotiating a merger a year ago.

title: BANK OF AMERICA BUYS TRADING-SOFTWARE COMPANY
description: The Bank of America Corporation said yesterday that it had bought the Direct Access Financial Corporation, a private company that makes software for trading securities, to improve its new electronic trading services unit. Terms were not disclosed. Direct Access, which is based in Dallas, will become part of the bank's securities unit. Bank of America said its electronic trading services group would offer choices like program trading, in which a computer program is used to send buy or sell orders for single stocks, a list of securities or a block trade. Bank of America is based in Charlotte, N.C.

Survived by daughter Eva (Robert), daughter Krystyna (partner Joy). Born in Bobrujsk. description: Despite Iranian disavowals, International Atomic Energy Agency experts in Iran have found evidence of indigenous production of a concentrated fuel that, if pure enough, can be used to make nuclear weapons. They said in an inspection report that equipment made there showed many traces of the fuel, highly enriched uranium.

title: Cajun Spice Is in New York's Melting Pot Again
description: HAS it really been 20 years since a wave of Louisiana restaurants paraded through New York, flashing their wares like gaudy Mardi Gras beads, and then just as quickly high-stepped off? Back then, ravenous crowds practically wiped out the redfish population at restaurants like La Louisiana and Gulf Coast, Bon Temps Rouler and Texarkana. Hands more accustomed to caressing crystal brandished Mason jars holding Cajun martinis. New Yorkers happily waited for hours when the celebrated Cajun chef Paul Prudhomme brought his K-Paul's Louisiana Kitchen to the Upper West Side for a temporary stint in 1985.

title: After Months of Contention, The Passion Arrives in Theaters
description: Called everything from a deeply spiritual meditation to an inflammatory bloodbath, "The Passion of the Christ," the film about the last hours of the life of Jesus, is opening in 3,006 theaters nationwide today on the heels of a media onslaught of biblical proportions.

title: Saudis Debate Expert in U.S. On Outlook For Their Oil
description: Saudi Arabian oil executives said Tuesday that they planned to maintain production capacity at the current rate of 10 million barrels a day for the rest of this decade but could increase maximum output by 20 percent to 50 percent in about 10 years.

title: World Briefing | Asia: India: Space Center Fire Killed 6
description: Officials confirmed that six people were killed when rocket fuel exploded at India's main space launching facility in Andhra Pradesh. Officials said the accident would not slow future space missions, including plans to send a satellite to the moon by 2007 or 2008. Hari Kumar (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BLOCH, GILBERT M.
description: BLOCH--Gilbert M. On Monday, February 23, 2004, in Palm Beach Gardens, FL at age 76. Devoted and loving husband of Beatrice, much beloved and caring father of Larry (Cindy) Bloch, Babette (Marc) Mellon, Jayne (Brian) Hickey; cherished grandfather of Reisa, Matthew, Julia, Rachel, Daniel and Liana; brother to Roslyn Hinderstein; son of the late Henry and Estelle Bloch; and son-inlaw of Anneliese and the late Otto N. Weil. He was a most inspiring human being who fought his illness with courage and dignity. His creativity and tenacity was an inspiration to all who knew and loved him. Funeral services 11:30AM, Thursday, February 26 at Wien and Wien Memorial Chapel, 402 Park St, Hackensack, New Jersey. A Memorial Service will also be held on Sunday, February 29 at 12:30PM at Temple Israel, West Palm Beach, Florida. In lieu of flowers memorial contributions may be sent to Morse Geriatric Center, West Palm Beach, Florida.

title: Is the Stemware Correct If It Doesn't Have a Stem?
description: Does your dishwasher occasionally attack the stems of your wine glasses? Maximilian Riedel has beaten the machine at its own game and lopped off the stems, sleekly. Mr. Riedel, whose family's company has a glass for every grape, has a new line of rounded tumblers called O. ''If you watch the way people drink wine, they usually hold the glass by the bowl, not the stem,'' Mr. Riedel said. As for the warmth of one's hands on the wine, he said he felt it was not significant. ''These glasses are not designed to replace stemware,'' he added. ''They're just a convenient alternative.''

title: Circuit City Reviews Its Creative Account
description: Circuit City is placing in review the creative part of its general market advertising account, which has been handled for three years by the Chicago office of Foote Cone & Belding, part of the Interpublic Group of Companies. Circuit City, the consumer electronics retailer based in Richmond, Va., spends about $220 million a year on such advertising and has been seeking to stimulate sluggish sales. The company recently closed 19 stores.

title: A Troubled Marriage and the Trouble With Junior
description: Eye-teasing, light-stroked surfaces tantalize the unhappy characters in ''Beautiful Child,'' Nicky Silver's portentous play about parental love and the lies that families live by. The reflective sheen of a pale boy's skin, the white radiance of a snowscape, the beckoning blue of an elusive woman's coat: these images accumulate in a gorgeous inventory of ephemera in this grim comic drama, which opened last night at the Vineyard Theater.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Business Confidence Slips
description: German business confidence fell in February as a result of the euro's record strength against the dollar, a monthly survey by the Ifo Institute said. After 10 months of growing optimism, the overall index, based on a survey of 7,000 businesses about the current business climate, fell to 96.4 from 97.5 in January. Petra Kappl (NYT)

description: Driving to lunch several weeks ago, Phil Mickelson was asked what he expected in 2004. Mickelson turned off his car radio so every word could be heard.

title: Defiant Downloads Rise From Underground
description: More than 300 Web sites and blogs staged a 24-hour online protest yesterday over a record company's efforts to stop them from offering downloadable copies of ''The Grey Album.'' A popular underground collection of music, ''The Grey Album'' mixes tracks from the Beatles' classic White Album with raps from Jay-Z's latest release, ''The Black Album.''

title: World Briefing | Americas: Argentina: Freeze On Ex-President's Assets
description: A federal judge ordered a freeze on all of the personal assets of Carlos Sal Menem after determining that the former president failed to declare at least $500,000 uncovered in a Swiss bank account. Mr. Menem, who governed Argentina for a decade ending in 1999, is under investigation for suspected activities ranging from arms trafficking to accepting payoffs for thwarting an inquiry into a bombing in Buenos Aires that Iran is alleged to have organized, and Swiss authorities agreed recently to relax their bank secrecy laws and place his name on a list of foreign leaders suspected of corruption and money laundering. Larry Rohter (NYT)

title: Police Kill Suspect as Thousands Watch the Shooting on TV
description: When Los Angeles police officers unleashed a barrage of bullets early Monday into the car of a robbery suspect, killing him, five television helicopters hovered above, beaming the scene into thousands of viewers' homes.

title: World Briefing | Africa: South Africa: Aids Treatment Closer
description: Officials belatedly rolled out a plan to supply antiretroviral drugs to the nation's 5.3 million H.I.V.-positive citizens, saying that nutritional supplements and anti-H.I.V. drugs would be made available at least one center in every health district within a year and in all towns within five years. The drugs will be warehoused in each of the nation's nine provinces, officials told Parliament, but supply constraints could be a problem because crucial ingredients would be imported from China and India, which have their own mounting H.I.V. problems. Michael Wines (NYT)

title: California Attorney General Is Pressed on Gay Marriage
description: As President Bush declared his support for a constitutional amendment banning gay marriage, the political and legal landscape surrounding the marriage licenses issued here to same-sex couples appeared rockier than ever on Tuesday.

title: Political Memo; Bloomberg Tries Makeover, Daring to Look Like Politician
description: It was the blink of an eye, really, 30 short minutes out of a busy and protracted Thursday: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, standing in a barren lot in Washington Heights, announced that the city would soon have a new parking garage. There were five speakers, including Mr. Bloomberg, who banged his hands together to fight off the cold as each person took his turn expounding on the traffic troubles in upper Manhattan.

title: National Briefing | Southwest: Texas: Arson Damages Mosque
description: An arson fire damaged a mosque in southeast Houston on Monday, the police and federal agents said. The Msjiad Almuhaymin mosque was empty and locked for the evening when neighbors spotted smoke and flames and used garden hoses to extinguish the fire, limiting damage to a corner of the structure. Steve Barnes (NYT)

title: Simple Dcor For Cakes Made For Eating
description: Neil Kleinberg, left, who owns Clinton St. Baking Company and Restaurant, 4 Clinton Street (Houston Street), likes uncluttered cakes. His new line for birthdays or other special occasions consists of home-style cakes with fairly dense layers of dark chocolate or golden vanilla cake neatly covered with plain chocolate or vanilla butter cream and decorated with just a little writing. Because the cakes are all about yummy cake and icing, only crumbs will be left after the party. In the spring Mr. Kleinberg said he will make strawberry and whipped cream cakes and maybe coconut. An eight-inch cake is $25, a 10-inch is $40 and a 12-incher is $50, to be ordered 48 hours in advance from (646) 602-6263.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a report in the Metro Briefing column on Friday about Representative Anthony D. Weiner's withdrawal of a query to the New York City Campaign Finance Board misstated the question he had asked. It was how he could use congressional campaign money for a mayoral campaign without violating pending city legislation barring such uses. He did not ask for the board's permission to do so.

title: Europe May Tell Microsoft to Split Software
description: European antitrust regulators are considering a requirement that Microsoft sell two versions of Windows in Europe -- one with the music- and video-playing software stripped out -- should they find the company to be an abusive monopoly, people close to the case said Tuesday.

title: Council Speaker Taking Aim At Bloomberg's School Policies
description: In his annual address to the city today, Gifford Miller, the City Council speaker, plans to call for improving school safety and giving money to teachers for classroom supplies, signaling that he intends to challenge the Bloomberg administration on education, its signature issue.

title: Happy Marriage Between Eggs and Greens
description: ''MY father would drive five hours for the right pancetta, the right pecorino,'' Cesare Casella said as he whisked a shot of olive oil into a deep garnet pool of balsamic vinegar, red wine and red wine vinegar. ''This dish takes five minutes.''

title: Camden Relay Team Cracks Barrier
description: Camden High School of New Jersey became the first United States schoolboy 4x200 meter relay to run under 1 minute 27 seconds when the foursome of Dwayne Lewis (21.9 seconds), Sherron Bullock (21.3), Alonzo Brown (21.9) and Carl Smith 21.8 won the event last night in 1:26.90 in the Eastern States high school championships at the Armory Track and Field Center in Manhattan. William J. Miller

title: Good and Evil Locked In Violent Showdown
description: There is a prophetic episode of ''The Simpsons'' in which the celebrity guest star Mel Gibson, directing and starring in a remake of ''Mr. Smith Goes to Washington,'' enlists the help of Homer Simpson, who represents the public taste (or lack of it). Homer persuades Mr. Gibson to change the picture's ending, replacing James Stewart's populist tirade with an action sequence, a barrage of righteous gunfire that leaves the halls of Congress strewn with corpses. The audience flees the theater in disgust. I thought of Homer more than once, with an involuntary irreverence conditioned by many years of devotion to ''The Simpsons,'' as Mr. Gibson presented his new movie, ''The Passion of the Christ,'' to carefully selected preview audiences across the land, making a few last-minute cuts, and then taking to the airwaves to promote and defend the film. It opens today nationwide.

The highway passes a new water park, a new factory district, a new international school and a new golf course. Eventually, the newly repaved road ends at the beaches of Sihanoukville, where an 800-room hotel opens in June.

title: Perhaps a Dish of Carrots To Pair With 'Seabiscuit'?
description: Are you rooting for ''The Lord of the Rings: The Return of the King'' to win the Academy Award for best picture on Sunday night? Then you might turn to the chapter on knights and kings in ''Movie Menus, Recipes for Perfect Meals With Your Favorite Films'' by Francine Segan (Villard, $16.95) and check out the roast garlic-saffron toasts, which are based on a 14th-century dish. The recipes, designed for easy entertaining on Oscar night, are grouped according to movie categories like westerns, romance and gangsters. Buttermilk biscuits could accompany Jude Law's scenes from ''Cold Mountain'' and, from the chapter on romantic dinners, to salute Diane Keaton in ''Something's Gotta Give,'' beef tenderloin with pink peppercorn sauce. There are more bits of movie trivia and quotations in the pages than there are peas in a potpie.

title: Socially Conscious Coffee Drinkers, Raise Your Cups
description: La Semeuse coffee, roasted and blended in Switzerland and sold in vacuum packages, has introduced its first organic coffee, Soleil Levant. The coffee is grown in Colombia, Peru and Indonesia according to Fair Trade standards, which guarantee better prices for farmers and work to improve health care and education in their areas.

title: A Top bin Laden Aide Threatens New Attacks Against the U.S.
description: A senior leader of Al Qaeda threatened further attacks against the United States and denounced France for banning Islamic head scarves in statements on two audiotapes broadcast by separate Arab satellite channels on Tuesday.

title: North Korea May Get Aid If It Pledges Nuclear Curb
description: North Korea will be offered economic aid in return for a pledge to freeze and eventually dismantle its nuclear weapons facilities, according to senior Asian and American officials. But they said the offer was expected to be presented by South Korea, not the United States, in talks beginning on Wednesday in Beijing.

description: LEDDY--Faith M. Darling daughter of the late Honorable James & Natalie Mulholland. title: World Briefing: Americas
description: ARGENTINA: FREEZE ON EX-PRESIDENT'S ASSETS A federal judge ordered a freeze on all of the personal assets of Carlos Saul Menem after determining that the former president failed to declare at least $500,000 uncovered in a Swiss bank account. Mr. Menem, who governed Argentina for a decade ending in 1999, is under investigation for suspected activities ranging from arms trafficking to accepting payoffs for thwarting an inquiry into a bombing in Buenos Aires that Iran is alleged to have organized, and Swiss authorities agreed recently to relax their bank secrecy laws and place his name on a list of foreign leaders suspected of corruption and money laundering. Larry Rohter (NYT)

title: A Shortcut To Morocco
description: IT is not likely that anyone outside Morocco knows more about that country's cooking than Paula Wolfert, who moved there in 1959 and has been writing about it every since. So when a friend mentioned tasting a chicken and chickpea tagine scented with vanilla, I thought I would ask Ms. Wolfert, a longtime friend, if that dish sounded legitimately Moroccan.

title: Record Ratings for Final Fling With 'Sex'
description: The finale of ''Sex and the City'' paid off for HBO Sunday night with record ratings for the long-running comedy.

title: Critical of Public Schools, And Poised to Take Action
description: As Tom Vander Ark ambles through, teenagers eye him with intrigue or apathy, bright smiles or blank stares. They have no idea what he's doing there, but he wraps their hands in his, working the classroom like a politician at a banquet. And take a look at the principal, they howl. He's never worn such fancy clothes.

title: A Tuber So Homely, Only a Chef Could Love It
description: A FIELD in winter may look dead and barren, but good things often grow underfoot. Things like crosnes, small, bumpy tubers that might just be nature's quirkiest and most elusive vegetable.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Ireland Joins Britain On Migrant Worker Curbs
description: Ireland, the last European Union country to have no restrictions on immigrants from the eight former Soviet bloc countries joining the union in May, said it would limit access to social benefits. The announcement followed by a day a similar move by Britain. In Brussels, the president of the European Commission, Romano Prodi, said he was looking into whether such restrictions violated European law. Brian Lavery (NYT)

title: National Briefing | New England: Massachusetts: Voting Ruling
description: A redistricting map developed by the state House of Representatives in 2001 denies Boston-area minorities the right to an equal vote and must be withdrawn in 60 days, a federal appeals panel ruled. The panel, composed of three district court judges, said the new map, among other things, intentionally packed black voters into one Boston district to benefit incumbents. The ruling sharply rebuked the panel that created the map and the speaker of the House, Thomas M. Finneran, whose district was one of those redrawn, saying the House leadership ''knew what it was doing.'' The court can draw its own map if an alternative is not completed in 60 days. Katie Zezima (NYT)

title: A Place of Escape May Survive, Barely; Parts of Ornate Theater in Queens Included in Condo Plan
description: That palace of wonders, the RKO Keith's Flushing Theater in Queens, will never rise again. But there could still be a coming attraction: the amazing new curtain.

title: National Briefing | Washington: Contractor Investigated
description: The Department of Energy said it was investigating reports of fraud and misconduct by a contractor that provides health care to workers at the Hanford nuclear complex. The contractor, the Hanford Environmental Health Foundation, had been accused by workers and watchdog groups of failing to diagnose correctly the occupational illnesses of workers now involved in the cleanup of Hanford, the nation's most contaminated nuclear site. Spencer Abraham, the energy secretary, asked the department's investigator general this week to investigate the medical contractor, which had provided medical services at Hanford for 38 years but lost the contract this year. Sarah Kershaw (NYT)

title: Corrections

Rigas, former chief executive of Adelphia Communications, and two of his sons, Michael and Timothy, misidentified a man shown with Michael Rigas outside the court. He was Adam J. Wasserman, a lawyer for Michael Rigas -- not Michael Mulcahey, former director of internal reporting, who is also on trial.

title: Supreme Court Roundup; Prosecutorial Misconduct Leads Justices to Overturn Death Sentence in Texas
description: The Supreme Court overturned a Texas inmate's death sentence on Tuesday on the ground that the prosecution deliberately withheld evidence that would have made jurors less likely to impose the death penalty had they been made aware of it.

title: Trade and Jobs at Center Stage As Democrats Court Ohio Vote
description: In May, 2002, Representative Tom Sawyer, an eight-term Democrat, was handed a stunning primary election defeat by 28-year-old Tim Ryan in a district stretching from Akron to Youngstown. The major issue was trade.

description: Can people who have been taught only submission for generations, who are strangers to democracy, be trusted to govern themselves?

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Emergency Official Named To California Post
description: A former official at the New York City Office of Emergency Management has been appointed to a senior post in the California Office of Emergency Services, Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger announced yesterday. The official, Frank McCarton, 35, a deputy commissioner in the New York agency, where he was the spokesman, was named deputy director of emergency operations and training for the California agency. William K. Rashbaum (NYT)

title: Senators Threaten to Delay Action on Medicare Nominee
description: Two Democratic senators said Tuesday that they would hold up the confirmation of a new Medicare chief until the Bush administration explained why it was adamantly opposing imports of lower-cost prescription drugs from Canada.

title: Conjuring Histories at a Crucible of the Revolution
description: Robert A. M. Stern's new design for the National Center for the American Revolution at Valley Forge is a lovely surprise. Imagine Frank Lloyd Wright crossed with Peter Eisenman, and you've clearly got something more than the usual roadside attraction. Critics like myself sometimes belittle Mr. Stern as a theme park designer, and the mind reels trying to figure out what he intends this building's theme to be. Jacques Derrida over Fallingwater, perhaps. Radical forms to commemorate a revolutionary past.

title: A Little-Known New York Assemblyman Has Senator Schumer in His Sights
description: Howard Mills, a little-known Republican assemblyman from Wallkill who is seeking to challenge Senator Charles E. Schumer, jumped into the race on Tuesday by trying to establish himself as a serious candidate and addressing doubts about his ability to compete financially.

description: Since John Edwards and John Kerry are out trolling for a new job, they must figure other people are interested in employment as well.

Weiner's withdrawal of a query to the New York City Campaign Finance Board misstated the question he had asked. It was how he could use congressional campaign money for a mayoral campaign without violating pending city legislation barring such uses. He did not ask for the board's permission to do so. ( Go to Article )

title: Libyan Casts Doubt on Plane-Bombing Guilt, Ending Thaw for Now
description: Libya's prime minister, Shukri Ghanem, brought the thaw in relations between his nation and the West to a sudden standstill on Tuesday by suggesting that Libya was not responsible for the Lockerbie bombing and other major acts of terrorism, even though it has agreed to pay compensation to victims' families and accepted responsibility in writing.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BENENSON, CHARLES B.
description: BENENSON--Charles B. Devoted and beloved husband of Jane. Devoted and beloved father of Bruce William, Frederick and Lawrence. Cherished brother of Lawrence and Raymond. Passed away suddenly on February 22 in Palm Beach, FL. He lived to be 91 years old and remained active in his many pursuits to the very end. In addition to his sons and his brothers, he will be greatly missed by his four grandchildren, dedicated office staff, nieces, nephews, cousins and business associates, all of whom benefited from his wonderful qualities and dedication. His business career, spanning a remarkable 70 years, and his passion for the arts brought him in close intimate contact with all aspects of New York City life. His contributions to the arts, education for inner-city children and Jewish philanthropic causes were known to all, as was his personal commitment to Yale University. He was a founding member of the Association for a Better New York, the Realty Foundation, the Lincoln Center Real Estate and Construction Council, the New York Junior Tennis League, the I Have a Dream Program, and the Museum of African Art and numerous other charitable organizations. Widely respected for his wisdom and integrity in the real estate industry, his humor, optimism and vitality enriched the lives of all who came to know him. His sophistication and intellect were an inspiration to all who knew him. His devotion and love were of inestimable value to those closest to him; their loss is irreplaceable. Funeral services at Temple Emanu-El, 65th Street and Fifth Avenue, at 10 am, Friday, February 27. Visiting at Campbell Funeral Home, 1076 Madison Avenue, Wednesday, February 25, and Thursday, February 26, 6 pm to 9 pm. In lieu of flowers, send donations to the American Jewish Committee, 165 East 56th Street, New York, NY 10022, Inner-City Scholarship Fund, 1011 1st Avenue, New York, NY 10022, or the New York Junior Tennis League, 24-16 Queens Plaza South, Long Island City, NY 11101.

title: Edwards Focuses His Efforts On 3 Promising Constituencies
description: If Senator John Edwards is to span the imposing gap separating him from Senator John Kerry, he knows he must directly appeal to every possible wavering constituency, especially those most amenable to his message of economic disparity and working-class empowerment.

title: World Business Briefing | Middle East: Iran: Telecom Contract Awarded
description: A consortium led by the Istanbul-based mobile phone operator Turkcell beat four competitors to win a contract to build Iran's second mobile phone network, officials announced. The consortium, which includes Ericsson of Sweden and Teliasonera of Finland, as well as an Iranian partner, agreed to pay $385 million and hand over a share of its revenue to the state-owned monopoly. It expects to introduce the network in 2005. Borzou Daragahi (NYT)

title: Rock the Cradle? Let's Rock the World
description: On West 44th Street in Manhattan Golda Meir has been holding court in relatively conventional fashion for months. But if you prefer your prominent 20th-century women deconstructed, fractured, filtered and reinvented, walk a few blocks south. There, in two shows, are glimpses of Madame Mao, Eva Pern, Imelda Marcos, Elena Ceausescu, Eva Braun and Clara Petacci, along with a torrent of fragmentary thoughts about power, sex, second-class citizenship and whale vomit.

title: S.&P. 500 and Dow Decline a Fifth Consecutive Day
description: Stocks fell yesterday, pushing the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index and the Dow Jones industrial average down for a fifth straight day, the longest losing streak since January 2003.

title: Education Panel Asks for 2 More Weeks
description: With time running out before the state budget is due, Frank G. Zarb, the chairman of Gov. George E. Pataki's education commission, has asked for an extra two weeks to calculate how much it will cost to provide every schoolchild in New York City with a sound basic education.

title: Landmark Status, Not Razing, Is Now Likely for S.I. Home
description: The Staten Island home of Henry Hobson Richardson, a 19th-century architect so influential that a style of architecture bears his name, appears to have been spared from impending demolition and is likely instead to be made a New York City landmark.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Gates Demonstrates Security Measures
description: Microsoft's chairman, Bill Gates, yesterday demonstrated security features planned for the Windows XP operating system. He said Microsoft had decided to turn on, by default, firewall protection for Windows-based computers connected to the Internet, to make it harder to exploit vulnerabilities in the operating system. The features, to be introduced sometime in the next four months, also include additions to Internet Explorer and a centralized Windows Security Center panel. John Markoff (NYT)

description: The Yamanouchi Pharmaceutical Company agreed Tuesday to buy the Fujisawa Pharmaceutical Company for 842 billion yen ($7.78 billion) in stock, creating the No.2 Japanese drug maker, to compete in the faster-growing United States and European markets.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SCHEINBERG, DR. LABE C.
description: SCHEINBERG--Dr. Labe C. The family and friends of Labe mourn his death on February 22, 2004 at age 78 and celebrate his life as husband, father, physician, scientist, author and educator. Dr. Scheinberg was a Neurologist and neuro-scientist specializing in the treatment of Multiple Sclerosis. Mr. Martin has struggled to restore public confidence after a report from the auditor general that outlined how the companies -- the national passenger rail carrier, the post office and the Business Development Bank of Canada -- played a role in funneling public money to advertising agencies aligned with the party in Quebec. description: As shortages of influenza vaccine led to nationwide worries and long lines at health clinics at the height of the flu season, 80 percent of a new nasal spray vaccine went unsold and will probably have to be destroyed, the manufacturer told a federal panel on Tuesday.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Bank's Profit Rises
description: Citing a steep decline in loan loss provisions, the Bank of Montreal said its first-quarter income rose 34 percent and it raised its quarterly dividend to 40 Canadian cents a share from 35. Net income in the latest period was 532 million Canadian dollars ($398 million). The bank attributed the improved loan recoveries partly to the stronger American economy. Bernard Simon (NYT)

description: Just as President Bush continues to raise vastly more money than the two main Democratic presidential contenders, fund-raising by the national political parties that support the candidates has also been lopsided.

title: Technology Briefing | Biotechnology: SciClone Loss Widens As Expenses Rise
description: SciClone Pharmaceuticals said yesterday that its net loss widened in the fourth quarter as research and development costs rose. Shares of the company dropped 19 percent. The net loss was $4.69 million, or 11 cents a share, compared with a loss of $2.62 million, or 7 cents a share, a year earlier. Revenue climbed 4.1 percent to $5.24 million, the company said. The wider loss was primarily because of higher costs of testing experimental medicines, the company said. This year, SciClone, based in San Mateo, Calif., expects a net loss of $18 million to $20 million, or 43 cents to 50 cents a share, as it seeks regulatory approvals for the anticancer drug Zadaxin in the United States, Europe and Japan. SciClone shares fell $1.39, to $6.11.

title: U.S. CHARGES TWO AT GUANTNAMO WITH CONSPIRACY

The Greek Orthodox clergyman said he was predisposed to like it; the Methodist minister and the Roman Catholic priest were curious, but wary of its claims of Gospel authenticity; and the Jews were afraid that it would inflame anti-Semitism.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Security Concerns Merge

Falck will spin off its rescue and global-solutions units to create a separate company that will be listed in Copenhagen. title: Paid Notice: Deaths   JANNOR, ANDREW

title: Supreme Court Approves Denial of Divinity Scholarships
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 — The Supreme Court ruled today, in a case watched by public officials and educators across the country, that the states can withhold public scholarship money from students pursuing religious studies.

title: Another Mistake by Rod Paige
description: Rod Paige, the education secretary, made a staggeringly stupid comment this week, comparing the nation's largest teachers' union to a ''terrorist organization'' because it opposes many elements of the two-year-old No Child Left Behind Act. This is the latest in a series of missteps by Mr. Paige.

description: The period of Pete Rose's gambling that led to his banishment from Major League Baseball will be the focus of an ESPN film that is scheduled to be shown in September, the network announced yesterday.

title: A Plan for Wall St. Security, Without the Pickup Trucks
description: The double ranks of pickup trucks that now control seven intersections leading to the New York Stock Exchange will be replaced with retractable posts, wedgelike vehicle barriers and custom-designed barricades resembling small sculptural bronze boulders.

title: Sports of The Times; Boston Again Takes the Bumpy Road

The pitching ace, who doesn't have a contract for next season and may not get one, showed up several days late, with permission, and said if his team doesn't want him, fine, he'll go elsewhere.

title: A Lavish Ice Palace High Above the Din
description: DINING at Asiate begins with a whoosh! as the elevator shoots up 35 floors to the restaurant's glassed-in perch. On the way up, it's hard not to feel camaraderie in the air. There is the thrill of having secured one of the most elusive reservations in town, the excitement of dining in the new Time Warner Center as it transforms itself into a luxury food court and the simple anticipation of a fine meal.

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: EUROPEWIDE BAN ON U.S. POULTRY The European Union imposed a ban until March 23 on importing live poultry and eggs from the United States, citing an outbreak of avian influenza in Texas. Last year the union imported 9 million eggs worth $25 million, a quarter of all eggs imported into the European bloc. Mexico also imposed a ban on poultry imports from the United States. That country bought nearly $100 million worth of American poultry in 2003. Elizabeth Becker (NYT)

title: Kerry Maintains the Administration Is Partly to Blame for the Unrest in Haiti
description: Senator John Kerry accused the Bush administration on Tuesday of helping foster the political instability in Haiti that has given rise to the armed rebellion threatening to overthrow the government of President Jean-Bertrand Aristide.

title: Despite Missteps, Lilly Remains A Hard Stock To Bet Against
description: For the family of the healthy 19-year-old Bible student who hanged herself this month during a test of Cymbalta, an antidepressant being developed by Eli Lilly, the company's quick assurances that the death would not delay the drug's expected introduction this summer were wounding.

title: Some Legitimate Athletes Go to the Mat
description: He was one of the most successful amateur wrestlers of the 1990's, winning a gold medal for freestyle wrestling in the 1996 Olympics and capturing six United States championships. title: Corrections
description: An article on Feb. 11 about a student organization at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology that examines the science of chocolate misstated the properties of three chemical compounds in a major component, cocoa butter. Palmitic acid is a 16-carbon chain, not a 14-carbon chain; stearic acid is an 18-carbon chain, not a 16-carbon chain; and oleic acid is an 18-carbon chain with a double bond, not just an 18-carbon chain.

description: The plaque is back, and for that, city officials of Garfield, N.J., are grateful.

title: C.I.A. Says Iran Elections Portend New Era of Repression
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 25  With the victory of religious hardliners in last week's parliamentary elections in Iran, the Central Intelligence Agency is warning of a new era of repression and inflexibility by the country's clerical regime.

title: Dean Withdrawal Leaves A Wild Card in the Race
description: When Howard Dean withdrew from the Democratic presidential race last week, he left hundreds of thousands of passionate voters without a candidate. He left a highly efficient Internet organizing and fund-raising machine without a cause. And he left state operations, the envy of his opponents, without any reason to be.

title: 2 Doors, 617 Horses, Just $2 Million
description: The Gold Coast of Long Island needs more opulence the way the Yankees' Alex Rodriguez needs a raise, but early this year, another million-dollar bauble rolled into East Egg.

title: U.S. Units of Parmalat Seek Bankruptcy
description: Parmalat's dairy subsidiaries in the United States filed for bankruptcy protection yesterday, saying they were trying to protect their assets while preparing for a possible sale that could help settle the parent company's debts.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an obituary on Feb. 12 about Philip A. Straus, a financier and patron of art and education, misstated the date of his gift to the Fogg Art Museum at Harvard for its art restoration center, later named the Straus Center for Conservation and Technical Studies. It was in the 1980's; 1928 was the center's founding year.

title: Learn From History, And Then Repeat It
description: At a time when architects are radically rethinking the urban landscape of Europe, it is a commentary on the marginal influence of fashion that no designer has attempted to produce a similar sense of excitement in clothes. What you saw in Giorgio Armani's ample coats, with their spreading collars and nipped waists, was not the style of Norman Foster's London but the style of London before the motorcar. And despite Miuccia Prada's love of architecture, you didn't see in her romantic steeple prints the new Germany of Daniel Libeskind but the old Germany as recalled in the dog-eared tourist guides you find in the Berlin flea market, of Ulm and Baden-Baden in their doily days.

title: U.S. Scientist Tells of Pressure to Lift Bans on Food Imports
description: A senior scientist at the Department of Agriculture says its scientific experts have been pressured by top officials to approve products for Americans to eat before their safety can be confirmed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SALETSKY, LEONARD
description: SALETSKY--Leonard, on February 24, 2004. Devoted husband to Natalye, father to Sharon Saletsky and Doria Asen, father-in-law to Barry, and grandfather to Alex and Faran. We will miss your warmth, generosity, sense of humor and Sunday brunches. We love you always. Funeral Thursday AM at Schwartz Bros., Forest Hills, NY.

description: A day after Education Secretary Rod Paige compared the nation's largest teachers union to a ''terrorist organization'' because of its criticism of President Bush's centerpiece education law, the union brushed aside his apologies and called for his dismissal.

description: Offering some flexibility on the city's strict new promotion requirements for third graders, Schools Chancellor Joel I. Klein said yesterday that he would create an appeals process based on teacher evaluations of students' work.

title: The Pick of the Pots for Patio and Terrace
description: THINKING about spring? It arrives in three weeks, and though it is too early to plant a summer garden, it is almost time to decorate terraces, patios and yards with potted plants. Pots come in various styles and materials, and this year there are better fakes than ever, including urns that look like stone or bronze but are made of lightweight fiberglass or composites. For traditionalists there are still plenty of containers made of the real thing.

title: Bush to Limit Testimony Before 9/11 Panel
description: President Bush and Vice President Dick Cheney have placed strict limits on the private interviews they will grant to the federal commission investigating the Sept. 11 attacks, saying that they will meet only with the panel's top two officials and that Mr. Bush will submit to only a single hour of questioning, commission members said Wednesday.

description: ''No war comes without cost, but the cost should be born out of conflict with the enemy, and not because of egregious violations by some of our own troops.''

description: In another sign of the slackening demand in the once-hot category of flavored malt beverages, the Miller Brewing Company is ending ventures with Allied Domecq and the Brown-Forman Spirits division of Brown-Forman under which Miller produced and sold three ''malternative'' brands.

title: Priest Called Negligent In Rape Case
description: An organizer of a Roman Catholic priests' group on Long Island was accused yesterday of ignoring an indecent exposure complaint against a parochial school music director, who later raped another child.

title: 2 Cancer Drugs, No Comparative Data
description: Nearly two years into the planning of a head-to-head federal test of two expensive widely used cancer drugs, not a single patient has been enrolled in the study. But in a sense there is no hurry: Congress has barred the government from using the results in deciding how much to pay for the drugs.

description: Home Secretary David Blunkett, Britain's top law enforcement minister, announced a major expansion of the country's domestic espionage agency on Wednesday and urged a strengthening of antiterrorism laws including those allowing detention of foreigners without trial.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Arrests Hurt Softbank Shares
description: Shares of the Softbank Corporation tumbled on news that the police arrested four men on suspicion they tried to extort money from the company after obtaining personal data for as many as 4.6 million subscribers to its Yahoo BB broadband Internet service. Softbank said it was looking into reports of a leak amid concerns about the company's internal controls after it said earlier this year that private information on 242 users of its broadband service had leaked out. The information included addresses, names and telephone numbers.

description: LEDDY--Faith M. Darling daughter of the late Honorable James & Natalie Mulholland. title: Yanks Want Second Baseman to Fit Like a Glove
description: It is the Baltic Avenue of Yankeeland, the one spot on the field where the starter does not make even $1 million and has never made an All-Star team. When the Yankees traded Alfonso Soriano to the Texas Rangers for Alex Rodriguez, they left themselves without an established second baseman. And for now, they are not even looking for one.

title: Tradition? The Delicate Task of Retuning 'Fiddler'
description: Junior Sondheims keep plying their hopeful craft, but despite their best efforts the Broadway musical is fast going the way of opera. Where a steady flow of new shows was once the rule, revivals now predominate. For the American musical the canon is closing. In opera, with its head start of three centuries, it is as good as closed. Like opera fans, Broadway audiences have come to prefer what they grew up on, with just a dusting of the new.

title: Jamal Lewis Charged in Drug Case
description: Just as the Baltimore Ravens were exhaling after the murder trial of linebacker Ray Lewis in Atlanta during the summer of 2000, F.B.I. officials were investigating the team's next legal nightmare, also in Atlanta.

description: Not many employers hire people who are likely to flip at work, let alone actively seek them out. For the United States freestyle aerials ski team, however, that is exactly what is happening.

description: In 1997, when Cablevision bought out its partner, ITT, to take control of Madison Square Garden, Cablevision must have assumed it had a successful team in the Rangers. title: Justice Dept. Moves to Block Oracles Bid to Buy PeopleSoft
description: The Justice Department said this afternoon that it was filing an antitrust lawsuit to block the Oracle Corporation's $9.4 billion bid to acquire PeopleSoft Inc. , its competitor in the business software market.

title: The Humble Weed That Could Save a Life
description: THALE CRESS is the kind of plant that grows in sidewalk cracks and parking lots, the kind that gets yanked up if it gets noticed at all. Lately, however, this unassuming weed, a member of the mustard family, has been making history. In 2000 it became the first plant to have its genome sequence fully mapped. Now, Aresa Biodetection, a Danish biotech company, is adapting it to help detect land mines.

title: Excerpts From Ruling on Religious Scholarships
description: Following are excerpts from the Supreme Court decision on Wednesday that states that subsidize secular study at the college level may withhold the scholarships from students who are preparing for the ministry. The vote, in Locke v. Davey, was 7 to 2. The opinion was written by Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist. Justice Antonin Scalia wrote a dissent, joined by Justice Clarence Thomas. The full ruling is online at nytimes.com/washington.

title: MILITARY WOMEN REPORTING RAPES BY U.S. SOLDIERS
description: The United States military is facing the gravest accusations of sexual misconduct in years, with dozens of servicewomen in the Persian Gulf area and elsewhere saying they were sexually assaulted or raped by fellow troops, lawmakers and victims advocates said on Wednesday.

title: Wolves End Two Streaks, The Nets' And Frank's
description: Never in the Nets' magical stretch of success had Coach Lawrence Frank been in a game this tight against an opponent this skilled. How good are the Minnesota Timberwolves? Enough to be the choice in some circles as the N.B.A. champion this season.

description: The New York Civil Liberties Union charged yesterday that a city education official improperly sought to restrict school employees from speaking with reporters, in violation of the employees' constitutional rights.

description: When John Kerry was asked to list his closest foreign policy advisers the other day, he served up two names: Richard C. Holbrooke and Samuel R. Berger, veterans of Bill Clinton's presidency.

title: Results Confirm Hard-Liner Gain in Iran
description: Final election results announced by the government on Wednesday confirmed that Iran's religious conservatives made significant gains in Parliamentary balloting on Friday, which reformists had previously dismissed as illegitimate.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Serbia: Law Changed To Fill Presidency
description: Parliament voted to scrap a law that required 50 percent voter turnout for a presidential election, a rule that thwarted three attempts to elect a new president in the last 15 months. A new presidential election is to be called within the next four months. Nicholas Wood (NYT)

title: Unicef Urges Countries to Improve Care of Indigenous Children
description: In Siberia, teachers follow reindeer herds to instruct children of the nomadic Nenet people. In Peru, indigenous Andean women can spend their final weeks of pregnancy in professional health care centers, accompanied by their husbands, children and sometimes livestock, to reduce the chance of infant death.

title: Pension Fund And Proxy Firm Join Critics Of Disney Chief
description: The nation's largest public pension fund said Wednesday that it would withhold its votes for Michael D. Eisner, the besieged chief executive of the Walt Disney Company, signaling that the ranks of disaffected shareholders are growing ahead of next week's annual board election.

title: National Briefing: Southeast
description: LOUISIANA: MISSISSIPPI REOPENING TO SHIPS The mouth of the Mississippi River partly reopened to traffic after a supply vessel that sank after a collision on Saturday was moved aside, the Coast Guard in New Orleans said. Officials still do not know when the vessel, the Lee III, will be raised and traffic fully restored, but they are slowly clearing a logjam of more than 100 ships. Of five missing crew members, one has been recovered and the bodies of two were seen by divers. Ariel Hart (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Cray To Buy OctigaBay For $115 Million
description: Cray has agreed to buy the OctigaBay Systems Corporation for about $115 million in stock and cash, adding lower-end machines to its product line. The Seattle-based company will pay about $15 million and 12.7 million shares and assume 400,000 employee options. The company said in January that fourth-quarter revenue grew 71 percent, to $67.2 million. The transaction is expected to close in about 60 days, Cray said. The 66 employees of OctigaBay, which is based in Vancouver, British Columbia, will join Cray and operate as a separate unit, said Steve Conway, a Cray spokesman. OctigaBay is building machines similar to Cray's at lower prices, he said.

title: Another Front in the Culture Wars: The Talk Is of 'The Passion'
description: To the Editor:

title: Sather Quits as Coach, Keeps Other Hats
description: Glen Sather stepped down as the head coach of the Rangers on Wednesday, tossing one of his three job titles overboard as the team heads toward its seventh consecutive season without a playoff berth, four of them with him in charge.

title: U.S. Urges Israel to Work With Arabs in Any Pullout
description: The Bush administration, pressed by Israel to endorse its plan to withdraw from parts of Gaza and the West Bank, is urging Prime Minister Ariel Sharon to work with Palestinian leaders in carrying out the pullout, a senior Bush administration official said Wednesday.

title: Europe Weighs Antitrust Steps For Microsoft
description: Antitrust regulators from the 15 member nations of the European Union will gather here on March 15 to discuss a European Commission antitrust ruling against Microsoft, a diplomat close to one national regulator said on Wednesday.

title: European Union Says U.S. Faces $4 Billion in Trade Sanctions
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 The European Union's trade commissioner told senior lawmakers on Thursday that the United States would face $4 billion in sanctions starting Monday because Congress had failed to eliminate overseas tax shelters for American exporters that were declared illegal by the World Trade Organization.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about a series of racial incidents at Columbia University misspelled the surname of a student leader who complained of an absence of racial sensitivity on campus. He is David J. Johns, not Jones.

title: U.S. to Study Importing Canada Drugs
description: Hoping to mollify its critics, the Bush administration said Wednesday that it would conduct a yearlong study of how prescription drugs might be safely imported from Canada. But it then infuriated the critics by selecting Dr. Mark B. McClellan, the commissioner of food and drugs, to lead the study.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   VOGEL, DONALD
description: VOGEL--Donald. The members of the Art Dealers Association of America mourn the passing of their colleague who 50 years ago founded the Valley House Gallery in Dallas and who served his clients and the artists he represented with great distinction. Our condolences to his wife, Erika and his children Eric, Kevin and Barley. Richard Solomon, Pres. Gilbert S. Edelson, Admin VP

title: Britain Drops Charges in Leak of U.S. Memo
description: In a sudden reversal, Britain said Wednesday that it would not prosecute a 29-year-old government linguist who admitted leaking a top secret American request for assistance in bugging United Nations diplomats.

title: A Force of Nature Accompanied by a Big Band of One
description: Eddie Palmieri has spent 50 years perfecting the art of making his piano ring out over forceful dance orchestras, from the mambo era to the salsa era to the current time of refinements in the relationship between Afro-Cuban music and jazz. And the raw power of his playing, its cathartic, almost therapeutic quality, is part of his musical personality: he comes on like a force of nature.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Mining Profit Rises
description: The British-based mining company Anglo American posted a 1.9 percent increase in profit last year as gains on sales of noncore businesses offset the impact of the stronger South African rand against the United States dollar. The company gave an upbeat outlook for the current year. In a presentation to analysts, Anglo's chief executive, Tony Trahar, said that current trading showed commodity dollar price increases were more than offsetting the effects of exchange rates. ''After two decades of generally flat or declining real prices for metals, despite a background of steadily increasing demand, the backdrop for commodities is now more positive than it has been for a number of years,'' Mr. Trahar said. Net profit last year was $1.59 billion.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BLOCH, GILBERT M.
description: BLOCH--Gilbert M. On Monday, February 23, 2004, in Palm Beach Gardens, FL at age 76. Devoted and loving husband of Beatrice, much beloved and caring father of Larry (Cindy) Bloch, Babette (Marc) Mellon, Jayne (Brian) Hickey; cherished grandfather of Reisa, Matthew, Julia, Rachel, Daniel and Liana; brother to Roslyn Hinderstein; son of the late Henry and Estelle Bloch; and son-inlaw of Anneliese and the late Otto N. Weil. He was a most inspiring human being who fought his illness with courage and dignity. His creativity and tenacity was an inspiration to all who knew and loved him. Funeral services 11:30AM, Thursday, February 26 at Wien and Wien Memorial Chapel, 402 Park St, Hackensack, New Jersey. A Memorial Service will also be held on Sunday, February 29 at 12:30PM at Temple Israel, West Palm Beach, Florida. In lieu of flowers memorial contributions may be sent to Morse Geriatric Center, West Palm Beach, Florida.

title: Corrections

They included only naval vessels from Russia and South Korea, not from Japan.

title: Tom Ford Goes Out With a Roar
description: One of the greatest rides in fashion history ended Wednesday night as Tom Ford, a gardenia in his lapel, came down the runway at Gucci, stopped to kiss his companion and walked the rest of the way alone as a thousand people rose to their feet and cheered.

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: TURKEY: CHARGES IN ISTANBUL BOMBING Prosecutors charged 69 people with involvement in four suicide bomb attacks in Istanbul last November, and a court will begin hearing the case within days, the Anatolian news agency reported. The indictment, completed after a three-month investigation, identified a Turkish representative of Al Qaeda as masterminding the truck bombings. They tore into the British Consulate, a British-owned HSBC bank and two synagogues, killing 61 people and injuring 644. The news agency said 50 of the 69 accused were in custody. (Reuters)

title: Red-Carpet Days For HBO Films; Modest Budgets, but Big Rewards
description: During the last two decades HBO Films has sent its casts and crews all over the world, from Norway (''Gulag,'' 1985) to Morocco (''Live From Baghdad,'' 2002) to Rwanda, where ''Sometimes in April,'' a story of the Rwandan genocide, is being filmed.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Tekelec To Acquire Taqua For $85 Million
description: Tekelec, a maker of telecommunications switches, agreed yesterday to buy the closely held Taqua Inc. for $85 million in cash to expand its range of products. The acquisition will include the assumption of Taqua's outstanding options, said Tekelec, which is based in Calabasas, Calif. A spokesman, Michael Attar, did not immediately return a call to his office. Taqua, based in Richardson, Tex., makes a new type of small switch, or device that transmits phone calls between segments of a network, for service providers. Shares of Tekelec rose 96 cents, or 5.2 percent, to $19.25; the news was released after the close of regular trading. Tekelec shares have more than doubled in the last year.

title: What's a Small Plastic Gizmo That Tries to Read Your Mind?
description: If you're like me, you may feel a bit unnerved when a $10 children's toy appears to read your mind, but Radica's 20Q does something very much like that. A palm-sized plastic device with a digital display and few buttons, 20Q promises that it can name the object you are thinking about based on your answers to 20 questions. You can answer ''yes,'' ''no,'' ''sometimes'' or ''unknown'' to questions like ''Is it flat?'' and ''Is it heavier than a pound of butter?''

Claire was a graduate of Kent Place School and Smith College. She is survived by her husband, William D. Lyon Jr; her sisters Jean Newbold of Waterford, CT and Lynn Rinek of Essex, CT; two sons, James M. Lyon of NYC and W. Cecil Lyon of Essex, CT; eight grandchildren and eight great - grandchildren. title: The Japanese woman's perpetual quest for perfect skin

title: In Haiti, All the Bridges Are Burned
description: The world is now watching what is going on in Haiti. Everyone has seen how the population of Cap Haitien, Haiti's second-largest city, welcomed as liberators a motley group of rebels who now vow to march here to the capital. But that's only the most obvious sign of a resentment against President Jean-Bertrand Aristide that has been growing for years. The most popular song of the Carnival that just ended, for example, was an attack on a government official, ''Madan Gougou,'' and by extension, on Mr. Aristide's Lavalas party. Schoolchildren pass around unflattering caricatures of the president, and anti-Aristide graffiti have proliferated in the streets.
