title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Airline Posts Loss
description: The airline Lufthansa said it lost 980 million euros ($1.22 billion) last year, down from a profit of 717 million euros a year earlier. The airline, based in Cologne, Germany, said it earned a profit of 30 million euros when excluding one-time items, reversing a year-earlier operating loss of 154 million euros. The company had write-downs of 800 million euros last year, mostly related to its catering business, LSG Sky Chefs. Lufthansa said its results improved in the fourth quarter and it expected to post a profit this year. Petra Kappl (NYT)

title: National Briefing | South: Louisiana: Mississippi Reopening To Ships
description: The mouth of the Mississippi River partly reopened to traffic after a supply vessel that sank after a collision on Saturday was moved aside, the Coast Guard in New Orleans said. Officials still do not know when the vessel, the Lee III, will be raised and traffic fully restored, but they are slowly clearing a logjam of more than 100 ships. Of five missing crew members, one has been recovered and the bodies of two were seen by divers. Ariel Hart (NYT)

title: Adopting a Classic Underdog Forgotten in the Music Pound
description: It has been nearly two centuries since audiences responded to the music of Antonio Salieri with cheers, stomping and demands for more. But the mezzo-soprano Cecilia Bartoli can sell just about anything, and on Tuesday evening at Carnegie Hall she and the Orchestra of the Age of Enlightenment -- one of the better British period instrument bands -- made a dozen of of Salieri's arias and a handful of his orchestral works sound like the most magnificent music ever composed, and the audience ate it up.

title: Judge Bars Search Evidence, Says F.B.I. Lied for Warrant
description: A federal judge in Brooklyn ruled yesterday that an F.B.I. agent made false statements in a sworn application for a search warrant in a drug paraphernalia case. The judge therefore barred prosecutors from using any of the evidence they found during the search.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Telecom Resignations Offered
description: Executives of SK Telecom, the wireless company, offered to resign, ending a standoff with minority shareholders. Pyo Moon Soo, chief executive and president of SK Telecom; Son Kil Seung, chairman; and Chey Tae Won, chairman and majority owner of the SK Corporation, said they would step down from the board of SK Telecom. Mr. Son, above, and Mr. Chey were convicted last year for their role in an accounting scandal at a unit of the SK Group. Mr. Pyo said he would quit to provide opportunities for other managers. Shareholders will vote on the resignations on March 12.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: AT&T Offers To Buy Back $1.5 Billion In Notes
description: AT&T yesterday offered to buy back its $1.5 billion of notes due Nov. 15, 2006, as well as some of its 2 billion euros of notes ($2.5 billion) due that month, to pare debt costs. The company will spend up to 500 million euros in buying back the 6 percent euro notes due Nov. 21, 2006, it said in a statement. The euro notes now have an interest rate of 6.75 percent. The $1.5 billion of notes yield 6.5 percent and have a 7.25 percent interest rate. The chief executive, David W. Dorman, is buying back AT&T's debt to lower interest expense as revenue from residential and business phone service falls. AT&T had $14.4 billion of debt and $4.35 billion of cash at the end of last year, compared with $22.6 billion and $8.01 billion at the end of 2002. AT&T's board approved the repurchase of as much as $3 billion in debt, the company said last month. The company's debt peaked at $65 billion in 2000 under Mr. Dorman's predecessor, C. Michael Armstrong, who acquired cable television companies in a failed attempt to sell a variety of services from under one roof. AT&T shares rose 30 cents, to $20.25.

title: Can One Group's White Elephant Be Another's Gold Mine?
description: When Hollywood and Highland, above, a complex including movie theaters, shops, restaurants and the Kodak Theater (where the Oscars will be held on Sunday) opened just over two years ago, it was expected to be the crown in the revival of Hollywood Boulevard. But it has proved to be a white elephant bigger than those atop its fake Babylonian towers. The owners, Trizec Properties, are selling it to the CIM Group for around $200 million. (It was once said to be worth more than $600 million.) The CIM Group hopes to turn Hollywood and Highland around, but it faces a serious challenge. Not only did the project suffer from a dramatic downturn in the economy and initially annoy drivers with expensive parking, but it wavered between the theatrical and the tasteful: ''It looks like it was designed by some Romanians based on a postcard of Las Vegas,'' said the Los Angeles architecture critic Michael Webb. And the development largely faces away from one of the few streets in Los Angeles that has a lot of foot traffic. ''Hollywood is about its pedestrian night life,'' said Rose Apodaca Jones, the West Coast bureau chief of Women's Wear Daily and a co-owner of three popular Hollywood bars. In the Hollywood and Highland complex, she said, ''you are trapped.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LANDAUER, BEVERLY FOY
description: LANDAUER--Beverly Foy, of ''The Fountains'' Millbrook, NY, died peacefully February 21, 2004, at Sharon Hospital, Sharon, CT, with her sister, Barrie L. Estes, at her side. She was born March 29, 1926, at Miss Lippincott's Lying-In Hospital in New York City to Ruth Yarbrough and James Dittman Landauer. She graduated from the Madeira School, Class of 1944, and from Smith College in 1948. She received a Master's Degree in Early Childhood Education from Hunter College and was a much loved teacher at Lenox Hill Neighborhood Day Care Center, All Soul's School and The International Play Group. She was a member of the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church and the Colony Club. In addition to Barrie L. Estes of New York City, she is the beloved sister also of Barbara L. title: The Secret Life Of Off-Duty Characters
description: EVER since the release of ''Toy Story'' in 1995, computer-animated movies have been dropping an anvil on traditional cartooning. ''Finding Nemo'' and other pixel-powered hits have done so well that Disney is going nearly all-digital. On television, however, things are different. Budgets are smaller, nowhere near the $94 million price tag for ''Finding Nemo.'' Schedules are tighter. Decidedly low-tech cartoons like ''South Park'' rule.

The woman was described by witnesses as 25 to 30 years old, 5 feet 5 or 5 feet 6 inches tall and with shoulder-length hair in a ponytail. She was wearing a gray sweatshirt with blue lettering. The baby was left in a leather handbag in the third-floor hallway of the building, at 127 West 127th Street. Infant abandonment is illegal unless the baby is left at a safe haven like a hospital or police station. Shaila K. Dewan (NYT)

title: World Briefing: Africa

"We spent the night under the rain, in the cold," one man said. "We want building material, bricks, cement, iron to rebuild our homes." Nearly 600 people were killed and thousands were left homeless. Rescue teams continued to search for survivors in the rubble, but hopes were dim. (Reuters)

Dr. Riker spent his entire 53-year medical career at Weill Cornell and led the Department of Pharmacology for 27 years, beginning in 1956. A distinguished educator, clinician, and research scientist, among many achievements, he was responsible for major advancements in the diagnosis and treatment of neuromuscular diseases. Dr. Riker will be greatly missed. Our sincerest condolences are extended to his family. Dr. Antonio M. Through May 30 at 369 East First Street, Los Angeles. Reissues of Noguchi's 1944 Fin Series of tables and stools, made of wood and chromed tubular steel, are new in showrooms. description: A federal judge allowed prosecutors to dismiss charges of capital murder against a man whom they had accused of killing two hikers in 1996 in Shenandoah National Park. Moon, denied a request from defense lawyers to bar further charges against Mr. Rice. Adam Liptak (NYT)

title: ChevronTexaco Says It Will Buy an Enron Tower
description: ChevronTexaco said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire one of the office towers built by the Enron Corporation and consolidate most of its operations in Houston. ChevronTexaco, based in San Ramon, Calif., said it planned to relocate about 500 employees from offices in New Orleans, Northern California and Midland, Tex., to the building, which is expected to eventually house about 3,700 employees. Enron, which sought bankruptcy-court protection in 2001, never occupied the building that was designed by the architect Cesar Pelli and built at an estimated cost of $300 million. ChevronTexaco did not disclose the financial terms of the deal, but the city of Houston said the company would pay taxes on an estimated base value for the building of about $80 million. The seller, Intell Management and Investment of New York, paid $102 million for the building in 2002. Enron's other building was bought by a group of investors last December for $55.5 million. Simon Romero (NYT)

title: Latin America's Half-Term Presidents
description: Rebel efforts to oust President Jean-Bertrand Aristide of Haiti fit a troubling pattern across Latin America. For years, democratically elected presidents in the region were routinely deposed through military coups. Today, many elected leaders continue to see their terms cut short, but through popular uprisings aimed at their removal, like the one in Haiti. Not long ago, Gonzalo Snchez de Lozada was ousted as president of Bolivia after widespread protests stemming from a natural gas deal. In 2001, President Fernando de la Ra of Argentina resigned halfway through his term after protests about the economy. Today, in addition to efforts to depose Mr. Aristide, large groups of citizens or foreign governments are calling for the resignation of Hugo Chvez in Venezuela and Alejandro Toledo in Peru.

title: Nostalgia for the Look of East Berlin's Bad Old Days
description: In the comic German movie ''Goodbye, Lenin,'' Katrin Sass, right, plays an East German woman who goes into a coma just before the fall of the Berlin Wall. She wakes up eight months later to an apartment lovingly recreated by her son to appear exactly as it was in the old days before he installed things like miniblinds. The movie, which opens tomorrow, was a sensation in Germany, spawning ''ostalgie,'' a cult of nostalgia for remnants of East Germany. Shown here, the mother's bedroom with its wallpaper, heavy curtains and old-fashioned Socialist goodies. The set for the apartment, in East Berlin, is now rented out for ostalgie parties; fax requests to: 011.49.30.670.44.223.

title: National Briefing | Southwest: Texas: Governor To Reimburse Donors
description: Gov. Rick Perry, a Republican, will use campaign money to reimburse political donors and consultants who arranged a three-day retreat to the Bahamas this month attended by Mr. Perry, his wife and three aides, the governor's office said. title: France Seeks U.N. Force in Haiti And the Resignation of Aristide
description: France called Wednesday for the immediate formation of a United Nations-backed security force to go to Haiti and stabilize the country, which is in the third week of a rebel uprising. It also urged President Jean-Bertrand Aristide to resign.

title: A Primary Endorsement
description: The search for a Democratic presidential nominee has been defined by an Anyone-but-Bush sentiment, an obsession with choosing the man who will run the best campaign. But in the end, the party needs to pick the person who is most qualified to be president. That's why this page endorses Senator John Kerry in Tuesday's primary.

title: Con Edison Is Expected To Request Rate Increase
description: For the first time in nearly a decade, Con Ed will ask in the coming weeks for permission to raise its electricity rates, utility analysts and state lawmakers say. The utility has requested a hearing with state regulators to discuss its rates, but officials, speaking in an interview yesterday, would say only that they might seek an increase and would not say how much.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: Hunt For Air Controller's Killer
description: The police were hunting for the killer an air-traffic controller who was on duty at Zurich airport when two planes collided over southern Germany in July 2002, killing 71 people, mostly Russian schoolchildren. The authorities suspect a revenge killing. The controller, a 36-year-old Dane, has never been named. He was stabbed to death at his home in Zurich. Fiona Fleck (NYT)

Rick Perry, a Republican, will use campaign money to reimburse political donors and consultants who arranged a three-day retreat to the Bahamas this month attended by Mr. Perry, his wife and three aides, the governor's office said. title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Thailand: Satellite Concern's Profit Falls
description: Thailand's sole satellite communications company, Shin Satellite, reported its second year of lower profit and said that it planned to sell $90 million worth of new shares in a public offering to finance expansion and pay debts. The company, which is controlled by the family of Prime Minister Thaksin Shinawatra, said net profit last year fell 23 percent, to 1.08 billion baht ($27.5 million). The company plans to launch a new satellite that would enable it to expand its service to Australia and New Zealand. Wayne Arnold (NYT)

There are the two Academy Award ceremonies he produced in the late 1980's, including the 1987 ceremony in which the 79-year-old Bette Davis presented an award in such a rambling, ad hoc manner that the president of the academy, Robert Wise, was poised to walk onstage to assist her.

title: Broke the Bank Last Year? Settle for a Camera Upgrade
description: Observing a time-honored practice of electronics makers, Eastman Kodak has introduced an improved version of its 14-megapixel digital camera, the DCS Pro SLR/n, priced around $5,000. But unlike countless digital camera buyers before them, owners of last year's model, the DCS Pro 14n, will not have to buy the new camera to benefit from advantages like a greater sensitivity in low light. Instead, Kodak is offering to upgrade the image sensor and software of the older model for about $1,500.

title: C.I.A. Says Election in Iran Dealt Blow to Reform
description: With the victory of religious hard-liners in this week's parliamentary elections in Iran, the Central Intelligence Agency is warning of a new era of repression and inflexibility.

title: National Briefing | West: California: Trying To Block Killer's Appeal
description: State Attorney General Bill Lockyer asked the United States Supreme Court to intervene in the case of Kevin Cooper, whose execution on Feb. 10 was halted by a federal appeals court. Mr. Lockyer is trying to block the appeals court from sending the case for a review of evidence that defense lawyers say will exonerate him in four killings in 1983. Mr. Lockyer's office wants more time to prepare its challenge. Dean E. Murphy (NYT)

title: Roaming Fees Likely to Fall For Europe
description: Some of Europe's biggest mobile phone groups have all but persuaded antitrust regulators at the European Commission that they would no longer overcharge consumers for using their phones abroad, an official close to the commission's competition department said on Wednesday.

title: Sensing Opportunity In Mad Cow Worries
description: From cows to cats, the work of finding and identifying animals is becoming more high tech. And that could prove promising for the Digital Angel Corporation, a St. Paul company that has been tracking livestock for six decades.

title: Study Finds Most Health Care Workers Do Not Get Flu Vaccines
description: Only 36 percent of health workers receive influenza vaccinations each year, despite a longstanding federal recommendation that such workers be immunized for their own protection and to prevent the spread of the disease, a leading health organization said here Wednesday.

title: From the Sphinx to King Tut, a Feast for Budding Egyptologists
description: Seven millenniums of Egyptian culture and history are now available in a most modern way: through a new Web site called Eternal Egypt. A result of three years of cooperation between I.B.M. and Egypt's government and major museums, Eternal Egypt is intended to encourage preservation while providing an immense amount of data that could formerly be absorbed only by visiting Egypt. And of course, the Egyptian government hopes that some of the virtual tourists will be persuaded to make the actual trip.

title: Fitch Raises Credit Rating of Hasbro
description: The credit rating of Hasbro Inc., the toymaker, was raised to investment grade yesterday by Fitch Ratings after the company lowered debt and increased profit and sales. The increase, to BBB- from BB+, affects about $700 million in debt, Fitch said. Hasbro's focus on its classic brands such as Transformers and G.I. Joe, instead of relying on hit items like Pokmon, has paid off, Fitch said. The company, which is based in Pawtucket, R.I., also trimmed costs and pared debt by $369 million last year, the rating company said.

title: Triple Shooting in Queens Kills a Bystander, Investigators Say
description: Investigators think two of the victims in a triple shooting in Jamaica, Queens, on Tuesday night were bystanders, a police official said yesterday. One victim, Terence Burt, 35, who died, was the father of three young children and the caretaker of three more, his family said.

title: Libya Thaw to Proceed; Guilt Is Reaffirmed
description: President Bush is expected to remove American travel restrictions to Libya on Thursday and allow for a significant expansion of diplomatic interchange now that Libya has dismantled most of its nuclear infrastructure and reaffirmed its responsibility for the bombing of Pan Am 103 more than 15 years ago, senior administration officials said on Wednesday.

title: The Barbie and Ken Roadshow: Tomorrow, New York
description: When the costume designer Greg LaVoi posed his Barbie and Ken for a picture shoot at Zuma Beach, Calif., left, a passing surfer told him, ''You've got way too much time on your hands.'' But Mr. LaVoi, who received his first Barbie as a child in 1962 and credits her with inspiring his career, has taken Barbie and Ken all over the city, shooting them at Los Angeles landmarks, including the new Walt Disney Concert Hall and the old Pink's Hot Dogs. And note the attention to detail. Barbie and Ken at Zuma Beach wear their original Mattel outfits in front of a customized Mattel car and clutch surfboards made to scale by Mike Geib, Mr. LaVoi's neighbor. ''Barbie Loves L.A.'' ($30, Angel City Press) has a foreword by the Hollywood costume designer Bob Mackie. And ''Barbie Loves New York'' is coming soon.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Ferry Service Seen For La Guardia
description: The operators of La Guardia Airport said yesterday that they had begun soliciting bids from companies to provide ferry service to the airport from downtown Manhattan. The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, the agency that operates the airport, will select a ferry operator later this year, a spokesman said. New York Waterway ran a ferry service to La Guardia's Marine Air Terminal, but discontinued it. The company recently submitted a proposal for the planned service, a company spokesman said last night. Councilman Peter F. Vallone Jr. said he hoped the service would help kill a plan to extend the N subway line to the airport, which he said would put a ''horrible, loud, noisy ugly elevated train line through the heart of a vibrant Astoria community.'' Mr. Vallone said he was told that the planned ferry service could begin by the end of the year and connect to airport buses with routes to terminals. Corey Kilgannon (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Staten Island: 30 Accused Of Drug Sales
description: After a 17-month investigation, federal prosecutors filed charges yesterday against 30 members of two Staten Island gangs they said were involved in crack cocaine sales and gang battles that involved at least six shootings. Prosecutors said the Deuce Mob sold crack from a front porch in the Port Richmond area. The investigation of the rival Mob-Up crew, the prosecutors said, included a shooting by a gang member that was captured on a surveillance video camera. William Glaberson (NYT)

title: A Remote That Can Travel All Over the House
description: A set of low-cost devices to be introduced this spring can operate every audio and video component in the house -- even from outdoors.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Serbia: Trial In Ex-Leader's Murder Begins
description: Nine members of an elite police unit accused of abducting and murdering the former Yugoslav president, Ivan Stambolic, in 2000 went on trial in Belgrade. Prosecutors say the men were ordered to carry out the execution by Slobodan Milosevic, the president at the time of the murder. Mr. Milosevic was indicted along with the nine others but is not being tried in Belgrade because he is before the war crimes tribunal in The Hague. Nicholas Wood (NYT)

title: Britains First Citizenship Ceremony
description: LONDON, Feb. 26 - Under British and European banners and facing a portrait of Queen Elizabeth II, 16 adults from 10 countries, along with three children, on Thursday became the first foreigners to be granted British nationality at a new public ceremony modeled on American citizenship procedures.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Rahway: Fire Destroys Prison Barracks
description: A fire broke out at the East Jersey State Prison yesterday, destroying a barracks and forcing the evacuation of nearly 100 minimum-security inmates, officials said. No injuries were reported. The inmates were moved to the gymnasium in the prison's main building. Matt Schuman, a spokesman for the New Jersey Department of Corrections, said the cause of the fire was under investigation. Prison officials had not decided whether to house the inmates elsewhere in the prison or relocate them to a different prison. Yaniv Gafner (NYT)

title: When to Post 'Watch for Falling Asteroid' Sign
description: For nine hours last month, a small band of astronomers got a scare. Their calculations indicated that a newly discovered asteroid was on a collision course with Earth and that it had a one-in-four chance of striking the planet, somewhere in the Northern Hemisphere, within days.

description: Senator John Kerry began running this 30-second advertisement throughout Ohio and in upstate New York, two economically distressed areas, yesterday.

The vote, in Locke v. Davey, was 7 to 2. The opinion was written by Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist. Justice Antonin Scalia wrote a dissent, joined by Justice Clarence Thomas.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BENENSON, CHARLES B.
description: BENENSON--Charles B. Devoted and beloved husband of Jane. Devoted and beloved father of Bruce William, Frederick and Lawrence. Cherished brother of Lawrence and Raymond. Passed away suddenly on February 22 in Palm Beach, FL. He lived to be 91 years old and remained active in his many pursuits to the very end. In addition to his sons and his brothers, he will be greatly missed by his four grandchildren, dedicated office staff, nieces, nephews, cousins and business associates, all of whom benefited from his wonderful qualities and dedication. His business career, spanning a remarkable 70 years, and his passion for the arts brought him in close intimate contact with all aspects of New York City life. His contributions to the arts, education for inner-city children and Jewish philanthropic causes were known to all, as was his personal commitment to Yale University. He was a founding member of the Association for a Better New York, the Realty Foundation, the Lincoln Center Real Estate and Construction Council, the New York Junior Tennis League, the I Have a Dream Program, and the Museum of African Art and numerous other charitable organizations. Widely respected for his wisdom and integrity in the real estate industry, his humor, optimism and vitality enriched the lives of all who came to know him. His sophistication and intellect were an inspiration to all who knew him. His devotion and love were of inestimable value to those closest to him; their loss is irreplaceable. Funeral services at Temple Emanu-El, 65th Street and Fifth Avenue, at 10 am, Friday, February 27. Visiting at Campbell Funeral Home, 1076 Madison Avenue, Wednesday, February 25, and Thursday, February 26, 6 pm to 9 pm. In lieu of flowers, send donations to the American Jewish Committee, 165 East 56th Street, New York, NY 10022, Inner-City Scholarship Fund, 1011 1st Avenue, New York, NY 10022, or the New York Junior Tennis League, 24-16 Queens Plaza South, Long Island City, NY 11101.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HADDEN, SARAH R.
description: HADDEN--Sarah R., 82, died peacefully surrounded by family and her dear friend on Monday, February 23, 2004 in Wellington, FL. Sally was a strong presence in the lives of all who knew her; there was almost no adversity she was unable to surmount. She inspired and engaged and entertained us. Born in Keene, NH in 1921, she grew up in Chestnut Hill, Massachusetts, and graduated from the Beaver Country Day School. In 1942 in the midst of WW II she married her husband of 54 years, Hamilton Hadden, Jr. They settled in Westbury (and later Brookville), NY. Sally was a devoted wife and mother, whose family danced mostly to her tune amidst numerous dogs and horses. She was a longstanding member of the Colony Club of New York. She loved and fortified her homestead in Manchester, VT. In 1996, at the age of 75, she and her husband moved to Duncaster in Bloomfield, CT, where she found an inviting community in which to knit supportive and stimulating friendships. She was a former President of Planned Parenthood of Nassau County, NY, and an Endowment Trustee of the Greater Hartford Association for Retarded Citizens (HARC) in CT. She passionately embraced her causes and those of her family. She was predeceased by her husband, Hamilton, and grandson, Sam Hadden; and survived by her children and children-in-law, Kitty and Harry Lee, Susie and David Lawrence, Ham and Hilary Hadden, and David and Sara Hadden; as well as her grandchildren, and their spouses, all of whom delighted her: Johnny and Ashley Lee, Bob Lee, Claire Lee, John and Tara Lawrence, Katie Lawrence and Matt Sawatzky, Sarah Lawrence, Ham and Patricia Hadden, Alice Hadden, Lee Hadden, Jamie Hadden and Liza Hadden. A service of celebration will be held on Saturday, February 28 at 12:30 PM in the meeting hall at Duncaster, 40 Loeffler Road, Bloomfield, Connecticut. Contributions in her honor may be made to HARC (for the Samuel Taylor Hadden Endowment Fund), 900 Asylum Avenue, Hartford, CT 06105; the Duncaster Foundation, 40 Loeffler Road, Bloomfield, CT 06002; or Planned Parenthood of Nassau County, 540 Fulton Ave., Hempstead, New York 11550.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BENENSON, CHARLES B.
description: BENENSON--Charles B. Devoted and beloved husband of Jane. Devoted and beloved father of Bruce William, Frederick and Lawrence. Cherished brother of Lawrence and Raymond. Passed away suddenly on February 22 in Palm Beach, FL. He lived to be 91 years old and remained active in his many pursuits to the very end. In addition to his sons and his brothers, he will be greatly missed by his four grandchildren, dedicated office staff, nieces, nephews, cousins and business associates, all of whom benefited from his wonderful qualities and dedication. His business career, spanning a remarkable 70 years, and his passion for the arts brought him in close intimate contact with all aspects of New York City life. His contributions to the arts, education for inner-city children and Jewish philanthropic causes were known to all, as was his personal commitment to Yale University. He was a founding member of the Association for a Better New York, the Realty Foundation, the Lincoln Center Real Estate and Construction Council, the New York Junior Tennis League, the I Have a Dream Program, and the Museum of African Art and numerous other charitable organizations. Widely respected for his wisdom and integrity in the real estate industry, his humor, optimism and vitality enriched the lives of all who came to know him. His sophistication and intellect were an inspiration to all who knew him. His devotion and love were of inestimable value to those closest to him; their loss is irreplaceable. Funeral services at Temple Emanu-El, 65th Street and Fifth Avenue, at 10 am, Friday, February 27. Visiting at Campbell Funeral Home, 1076 Madison Avenue, Wednesday, February 25, and Thursday, February 26, 6 pm to 9 pm. In lieu of flowers, send donations to the American Jewish Committee, 165 East 56th Street, New York, NY 10022, Inner-City Scholarship Fund, 1011 1st Avenue, New York, NY 10022, or the New York Junior Tennis League, 24-16 Queens Plaza South, Long Island City, NY 11101.

title: Editorial Observer; Behind the Rise of Google Lies the Rise in Internet Credibility
description: For the past few months, it has seemed as if every week has brought more news about Google, the search engine invented in the mid-1990's by a couple of Stanford graduate students. Microsoft has offered, in vain, to buy the company and is now developing its own proprietary search engine, in part by looking for soft spots in Google's patents. Yahoo has introduced a Google-like search tool of its own and dumped Google's. Meanwhile everyone is waiting for Google's initial public offering, an event that many people hope will begin a new round of I.P.O.'s, a round that carries us back in equity and optimism to the late great tech bubble at the end of the last century. Microsoft and Yahoo want their share and more of the nearly $1 billion in ad revenue that Google generates. Investors want their share and more of Google stock. Most of the rest of us -- at some 200 million searches a day -- just want to keep Googling.

description: Auto safety regulators said on Thursday that Bridgestone/Firestone North America had begun the first tire recall since the government started using a new early warning system created in the wake of the rollover problems of Ford Explorers equipped with Firestone tires in the late 1990's.

title: Ex-Leader of Japan Cult Sentenced to Death in Gas Attack
description: TOKYO, Feb. 27  Shoko Asahara, the former leader of the religious cult that released deadly sarin gas into the Tokyo subway in 1995, was found guilty today of directing the attack and other crimes after an eight-year trial. He was sentenced to death.

title: Corrections

title: Corrections

The headquarters building of the Compuware Corporation, the site of a new Borders store, is the third new office building to be built there since the 1970's, not the first. The article also referred incorrectly to the availability of T-shirts for sale in the area. They are indeed available, at stores that sell souvenirs and sundries.

title: Court Allows Medicinal Use Of Marijuana
description: The federal appeals court here has refused to reconsider its ruling that allows Californians to grow and use marijuana to treat their illnesses.

title: Hate Fliers Investigated By Police In Westchester
description: While investigating several recent appearances of racist and anti-Semitic literature, Westchester County police came upon another, this one arriving in their own mailboxes. Since Monday, 29 packages of anti-Semitic and antiblack literature -- photocopies of pages from hate Web sites -- have been mailed to municipal police departments in the county.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Spain: Protest Against Basque Guerrillas
description: Despite a pouring rain, 5,000 people gathered under umbrellas in Barcelona in a silent protest against the violent Basque separatist group E.T.A., which last week unilaterally declared a truce applicable only to Catalonia. The protest was held just before the opening of campaigning for national elections on March 14. The selective truce has become a campaign issue. Dale Fuchs (NYT)

title: In Search Of the President's Missing Years
description: Over the past few weeks, President Bush has responded to recurring questions about his National Guard service by saying that the subject is old and tiresome. According to Mr. Bush, reporters conducted a thorough investigation of his time in the Texas National Guard when he ran against Ann Richards for governor in 1994, and again when he ran against Al Gore in 2000. The complete Guard records, the president told Tim Russert on ''Meet the Press,'' were ''scoured.''

title: I.B.M. WinsEx-Workers' Cancer Suit
description: A California jury ruled on Thursday in favor of I.B.M. in a case brought by two former employees who contended that they contracted cancer because they had been exposed to dangerous chemicals at I.B.M.'s disk-drive factory in San Jose.

title: Political Memo; Meeting Local Needs In a Presidential Primary
description: On the face of it, the parade of New York politicians who attached themselves to the elbows of Senator John Kerry and Senator John Edwards this week was all about galvanizing Democratic Party loyalists and beating President Bush. But it was also about -- well, Charles B. Rangel, for one.

title: Lewis Pleads Not Guilty to Drug Charges
description: Jamal Lewis, the Baltimore Ravens' star running back, pleaded not guilty on Thursday to federal charges that he tried to help a friend buy cocaine in June 2000, a month before he signed a $35.3 million contract with the Ravens.

title: With a River Running Through It, Play Is Postponed
description: The golf course at La Costa Resort and Spa was saturated Thursday by heavy rains, forcing postponement of the second round of the Match Play Championship. Second-round matches will be played Friday morning, followed by third-round matches in the afternoon.

title: Criticism Mounting As Disney's Leader Faces Crucial Vote
description: What began as a trickle of discontent over Michael D. Eisner's leadership of the Walt Disney Company has become far broader as a growing number of large investors have expressed a lack of confidence in the company's management.

title: MERCK TO WORK WITH GENE MAPPER ON NEW TREATMENTS
description: Merck has agreed to work with Decode Genetics to develop disease treatments using a gene database for the population of Iceland, Decode said yesterday. Merck also bought a $10 million stake in Decode at $14.50 a share, Decode said. Merck, based in Whitehouse Station, N.J., may buy an additional $50 million stake at $29 a share over five years and will pay royalties on drugs or diagnostic products developed. Decode, based in Reykjavik, Iceland, is using medical records in Iceland, cut off from much of the world for 11 centuries before World War II, to trace 50 diseases. Shares of Decode rose $2.60, or 24.5 percent, to $13.20, on Nasdaq. Decode said that it would help Merck develop drugs for obesity, Alzheimer's disease, cardiovascular disease and diabetes.

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times: New or noteworthy pop and jazz concerts in the New York metropolitan region this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended concert.

description: Seventh Regiment Armory

title: Men Illegally Performed X-Rays To Test Machines, Officials Say
description: A father and son who worked for a New Jersey company that manufactures X-ray machines have been charged with improperly exposing 11 people, including a 19-year-old woman who was X-rayed about 50 times, to unnecessary radiation while testing a new X-ray machine, the authorities said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CANTOR, MYRA H.

description: For years, at thousands of New York City intersections, well-worn push buttons have offered harried walkers a rare promise of control over their pedestrian lives. The signs mounted above explained their purpose:

title: IRAQI AYATOLLAH INSISTS ON VOTE BY END OF YEAR
description: Grand Ayatollah Ali al-Sistani, Iraq's most powerful religious leader, demanded Thursday that nationwide elections be held by the end of the year, but dropped his earlier insistence on holding them before the United States transfers sovereignty to the Iraqis on June 30.

title: Ex-Reporter For The Times Tells in Book Of Deceptions
description: Jayson Blair, the former New York Times reporter who was found last year to have fabricated or plagiarized portions of more than three dozen articles, admits many of his deceptions in a forthcoming memoir but writes that they were fueled by ambition, cocaine and alcohol abuse and an undiagnosed condition of manic depression.

title: Buccaneers Sign a Wide Receiver
description: TAMPA, Fla., Feb. 26 (AP)  Wide receiver Sylvester Morris, a first-round draft pick of Kansas City in 2000, signed with the Tampa Bay Buccaneers on Thursday, three seasons after he caught his last pass.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Zimbabwe: Voice Of America Termed A Threat
description: The government's media commission called the Voice of America a national security threat, accusing the service of ''peddling lies about this country resulting in the deterioration of the Zimbabwean image.'' The commission issued the broadside as the state-controlled Daily Herald fired three journalists who had worked in second jobs for the Voice of America. Separately, South Africa's deputy president issued a muted call for greater press freedom in Zimbabwe, saying that South Africa's cacophony of media voices is ''what we would want to see in any other country.'' South Africa's foreign minister caused an outcry this month by saying that Zimbabwe's suppression of a free press was acceptable because a court had sanctioned it. Michael Wines (NYT)

title: With Last 50 Pickups, Ford Ends 56 Years of Work in Edison
description: The Ford Motor Company ceased production at its sprawling assembly plant here on Thursday, ending 56 years as a manufacturing fixture in north-central New Jersey and stripping away yet another major name from the state's industrial base.

title: Estelle Stewart Axton, 85, A Founder of Stax Records
description: Estelle Stewart Axton, whose name put the ''Ax'' in Stax Records, the Memphis soul label she founded with her brother, died on Tuesday in Memphis. She was 85.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DEL REGNO, HUGH FRANCIS
description: DEL REGNO--Hugh Francis. Born on July 26, 1927 in New York, New York. Passed away on February 25, 2004 in Studio City, California. For info J.T. Oswald Good Shepherd Chapel (818) 769-0021

title: International Justice
description: The resignation of Richard May, the chief judge in Slobodan Milosevic's trial, has added a serious complication to proceedings that, after two years and 300 witnesses, are a long way from finished. One of three judges at the special tribunal for the former Yugoslavia, Judge May, of Britain, retired for health reasons just as the prosecution rested its case a full year later than expected. The delay was caused by the volume of the accusations, and Mr. Milosevic's defiant tactics and repeated illnesses. Even if the judge had not stepped down, Mr. Milosevic was expected to use his defense for maximum theatrics and propaganda. Now Mr. Milosevic, the former Yugoslav president, has grounds to demand an entirely new trial, or even a mistrial.

title: State Action Is Pursued On Same-Sex Marriage
description: In state after state, fierce battles have broken out this week in the legislative aisles, as conservative lawmakers push for much more than the federal constitutional amendment banning gay marriage that President Bush has endorsed.

title: Truckloads of Armed Men Vow to Defend Haitis Capital
description: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti, Feb. 27  With a rising panic creeping across Haiti's capital, truckloads of armed men, many in ski masks, patrolled the city today, vowing to kill anyone who dared challenge the embattled presidency of Jean-Bertrand Aristide.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GAHAN, SYLVIA BARNETT
description: GAHAN--Sylvia Barnett, on February 26, 2004, at age 98. Much loved widow of Edward Francis Gahan; mother of Antony Gahan; grandmother of Rebecca Fletcher, Victoria Cliche and Christopher Gahan; great grandmother of Rachel, Leila Rose, Stanley and Spencer. Sylvia was the last surviving child of Theresa and Jacob Barnett. She loved people, was a fine teacher and always concerned with the betterment of society. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81st St, from 11AM on Sunday with services at 12 noon.

title: GENZYME AGREES TO BUY MAKER OF CANCER DRUGS
description: The Genzyme Corporation, which sells treatments for rare genetic diseases, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy Ilex Oncology for about $1 billion in stock. Shareholders will get Genzyme stock valued at $26 for each Ilex share, Genzyme said. In buying Ilex, based in San Antonio, Genzyme, based in Cambridge, Mass., will gain the Campath leukemia treatment and experimental cancer drugs. Ilex is developing clofarabine, a treatment for bladder cancer, and synthadotin, a drug for skin and lung cancers. Campath had sales of $72 million last year, up from $44 million in 2002, according to a company regulatory filing.

title: China Grants an Early Release of Tibetan Nun
description: BEIJING, Feb. 26  The Chinese government on Thursday released a Tibetan nun who had been a political prisoner for more than 14 years and had become internationally known as one of the "singing nuns" of Drapchi Prison in Tibet, according to a San Francisco-based human rights organization.

title: Living Proof That Clocks Move in Two Directions
description: Rod Stewart's career unfolded in reverse. By the time he turned 25, in 1970, he was already a rock 'n' roll veteran with an elegant, battered voice. He was recording with both the Jeff Beck Group and the Small Faces, later known as the Faces, and as a solo act; his style, which drew from folk and the blues, seemed old-fashioned right from the start.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Insurer Reports Profit
description: The French insurance company AXA delivered strong annual results for 2003 on cost-cutting measures and good results from its property and casualty department. The company, based in Paris, said its net income increased 6 percent in 2003 to 1 billion euros ($1.24 billion), while operating profit, which excluded Sept. 11 claims and capital gains, rose 21 percent to 2 billion euros ($2.5 billion). The insurer's property and casualty division however rose 233 percent to 753 million euros ($935 million) on lower claims and rate increases. Helped by those results, AXA, which has bid $1.5 billion for the Mony Group, the New York-based insurer, is looking at takeover opportunities in markets where it already has a strong presence, the chief executive, Henri de Castries, said. Ariane Bernard (NYT)

title: BANKRUPTCY JUDGE REFUSES TO FORCE LIQUIDATION OF FAO
description: A judge overseeing the bankruptcy case for the toy retailer FAO Inc. refused to appoint an administrator to handle the company's liquidation. Instead, he ordered the company to submit a plan to pay creditors within 60 says. A United States trustee, an official assisting the Justice Department in bankruptcy cases, made the request to convert the case to a Chapter 7 liquidation from a Chapter 11 reorganization to reduce costs. But the judge, Joel B. Rosenthal of United States District Court in Wilmington, Del., declined to order the conversion. FAO, which exited bankruptcy in April, filed again for protection from creditors in December. It is liquidating its Zany Brainy toy unit and has sold its Right Start toy chain and F.A.O. Schwarz stores.

title: Woodstock Rocks On, but the Beat Is Quieter
description: FOR a place synonymous with music, Woodstock is eerily silent at night. The Tinker Street Cafe, where Bob Dylan composed two influential albums of the 1960's -- ''Another Side of Bob Dylan'' and ''Bringing It All Back Home'' -- is now a hushed photography gallery. The Bearsville Studios, where artists from the Band to Muddy Waters recorded albums, may soon become a private residence. And the Joyous Lake club, where Phish once threw surprise concerts, has been shut more than a year.

title: Regulators Conduct Search of Microsoft's Office in Tokyo
description: The Fair Trade Commission of Japan raided the Tokyo headquarters of Microsoft on Thursday, seeking information on how the company supplies software for personal computers sold in the country.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article last Friday about snowboarding at Mountain Creek in northwestern New Jersey misstated the character of the area around Route 23, a highway nearby. It is not heavily industrial or commercial, and does not have concrete noise barriers. That description applied to highway sections in eastern New Jersey, which were part of the drive from Manhattan.

description: HONG KONG  Many of Hong Kong's top antiques dealers call Hollywood Road home. Relics representing 5,000 years of Chinese culture and design can be found in the shops and galleries that line the street. Exquisite Tang dynasty horses made of fired clay are not too far from stores crammed with the most graceful Ming-era furniture and specialists in delicate Qing Imperial robes and embroideries.

title: PENTHOUSE SEEKS TO PROVIDE CAPITAL FOR TROUBLED UNIT
description: General Media, which owns Penthouse magazine, has scrapped a reorganization plan intended to help it shed debt and will instead ask a judge to approve an injection of capital from its parent, a company lawyer said yesterday. The new plan calls for repaying bondholders owed about $47 million and allowing the parent company, Penthouse International, to retain its 99.5 percent ownership in General Media, the lawyer, Robert J. Feinstein, said. The plan will be financed by a $30 million exit loan, Mr. Feinstein said, but he declined to provide further details. General Media has until next Wednesday to provide the court with the documents related to the new plan.

title: F.D.A. Approves Cancer Drug From Genentech
description: The Genentech drug Avastin, which validated a decades-old theory about a new way to attack cancer while spurring investor enthusiasm for the biotechnology industry, won approval yesterday from the Food and Drug Administration.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: 12 Accused Of Fraud
description: Twelve Queens residents were charged yesterday with defrauding the New York State workers' compensation system of more than $172,000 from 1999 to 2003, including a factory worker who was said to have been using a motorized water scooter while claiming to be too badly injured to work. The 12 charged yesterday tried to defraud the compensation system by either submitting false claims or remaining at work while injured and receiving compensation payment, the Queens district attorney, Richard A. Brown, said. One worker continued to work as a custodian while receiving payments, and another worked as a truck driver, Mr. Brown said. He said that Henryka Gorzelska, 50 , of Queens, a machine operator, was seen using the water scooter while collecting payments. Anthony Battisti, a lawyer for Ms. Gorzelska, said yesterday that she was not guilty. Corey Kilgannon (NYT)

title: Down and Dirty in the Gun Debate
description: President Bush has long been on record supporting two crucial gun-control measures: the renewal of the assault weapons ban, which has been the law for 10 years, and a new law to close the loophole that shady dealers can use to slip weapons to buyers at gun shows. For an equally long time, he did nothing to back up his words. Now, in the early days of his re-election campaign, Mr. Bush has finally acted. He has stepped in at a critical hour in an attempt to kill both of those vital laws and promote instead a plan to grant unreasonable immunity from victims' damage suits to reckless gun dealers and manufacturers.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Officer Catches Robbery Suspect
description: An off-duty police officer caught a man suspected of robbing a bank in Brooklyn, after the officer, in line in the bank, chased the suspect, the police said. The suspect, Anthony Aponick, 32, had just fled a branch of the Greenpoint Savings Bank at 7120 New Utrecht Avenue with cash he had taken from a teller at 11 a.m., the police said, when the off-duty sergeant, Angelo Russo, was told of the robbery. Sergeant Russo followed him, called other police officers for assistance on his cellphone and, with the help of two other officers, caught the suspect. Mr. Aponick, of Gravesend, was charged with robbery and criminal possession of stolen property, according to a police press statement. Sabrina Tavernise (NYT)

title: DINER'S JOURNAL
description: A few old friends dropped in on an old friend for dinner the other night, after a long absence. This sort of thing happens in New York all the time. New experiences come calling. We lose track, and then catching up is hard. It's awkward.

title: National Briefing | Southwest: Texas: New Chief
description: Chief Harold L. Hurtt of the Phoenix Police Department was named by Mayor Bill White as the new leader of the Houston police. The department has been troubled by accusations of racial profiling and excessive force.

title: Public Uncertain on Marriage Amendment
description: When George W. Bush announced his support this week for a constitutional amendment to ban gay marriage , he did so to a public wary of changing the Constitution and marginally more inclined to leave the matter to individual states than to make changes at the federal level, according to opinion polls made public before and after the announcement.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Verisign Files Antitrust Suit Against ICANN
description: Verisign, which assigns and administers more than half of the world's 60 million Internet addresses, filed a federal antitrust lawsuit yesterday against its regulator and nemesis, the Internet Corporation for Assigned Names and Numbers, seeking to free itself from at least part of Icann's control. The suit, filed in the United States District Court for the Central District of California, asserts among other things that Icann has exceeded the boundaries of the contract it signed with Verisign in May 2001, authorizing Verisign to provide ''registry services'' to companies that sell domain names with the popular .com and .net suffixes, among others. In effect, Verisign says that Icann has illegally prevented it from selling services that do not fall under Icann's purview, as it is set forth in the companies' contract. ''Our contract spells out Icann's jurisdiction, and what a registry service is, but by trying to assert that essentially every service is a registry service, it has led to delays and mission creep,'' said Tom Galvin, Verisign's vice president for government relations. Representatives of Icann, which is a private nonprofit corporation, declined to comment. Bob Tedeschi (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Scores Of Cars Slashed

The first call came to the police at 7:20 a.m., from Rutland Road between Flatbush and Nostrand Avenues, east of Prospect Park, the police said. The heaviest concentration of damaged vehicles appeared to be on those three blocks, with others scattered through the area, the police said. A few of the vehicles also had had their windshields broken. Investigators had no description of a suspect or suspects. Michael Wilson (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LEWITIN, ALICE MIZNER
description: LEWITIN--Alice Mizner. Died at midnight February 15, 2004 of acute cardiac failure. She was 89 and living in Amherst, MA. Made a Knight of the Order of Arts and Letters by the French government in recognition of her contributions to Franco - American under standing, she was born September 28, 1914 in Saint Louis, MO., the daughter of the late Rev. Henry Watson Mizner and Margot Postlewaite Mizner. She was the widow of the painter, Landes Lewitin, who died in 1966 and mother of Margot Lewitin. While living in New York City, she was active on the Diocesan Board of Episcopal Church Women and served as a Delegate to several Triennial Meetings of the Episcopal Church, the Province II Synods, and as a Representative to the Special General Convention of 1969. She was Companion - in Charge of the Society of the Companions of the Holy Cross from 1969 to 1975. She is sorely missed by her colleagues at SCHC, friends in Amherst and family. The funeral and interment of ashes is Saturday, March 6th, 11AM at Grace Episcopal Church, 14 Boltwood Ave, Amherst, MA. A reception will follow the services in the Parish Hall. Contributions in lieu of flowers may be made to Grace Episcopal Church, Amherst, MA. 01002 or to SCHC, Adelynrood, 46 Elm St., Byfield, MA. 01922.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Man Sentenced For Sex Crime
description: A man was sentenced yesterday to 20 years in prison after he admitted that he sexually assaulted his girlfriend's 8-year-old daughter, who became pregnant. The man, Chancellor Drayton, 44, of Queens, pleaded guilty on Feb. 3 to a charge of sexual conduct with a child under age 11. Mr. Drayton admitted engaging in sexual acts with the child at his residence between December 2001 and October 2002, which caused the child to become pregnant, the Queens district attorney's office said. Mr. Drayton, a street vendor, was sentenced before Justice Barry Kron. Stacy Albin (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Autodesk Profit Rises Ninefold
description: Autodesk said yesterday that fourth-quarter profit rose ninefold as sales jumped 51 percent, beating the company's and analysts' estimates. Net income for the quarter ended Jan. 31 was $57.6 million, or 48 cents a share, compared with $6.41 million, or 6 cents a share, a year earlier. Sales rose to $295.3 million from $195.5 million, the company, based in San Rafael, Calif., said in a statement. Autodesk raised its sales and profit forecasts for the current period. The jump in sales was the third straight quarterly increase after six quarters of no growth or declines. Sales of software subscriptions grew 52 percent from a year earlier, the chairwoman and chief executive, Carol Bartz, said. Autodesk's software is used to design products like aircraft, buildings, telecommunications networks and video games. Autodesk now expects profit for the first quarter ending in April to be 12 cents to 17 cents a share, or 16 cents to 21 cents excluding certain costs. The sales are expected to be $240 million to $250 million, the company said in yesterday's statement. The company's shares rose as much as $4.28, or 16 percent, to $30.25 in extended trading after the close of markets. They rose 7 cents, to $25.97, in regular trading.

title: CLINICAL DATA ADDS $6 MILLION TO BID FOR MOORE MEDICAL
description: Clinical Data Inc. said yesterday that it was adding about $6 million, or $2 a share in cash, to its $37 million bid for Moore Medical, a health care products distributor, in an attempt to trump an offer by McKesson. The board of Moore Medical approved McKesson's offer of $12 a share in cash, or about $36 million, on Jan. 19. Clinical Data countered this week by announcing that it was prepared to offer 0.698 share of its stock for each share of Moore Medical. Based on Wednesday's closing prices, that offer values Moore Medical, based in New Britain, Conn., at $12.42 a share. The sweetened offer would value Moore at $14.42. Clinical Data is based in Newton, Mass.

The bill was introduced by Councilman Michael McMahon, with the support of Council Speaker Gifford Miller and other council leaders. Many small private schools have complained that they do not have a full-time nurse available to them. City health officials have said that providing a nurse to all private elementary schools, which typically have smaller enrollments than public schools, would lead to an inequitable distribution of city resources per student. Winnie Hu (NYT)

title: 36 Hours | Fort Lauderdale, Fla.
description: THE story of Fort Lauderdale's transformation from spring-break haven to stylish beach resort is more than a decade old. But it's a story that is still unfolding: The city, which already has a big-league theatrical complex, a trendy shopping district and a stately waterfront park, will become home to six major new resorts over the next couple of years. And business continues to boom at Port Everglades, one of the world's largest cruise ports and the winter home of the new Queen Mary 2. But the city hasn't completely forsaken its fun-in-the-sun past, epitomized by the 1960 film ''Where the Boys Are.'' The bars along the beach still welcome revelers until the wee hours, and with an average water temperature of 72 degrees this time of year, the shore still beckons the Coppertone crowd. title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: I.B.M. Expands Server Share To 36%
description: I.B.M. expanded its share of server revenue to 36 percent in the fourth quarter of 2003 amid signs the industry is recovering, the market researcher Gartner said yesterday. I.B.M., based in Armonk, N.Y., generated $4.84 billion in sales of servers, the fast computers that manage Web sites and databases, compared with $4.08 billion in the period a year earlier, when it had a 34 percent share, Gartner said. The worldwide server industry grew 12 percent in total revenue, to $13.4 billion in the fourth quarter from a year earlier, Gartner said, adding to evidence that customers are starting to spend more on computers, software and related gear and services. The gain in spending in the fourth quarter from the third was 21 percent. Hewlett-Packard, based in Palo Alto, Calif., was second with $3.57 billion, maintaining a 27 percent share, Gartner said. Revenue at Sun Microsystems, in third place, dropped 2.3 percent to $1.44 billion, from $1.47 billion a year earlier. Market share for Sun, which is based in Santa Clara, Calif., declined to 11 percent from 12 percent. I.B.M. shares rose 25 cents, to $96.79, while Hewlett-Packard shares rose 47 cents, to $23.22. Sun's shares rose 4 cents, to $5.21.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary by The Associated Press on Jan. 22 about Harry E. Claiborne, a former federal district court judge from Nevada who went to prison in 1986 for income tax evasion, referred incorrectly to a precedent. This was not the first case in which a federal judge was sent to prison. Legal historians consider the first to be that of Martin T. Manton, of the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit, in Manhattan. Judge Manton resigned in 1939 shortly before his indictment for bribery in a case before him. He was convicted and served 18 months. Judge Claiborne, who was impeached and removed from office while in prison, was the first sitting federal judge to be imprisoned for a crime committed while he was on the bench. This correction was delayed for research.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Blasts Kills 25

Mr. McCarthy was the chairman of an investment firm that hired friends of Connecticut's former state treasurer, Paul J. Silvester, in exchange for state business. Mr. McCarthy, 62, pleaded guilty in September to giving $1 million consulting contracts to an associate of Mr. Silvester and his mistress to reward Mr. Silvester for investing $200 million of state pension money with Triumph Capital Group, his family's firm. Prosecutors recommended 15 months. But Judge Ellen Bree Burns reduced that after Mr. McCarthy's lawyers spoke about his charitable giving. title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Some E-Zpass Users To Pay Extra Fee
description: More than 400,000 nonbusiness users of the E-ZPass electronic toll system will be charged a $1 monthly surcharge beginning in May because of reduced traffic after the Sept. 11 terror attack, The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey said. The authority expects to raise more than $5 million to partly offset the $31 million it costs to operate the system, Ken Philmus, the authority's director of tunnels, bridges and terminals, said in an interview yesterday. The authority's 15,000 business customers, who already pay $23.50 for each tag, will not pay the fee. Matthew C. McCue (NYT)

title: Nestl Posts 18% Drop In Earnings for 2003
description: High cocoa prices, a weak dollar and the effects of SARS on Asian business reduced Nestl's 2003 profit by almost 18 percent, the company said on Thursday.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: New Equipment To Treat Waste Gas
description: Eight fuel cells will convert waste gases into energy to help provide power, and eliminate odors, at four sewage treatment plants in Brooklyn, the Bronx and Staten Island, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg announced yesterday. The 200-kilowatt fuel cells are designed to operate on the gaseous byproducts of the wastewater-treatment process, producing electricity and heat through a chemical reaction. Mike McIntire (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Ireland: Eircom To Sell Shares
description: Eircom, the telephone company once owned by the government of Ireland, will raise 300 million euros ($372 million) next month by issuing new shares on the Dublin and London stock exchanges, its parent company, Valentia Holdings, said. The sale will be Ireland's first initial offering since late 2000, and the biggest since the government sold the company, then called Telecom Eireann, in 1999. Valentia bought Eircom, which controls 80 percent of the Irish market, for 3 billion euros ($3.7 billion) in 2001, and its owners, the billionaires George Soros and Tony O'Reilly, and Providence Equity Partners, are expected to sell significant quantities of existing shares. Eircom, which sold its cellphone unit to Vodafone in 2001, said it might re-enter the cellular market. Brian Lavery (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Singapore: Economy Growing
description: The government has raised its forecast for its economic growth this year after reporting that gross domestic product rose by an annual rate of 11 percent in the fourth quarter. Growth was fueled by rebounding shipments of electronics and pharmaceuticals, the government said. The ministry of trade and industry projected G.D.P. growth of 3.5 percent to 5.5 percent this year. Wayne Arnold (NYT)

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: SPAIN: PROTEST AGAINST BASQUE GUERRILLAS Despite a pouring rain, 5,000 people gathered under umbrellas in Barcelona in a silent protest against the violent Basque separatist group E.T.A., which last week unilaterally declared a truce applicable only to Catalonia. The protest was held just before the opening of campaigning for national elections on March 14. The selective truce has become a campaign issue.    Dale Fuchs (NYT)

Ms. Moore has been the director of the Center for Dance Education at the Boston Ballet since 2001. The executive committee of the Ballet Theater board of directors met Wednesday, and its choice was affirmed by the full board yesterday.

title: Owens Misses Deadline for Becoming Free Agent
description: Wide receiver Terrell Owens will not be an unrestricted free agent on Wednesday after all. The N.F.L. informed the San Francisco 49ers yesterday that Owens would not be on the list of free agents because Owens and his agent, David Joseph, had missed the deadline to file the paperwork to void the final three years of Owens's contract with the 49ers.

title: World Business Briefing | Australia: Bank Investigation
description: The National Australia Bank said that the Securities and Exchange Commission in the United States was investigating a possible auditing breach and that it might have to pay 543 million Australian dollars ($418 million) in extra tax. The S.E.C. has asked the bank to supply more information regarding some nonaudit services provided by the accounting firm KPMG. The development is another blow to investor sentiment after a rogue foreign currency trading scandal led to the resignations of the bank's chief executive and chairman.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Growth Rate Is Up
description: The growth rate in Canada accelerated to 3.8 percent, adjusted for inflation, in the final quarter of 2003 from 1.3 percent in the previous three months, Statistics Canada reported. But business and consumer spending stagnated, with the bulk of the improvement coming from a rise in inventories. The growth rate for the year was 1.7 percent, down from 3.3 percent in 2002. Seeking to stimulate demand, the Bank of Canada is expected to cut interest rates for the second time this year when it meets to review monetary policy on Tuesday.

title: National Briefing: Washington
description: SUGGESTIONS TO UPGRADE F.B.I. DISCIPLINE The F.B.I. system to discipline employees is riddled with problems and "has lost touch with its original mission," according to a report from an independent commission. Among the major problems was that senior officials were often perceived as receiving lenient treatment for wrongdoing. The panel recommended reorganizing the disciplinary office and attracting "high-caliber employees" to work in it. The director of the bureau, Robert S. Mueller III, said he planned to adopt most of the changes.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Lithuania: Russian Diplomats Expelled
description: The government has expelled three Russian diplomats it accused of seeking, among other things, confidential information on the impeachment process against President Rolandas Paksas, according to the Foreign Ministry. The impeachment charge against Mr. Paksas involves allegations that link him to Russian organized crime. The explusions come as the small Baltic nation, a former Soviet republic, prepares to join the European Union and NATO. Seth Mydans (NYT)

title: National Briefing | Rockies: Colorado: Apology In Lieu Of Accusatory Jesus Sign
description: The Rev. Maurice Gordon, who posted a sign that read, ''Jews Killed the Lord Jesus,'' on Ash Wednesday, has changed the sign, which now offers an apology. The sign outside the Lovingway United Pentecostal Church in Denver read: ''I am deeply sorry for offending the Jewish people, whom I love. Brother Gordon.'' The pastor said the release of ''The Passion of the Christ'' had motivated him to put up the first sign. The United Pentecostal Church International said in a statement that it did ''not now and has never in the past taught that the Jewish people as a race or nation are responsible for the death of Jesus Christ.'' The group did not mention Mr. Green, but it said ''the statement of one individual should not identify the U.P.C.I.'' Mindy Sink (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Economy Contracts Again
description: Brazil reported weaker-than-expected growth in the fourth quarter, confounding expectations that recent interest rate cuts by the central bank would cause the economy to grow at a faster pace. The government statistics agency said that the gross domestic product contracted 0.1 percent in the fourth quarter from a year earlier. The rate was an improvement from the contraction of 1.5 percent in the third quarter, but it was below analysts' forecasts that the economy would expand more than 1 percent. For 2003, the economy shrank 0.2 percent, the worst result in a decade.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LESSER, RUTH, PH.D.
description: LESSER--Ruth, Ph.D. The Interpersonal Orientation of the New York University Postdoctoral Program in Psychotherapy and Psychoanalysis deeply mourns the loss of Dr. Ruth Lesser, our beloved colleague and friend, a woman who spearheaded the Interpersonal movement at NYU and championed its tenets throughout her long and distinguished career. Dr. Lesser was a feisty advocate and untiring supporter of freedom, individuality, and the influence of culture on human development. In her work, a positive blending of compassion with confrontation, she made seminal contributions to the understanding of the enduring effects of sibling attachments on later interpersonal relations. She was unique and the likes of her shall not pass this way again.

description: Dignity Village, an encampment for the homeless that has been shuffled around Portland for four years, has a home on city property. The City Council voted to designate a one-acre corner of a leaf-composting center that tent village occupies, and the city will negotiate with the camp for a long-term lease. title: VISTEON'S CHIEF FINANCIAL OFFICER WILL RETIRE
description: The Visteon Corporation, the world's fourth-largest maker of auto parts, said the chief financial officer, Daniel Coulson, will retire March 31, four months after a successor turned down the job, citing unspecified personal reasons. Mr. Coulson, 60, has been chief financial officer since Visteon was spun off from Ford Motor in 2000. He had held the post on an interim basis since Nov. 26 when George Strickler, a BorgWarner executive, decided not to take the job five days before he was scheduled to start work. Mr. Strickler last week took a similar post with a steel supplier, Republic Engineered Products.
